New Zealand Dictionary Centre Database
  • Docs »
  • Lexicon »
  • N

N¶

N-type sheep¶

1 n. (Rural) a mutation of the Romney breed of sheep, used for experimental breeding.

He [Dr Dry] was a very good geneticist, working with what were called 'N-type' sheep..they were mutations from the Romney flock. They were hairy, the rams had horns. (Nov 9, 2000,Massey,21)

N.Zd¶

abbr. New Zealand [fairly rare, probably idiosyncratic]

BUTLER [consistently] (1820,Journals and Correspondence,97, 252, 365)

HASWELL N.Zd Co's Settlements [isolated use] (1841,Letters & Journals,1/62)

N.Zealand¶

n. New Zealand [ORIGIN: abbreviation, Also 1792 Vancouver's Expedition in McNab Historical Records 1/144 1820 S.Marsden in McNab op.cit 1/478 ; 1838 Polack New Zealand - A Narrative; 1839 T.M. Partridge in Revans to Chapman Letters 13; 1840-44 Colenso M.S. Memoranda; [Consistently uses N.Zealand (and N.Zealanders); 1846 J. White M.S. of Journal 20 [only occasionally used, with NZ and NZld.]]

McCRAE NOTES ON N. ZEALAND BY AN OFFICER. (1820,Journal,9,1928 ed.)

HASWELL In true N.Zealand style (1836,Letters & Journals,1/13 et pass.) [NOTES: [Consistently used (11 times in vol. I) but also N. Testament: - 1841 uses N Zd Co.', andN.Z.'; 1849-55 N.Zealand]]

MACKIE The N. Zealand flax - Phormium tenax -was growing abundantly by the road side - excellentrope is made from it ... (Feb 2, 1853,Traveller under Concern,74,1973 ed.)

WEEKES [G.A. N.Zealand was Selwyn's usual signature] (1843,Journal,42) [NOTES: ALSO 1843 Selwyn Journal 97 (et pass.)]

uses (Feb 7, 1/76 and Aug 13, 1/103) N.Zealand 1862-8 Ashwell Letters and Journals 3/412 pass [uses N.Zealand consistently] (1851,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1960 ed.) [NOTES: J.C. Richmond]

N.Zeald, N.Zld, N.Zd¶

n. New Zealand (rare, ?idiosyncratic) [ORIGIN: abbreviation, See 1838 Cunningham in Colenso Correspondence IV/6 N.Zeald [4 times] ;1840 Mar 16 E.J. Wakefield MS Diary NZd ;1850 John White MZ Journal N.Zld [1846 New Zld, New Z'l'ds] ; 1859 E.W. Stafford's usual abbrev. in Richmond-Atk. Papers eg. 17 Aug 1/481-482]

N.Zeeland¶

n. New Zealand [ORIGIN: abbreviation]

FORSTER The Land was seen N.E. by E. ...so we probably off West Cape, on the South part of N. Zeeland or Tavai poenamoo[e dieresis]. Feb 25 Anderson Journal in Cook's Journals (1967) 3/818 Not being sufficiently acquainted with the Language of N.Zeeland to converse with the natives ... (Mar 25, 1773,Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The,2/237)

na te whanau¶

phr. na (through), te (the), whanau (family) [ORIGIN: Maori, http://translator.kedri.info/index.html]

Followed by a church service at Te Paroa UrupaNau mai, haere maiNa te whanau (Jan 17, 2006,Whakatane Beacon,10)

naati¶

1 n. (Rural) a hardy breed of horse used as a saddle horse or station hack [ spec. to East Coast, North Island.]

Salisbury naati: brumby-type hack. (2000,Glossary,2)

CRUMP Here's how we're going to catch ourselves some of those long-haired tussock-eating ngatis. (1961,Hang on a Minute, Mate,54)

naati: a horse. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

Waka Huia: A story about a hardy breed of horse, Hoiho Naati, unique to Tologa Bay[sic]/Ruatoria. [ngati; naaiti] (Jan 6, 2002,Sunday Star Times,D12)

nab rate¶

n. (informal) catch rate

[Hdg] Speed cameras reset for nab rate rise. (Dec 12, 2000,Evening Post,5)

nabu¶

n. a non-adjustable balls-up [WWII] (See cf. sabu,tabu)

FULLARTON There are three words in the Middle East soldier's vocabulary describing the normal maladministration of an army. A Tabu, an acrostic word, is `typical army ball-up', a Sabu is self-adjusting ball-up, while a Nabu is a non-adjustable ball-up: eg be on the receiving end of a Tabu. (1994,Troop Target,38)

PARTRIDGE Nabu; sabu; tabu; Non-Adjustable Balls-Up; Self-Adjusting Balls-Up; Typical Army Balls-Up: Army, esp. among New Zealander's and Australians in N. Africa: 1940-3 (J.H. Fullerton, TroopTarget, 1943.) (1949,Dictionary of Slang Addenda,1116)

NAC¶

abbr. (historical) National Airways Corporation [ORIGIN: acronym]

NAC has a monopoly of internal scheduled passenger and mail transport by air ... (Oct 1952,NZ Geographer,158) [NOTES: Bishop]

Away For The Long Weekend BOOKINGS HEAVY ... National Airways will be making hundreds of flights in its busiest Labour weekend ever this year. N.A.C.'s bookings were heavy ... (Oct 15, 1954,Evening Post,6)

In this case the tumultuous history of the National Airways Corporation (NAC), so lovingly described as "the wings of the nation", has instead poked behind the political curtain... NAC was.. the first state-owned enterprise... Some will remember NAC for its crackers and cheese. (May 5, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),60)

NAC supports in principle the ultimatedevelopment of a diversionary airport inthe Wellington district. (Aug 14, 1968,Evening Post,20)

KEITH By 1948, NAC could advertise that it hadcarried 187,000 passengers on its 12,743kilometres of network air routes. (1991,Lovely Day Tomorrow, A,52)

Her uncle worked with NAC, Air New Zealand's predecessor. (Oct 13, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),32)

naerere¶

n. W.216 Na[a]ereere ... Scleranthus biflorus, a herbaceous plant.: the spg here French.

HOOKER Nae[acute]r[acute]ore[acute], Middle Island, D'Urville, Scleranthus biflorus. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),766)

nafa¶

n. an aftershock (acronym of not another f***ing aftershock) [ORIGIN: acronym, (February 2011) word modelled on Jafa q.v.]

NAFTA¶

abbr. New Zealand, Australia Free Trade Agreement. [ORIGIN: acronym]

LELAND N.A.F.T.A.: New Zealand-Australia, Free Trade Agreement. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,69)

NAFTA n. acronym for New Zealand, Australia Free Trade Agreement. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,747) [NOTES: 1986 NZPOD 498; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 323]]

It is important to remember that when the Closer Economic Relationship between Australia and New Zealand began to be aired about 10 years ago, the long-term goal was not only to come to terms with the cumbersome provisions of Nafta, but also to provide a basis of strength for an assault on world markets, including Asia. (Dec 12, 1987,Listener (New Zealand Listener),11)

[hdg] Nafta paved the path. Derogatory remarks have been made recently about the benefits to New Zealand of Nafta (the 1966 New Zealand-Australia Free Trade Agreement), comparing it unfavourably with CER (the 1983 Closer Economic Relations agreement). (Jun 1, 2004,Dominion Post,B4)

nafu¶

n. non-adjusting fuck-up [ORIGIN: acronym, WW2 (Army)] (See cf. nabu,safu)

[Infanteer' writes] Never was the phraseShe's right' used [in 1940-1944] ... to refer to a job badly done or done with a `couldn't-care-less' attitude. This was never necessary because in the Army we had other phrases to cover such contingencies when things did not go according to plan, such as NAFU and SAFU, the first being a non-adjusting fiasco, the second being a self-adjusting fiasco. (Jan 30, 1963,Dominion,8)

nag¶

v. talk [?=mag]

SUTHERLAND He and Dad will nag away for hours. (1978,Elver, The,43)

HOOKER Nahinahi, Lindsay. Convolvulus soldanella. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),766)

nahui¶

nahui [s] Alternanthera denticulata R.Br. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,51)

TAYLOR NAHUI (Alternanthera denticulata) Small introduced herb ... It is scattered throughout the North Island in damp places ... (1981,Weeds of Roadsides,103)

nail¶

2 n. [shearers' rhyming slang]

But [shearers] also use a rhyming slang sometimes among themselves; say, found a nail' for round the tail',hutch' for `crutch', and so on. I have always meant to collect these terms but never have. (C.) (Nov 25, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

BAKER found a nail, [shearers'] rhyming slang for `round the tail'. (1941,NZ Slang,42) [NOTES: [OEDS2] P: 1096/1 B 1941 NZ.]

nail in the boot¶

phr. (Rural) (of an animal) lame

LOUGHNAN nail in the boot: lame (of an animal.) Usually an auctioneer's euphemism for footrot. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,55)

nailrod¶

n. A dark tobacco in a tight nail-like roll. [(obs)]

MEREDITH Well, the fact is ... I want to enjoy the aroma as well as the smoke [of the cigar], and if it gets mixed with that of the nail-rod you fellows are smoking I shall miss it. (1875,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,125,1935 ed.)

(OED) Nailrod and 1lb bars ... with a full assortment of havana ... Cigars. (Nov 8, 1886,NZ Herald,7/3)

nailrod n. coarse, dark tobacco smoked by bushmen. [from shape of plug] (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,8)

PARTRIDGE Nail-rod or Nailrod. 1. orig. (ca 1885) a stick of `Two Seas' tobacco; obsolet. by 1915. from the shape (Morris) 2. Hence (- 1896), any coarse, esp. if dark, stick of tobacco; ob. by 1915, [obsolete] by 1925. Both senses, New Zealand and then Australian. The New Zealand Herald, Nov. 8, 1886 (1937,Dictionary of Slang,549)

.. a nailrod' was a double finger of tobacco;digger' was a familiar greeting of the 50's; ... (Apr 2, 1938,Press, The,18) [NOTES: McNab NZ Slang]

nailrod n. coarse, dark tobacco smoked by bushmen. (O.E.D.); Morris 1896 H. Lawson; AC1890 (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),13)

On Sale by the Undersigned .. 90 cases Cavendish and Nailrod Tobacco ... (Sep 27, 1850,Daily Southern Cross,2)

S. COCHRANE, BROTHER & CO. Will Sell at their Stores .. 1 half-tierce Fine Nailrod Tobacco .. (Jul 6, 1860,Daily Southern Cross,2)

DUNCAN McLEAN, BOUNDARY STREET, HAS FOR SALE .. TOBACCOS - Best brands, American Navy, Nailrod, and Aromatic ... (May 22, 1891,Grey River Argus,3)

And then for those who smoke a stick of "nailrod" per week is allowed, and every day for quarter of an hour after dinner incense at the shrine of My Lady Nicotine is permitted to be burned. (Oct 12, 1907,Manawatu Standard,9)

2 n.

NAIT¶

n. (Rural) [acronym for] National Animal Identification and Tracing [ORIGIN: acronym]

To enable animals to be traced, people in charge of cattle need to register with NAIT, tag and register their stock, and record when animals move off-farm. (Jul 2, 2012,NZ Farmers' Weekly,24)

Some key features of NAIT: * Properties associated with cattle and deer (farms, saleyards, meat processors, etc) will need to be registered on NAIT. * Farmers, transporters, processors, saleyards and other parties will need to record some new information about animals to meet NAIT purposes. (Jun 19, 2008,Daily News,A15)

Animals now need to be registered with NAIT within one week of being tagged .. to meet your NAIT obligations you need to: get a NAIT number, Tag your animals, Register your animals with NAIT ... (Jul 3, 2012,Rural News,15)

Nakahi¶

n. Old Testament- based religion developed by Hone Heke

Heke became Ngapuhi paramount chief and developed a religion, Nakahi, based on the Old Testament. (Mar 1, 2003,Dominion Post,A5)

Naki¶

adj. (informal) of Taranaki (See Naki noun)

After two big defeats against Otago and Canterbury, Steamers' captain Wayne Ormond said he was happy to take the victory against a "Naki" side that never took a backward step. (Aug 30, 2005,Whakatane Beacon,10)

[heading] Heat on 'Naki crowd to front THE pressure will be on the people of Taranaki as much as it is on the Hurricanes this week... (Feb 13, 2006,Dominion Post,D10)

Naki ('Naki, the Naki)¶

n. (informal) Taranaki [ORIGIN: abbreviation]

[Hdg] Slack Naki out to regain some flash. (Sep 15, 2002,Sunday Star Times,B6)

.. (if you're lucky - the mountain does briefly reveal herself on her last day in "the Naki", before retreating behind cloud again). (Apr 29, 2003,Dominion Post,A12)

The "plot" has Tom Cruise captured by samurai and held in a picturesque village high in the 'naki. (Jan 21, 2004,Capital Times,10)

Geary Gary had to get out of the Naki before he did something stupid. (2008,Six Pack 3, The,118)

.. poor Tom [Cruise] might find it difficult to truly get to know the Naki. (Jan 25, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),19)

The Naki chaps barracked for the Blues when they beat the Crusaders this season. (Jul 6, 2003,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),17)

He's won Pulp Comedy's New Faces award, has his sights set on the Billy T award, and he's from the 'naki - where they close the pubs early for Shortland Street.. (Apr 24, 2002,Capital Times,8)

I left Naki pursuing my law and came to Wellington for that reason, it wasn't really rugby-related. (Sep 10, 2004,Dominion Post Sport & RaceForm,3)

[Hdg] Mepi magic does trick for the 'Naki... So clearly there are no Eden Park heebie-jeebies for the men of the 'Naki. (Aug 18, 2002,Sunday Star Times,B3)

The site offers free videos of the 'Naki Yogis in action, plus pages of them in various poses with descriptions of how to contort. (Apr 30, 2003,Capital Times,4)

I don't recall Taranaki being known as "The Naki" before Devlin came along, trainspotting took on a whole new meaning when he used it (but then, he may have nicked it from someone else); and the Cake Tin might not have been Devlin's original phrase, but if it wasn't, it should have been. (Nov 6, 2004,Dominion Post,D8)

It's day three of the inaugural World Masters Surf Titles and the 'Naki is firing. (May 17, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),26)

According to a Diary spy, [Tom] Cruise will have a flood of bottled water in tow when he arrives here to film The Last Samurai in Taranaki early next year. Perhaps he has heard dark tales of "something in the water" in The 'Naki? (Dec 3, 2002,Dominion Post,B4)

She's just a chick from the 'Naki. (Nov 8, 2001,TV2) [NOTES: Shortland Street]

One barman tells me it's because the kids in the 'Naki like Hard House, and Havoc's tunes might be a bit soft. (May 26, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),21)

[Hdg] Six of the best as 'Naki All Black fan gets to milk it. (Jun 6, 2004,Sunday Times (NZ),B4)

[Hdg] 'Naki knackered. (Sep 26, 2004,Sunday Star Times,B1)

Nakiwood¶

n. Taranaki (after Tom Cruise)

[Hdg] Nakiwood has fled in Tom Cruise's jet, allowing the province's natural stars back into the limelight... Well, yes, but the Hollywood version was chopped well before Nakiwood Tom jumped back on his Lear jet and headed out into public. (Jul 6, 2003,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),16)

Try suggesting to Nakiwood locals that The Last Samurai's economic benefit to them might be arguable, and you've lost a vote. (Dec 13, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15)

"The inspection of animal flesh seems an inescapable royal duty"... In Taranaki - sorry, Nakiwood - Tom Cruise will be lucky to avoid it. Ibid. 18 New signs on the outskirts of New Plymouth these days say, "Welcome to Nakiwood", much-needed light relief from older billboards that monitor the province's facial-eczema-risk level. Ibid. 21 "NAKIWOOD!" yelled the sign on SH3. "Money!" yelled landlords on other roads. (Jan 25, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),4)

But right now he is enjoying a final coffee in Nakiwood. (Jun 14, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),33)

namu¶

n. The sandfly [Maori.] W.217 Namu ... Austrosimulium spp., sandfly. [nammoo, ngamu; interesting that there are no newspaper citations and none found on checking Papers Past.]

I think of the trees as old friends, and myself as a visiting namu, a [40]sandfly. (Jul 1998,NZ Geographic,No. 39/39)

DIEFFENBACH Simulium ? Namu, or sand-fly. Polack, New Zeal., p.319. ... To some insect, of a genus allied to Simulium, is to be referred the New Zealand sand-fly alluded to in the following passage:- A sort of little crane-flies (tipula alis incumbentibus) became remarkably troublesome during the bad weather. They were numerous in the skirts of the woods, not half so large as gnats or musketoes, and our sailors called them sand-flies. Their sting was extremely painful. . . . All, however, were not equally affected.' Forster, Voyage, ., pp. 135, 136.The most mischievous animals (at Dusky Bay) are the small black sand-flies, which are very numerous, and so troublesome, that they exceed everything of the kind I ever met with: wherever they bite they cause a swelling ...' Cook, Voyage in Resolution and Adventure, i., p.99. (1843,Travels in NZ,2/290) [NOTES: 17?? Forster quoted in 1843 Dieffenbach Travels in NZ 2/290]

NICHOLAS A sand-fly Nammoo (1817,New Zealand (various authors/titles),2/337)

LEE & KENDALL N|amu, s. A mosquitoe. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,184)

sandflies - nam|moo [namu] (1835,Boultbee Journal,109,1986 ed.) [NOTES: c1826-1827 list of Maori words in c1835 Boultbee Journal (1986) 109]

WILLIAMS [We] were most severely beset with namus; ... Ibid. 335 Namus and moschettos trying and vexatious. (Feb 25, 1833,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,285,1961 ed.)

MARKHAM Fine and Moon light Nights I go and sleep in the Bush as the House is full of fleas, Mosquitoes and Sand flys or Nammouies [namu]. (1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles),46,1963 ed.)

POLACK ... I was covered with the villainous kutus' [u-acute : sic], who have the license [sic] to crawl where they list among the natives; ... and the namu, or sand-fly, who never [234] leaves his victim until overgorged with blood, ... (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/233)

TAYLOR One of the greatest pests ... is a small black fly called the namu, a sand fly, it is little larger than a flea but not only bites much sharper but so poisons the wound as to create a large lump and intolerable itching, ... (Mar 29, 1839,Journal,2/78)

POLACK fn It is the scourge of sand-flies (namu) and mosquitoes, (waiwai-roa). (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/126)

DIEFFENBACH During the day a sandfly (ngamu), a tipula, is very troublesome in New Zealand, especially near the sea-shore; ... (1843,Travels in NZ,1/145)

ANGAS The women's limbs were anointed with kokowai, or red ochre and grease, to protect them from the attacks of the namu, a small species of sand-fly, the bite of which is peculiarly venemous and irritating. Ibid. 1/327 [Kokowai], mixed with oil, is also rubbed over the arms and legs to protect them from the merciless attacks of the namu, or sand-fly. (1847,Savage Life,1/274)

WEKEY Of insects the waeroa, or mosquito, I have seen in my room ... the namu, or black sand-fly, is troublesome in summer ... (1862,Otago As It Is,67)

COLENSO They sometimes rubbed the fresh juice of the Ngaio ... over their skin, to keep of the persecuting Namu (Sandfly)... (1869,TrNZI,1/III/38) [NOTES: Botany of the North Island]

COWAN Their bare legs and arms might be covered with namu (sandflies), but they apparently did not feel their bites. (1922,NZ Wars, The,2/13,1983 ed.)

ANDERSEN namu, a gregarious insect (Simulia australiensis), sandfly, a most pertinacious suicidal little bloodsucker which will suffer death rather than relinquish the feast. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/154) [NOTES: Maori Words in English]

ANDERSEN namu, a gregarious insect (Simulia australiensis), sandfly, a most pertinacious suicidal little bloodsucker which will suffer death rather than relinquish the feast. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/154) [NOTES: Maori Words in English]

DENNIS Sandflies (namu). (1981,Paparoas Guide,192)

namu pounamu¶

n. the blue fish Girella cyanea

Amongst the kelp-feeding fish ... the magnificent blue Girella cyanea, the namu poenamo of the Maoris, is conspicuous. (1928,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,9/290)

n. [Also called red moki] (See moki)

nana¶

v.

hey peeps was on my way home from a friends house last night and was in 1st gear accelerating and the revs just dropped and started missing quiet bad i could drive real softly and it would be sweet but any mid to hard acceleration it would just miss real bad???also the idle was real high,idling at just over 2grand???anyways i nanad home and had a look under the bonnet... (Jul 10, 2005,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://forums.skylinesdownunder.co.nz/showthread.php?s=&threadid=44973&goto=nextoldestAccessed 24/03/06. Date entered line one is date item was posted on site.]

nana-nap¶

n. ?

Tuesday, June 7 ... I really enjoy my nana-nap today and shortly after I awake Ruth and Abbi arrive with a DVD and yummy goodies to eat. ... Thursday, June 9 ... I have an early nana-nap today because I have a 1:30 post-discharge assessment at Burwood. (Jun 15, 2005,Christchurch Star,A5)

nancra¶

n.

BIDWILL It appears, however, that the very existence of these lakes is a mere matter of tradition, as none of the present generation have ever ascended to their shores, through fear of the nancras, or imaginary centipedes, or crocodiles (for it does not appear very clearly which is meant by the term), which inhabit the banks of all these inaccessible lakes, and with which even whole valleys are said to be so infested that it is impossible to get a native to visit them. (1841,Rambles in NZ,27,1952 ed.)

It helped that the laidback police were taking a decidedly Nandorian view of the dope smoke that clouded the tent city and wafted across the hill in front of the stage. (Jan 7, 2003,Dominion Post,C1)

nanny state¶

n.

It's curious that those who use the phrase 'nanny state' as an expletive are always those rich enough to afford nannies. (Oct 3, 1998,Listener (New Zealand Listener),29)

She was able to explain to New Zealanders that they could not expect "nanny state" to accompany them around the globe. (Mar 5, 2001,Dominion,2)

... let Maori keep their own tax money and decide for themselves how to get ahead, out of the brollie-shade of the nanny state. (Oct 30, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),23)

From July 1, 1997, NZF proposes that the nanny state should extract three percent of the total income of each adult... (Dec 14, 1996,Listener (New Zealand Listener),33)

He's [sc. Lindsay Perigo] back, and he's talking about cars. Ain't no one gonna stop him! Least of all the nanny state! (Nov 30, 1996,Listener (New Zealand Listener),86)

The scourge of the nanny state, Act's Muriel Newman, was quick to climb into the debate with her oft-stated view that Maori are being destroyed by welfare. (Mar 22, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),22)

For a right-wing politician who didn't plan to serve more than four terms, Maurice Williamson is proving strangely reluctant to sever his ties with nanny state. (Jul 28, 2003,Dominion Post,B5)

It's curious that those who use the phrase 'nanny state' as an expletive are always those rich enough to afford nannies. (Oct 3, 1998,Listener (New Zealand Listener),29)

nannygai¶

n.

SHERRIN NANNYGAI (Beryx affinis). ... It is called in Sydney nannygai which is said by Mr. Hill to be derived from the aboriginal name of mura ngin a gai, whatever that may mean. Among the early colonists it used also to be called `mother nan a di,' probably a corruption of the native name. (1886,Handbook Fishes of NZ,68)

AYLING GOLDEN SNAPPER Centroberyx affinis (Trachichthodes affinis) (Nannygai, red snapper, koarea) ... In spite of its name the golden snapper is not related to the true snapper and is in fact more similar to the roughys. ... Schools of golden snapper often move out over open sand flats ... and are then regularly caught in bottom trawls and sold as red fish. (1982,Collins Guide,177,1984 ed.)

[species name] red snapper .. [scientific name] Centroberyx affinis .. [other name(s)] golden snapper, nannygai, redfish (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] nannygai 1015 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

nanti palaver¶

phr. [circus argot]

WHITWORTH `Nanti palaver,' said the guv'nor, who was a Frenchman ... [fn] Shut up. (1879,Spangles and Sawdust,4)

SANSOM (1970,Stewart Islanders,23)

Nantucket sleigh-ride¶

n.

SANSOM The wonder was that the dinghy hadn't been towed out to sea by the [harpooned] whale, what the whalemen called `a Nantucket sleigh-ride'. (1970,Stewart Islanders,23)

nanua¶

n. W.218 Nanua ... Chironemus spectabilis ... = maratea -->[poss. a mishearing of e nanua pounamu] [no newspaper citations found]

SHERRIN EHOUHOUNAMU (Chilodactylus spectabilis). ... [19] Dr. Hector says it is common near the East Cape, and is called by the Natives ehouhounamu or nanua. The family to which this fish belongs - the Cirrhitidae - contains the hiwi-hiwi, the tarakihi, the moki, the trumpeter, and the porae, most of which are well-known fish, and stand, as it were, sponsors of its belonging to a good parentage. The same fish is found in Tasmania, where it is call the `carp,' (1886,Handbook Fishes of NZ,18)

CHIRONEMUS SPECTABILIS (Hutton). Maratea; Nanua. A fish common in the Auckland market. ... Distribution: North Island coasts (rare south of Bay of Plenty). (Jun 1921,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,IV/.116) [NOTES: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes]

PHILLIPPS Chironemus spectabilis Hutton. RED MOKI; NANUA. (1927,Bibliography of NZ Fishes,38,1971 ed.)

It is also famous for nanua, which are at their best in March, but-after that month lose condition. The nanua (Chironemus spectabilis) may also be caught. (1926,TrNZI,58/618) [NOTES: Buck]

BEST The following fish were caught with hook and line: araara, maomao, moki, mango, ngoiro, pakirikiri, kahawai, tamure, tarakihi, and warehou. The kanae, kehe, kopipiro, moho, nanu and other species were taken by net... The kehe, nanua, and kopipiro, are believed by the Maori to live on vegetable matter,... (1929,Fishing Methods,43)

GRAHAM RED MOKI (NANUA) Chironemus spectabilis Hutton (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,253,2nd ed.)

PARROTT THE RED MOKI Chironemus spectabilis (Hutton) ... Maori name: NANUA ... This is a northern species and is common around the Northern coasts of the North Island, and occurs rarely south of the Bay of Plenty. (1957,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,118)

DOOGUE & MORELAQND RED MOKI ... Other names: Chironemus spectabilis; banded morwong (Australia); nanua (Maori). (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,251)

MORELAND RED MOKI [Chironemus spectabilis] ... known as banded morwong in Australia and by the Maori name nanua in some of New Zealand's northern areas. (1967,Marine Fishes,40)

NATUSCH The red moki or nanua, C. spectabilis, red above, orange below, increases north of Cook strait. (1967,Animals of NZ, The,222)

AYLING RED MOKI (Banded morwong, nanua) Cheilodactylus spectabilis ... Coloration of the red moki is particularly distinctive with eight red-brown vertical stripes on the body and fins ... (1982,Collins Guide,243,1984 ed.)

nao¶

HOOKER Nao, D'Urville. Linum monogynum. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),766)

We "special people" had a good night out. We found that old-fashioned naps are better than throwaways - and a two-pinner is still more watertight than a one-pinner ... (Oct 18, 1989,Evening Post,33)

n. ?Usu. pl abbrev. of nappie, baby's napkin. [ca1940 Heard Dunedin by R Mason]

SLATTER Keeping kids off the flowers. Wiping up the pee on the floor. The stink of naps in the laundry. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,104)

LAY She shook her head, hugging the child to her. ... `Get me a dry nap, will you?' she said. (1988,Fools on the Hill, The,87)

nap the slap¶

phr. [circus argot]

WHITWORTH Barnes was a pantaloon ... taught him a few pantalooning tricks - how to `nap the slap', how to take the jumps, and so on. [fn] [nap the slap] Catch the clown's backhanded blow, and make a sound as of a hit. (1879,Spangles and Sawdust,8)

napia¶

n. W.218 Napia ... Heptatretus cirrhatus, blind eel. =hagfish.

DOOGUE & MORELAND HAGFISH ... Other names: Heptatretus cirrhatus; blind eel; tuere, napia (Maori). (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,297)

MORELAND HAGFISH [Eptatretus cirrhatus] ... Hagfish and blind eel are widely used alternative names, while the Maori tuere and napia are still in use. (1967,Marine Fishes,30)

Napier lunch cake¶

n.

NAPIER LUNCH CAKE ... butter ... sugar ... flour ... currants ... dried milk ... carbonate of soda ... vinegar ... Mix ... and bake ... (1906,Tetaka Kai: A Book of Well Tried Recipes,83)

Napier's boys¶

n. [OBS.]

THOMSON ... in 1855 Ahuriri was proclaimed a port of entry, ...; and a town ship was laid out, which was called Napier, in honour of the hero of Scinde, and the younger Ahuriri settlers gloried in being characterised as Napier's boys. (1859,Story of New Zealand, The,2/188)

Napierness¶

n.

It's the story of a little boy whose brief encounters with a powerful grandmother create a sense of "Napierness" ("a compound of sterling silver serviette rings, the damask of napkins - or rather serviettes - and of EPNS cake forks, nestling in velvet"), as good an explanation as any for why that rough little seaport took a Hollywood-esque role in a Wells documentary about art deco... The book closes with reconciliations with parents and with place. Napierness lives on, for "the past is always in the present, and, if it doesn't visibly exist, can be re-invented on the basis of the tiniest piece of existence". (Jun 1, 2001,Evening Post,5)

Napoleon boots¶

n.

PYKE His pants ... of blue dungaree, were carelessly tucked into Napoleon boots, once black, but now of the brown, brownest, and adorned with soiled red knee-caps, whereon were faintly depicted certain indefinite fragments of the `Bird of Freedom'. (1873,Wild Will Enderby,1/ii/9,1889,1974 ed.)

napoo¶

adj.

NAPOO. - Army French for finish.' <i>Ibid.</i> 165 W'en t'e t'ing napoo, t'e Maori Chief no sayNapoo'. He say, `T'e potata is cook ...'. (1917,New Zealand At the Front) [NOTES: (Glossary) xiv]

LEE Nothing', Johnson admitted,Napoo', said a First World War soldier. `Napoo, Napoo and more Napoo'. (1970,Mussolini's Millions,90)

Another word used in general at theBritish front is "napoo"... It is acurious construction from the French "Iln'y en a plus" which means "There is notany more," and this is also how it isused - as for destroyed Ypres or Bapaumethey are "napoo," Arras, "presque napoo"- a subtle language, and if they stealsomeone's girl, it is "Napoo all right." (Jan 30, 1918,Chronicles NZEF,III/36 : 286)

nappy valley¶

n. Of various places: ? play on Happy Valley: in Wellington usu. Wainuiomata; and occasionally other places. [(There is an official Happy Valley in Wellington.)]

Developed through the 1960s and 1970s, Glenfield has shaken off its old image as a boring, unsophisticated nappy valley for young families. (Feb 4, 2006,NZ Herald)

The outer fringes of Ohariu-Belmont include the lifestyle blocks beyond Johnsonville and first-mortgage territory Newlands - the nappy-valley of Wellington, where pre-schoolers outnumber the national average. (Jul 9, 2002,Dominion Post,A4)

REDMOND Greg grew up in Wainuiomata and jokingly refers to himself as Wainuiomartian. His former hometown was also once known as 'Nappy Valley', due to the large number of young families who settled there in the 1960s and 1970s. (2000,Truckers: NZ Truckers on the Road,31)

After a housing boom in the 1940s - when Wainui first attracted the name Nappy Valley - the government looked at completing the tunnel. (Oct 25, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

How Nappy Vally changed its image. Wainuiomata has lost its `Nappy Valley' image. (Nov 14, 1972,Dominion,12)

MITCHELL [Wellington's suburbs] are all thoughtfully hidden away ... in the isolation ward of the Hutt Valley and its satellites such as Wainuiomata (or Nappy Valley as the locals have it). (1972,Half-Gallon Quarter-Acre Pavlova Paradise, The,34)

Time has seen [the Auckland suburb] Glenfield change from a nappy valley to a middle-class housing area. (Apr 9, 1987,TV2) [NOTES: 10.00 p.m. news]

It wasn't until the late '50s that things started really happening here. Known as Nappy Valley during the '60s, Wainui preceeded Porirua as the haven of young couples who could just scrape up mortgage deposits. (Oct 6, 1986,Salient,7)

This basic fact is completely lost on Taupo District Council which seems hell-bent on "lifting" reserve and tourist zoning stipulations on its own district plan just to please Lisland Properties so it can foist yet another intensive Nappy Valley subdivision on the already overtaxed services and recreational facilities of the small settlement of Kinloch. (Jul 8, 2001,Sunday Star Times,A8)

The Hutt Valley it was the original "nappy valley", associated with flooding from the Hutt River, problems with the train service and boguns getting out of hand on a Saturday night. (Oct 5, 2000,Evening Post,13)

The destination is one of Auckland's shake'n'bake instant suburbs, newly minted, with long, straight, wide, well-lit roads subdividing farmland that will be nappy-valley a year from now. (Jan 26, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),21)

WELLINGTON'S South Coast has been dubbed the new "Nappy Valley" as young families flock to the area bringing elements of cool with them. It also helps that many celebrities call the area home. (Jan 7, 2012,Dominion Post,4)

napuka¶

n. (Environment) the indigenous flowering plant Hebe speciosa

Napuka ( Hebe speciosa ), also known as the titirangi shows off its bottle-brush flowers all year round. (Dec 2006,Growing Today,30)

While revamping the hebe species border at Otari-Wilton's Bush recently, I was pleasantly surprised to meet Hebe speciosa (or napuka) blooming away happily. (Sep 25, 2004,Dominion Post,E13)

LAING & BLACKWELL Hebe speciosa (The Handsome Hebe) ... (Veronica speciosa). Maori name, Napuka. (1940,Plants of NZ,402)

MOORE & IRWIN HEBE SPECIOSA was discovered at Hokianga Heads in 1834 by Richard Cunningham who wrote the Maori name `napuka' on his field label, which still lies with his pressed specimen at Kew. (1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,174)

narangie¶

n.

But they might, if they only would think, now and then,/ That even the shearers and pressers are men/ Who are human, and feel as other men do,/ Whether squatter, narangie, or jackeroo;/ [This is a N.Z. (West Coast) poem] (Mar 20, 1911,Maoriland Worker,7/4/4)

nardoo¶

n. Gaultheria rupestris, snowberry.

Another bird ... is the kaka (Nestor meridionalis), which used to visit the grass country in large numbers when the berry of the Gaultheria rupestris (snowberry, or so called `nardoo' berry of Waipori) was ripe. (1918,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin) [NOTES: Marshall, Tuapea]

Narg¶

n. (offensive) an Indian

McGILL Narg an Indian; offensive. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,75)

nark¶

n. an annoying or unpleasant person or thing

MARSH It's a blooming nark, dinkum it is. (1937,Vintage Murder,114)

Nark - an unpleasant person. (1944,US War Dept. Short Guide to NZ,39) [NOTES: Glossary of Slang]

SOLJAK The following New Zealand expressions derive from British dialects, ... nark: to spoil; a fair nark: unpleasant person (1946,New Zealand (various authors/titles),116)

... when the narks had gone. (1948,Landfall,6/109) [NOTES: Ballantyne]

SLATTER He'll be back next week to see how we're doing. Not to be a nark like, he's not that sorta bloke.' <i>Ibid.</i> 167And here ya stickin up for Canterbury. What a bloody nark you turned out to be. A joker oughta bash ya.' (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,51)

255 You're bloody lucky I don't do you over just for being such a nark. (1960,Word for Word)

SARGESON nark: spoilsport. (1964,Collected Stories,301) [NOTES: 1964 Pearson Glossary to 1964 Sargeson Collected Stories 1935-1963]

n.(slang). spiteful, unpleasant person: one who takes pleasure in spoliing that of other people. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),621)

nark n. person who consistently deprecates the work of others; envious critic, soured obstructionist. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),14)

BENNETT `There you go, lad, picking on a fellow again, the moment you see him. Bloody little nark you are. Can you lend me a quid?' (1980,Canterbury Tale, A,83)

nark Brit. & N.Z. sl. ~ n. 1. an informer or spy: copper's nark. 2. someone who complains in an irritating or whining manner. vb. 3. (tr.) to annoy, upset, or irritate. 4. (intr.) to inform or spy, esp. for the police. 5. (intr.) to complain irritatingly. [C19: prob. < Romany nak nose] (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,749) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 499; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 323]]

v. [criminals']

He believed someone had "narked" on his drug activities to the police after his mother's house was searched and went to a Porirua house to"have it out with them". (Feb 17, 2000,Evening Post,9)

Looser A person who breaks [solidarity] by narking (informing to the authorities) risks serious reprisals. Once labelled a nark or a finger the person is branded and cannot escape this reputation even if he or she relocates to another prison. (Oct 1999,NZWords,2 (2): 2)

NEWBOLD NARK (v) Betray, inform upon. Possibly from French narquois (sly, cunning). (1982,Big Huey, The,251)

He declined to join the witness protection programme even though he was clearly in the extremely vulnerable position of not only giving evidence against gang members, but of hoping to be one himself - an unlikely progression now that he had marked himself out as someone who would nark to the police. (Jul 20, 2002,Weekend Herald,B5)

narrow tractor¶

n. a tractor designed to fit between rows of trees or vines.

Narrow Tractor Field Day Demonstrating the latest Fendt and Massey Ferguson vineyard/orchard range. (May 29, 2004,Hawke's Bay Today,C13)

narrow-leaved¶

adj. As a distinguishing epithet in names of plants see fern, adder's tongue; cassinia, celmisia, coprosma, hinehine; orchid, ===== .bd;hooded; lacebark, lawyer, linsaya, maire, nothop grass, oat tussock; oreobolus; cress; grass, brome, narrow-leaved; tussock, snow tussock; vetch; fer, polypody; snowberry, uncinia, willow herb.

narrow-leaved cress¶

n.

HILGENDROF NARROW-LEAVED CRESS (Lepidium ruderale) is also called cress, pepper cress, way-side cress, wild cress, pepper cress, pepper weed, and scurvy grass. It is common on waste lands, especially near the sea. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,95,1967 ed.)

narrow-leaved lacebark¶

n. Hoheria sexstylosa

COCKAYNE (1924,Cultivation of NZ Plants, The) [NOTES: And]

n.

narrow-leaved maire¶

CHEESEMAN O[lea] montana, Hook.f. ... A much-branched round-headed ... tree, 20-50 ft. high ... Orooro; Narrow-leaved Maire. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,438)

MATTHEWS (1905,Tree Culture in NZ) [NOTES: (And)]

(1907,AJHR) [NOTES: Cockayne Report on a Botanical Survey of Kapiti Island (And)]

nasal bot¶

n.

As regards "nasal bot", symptoms in all cases gradually lessened from this date onwards. (1896,Ann. Rep. Dept of Agriculture,35)

nasal enema¶

n.

[Hdg] Contractor told to stop nose enemas... The instruction was issued.. a day after NZ First leader Winston Peters ridiculed a Hamilton programme in which participants were offered "nasal enemas", required to sit cross-legged humming, laugh at each other or watch the movie One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest (Mar 26, 2004,Dominion Post,A5)

"Is the Minister aware that Accident Compensation Corporation rehabilitation programmes ... require accident victims to undertake a nasal enema by pouring water into their noses, sit cross-legged on the floor with their thumbs in their ears, humming, and ... to stand in a paddock and laugh at each other." Mr Peters reveals the latest strategies to prepare AC claimants for a return to work. (Mar 29, 2004,Dominion Post,B5)

nasal irrigation¶

n.

An ACC contractor has been told to stop offering accident victims nasal irrigation as part of a back-to-work programme. (Mar 26, 2004,Dominion Post,A5)

ACC claimants in Waikato were given nasal irrigation to help prepare them for a return to work... I am dismayed, but not surprised, by the scorn that is being heaped on ACC for running courses on nasal irrigation and yogic humming for its claimants. (Mar 27, 2004,Dominion Post)

Nash¶

n. a Dalmatian

The words Jugoslaven, Dalmatinac and Nash (our person) were very much intertwined and used as if they were all one and the same. (Aug 2004,NZ Memories,No. 49/48)

nashi¶

n. an Asian pear-like fruit, alsonashi pear [Although a pear, nashi are apple-shaped - perhaps this should go into the definition somewhere.]

Yet Turners has also been a vigorouschampion of free enterprise, leading thesuccessful battle against the behemoth ofthe Apple and Pear Marketing Board, whenit looked as though the new glamour crop,the nashi, might be regulated as a pearand go under the exclusive export controlof the board. (Jun 20, 1987,Listener (New Zealand Listener),60)

On behalf of the public relationsconsultants to Turners & Growers ExportsLtd, major exporters of New Zealandnashi, I wonder if you would mind mepointing out an error in your foodarticle... You mention that nashi areexported to Japan. This is not so. (Jun 13, 1987,Listener (New Zealand Listener),6)

BOLLARD The nashi, or oriental pear (Pyrus serotina) is a pip fruit which essentially has not been tried in New Zealand. (1981,Prospects for Horticulture,111)

YEREX Asian pear (nashi) is not really a subtropical at all as it will, in the main, grow in most areas where apples and ordinary pears grow. (1988,Best of Both Worlds,108)

The word 'nashi' is Japanese for pear and, in New Zealand, is now used to describe pear cultivars that have been introduced from Japan. (1990,Nashi,2)

Nashi cultivars have been selected from the wild pear, Pyrus pyrifolia Nakai (P. Serotina Rehder), which is endemic to Japan and the southern parts of China and Korea. Ibid. 76 The NZ Nashi Council has formed a Grade Standards Committee. (1990,Nashi,2)

Nashi¶

n. Dalmatians

There was a time when we cared, a death in the community was attended by all; we all came in for our sister, our brother, our mother, our father, our son and our daughter, our cousin , our friend, as long as they were Nashi, they were ours to mourn. (Aug 2004,NZ Memories,No. 49/48)

nassella¶

n. An originally South American tussock-forming grass, a troublesome weed especially in the South Island [tussock, nassella, Nasella Tussock Board nasella tussock. OED from 1909] (See tussock,nassella,Nasella Tussock Board)

This is not to be confused with Nasella Tussock which is a coarser plant with much rougher leaves. (Jul 11, 1944,Ellesmere Guardian,2)

1 n. (Rural) an invasive tussocky grass, a native of Chile [well-established in New Zealand, particularly North Canterbury.]

ALLAN Nassella trichotoma, a rather graceful tussocky species, somewhat resembling Festuca novae-zelandiae in habit. (1936,Introduction to the grasses of NZ, An,118)

Nassella tussock..This insidious pest crept almost unawares on to some of our good pastoral country. (Jun 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,515)

Nassella is going to cost a lot in time, money and energy. (May 10, 1951,NZ Farmer,4)

Nat¶

n.

n. a National Party member [Nats incorporates supporters as well as members] (See Nats)

[Hdg] Nats didn't want Apec party. (Sep 12, 1999,Sunday Star Times,A3)

Yet, although Banks was never regarded as a clubbable True Blue Nat, he counted among his close friends and supporters several of National's most aristocratic seniors. (Nov 3, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20)

It's equally unwise (as the Nats are finding) to promise not to raise taxes. (Mar 26, 1993,Independent (Auckland),30)

LEE March .....At the same time the Nats circulate my scarlet letter. (1939,John A. Lee Diaries,138 18,1981 ed.)

MITCHELL Nats: Government of New Zealand from time immemorial. (1972,Half-Gallon Quarter-Acre Pavlova Paradise, The,183)

MOORE I used to joke that it was quality not quantity that mattered: the Lord only had a dozen workers and one of them was a Nat! (1987,Hard Labour,29)

Meurant simply seized on probably the only appealing aspect of Muldoonism these days for the born-again Nats, the former prime minister's cheery ability to throw ... allegations of treason ... (Oct 8, 1987,National Business Review,10)

The Nats have had so many absolute political gifts lately, but the minute they get the Government on the ropes, the dill-brains start slogging themselves on the chops instead. (Jul 19, 1987,Sunday News,37)

[Hdg] Nats get nasty. (Apr 9, 1979,Salient,3)

The Nats have another caucus... (Apr 19, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),13)

Naturally, the Nats paint a differentpicture of their economic performance. (May 16, 1993,Sunday Star (Auckland),D-6)

Bona fide Nats who spend their childhoodon horseback are not expected to everwalk properly and their parents shouldenrol them before birth. (May 10, 1975,Listener (New Zealand Listener),8)

Ms Bradford says some of the housing in question is on one of the last waterfront areas that is still in public housing. 't appears that the temptation to hand it over to their rih mates in the private sector was just too much for the Nats,'said Ms Bradford. 'This is an eptionally callous act, even by National Party standards. (Nov 10, 2011,Scoop)

Say, did you see the other day / the Hoppersition's great array / Uv the noo recruets who 'ave signed / Up with the Nats? .. / An' that our Miss Red Ridin'ood / (Meaning the Nats.) will beat the big / Bad wolf to it. (Aug 4, 1938,Evening Post,8)

Nat Gould¶

n. a class of NZ soldier in WWI [WWI humorous]

INGRAM The 32nds. [Reinforcements] are nicknamed the Half Minutes', and all reinforcements now arriving, being conscripted men, come under the general name ofNat Goulds'. This from the fact that Nat Gould was the author of a book titled `Landed at Last'. (Feb 23, 1918,Anzac Diary,87,1987 ed.)

There are two great primary classes [of diggers] a) Aucklanders b) others. They may be further subdivided into. 1) Nat Goulds 2) Dinks 3) Stokers 4) Main Bodymen. (1918,New Zealand At the Front,32)

Mac's face wore a Nat Gould smile -"Landed at Last." (Aug 16, 1918,Chronicles NZEF,V/50 : 34)

NATFORT¶

abbr. Nationals for the Treaty [ORIGIN: acronym]

They plan to set up a group called "Nationals for the Treaty" or NATFORT. ... NATFORT would work to reduce that imbalance, aiming to return to the party's roots of working cooperatively with Maori, he [Dr Kidd] said. (Sep 26, 2005,NZ Herald,A6)

Nati¶

n. a strain of horses

Morice, of Ngati Porou descent, brings to the partnership his strong Nati mares (the vertically challenged all-purpose horse used in the Ngati Porou region) and his full background of work on stations. Ibid. 17 Over the years and through harsh working conditions, Morice says, the East Coast Nati developed into a gutsy horse with plenty of spirit. (Feb 1997,North & South,16)

n.

At Mangahanea in teeming rain the Nati rose to the occasion. (Aug 17, 1935,Na To Hoa Aroha,3/189) [NOTES: Ngata]

national¶

adj. NZ in various senses. a. Maori.

MARSDEN The Ngati-Whatua, Uri-o-Hau, and Roroa met him on the banks of the Waimako with over 1,000 men, but these were armed only with the old national weapons and had but two muskets among them. (1932,Letters & Journals of Samuel Marsden,427,Elder (ed.)1932 ed.) [NOTES: [=Maori : Battle of Te Ika-a-ranga-nui, Feb 1825]]

GRACE This Church will be, if finished according to Maori architecture, the greatest monument of national art that New Zealand contains, and which the present race is likely ever to execute. (Dec 31, 1851,Pioneer Missionary Among the Maoris, A,16,1928 ed.) [NOTES: 1851 Dec 31 T.S.Grace Report of Turanga District in Grace Pioneer Missionary (1928)]

COLENSO Nearly in the midst stood Hakitara, a tall Native of the Rarawa Tribe, dressed in a very large and handsome silky white kaitaka mat (finest and best kind of garment, only worn by superior chiefs), ... the whole of Native (I might truly say of national) design and manufacture. (1890,Treaty of Waitangi,15)

He suggested that National lost the Rangitikei seat because the party had lost touch right across the board. (1981,Evening Post,2)

Now National has removed that commitment from the department's mission statement. (Oct 6, 1992,Evening Post,16)

National engaged Logos last year to soften up the public. (Oct 8, 1992,Evening Post,10)

n. NAC, NZ's first national domestic airline (See NAC)

On his return to Wellington, he.. worked for the National Airways Corporation, married, went into business and later owned Timber Treatments Ltd, seller of borer bombs and other timber-proofing products. (Sep 23, 1999,Evening Post,7)

National Certificate of Educational Achievement¶

n.

The first level of the National Certificate of Educational Achievement (NCEA) was introduced last year replacing school certificate for the country's year 11 students and the Government has urged colleges to press ahead with level two of the scheme, which will replace sixth form certificate. (Nov 19, 2002,Capital Times,2)

I cannot let him get away with the reference to the National Certificate of Educational Achievement (NCEA), the national qualification that replaces School Certificate in 2002. (Jun 16, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),8)

In a move seen by traditionalists as a dumbing down of secondary-school education in New Zealand, the government's proposed National Certificate in Educational Achievement (NCEA) is due to replace School Certificate. (Aug 5, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),18)

national death¶

n. drowning [aka New Zealand death; drowning] (See also New Zealand death)

There is too much reason to fear that another instance of what has been not inaptly termed the "national death" of the colony, has occurred at the New River, the victim being mr George Gidgood, and very old settler on this coast. (Aug 3, 1882,Grey River Argus,2)

PASCOE For drowning was in those days [c1860s] called the `national death', so often did glacier-fed mountain rivers claim victims. (1960,Over the Whitcombe Pass,15)

THE NATIOINAL DEATH .. This morning his mate reported to the police, who dragged the river and recovered the body of deceased. (Aug 3, 1883,Grey River Argus,2)

national draught¶

1 n. (Rural) billy tea.

We find no-one "at home" but there is a billy handy, in which there is some good lukewarm tea, which following the bush custom, we proceed to commandeer. Refreshed by the national draught, we make onwards... (Aug 14, 1900,Hawera Star,4)

Another student, Walter Harris, was ensnared by Shelley's passion for drama and play production; as an officer of the department he later went on to establish the National Film Library and was the founder of the National Film Archives. (Sep 27, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),49)

National Mortgage Corporation¶

n. (historical)

SINCLAIR Mortgages and state loans were converted compulsorily to a lower rate of interest. A National Mortgage Corporation, partly on the lines of the German land banks, was created in the hope of making cheaper credit available. (1959,History of New Zealand,254)

National Orchestra¶

n.

How you winced when you thought of your friends who said you ought to be in Wellington leading the National Orchestra and imagined them reading the sign and the advertisements! (1984,All Visitors Ashore,17,1986 ed.)

National Park¶

n.

We are doing our very best to stop the introduction of heather and gorse into the National Park. (Dec 9, 1924,Otago Witness,44)

It may be remarked that National Park is American in origin, dating from 1872, about the time that Yosemite was set aside for recreational purposes. In England, park, like forest, may have a definite legal meaning when it applies to a tract of land held by royal grant for keeping beasts of the chase. Unlike a forest, a park is enclosed, and [31] it does not have special laws or offices. In all the uses to which park has been put in England, until the recent adoption of National Park, there has been the idea of enclosure, as there is in the cognate paddock. The term forest park, as in the Tararua Forest Park, would once have seemed a contradiction in terms. (Sep 1958,Tararua,30) [NOTES: Ruth Mason `Track and Trail']

The concept of national parks - places where the natural environment would be preserved - developed quickly in New Zealand. Our first national park - Tongariro National Park - was created in 1877, only five years after Yellowstone in the United States, the first in the world. (Nov 19, 2001,Evening Post,19)

The Main Trunk railway runs within a few miles of this proposed National Park. (May 14, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,8)

Judging from the question put down by Mr.W.F. Buckland as to native disputes over the block at the Tongariro National Park, that gentleman is of the opinion that the title to the lands is not finally settled.Ibid. 14 May I called today on Mr. McKerrow, Surveyor-General,.. with a view to the inspection of the maps in relation to the national park, Tongariro, which it is proposed to set aside by statute. (May 7, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,14)

The Tongariro National Park proved more popular than ever this season as a tourist resort. (Jan 5, 1949,Auckland Weekly News,19)

National Party¶

n. a conservative NZ political party

National Party n. 1. (in New Zealand) the more conservative of the two main political parties. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,750)

Mr Harry Atmore, Independentmember for Nelson, said there wereunmistakable indications of anoverwhelming desire among the people fora genuine National Government... Hebelieved that a large number ofcandidates for the next election would beannounced as Nationalists. (Jun 4, 1925,Evening Post,6)

Nothing has yet been decided aboutcalling a caucus of the National Party todiscuss the Budget. (Sep 17, 1935,Dominion,12)

DOWNES & HARCOURT On 15 September 1964 the National Programme came into operation. (1976,Voices in the Air,171)

Jack Perkins delivered the most uplifting tale of community devotion in a very special Spectrum programme on National Radio. (Aug 24, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),67)

National Roads Board¶

n. (historical)

The National Raods Board was born in the mid-1950s. Its job was to bring State highways up to modern standards and subsidise local authorities' road programmes. (Feb 22, 2002,Evening Post,6)

national station¶

n.

3ZM started the breakfast sessions. Thesewere copied by the National Stations. (Nov 23, 1935,Christchurch Star-Sun,24)

FRAME He even smiled amusedly, noting that the'old' national station that once keptstrictly to 'Where E'er You Walk', 'BlessThis House', 'I'll Walk Beside You', andbrass band music, now played a 'musak'selection. (1988,Carpathians, The,68)

National Super¶

n. (informal) National Superannuation [ORIGIN: abbreviation]

Not surprisingly, National wants to get back to National Super, the title bestowed on the state pension scheme by glad-handing Rob Muldoon several centuries ago. (Jul 9, 1990,Listener (New Zealand Listener),8) [NOTES: Listener and TV Times]

National Superannuation¶

n. [some citations here belong with National Super q.v.]

The highly generous National Super immediately became the biggest drain on public funds in the country's history and the Lange Government elected in 1984 quickly imposed the "surtax", to claw back the pension from the wealthiest 20 per cent of recipients. (May 2000,North & South,42)

The largest benefit category is New Zealand Superannuation, the state pension paid to 459,595 people, followed by the 164,902 registered unemployed who are paid what is now called the "community wage". (Oct 1999,North & South,50)

He tells me he is 49 going on 50, but as you can see from his photograph, he looks a healthy hike away from his national super. (Feb 24, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),34)

national superannuation n. N.Z. a government pension given on the attainment of a specified age; old age pension. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,750)

OVENDEN Grog... early retirement and ten years getting fat on National Super. (1986,O.E.,111)

Nationalist¶

adj. (historical)

There will be 39 straight-out contests 14 between Reform and Labour, 15 between Reform and Nationalist Party; 6 between Nationalists and Labour.. and one between Labour and an Independent Liberal. (Oct 28, 1925,Evening Post,6)

[Hdg] Nationalist Views... That wasthe opinion of a Nationalist member ofthe House, who apparently had hoped for amore persuasive programme for theelection campaign. (Oct 19, 1935,Dominion,10)

n. (historical)

Throughout the electorates under the guiding hand of Bob Masters the two parties [United and Reform] have been getting together and forming local Nationalistic committees. Ibid. 3/198 (Ngata) Then there is one of the Ormond [sc. Omana] boys of Mahia out as the Ratana candidate. (Aug 17, 1935,Na To Hoa Aroha,3/197) [NOTES: Ngata]

Mr Forbes said the Liberals had been criticised for changing their name to Nationalists. (Oct 27, 1925,Evening Post,9)

The Reformers stood for speculation, and apparently the Nationalists favoured the same thing. (Oct 28, 1925,Evening Post,9)

[Hdg]. A National Party. Why it isNecessary... Mr Harry Atmore, Independentmember for Nelson, said there wereunmistakable indications of anoverwhelming desire among the people fora genuine National Government... Hebelieved that a large number ofcandidates for the next election would beannounced as Nationalists. (Jun 4, 1925,Evening Post,6)

Nationals¶

n. national championships, esp. in swimming, athletics etc.

When we did get away to the nationals, the added competition always sent me home feeling I was on the right track.. and my training would go up to another level. (Jan 30, 2002,Capital Times,4)

"A lot of us were training for [secondary school] nationals which are in December and after that meeting we just continued about three times a week." (Mar 12, 2002,Evening Post,29)

In between, they have been polishing their performance for the national [Marching Team] champs at Inglewood... On the lead-up to the nationals, they were practising two weeknights and a Saturday afternooon every week. (Mar 16, 2002,Dominion Weekend Magazine,3)

[Hdg] High hopes for Lyall Bay junior at nationals... The New Zealand developmewnt squad member will also target the surf race at the nationals. (Mar 14, 2002,Evening Post)

'Are you going to try out for the Nationals, Space?' 'Nah, I can't afford the time and money to get there this year.' (2003,Huia 5: Contemp. Maori Fiction,42)

native¶

n. native plant

GUTHRIE-SMITH Another reason assigned for the disappearance of the natives is ability to compete with alien breeds in regard to food supply. (1926,Tutira,204)

But when you've got trees there's always something happening - at the moment the natives are flowering and the tuis are everywhere. (Dec 16, 2004,Dominion Post,C9)

adj. In combinations merging into compounds in the popular names of local fauna and flora, especially where the local variety was named after some real or fancied resemblance to a European or overseas model (eg native bluebell). This use can be (and is being) replaced by New Zealand aj, and Maori aj. In the dictionary native is considered as a separable prefix for reasons of convenience when used in names of fauna and flora. See anise, aniseed, ash, bitter cress, bleu-bell, bramble, burr, carrot, clematis, currant, cypress, daisy, dock, fig, flax, fuchsia, heath, hemp, holly, honeysuckle, ivy, laburnum, laurel, lilac, mimosa, mistletoe, mulberry, myrtle, passion fruit, pepper, sarsaparilla, teak, thorn, tobacco; honey; quail, salmon.

SWAINSON .. for a period of ten days or a fortnight, little or no gold was to be seen. The sight of even a single ounce ... would now have satisfied the most impatient, ...; still, not an ounce of native gold could be purchased in Auckland. (1835,Auckland,105)

adj. (of country) in its aboriginal state, virgin.

On native country Flax is always a sign of good land. (Oct 14, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Gloss]

POLACK My native property has been purchased in a manner agreeably to the custom of the missionaries, ... (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/xxxii)

n. item of native fauna

HUNT No, my father didn't mind us shanghaiing thrushes and that, but he alwayssaid don't touch the natives. We did, though - pigeons and tomtits and tuis. (1985,I'm Ninety-five,261) [NOTES: Wattie, Stewart I.)]

Although many of the creatures are exotic, they are now concentrating on New Zealand natives, including the extinct Canterbury mudfish, which looks like thriving. (Jul 28, 1986,NZ Woman's Weekly) [NOTES: quoted in 1986 Oct 4 Listener 5]

n. native tree

Owaka department of Conservation staff are worried about the felling of natives for firewood. (Aug 3, 1988,Clutha Leader) [NOTES: quoted in 1988 Aug 27 Listener 11 quoted]

1 n. (Rural) land in its indigenous state.

NEWTON .. discable areas of native at the homestead are gradually being brought in ... (1973,Big Country of the South Island,79)

NEWTON .. there is also another 3,000 acres of easily-worked country still in the native ... (1973,Big Country of the South Island,218)

There are such expressive terms as to 'bring in,' referring to developing land out of the native for farming ... (Feb 2, 1977,Press, The,19)

BEACH .. the distinct trail would get hard to follow as it traversed across boney patches in the native. [in the native] (1993,Over 30 Years Pig Hunting,132)

3 adj. [176? Cook see wild celery. See also: (note that these epithets often gradually dropped off - plant etc names) anise, aniseed, arbutilon, ash, bamboo, beech, begonia, bignonia, bluebell, bramble, broom, burr, carrot, cedar, celery, clematis, convolvulus, corkwood, currant, cypress, daisy, everlastinf, fig, flax, fuchsia, geranium, groundsel, harebell, hawthorn, heath, heather, hemp, holly, honeysuckle, ice-plant, iris, laburnum, laurel, lilac, mimosa, mint, mistletoe, mulberry, myrtle; grass, oat grass; parsley, passion-flower, passion-vine, pepper, sandalwood, sarsaparilla, scabweed, screw-pine. teak, thorn, thyme, violet, water milfoil; lark[add rest of birds etc]; dog.] (See also native forest)

DAVIS ... did you notice anything about that big native tree we just passed? (1964,Watersiders,111)

POLACK The trees in the native forests are full of similar resins, which often exudes even from the tops of the leaves. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/347)

But the native trees and shrubs are as thickly coated as ever with their green leaves; ... (1841,Establishment of New Plymouth Settlement,78,1940 ed.)

MACKIE In the afternoon ... I went in search of a few native shrubs and trees to plant about the meeting house. (1973,Traveller under Concern,105) [NOTES: 1853 May 6 Mackie Traveller under Concern (1973)105]

It is a neat and pretty town, in a first-class farming district, and has a beautiful park of native forest-trees. (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,57)

... with windows to the ground opening on a wide Verandah, and a terrace, beyond which a sloping lawn with flower beds and then a belt of shrubbery partly native trees, ... (1940,Founding of New Zealand, The,205) [NOTES: 1873 S.Mathew Autobiography in 1940 Founding of NZ 205]

BARRY ... to join forces for the purpose of erecting an up to date saw-mill to work this and other djacentareas of native timber. (1966,In the Lee of the Hokonuis,146) [NOTES: 1926 Prospectus of the Waitane Saw-milling and Afforestation Ltd in 1966 Barry In the Lee of the Hokonuis 146]

BEATTIE One of the prettiest sights I ever saw was a hillside at Hakataramea covered with mauve, blue and coloured native plants (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,194)

I regret my inability to give either native or settler's names of the native grasses, as requested. Very few indeed of our northern natives have any knowledge of the old native names, and my residence in the colony has been but short. (1872,TrNZI,4/298) [NOTES: Report on Grasses]

FIRTH He [a Tuhoe elder] knew the old Native names of every tree, shrub, plant, or fern in the forests of Tuhoeland. (1929,Primitive Economics of NZ Maori,43)

MIDDLETON The kumara is a curious plant,' he said. ...But it's a native, Dan, isn't it?' (1959,Stone, The,65)

Native¶

n. Applied to Maori people and their concerns. a. The synonym Aborigine(q.v.) was used very early as a term familiar to the Colonial Office (and perhaps to missionary organisations as the Church Missionary Society) and had some currency from the offical name and office Protector of Aborigines'. See also Cook's (and early explorer's) indian. b. native preceded Maori q.v. in common use in early journals and accounts. (eg Markham, Polack etc) the latter being first used (as perhaps native was) as an adjective, and its frequency was (until the 1850's or 1860's) matched only by the use of New Zealand and New Zealander (especially the latter as a noun) forMaori'. -->[Discuss usage in eg. Markham, Williams, McLean etc.] In Richmond - Atkinson papers Maori seems to be the main personal usage of the correspondents except for H. Atkinson who uses negro, nigger in private correspondence. Abusive early synonyms: see black, nigger, later hori.

PARKINSON ... discovered many of the natives (who seemed to be of very dark hue) and several of their canoes hauled upon the beach. (Oct 9, 1769,Journal,87) [NOTES: [used for Maori from the first sighting]]

Towards noon we were visited for the first time by some of the Natives, they stayed and dined with us and it was not a little they devoure ... . (May 23, 1773,Cook's Journals,2/167) [NOTES: [not Indian]]

... every man, woman, and child in the colony shall be taxed to pay it [i.e. the debt of the New Zealand Company], not only English, but Native. (Sep 27, 1851,Lyttelton Times,5)

Nelson ... deficient in natives. (Feb 7, 1851,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/77)

MOSER [cap] It merely represented what my early impressions were on the moral condition of the Natives, and ... closer intimacy with the Maori race has considerably shaken the opinions I thenformed. (1863,Mahoe Leaves,58)

BUDDLE The hon. gentleman said, `Hitherto there has been no attempt to meet the special and local wants of the Aborigines ... Between the provincial Councils and the General Assembly the wants of the Natives in [17] these respects have ... been wholly neglected.' (1860,Maori King Movement,16)

CARBERRY It seems that a native from Taranaki was enduced to join the fighting Maoris here from promises of getting land and money belonging to the Pakeha - ... (Nov 18, 1863,Journal)

TAYLOR [?derog] As our countrymen increased and occupied the country, the necessity of keeping on terms of friendship with the natives became less felt, and by the fresh comers, not at all. Ibid. 113 The native is naturally as shrewd and sensible as the European, and far more so than many. (1868,Past and Present of NZ,111)

DOMETT [Maori : distinct from SETTLER (cf Maori v. colonist)] Having a little discussion about the New Zealand war, and to whose fault, that of the colonists or the Maories, it was attributable; Dr. H. [Hodgson, Professor Political Economy, Edinburgh] apparently getting the worst of the argument, came off triumphantly and turned it into a laugh by asking the riddle, Do you know the difference between a good oyster and a bad one?' -No!' Do you give it up?' -Yes!' `Well, a good oyster's a Native - and a bad one's a Settler!' - which settled the argument. (Aug 28, 1873,Diary,102,1853 ed.)

PAYTON It is always the custom in New Zealand, especially in the North Island, to use Maori words frequently in referring to the natives and their doings; a colonist would no more dream of calling a Maori whare a house,' or a tangia ceremony of weeping' than he ... (1888,Round about NZ,viii)

COLENSO [cap consistently used `If Pikopo and his priest go in, we [Colenso et al.], for the sake of our position among the Natives, should go in also.' [fn] The common Maori name by which the Roman Catholic bishop and the priests were known. Ibid. 15 Nearly in the midst stood Hakitara, a tall Native of the Rarawa Tribe, dressed in a very large and handsome silky white kaitaka mat (finest and best kind of garment, only worn by superior chiefs), ... the whole of Native (I might truly say of national) design and manufacture. (1890,Treaty of Waitangi,13)

[cap] The Natives still own about 20,000 acres, but not much of it is fit for settlement. (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,6)

`Waimate Witness' records that an old Native, Tiki, ... still smacks his lips in recollection of ... long pig. (Aug 17, 1905,NZ Truth,9-5-8)

WHITE Beginning with the shrubs at the back, first comes Pomaderris elliptica, or Kumarahou, as it is called by the natives. (1905,My NZ Garden,10)

A Colac Bay native narrated that the late Rawiri te Awha had been one of a party of Maoris living on the shores of Te Anau some eighty or ninety years ago. Under the custom of ohu the men were assembles assisting a man to make a garden at some distance from the whare (houses). (Apr 1921,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,4/88) [NOTES: Beattie]

MULGAN Pillar of the Church and sweats his work girls.'Made money in the war selling stores to the troops and ammunition to the natives.' Ibid. 44 There were always a few natives about. ... Some of them were in town on land court business. (1934,Spur of Morning,42)

GUTHRIE-SMITH Pakeha and natives alike, now that it was possible to do so, were eager to come to terms. (1926,Tutira)

PARTRIDGE [The] following [was] employed by those who served in the [Great] War ... ti-tree oneself, to take shelter from artillery, the ti-tree being very common in N.Z., where during the Maori War,the natives had an exasperating habit of retreating to `the bush', wooded country; (1935,Slang Today,286) [NOTES: 1935 Mitchell and Strong in Partridge Slang Today]

BEAGLEHOLE [cp Maori] Many Maoris resent the fact that they are called natives' by the pakehas. Joking among themselves, they may call each other natives, but the use of the word in this connection becomes a joke just because of the resentment at its use by the pakeha. One informant expressed the matter thus:We're not natives, we're Maori. A native is an aborigine, a savage, while we are three or more generations away from that. We don't like having a Native Department, or Native schools, or a Native Land Court, or a Native Minister. We like to be called Maori. We're proud of being Maori, not natives.' (1946,Some Modern Maoris,300)

WILLIAMS Aute, n. 1. Broussonetia papyrifera, paper mulberry, formerly cultivated by the natives in New Zealand. (1975,Dictionary of the Maori Language,1971 ed.)

Temple rightly notes Dieffenbach's enlightened perception of the Maori as the first inhabitants with fundamental rights, and not inferior, intellectually and morally, to the invading European. But he labours the point in seeing evidence of this in Dieffenbach's reference to them as New Zealanders, by implication the true inhabitants of the country, when the terms Maori and Native were become synonymous and implied that they were inferior to the intellectual and moral superiority of white, especially British, races'. At the time,New Zealanders' was commonly used (eg The New Zealanders Illustrated by G F Angas, 1847) while the term native', meaningnative to the place' without the depressed sense it was later to acquire, was also used freely by Dieffenbach. (Mar 8, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),36) [NOTES: Nancy M.Taylor review of Temple's New Zealand Explorers]

WILLIAMS At four we assembled for evening service in the chapel, when all the natives attended: we commenced with a native hymn, and after the church service we sang an english [sic] hymn, native prayer, after which I then addressed the natives from John 1.29. (Aug 24, 1828,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,142,1961 ed.)

EARLE some few among them ... had deserted from their ships, and were then leading a mean and miserable life amongst the natives. (1832,Narrative of a Nine Months Residence in NZ,82,1962 ed.)

Narcobatus fairchildi (Hutton). SOUTHERN NUMBFISH, OR WHAI REPO. ... The species is also called torpedo' orelectric ray.' Hutton states that the Natives (presumably of Napier) call it whai-ngenge. (1930,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,11/98) [NOTES: Phillipps]

LAMBERT When Dr. F.F. Ormond purchased the Orangitirohia block on the north side of the river, not allthe Natives had been satisfactorily dealt with, and a `Native difficulty' of the first grade soon arose. (1936,Pioneering Reminiscences of Old Wairoa,20)

CRAIK Among those which the natives principally make use of, are the henow, from which they extract a black dye, and the vow, a species of cork tree. (1830,New Zealanders, The,175)

The greatest reception the Governor has had from natives, the most loyal reverence for the Queen's name and `mana', the most intelligent acquaintance with the English tikanga[fn. Policy.], ... are to be found in the Ngapuhi ... (Mar 21, 1858,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/367,1960 ed.) [NOTES: F D Bell]

Native Land Act, 1865. "Native" shall mean an aboriginal Native of the Colony of New Zealand and shall include all half-castes and their descendants by natives. (1865,NZ Statutes,29 Vict. 71/264)

Native Land Act, 1873. "Native" shall mean an aboriginal Native of the Colony of New Zealand and shall include all half-castes and theirdescendants by natives. (1873,NZ Statutes,37 Vict. 56/239)

Native Land Act, 1931. "Native" means a person belonging to theaboriginal race of New Zealand; andincludes a half-caste and a personintermediate in blood between half-castesand persons of pure descent from thatrace. (1931,NZ Statutes,22 GV 31/165)

Native Housing Act, 1935. "Native" means a person belonging to the aboriginal race of New Zealand, and includes a person descended from aNative. (1935,NZ Statutes,GV 34/212)

FORSTER we found the voices came from some Natives, one of which stood on the top of a projecting rock. (Apr 7, 1773,Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The,2/248)

FORSTER we heard a loud hallooing on ... an island, which on this occasion obtained the name of Indian Island; and standing on the shore we perceived one of the natives ... He stood with a club or battle-axe in his hand, ... and behind him ... two women, each of them having a long spear. (1777,Voyage Round the World,1/137)

SAVAGE It is advisable not to suffer any natives to come on board until the ship is brought to an anchor, as the novelty of their appearance is liable to take off the attention of the seamen from their duty, ... (1807,New Zealand (various authors/titles),6)

MARSDEN In a few weeks some natives of New Zealand came to Port Jackson again; three of these men besides Duaterra (Ruatara) I took into my own house. (Nov 28, 1813,Marsden's Lieutenants,38) [NOTES: 1813 Nov 28 Marsden in Elder Marsden's Lieutenants (1934)]

NICHOLAS Government House, Sydney, New South Wales ... and his Excellency being equally solicitous to protect the natives of New Zealand and the Bay of Islands, in all their just rights and privileges, [32] as those of every other dependency of the territory of New South Wales, ... (Nov 9, 1814,New Zealand (various authors/titles),1/31) [NOTES: 1814 Nov 9 Sydney Gazette in 1817 Nicholas NZ]

MARSDEN When our arrival was known we were soon surrounded by numbers of the natives, who vied with one another in their attentions. None of us were under the smallest apprehensions of danger, any more than if amongst Europeans. (1815,Letters & Journals of Samuel Marsden,96,1932 ed.)

NICHOLAS Like the natives [of a North Cape tribe], he [a Tahitian who had been `civilised' in Port Jackson] wore the mat thrown over his shoulders, but the one he had on was bordered with a deep vandyke of different colours, and fairly bedizened with the feathers of parrots and other birds, ... (1817,New Zealand (various authors/titles),1/95)

McCRAE We were received very kindly by the natives ... (1820,Journal,13) [NOTES: 1820 McCrae Journal (1928)]

CRUISE The natives traded in the curiosities of their country, which they sold for axes, knives &c.; ... (1823,Journal,59,1957 ed.) [NOTES: 1820 Mar 20 in 1823 Cruise Journal (1957)]

SHEPHERD He saw a village built in the New Zealand Style and about 20 or thirty Natives, said they behave sivil to him. (Mar 22, 1826,Journal) [NOTES: 1826 Mar 22 Shepherd Journal in 1940 Howard Rakiura 363]

WILLIAMS [initial cap] I afterwards visited three settlements towards Waitangi. The first a few Natives from inland; the second a company of Ship girls; ... Ibid. 24 Aug. 142 At four we assembled for evening service in the chapel, when all the natives attended: we commenced with a native hymn, and after the church service we sang an english [sic] hymn, native prayer, after which I then addressed the natives from John 1.29. (Apr 22, 1827,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,53,1961 ed.)

MARKHAM Crow made all hands of the Natives (or Tangata Mouries) give us some of their Dances, ... Ibid. 53 The Sawyers tell the Natives when in Anger, They will exterminate the Tangata Mouries' as theRah Parkieah' has the `Rah Mourie'. (1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles),30)

[Boultbee does not use Maori] Price, who spoke but little of the language, told the natives Capt K was a tourikka or cookie and that he was of no note etc. (1827,Boultbee Journal) [NOTES: 1827 Boultbee Journal in 1979 Begg 196]

YATE [with NEW ZEALANDER, the usual term in Yate, MAORI isn't used] In this lake are large quantities of conger-eels; which are most sought after ... by the natives, as a most deliciousarticle of food. Ibid. 31 The flax-trade, on the present system, cannot last long in New Zealand. The natives' wants are supplied; and their natural idleness will prevail over their desire for luxuries. Ibid. 258 [cap] The following are Letters from some of the baptized Natives, expressive of their desire to be admitted to the Holy Communion. (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),8)

Captain Harled the Canous up to Hous [on the beach] Nativs went to the bush again. [ed note glossary 155] CANEW. - Canoes, or dug-outs', fashioned out of a single tree-trunk, ... were the only sea-going craft in the possession of the Natives at that time. In the Log they are calledboats', apparently in order to avoid a spelling difficulty. (Apr 14, 1837,Piraki Log,52,1911 ed.)

TAYLOR We called upon a Mr Wade who has a neat garden attached to his cottage, he introduced mice ... here which after him the natives call wadies. (Mar 15, 1839,Journal,2/74)

[aboriginal native] Provided always, that nothing in these our letters patent contained shall affect ... the rights of any aboriginal natives of the said colony of New Zealand to the actual occupation or enjoyment in their own persons, or in the persons of their descendants, of any lands in the said colony now actually occupied or enjoyed by such natives. (Nov 16, 1840,Charter for Erecting the Colony of NZ) [NOTES: in 1949 Rutherford ed. Select Documents 8]

I beg to apologize for the very soiled state of the treaty, but the native habits are so filthy it could hardly be avoided. (May 23, 1840,GBPP,104) [NOTES: 1840 May 23 James Stack to Willoughby Shortland, Acting Col.Secretary in GBPP House of Commons 1841 (No.311) 104]

AAA. Reserves ... that on Thorndon Flat is occupied by an extensive native pah, which the natives have not alienated ... The second was intended for a basin, an idea suggested probably by the swampy character of the ground around it; but besides that, such a project is of very questionable advantage; ... (Oct 20, 1841,GBPP,185) [NOTES: 1841 Oct 20 F.Mathew to Hobson in GBPP 1842 (No.569) 185]

WILY & MAUNSELL I am thankful to say that things are going on amicably between the colonists and natives. Government will have justice done to the natives. The aborigines have lost a real friend in our poor late Governor. (Mar 31, 1842,Robert Maunsell,76,1938 ed.) [NOTES: 1842 Mar 31 in Wily and Maunsell Robert Maunsell (1938) 76]

HEAPHY The natives of Port Nicholson have since proved that they appreciate the introduction ofEuropean [5] civilization; ... Ibid. 50 The New Zealanders have been gradually improving since the first visits of Europeans. I deny that the irregular settlement of many parts of the country by white poeple has had, in any way, a demoralizing influence on the aborigines. The natives living about the whaling stations are generally the best informed, ... (1842,New Zealand (various authors/titles),4)
