BARTHROP The Blacks or Mowreys acted very well. ... The Natives ware [sic] no clothes at all but some old shirt tied around there weastes. [sic] (1979,To Face the Daring Maori,71) [NOTES: 1845 Whisker Memorandum Book in 1979 Barthorp To Face the Daring Maori 71]

TAYLOR I had natives for conversation and medicine (and tooth drawing) to a late hour. (Mar 14, 1847,Journal,V/4)

[cap cp colonist] Supposing this intended with a view of giving full effect to the system of amalgamation, there should be no exceptional law for natives within the municipalities, Native Protectors, for example, are an exceptional class of officers, whose very appointment suggests the idea of a natural hostility between the colonists and the Natives; ... letters addressed to `Squire Clarke', the chief Protector of the Aborigines under Captain Hobson ... (1949,Selected Documents,15A) [NOTES: 1846 Jan 20 E.G. Wakefield to Gladstone in 1949 Rutherford ed. Select Documents 15A]

n. a Moriori

The Natives who had quitted their station as soon as they saw us land now advanced hastily, ... (Nov 29, 1791,Journal of the 'Chatham') [NOTES: in 1908 McNab Historical Records 2/504]

  • we had proceeded but a little way when we first observed the [Chatham Island] Natives forming rather hastily into a Body by the edge of the wood [63] abreast of us, - (Nov 1791,Journal of the 'Chatham',62) [NOTES: 1791 Nov E.Bell Journal of Voyage in H.M.S. `Chatham' (Vancouver expedition) (MS ATB)]

adj. Used within New Zealand, in competition with the more specific New Zealand, Maori to denote especially fauna (including human fauna) and flora considered indigenous. It is now (1984) anobsolescent or non-preferred use, chiefly because of the felt derogatory application to people and things Maori (cf the change in 1947 from Department of Native Affairs' toMaori Affairs', and such shifts as native earth oven amended to earth oven between the sixth (1957) and seventh (1971) editions of Williams Dictionary (Umu 1 p467); and also of greater feeling of identity among born New Zealanders expressing itself in a more specific descriptive term New Zealand'. (Shifts such as native bush to indigenous forest are an example of vernacular or common as against technical orprofessional' forestry usage: the latter being the converse of exotic forest.) The New Zealand non-specificity of native can be seen in its Australian applications (see Morris), and is illustrated by OED 13c. In the names of Australian animals and birds in the names of Australian plants, fruits, etc.' [J.A. Andersen's comments (Popular Names of New Zealand Plants': 1926 Tr NZI 662) still hold: The wordnative' has been prefixed to almost as many names as the words New Zealand .... This word may perhaps be descriptive if used within New Zealand and between New Zealanders; but if used outside - say in Australia - its meaning will be quite changed; for should the New Zealander speak ofnative teak' the Australian would think not of a New Zealand but of an Australian tree. The confusion might be avoided were the word Maori' used instead of the wordnative', and indeed, instead of the long double `New Zealand'. See also 1933 Acland's note on indigenous. Usage is separated below into 1. general and 2. specific applications. 1.]

There is a change-over in manyDepartments from "Native" to "Maori" asoccasion demands. (1947,NZ Parliamentary Debates,CCLXVI/491)

Maori Purposes Bill... It is the usualyearly Bill with this difference that itprovides for the alteration of the word"Native" to "Maori" in all Statutes. (1947,NZ Parliamentary Debates,CCLXXIX/952)

Wherever the term "Native" appears in anyAct, regulation, rule.. that term shall..be hereafter read as the term "Maori." (1947,NZ Statutes,59/653 Sect. 2(2)) [NOTES: Maori Purposes Act, 1947]

GUTHRIE-SMITH [Hdg] The future of native avifauna. (1926,Tutira,203)

POLACK Native Tomahawk',Native spear' (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,2/31/2)

ASHWELL Native minister .... the native question. (1861,Letters & Journals,3/386)

(Acland Gloss.) Native.- Indigenous. Not as a rule used here in the Australian (and Kipling's) sense of `the native born'. N. used in combinations to make names of various plants and birds, e.g. n. broom, n.pigeon. ([1898 Morris Austral-English]) (Nov 11, 1933,Press, The,15)

ELDER We were presently surrounded by many native men, women, and children ... (Sep 6, 1934,Marsden's Lieutenants,59) [NOTES: 1814 Sep 6 Kendall in Elder Marsden's Lieutenants (1934) 59]

ELDER I went up to Ranghee Hoo (Rangihoua) to see if the woman was dead or not; a native boy went with me. (1934,Marsden's Lieutenants,107) [NOTES: 1815 Aug 13 John King in Elder Marsden's Lieutenants (1934) 107]

MARSDEN For this purpose we took two native guides and set off on our journey. ... We arrived at a native village just at dark, very wet, where we took up our lodgings for the night, ... (1820,Letters & Journals of Samuel Marsden,251,1932 ed.)

ELDER This week I am teaching two more native sawyers to saw timber. (1934,Marsden's Lieutenants,220,1934 ed.) [NOTES: 1819 July 1 William Hall in Elder Marsden's Lieutenants (1934)]

(a) The Governor avails himself of this occasion to appeal to the good feelings of the colonists generally in favour of their fellow-subjects of the native race, who require only instruction and good example to become equal to Europeans in moral, as they already are in physical attainments, ... (May 3, 1841,Governor Hobson's Proclamation) [NOTES: in 1949 Rutherford ed. Select Documents 11]

HEAPHY Turnips have for a length of time been grown in the native plantations, ... and the indigenousPolynesian vegetable, `Taro'. (1842,New Zealand (various authors/titles),30)

TAYLOR [patronising] It is surprising how the gospel enlarges the native mind so that the slave soon outstrips his master in knowledge ... (Apr 11, 1847,Journal,V/23)

SWAINSON `Aware of the advantages ... which the district possesses in an abundance of native labour, and deeming that the Society might do something to advance the improvement of Maori labour by taking notice of the deserving, and encouraging the most meritorious ... the Committee added to the list of prizes a premium of two sovereigns to the best and most trustworthy native servant; ... (1853,Auckland,139) [NOTES: 1850 Apr 13 Report of the Auckland Agricultural Society in 1853 Swainson Auckland 139]

ROCHFORT On going down to the beach, some Maories* came ashore in a canoe. They were about building a market-place to trade with the white man. [fn] Maorie, native name of the aborigines. (1853,Adventures of a Surveyor,14)

Probable Amount of Maori Contribution to Revenue. [heading] 39. In estimating the amount of native contribution to the Customs revenue, it should be remembered that, not only as consumers, but as producers, they swell the amount of its receipts. (Oct 13, 1858,Memorandum by Native Secretary) [NOTES: 1858 Oct 13 Memorandum by Native Secretary in 1949 Rutherford ed. Select Documents 105.39 X.]

'K' Here we stop for a few minutes to enable our native companion to be tangi'd over. (1885,Visit to Lake Rotoaira, A,4)

In the South Bay ... is the most historic spot in pakeha Kaikoura, the whaling station, alongside the little native village of Te Hiku-o-te-Waero ... (1926,Travel in NZ,(Vol II South Island) 23)

LEE [ironic?] New Zealand had Maori wars in which the Native Race, in its resistance to the encroachments of the white, alternated between blood-curdling ferocity and chivalry. (1934,Children of the Poor,121,1949 ed.)

MULGAN Men! Why, there are only two boys over seventeen.'Go on. What's that native forward? Twenty, I'll bet. They tell me he's married.' (1934,Spur of Morning,24)

HYDE People, white and native, lived in the landscape, though you didn't see them. ... It was Maori country ... [reference Northland] (1938,Godwits Fly, The,128,1970 ed.)

BEATTIE The whites would copy the native way of scraping flax for various purposes [c1840], and when their boots gave out would sometimes wear Maori `pararas' or sandals. (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,12)

HOWARD Mutton-birding is the only modern survival of native enterprise, the only phase of primitive economic development which has withstood the destructive competition ... introduced by the white man. (1940,Rakiura,210)

Tuberculosis, against which this Native people had not as yet developed the pakeha's immunity, was her [sc. district nurse] greatest worry. But the Maoris were good patients . (1948,Our Own Country,44) [NOTES: from Korero, AEWS magazine]

CAMPBELL The Pakeha was much too valuable an animal in those days to be killed and eaten; that game did not pay at all. Cannibal feasts did come off now and again on the sly, but the Pakeha was too dear a morsel, and moreover, was far too salt to be put into a Hangi (native oven) for epicurean Maories. (1881,Poenamo,2/2/61)

For the purpose of rendering any Nativeland or any land owned by Natives fit forsettlement, the Native Land SettlementBoard (formerly the Native Minister) maydecide to apply the provisions of section522 to that land. (1934,AJHR,G-11/32)

TRAMP ﻿That famous treaty [sc. of Waitangi] isas dead as the jumbuck that supplied theparchment for it. The native childrenrattle the old bones of the dead treatyoccasionally. It amuses them and does usno harm. (1891,Casual Ramblings,31)

n. [the Colony being NSW?]

Mr. John O'Neal, mate of the vessel and a native of the Colony, for some time defended Mr. Burnett against the attacks of several adversaries, with an empty musket. (1934,Marsden's Lieutenants,90) [NOTES: 1815 Aug 31 Burnett quoted in Elder Marsden's Lieutenants (1934) 90]

n. the Maori language

WILEY & MAUNSELL He has rapidly advanced in native, and can preach with some fluency. (1938,Robert Maunsell,76) [NOTES: 1842 Mar 31 in Wily and Maunsell Robert Maunsell]

TAYLOR Mr. Laurie dined with us. He is a B.A. of Cambridge and a very gentlemanly man ... He alluded to the complaint made by some of the writers on New Zealand that we taught the natives the Christian faith in native instead of English. (Jan 20, 1849,Journal,6/27)

n. a Maori [Native n and aj. remained in official use until 1947. (Cf R. Mason's note, 1953.) The term Native' inNative Minister', Native Department' etc. was dropped during the war in favour ofMaori'. I understand in deference to opinion of B.B.C. who found native `a term much disliked in India etc. & wished to avoid it in broadcasts. Native schools now Maori schools')]

MARKHAM New Zealand or the Northern Island, as there are three, is known to the Natives by the name of Eaheinomawe...When the Bar was cross ed Canoes or in the Native Mourie [Maori] Tongue, Walker [waka] Mouries, or Native Boats, boarded us, ... - (1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles),29,1963 ed.)

YATE The Pa, or native fortification, is a place in which the natives of single tribes ... when living near each other ... assemble in times of war, and secure themselves, their wives, their children, and their slaves, from the attacks of the enemy. (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),122)

BRUNNER I can trudge along ...with a pair of native sandals, called by the natives pairairai, made of the leaves of the flax, or what is more durable, the leaves of the ti, or flax tree. (1847,Great Journey,58)

Within the last few days great preparations have been making at Petoni for a native entertainment on rather an extensive scale, to be given by Epuni and the natives of his tribe to Rangiheata and his followers. (May 10, 1851,Lyttelton Times,6)

MORRIS Native, n. This word, originally applied, as elsewhere, to the aboriginal inhabitants of Australia, is now used exclusively to designate white people born in Australia. The members of the Australian Natives' Association' (A.N.A.), founded April 27, 1871, pride themselves on being Australian-born and not immigrants. Mr. Rudyard Kipling, in theTimes' of Nov. 1895, Published a poem called The Native-Born,' sc. born in the British Empire, but outside Great Britain. As applied to Plants, Animals, Names, etc., the word Nativebears its original sense, as inNative Cabbage,' Native Bear,'Native name for,' etc., though in the last case it is now considered more correct to say in Australia aboriginal name for,' and in New ZealandMaori name for.' (1898,Austral English,315)

GUTHRIE-SMITH ... Tutira was leased by forty native owners to T.K.Newton ... The block was held in common by these natives, ... (1926,Tutira,117)

Native Affairs¶

n. (historical)

The Hon. Mr. Mason (Minister of NativeAffairs) replied. (1946,NZ Parliamentary Debates,CCLXXIII/786)

When I first entered this House I saidthat the word "Native" should beabolished and the word "Maori" be usedinstead whenever it applied to the Maoripeople. Since then the fruits arebeginning to be seen because there usedto be a.. Native Affairs Committee..which is now called the Maori AffairsCommittee and I understand that the PrimeMinister, who is our Native Minister...Why not Maori Minister?... I think hewill eventually be called the Minister incharge of Maori Affairs. (1947,NZ Parliamentary Debates,CCLXXVI/269)

All references to the Native Minister inany Act, regulation.. shall be hereafterread as references to the Minister ofMaori Affairs. (1947,NZ Statutes,59/653 Sect. 2(3)) [NOTES: Maori Purposes Act 1947]

I gather that the administration ofNative affairs is not to be intrusted toMinisters, but to the Governor alone. (May 2, 1856,NZ Journal of Agriculture,1856-1858 / 49)

I want to know, since you gave it up who is at the head of the Native Reserve Department - ... Native Affairs. (May 23, 1859,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/459,1960 ed.) [NOTES: Domett]

Native Affairs Department¶

n. (historical)

The substance of that arrangement[founded on the departmental memorandumof May, 1856] was this: Ministers were toconsult the Native Affairs Department inthe ordinary way - that is, the adviseHis Excellency on all questions withoutexception, while His Excellency reservedto himself the absolute right of actingor not as he pleased. (Aug 10, 1860,NZ Parliamentary Debates,1858-1860 / 281)

The Native Affairs Department became the Maori Affairs Department, the Native Land Court the Maori Land Court, etc. (Dec 28, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),8)

Native Agent¶

n. (See also agent; Government agent; land agent)

COWAN Maclean's position as Native Agent on the East Coast was one peculiar responsibility in that era of turmoil in the Maori world ... (1940,Sir Donald Maclean,91)

BOYD The Liberal candidate in 1896 was A.L.D. Fraser, a Hastings land and native agent, ... (1984,City of the Plains,162)

A Native agent.. said there was a song composed by the defeated foe for ownership which told what they would do if opportunity arose. (Feb 5, 1924,Otago Witness,1)

native aniseed¶

n. [one ref to 'GINGIDIA MONTANA']

(1916,Catalogues of the Indigenous...) [NOTES: Dunedin Field Club (AND)]

(1917,Duncan & Davies' Catalogue) [NOTES: And)]

MOORE & IRWIN GINGIDIA MONTANA, native aniseed. A lush, tufted herb, reaching a height of half a metre, found from the middle North Island southwards ... (1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,108)

native ant¶

n.

McLINTOCK Ant, native .. .. poko, popokorua, upokorua .. ..Monomorium antarcticum (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

native ash¶

n.

Broadleaf, five-fingered Jack, (Panax arboreum) lacebark, matipo, red matipo, New Zealand coffee, titoki or native ash [fn Alecryon excelsum], ... jostle ... in the dense dry bush. (1900,Canterbury Old & New,184)

Native Assessor¶

n.

The characteristic feature [of theResident Magistrates Ordinance] is theinstitution of Native Assessors. (May 18, 1858,NZ Parliamentary Debates,1856-1858 / 444)

Native Assessorship¶

n.

The Native Assessorship is a mostvaluable and essential institution inthis country. (May 18, 1858,NZ Parliamentary Debates,1856-1858 / 445)

native aster¶

n.

HOOKER Aster, native. Celmisia , various sp. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),764)

native bee¶

n. an endemic wild bee

native bird¶

n.

The advantage to our native birds of compulsory protection has been amply demonstrated by results. (1899,TrNZI,31/10)

It is the opinion of the curator that native birds have considerably increased since he arrived on the [Little Barrier] island. (Nov 24, 1900,Egmont Star,19)

GUTHRIE-SMITH The real cause of diminution of native birds is easy to give. (1926,Tutira,205)

Surely it would be as easy to preserve what native birds we have, by their capture and removal, as to catch wild birds in far away England, and transport them fourteen thousand miles. (Nov 24, 1900,Egmont Star,19)

The Acts of 1880 protection of native birds and imported game is in force in Chathams. (Mar 1, 1906,Chudleigh Diary,431,1950 ed.)

SANSOM As for those, who despite our laws continue to kill native birds ..., as an old Orkney woman said `I dinna like them.' (1982,In the Grip of an Island,100)

NEAVE We were delighted with the background of native bush, and glad to ... listen to the lovely bird calls, which were strange to our ears, accustomed to ... absence of native birds in our district. (1980,Land of Munros, The,47)

MARSHALL (Kenneth's Friend) I could hear the native birds in the bush, and the waves on the beach. (1984,Day Hemingway Died, The,7)

Native bishop¶

n.

256 I hope the C.M.S. will persevere steadily on this point. We ought to give Native ChurchesNative Bishops. (1928,Grace Pioneer Missionary) [NOTES: 1877 July 19 T.S.Grace letter in Grace Pioneer Missionary (1928) 256]

native block¶

1 n. (Rural) a grazed area of land in indigenous tussock or other ground cover.

M H-B P Fine Wool 37 There are 33 blocks on the oversown country, ranging from 40 ha to 190 ha, three Maku blocks and five native blocks. (1982,Fine Wool)

native blowfly¶

n. [1850s in 1971 Hall-Jones Mr Surveyor Thomson 56 (Griffiths Collection)] (See also Maori blowfly)

Native blow-flies (Calliphora quadrimaculata) were very much more abundant in the country districts than they are now. Mr. Mieville, who settled in the Mataura district in 1854, in his contribution to Pioneer Recollections, collected by Mr. H. Beattie (second series), says, `The trouble of pioneers is the bluebottle-fly, which is to be met with only in new country, where its ravages are beyond belief.' (1922,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,4/275) [NOTES: (Bathgate, Otago)]

There's old timers we knew, and some who shot through A hard case, drag the chain, done a bunk, As busy as a blow fly, and bugalugs - from the boo-ai The rouseabout, as drunk as a skunk. (Dec 2004,NZ Memories,p18)

native bluebell¶

n.

A native bluebell.. is accompanied by interesting notes. (May 4, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,15)

Native boat¶

n. waka

MARKHAM [native Maori] Canoes, or in the native Mourie Tongue, Walker Mouries, or Nativeboats. (1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles))

Native boy¶

n.

SELWYN My native boys, ten in number, had now recovered from sea-sickness, and emerged in their newclothes to enjoy the sight of land. (1851,New Zealand (various authors/titles),Part V (Church in the Colonies XX) 97) [NOTES: 1848 Selwyn in 1851 NZ]

JENNINGS Started at 8.30 a.m., Poro, our native boy, going on before to fetch back one of the horses. (1880,Diary of an Expedition to the Table Land,1)

native broom¶

n.

LEVY ... shrubs common in the tussock zone: matagouri, native brooms, dwarf koromikos, monoao, sarmentose tutu, the grasslike spiky-leaved Spaniard, the harsh patotara, golden cottonwood, cushion-like pimeleas, and the low, matted, carpet-like growth of the scabweeds are characteristic of the low tussock country, ... Ibid. 72 The tussock is interspersed with shrubs, and of these the matagouri and native brooms are common. Ibid. 356 Native brooms - Carmichaelia spp . (1951,Grasslands of NZ,35,1970 ed.)

Many native broom species are on the decline because of land development, fire, animal browsing, ... (1987,Triennial Report Botany Division,60)

HOOKER Broom, native. Carmichaelia , various sp. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),764)

1/iii/40 Native Brooms. Carmichaellia crassicaulis, Hook. f. (1869,TrNZI) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

FEATON CARMICHAELIA (Brown.) The Carmichaelias, or native brooms. Ibid. [110?] CARMICHAELIA FLAGELLIFORMIS (Col) ... The `NATIVE BROOM'.- This species is well known by its long whip-like branches, ... (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,107)

Carmichaelia is perhaps the most characteristic of the many remarkable endemic genera ... represented from the North Cape to Foveaux Strait by numerous species ... but in all localities recognised by the settler as native broom and by the Maori as makaka. (1897,TrNZI,29/501)

The `wild Irishman' ... may be associated with the native brooms [fn Carmichaelia ] and several other almost leafless shrubs. (1900,Canterbury Old & New,179)

... although species of Carmichaelia (native broom) are unpalatable shrubs, they are often chewed ... (1938,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,20/233A)

EVANS The whole [Waikaka] valley and the ... ridges were covered [in 1876] with luxurious white tussocks (Poa caespitosa) diversified with a few snow grass tussocks (Danthonia raoulii), trees and shrubs comprising Maukoko, or native broom (Carmichaelia australia[?lis]), Koromiko (Veronica salicifo), daisy tree (Aleria rirgata [?virgata]), cottonwood (Cassinia fulvida), ... native thorns or matagouri and mingimingi (Coprosma propinqua). [check] (1962,Waikaka Saga,239)

Carmichaelia flagelliformis (1916,Dunedin Field Club Plant Catalogues) [NOTES: (And)]

Carmichaelia subulata (1914,TrNZI,46/) [NOTES: (And)]

native bush¶

n. indigenous forest [ca1950 still a popular term, though in technical and semitechnical Forest Service publications it has been replaced by the unpromising indigenous bush or forest (cf indigenous - rather than native timber, tree etc distinct from exotic).]

A tastefully-arranged lawn.. and a famous garden.. backed up by the grand old native bush complete the ideal of a rural home. (May 22, 1890,Otago Witness,00) [NOTES: Check page]

The farm has three main enterprises - a 500 cow dairy, a 30ha kiwifruit orchard and 65ha of productive forestry plantations, with another 100ha of native bush in steep gorges being fenced off. (May 27, 2004,Dominion Post,C7)

PYKE On the left side arose a succession of grassy bluffs surmounted by native `bush'. (1873,Wild Will Enderby,IV/iii/122,1889,1974 ed.)

Clearing piri-piri from edge of the native bush and planting tomatoes. The piri-piri is 7 ft. high round many trees with an average of three feet all about and thick as felted wool. (Nov 17, 1882,Chudleigh Diary,314,1950 ed.)

D'AVIGDOR Clearing piri-piri from edge of the native bush and planting tomatoes. The piri-piri is 7 ft. high round many trees with an average of three feet all about and thick as felted wool. (1888,Antipodean Notes,150)

DAVIDSON The native bush which covers a large portion of the [Dunedin] `town belt' is in itself a heritage to be highly prized, ... (1889,Stories of NZ Life,61)

... a wide bleak prospect opened out ... with random patches of native bush showing here and there ... (1889,Zealandia,1/6) [NOTES: (Graham)]

NEIL KORAMIKA (NATIVE VERONICA). ... It is found growing in almost every native bush. (1898,Family Herb Doctor,28)

HOCKEN Two or three hundred yards beyond begins an irregular fringe of native bush, broadleaf, veronica, fuchsia, pittosporum, and tangled supplejack; beyond these rise the lofty pines and other forest giants. (1898,Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand,79)

BELL To the artistic eye, the bush clearings ... may appear as a sore blemish on the face of the landscape. Thickly strewn with blackened logs and branches, ... these clearings stand out in ugly contrast with the virgin native bush. (1899,In the Shadow of the Bush,2)

KAYE The fragrance of the native bush (1900,Haromi,36)

WAITE The clean blue sky, the waving toi toi on the fringe of native bush, ... made an ineffaceable impression. (1919,New Zealanders at Gallipoli,9)

REISCHEK Perhaps, also, he will help to remind them how good, how strenuous life was `in the good old days,' when their Dominion was still half-savage, still unsettled after the toughest of colonial wars, and before the fire and axe of succeeding generations of peaceful settlers had robbed her of so much of her incomparable possession, the native bush. (1930,Yesterdays in Maoriland,7) [NOTES: H.E.L.Priday Preface]

HYDE Gradually he weaned them to trees and shrubs, and gave them long lectures about the duty of preserving their heritage of native bush - which they never saw, as it lay miles away over the hills. His favourite day in the year [32] was Arbor Day, ... (1938,Godwits Fly, The,31,1970 ed.)

CHERRILL ...a timber mill, right up in the native bush ... [53] Oh, that's just Native Bush. (1950,Story of a NZ Sheepfarm,43)

DEWAR Fern and moki and fuchsia, laced through with lawyer bramble, grew dense and hopeless at their feet. But beyond was the native bush [in Southland]. (1953,Chaslands,12)

HINTZ It is scrub-clad, with some lovely remnants of native bush. (1964,Trout at Taupo,36)

FRANCE Now the mountains marched beside them, and native bush swelled in the low valleys. (1961,Ice Cold River,43)

TURNER Now the mountains marched beside them, and native bush swelled in the low valleys. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,52)

ANDERSON It was held ... at Hood's Bush, a curious patch of native bush ... on the south side of the Whitecliffs bridge. (1972,Letter from James,143)

BELL If you follow the Waikato river, .../ There're waterfalls and native bush, breathtaking scenery;/ (1974,Ballads of a Racegoer,13)

NEAVE We were delighted with the background of native bush, and glad to ... listen to the lovely bird calls, which were strange to our ears, accustomed to ... absence of native birds in our district. (1980,Land of Munros, The,47)

MANTELL Native bush grew above them on the right, dark green, ... (1980,Murder and Chips,18)

DENNIS Thus plants which are the bane of farmers can be beneficial guardians of regenerating native bush. (1981,Paparoas Guide,23)

WHEELER George drove us up into the foothills, which open out into unexpectedly wide rolling tussocklands, with good stands of native bush in the gullies. (1982,Historic Sheep Stations NI,5)

KIDMAN There were many trees and bush around about and here and there a glimpse of woody-looking houses, stylish modern set-pieces for good placement amongst native bush. (1982,Mrs Dixon and Friend,131)

SHERWOOD She ... saw now why the early settlers had disliked the native bush, calling it gloomy ... (1985,Botanist at Bay,69)

McGILL The rail wound ... round the river, and presented a comprehensive picture of native bush. (1985,G'day Country,33)

FRAME At last we entered the Hauraki Gulf sailing slowly past the Bays with their unexpectedly colourful houses ... set against ... the darker green where stands of native bush remained. (1985,Envoy from Mirror City,160)

Chatham Island Warbler Gerygone albofrontata GRAY, 1844 ... The Chatham Island warbler has not adapted to human settlement and lives only in native bush. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,279)

native bush NZ woods or forests composed of indigenous trees and shrubs. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,500) [NOTES: nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 324]

Whoever burnt off the original native bush must have left them there, ... (Aug 29, 1987,Listener (New Zealand Listener),45) [NOTES: Davin]

The regenerating native bush ... has greatly diminished. (1988,Through the Looking Glass,154) [NOTES: Kirk]

SEWELL After surveying our Estates rode home with Mr Raven through the Native Bush - not so picturesque by half as the Wellington Woods, but striking. (1853,Journal,1/429,1980 ed.)

FRAME Yes, New Zealand trees. And there's native bush along the east of Gillespie Street, towards the mountains. (1988,Carpathians, The,23)

1 n. (Rural) forest composed entirely of native vegetation, with mixed species specific to locality [ not just manuka, ponga and ferns.]

LANDS & SURVEY The last name 'Bush-sickness' persisted long after it was known that the native bush had really nothing to do with the disease. (1975,Prosperity from Pumice Land,7)

BARKER .. great masses of native bush made dark purple shadows ... (1873,Station Amusements in NZ,112)

Fresh water stream flows through entire property. Areas of native bush retained. (Feb 1993,NZ Dairy Exporter,53)

The contour ranges from rolling to hilly with some steep scrub reverted sidlings merging into native bush. (Jun 15, 1994,NZ Farmer,44)

10ha land plus native bush, pony paddock. (Jul 9, 2000,First Choice for Real Estate,2 37)

Approx 170 ha in grass, 80 ha native bush, 50 ha scrub and pongas. (Feb 9, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,36)

.. near new sheep and cattle yards and loading race. Nice patch of native bush, good track access. (Mar 30, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,44)

native cabbage¶

n.

TAYLOR My party made an oven in which they place a large quantity of native cabbage which grows there [near Mangawhero] very plentifully. What a blessing did Cook confer on the country by thus sowing a little seed. (Nov 3, 1852,Journal,VIII/50)

WEKEY There is the native cabbage, a succulent plant, freely growing, and used by the Maories as a substitute for the last-named vegetable. (1862,Otago As It Is,45)

HOCKEN The natives ... caught a rat, cut some blubber from a stranded whale, and added a few pieces of a cuttlefish which had been left on the beach ...; these well mixed with a few potatoes, some wild native cabbage, and above all the optimum condimentum added, made a most sumptuous feast. (1898,Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand,54)

MORRIS Native Cabbage ... The Nasturtium palustre, De C., N.O. Cruciferae, is so called, but in spite of its name it is not endemic in Australia. In New Zealand, the name is sometimes applied to the Maori Cabbage. (1898,Austral English,315)

cabbage n.-native cabbage collective n. cabbage plants that have become wild in New Zealand; the Maori cabbage. (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,3)

native celery¶

n. aka Maori or wild celery, Apium prostratum

Here in New Zealand we also have a native celery, tutaekoau or Apium prostatum, a low creeping plant growing on beaches in gravel, rocks or mud. (Dec 24, 2004,Dominion Post,C9)

[Cook] put the native celery and scurvy grass on the menu for officers only. (Jun 2004,North & South,32)

I'll be looking out for native celery when I next go walking along the coast. This creeping plant, tutae koau (Apium prostratum) is found throughout the country, accoding to Andrew Crowe, the author of A Field Guide to the Native Edible Plants of New Zealand... (May 29, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),41)

Native chapel¶

n.

SELWYN On the next hill to the eastward a wooden chapel in now rising, intended chiefly for native services; ... Beyond the native chapel ... stands the ruined chapel of St. Stephen, built four years ago of unsound stone ... (Jun 23, 1848,New Zealand (Selwyn),Part V (Church in the Colonies XX) 7,1851 ed.)

Native chewing gum¶

n.

McGILL native chewing gum puha stalk used for chewing, bitter at first, good mixed with resin from tarata or lemonwood or the leaves of the rangiora. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,75)

Native church¶

n.

I hope the C.M.S. will persevere steadily on this point. We ought to give Native Churches Native Bishops. (1928,Grace Pioneer Missionary,256) [NOTES: >1877 July 19 T.S.Grace letter in Grace Pioneer Missionary (1928)]

Native Commissioner¶

n.

THATCHER When out troops get a slant these same wretches to slay, A Native Commissioner steps in the way. (1869,Maori Captives in Local Songs,14)

COWAN The next responsibility devolving on the young Native Commissioner was ... settling the ... dispute between pakeha settlers and Maori land-owners at Wanganui. (1940,Sir Donald Maclean,34)

Native Contingent¶

n. (historical) a Maori force fighting with the British in the NZ Wars

With such a financial inducement it was left to the main Kawanatanga fighting tribes or Native Contingents (NC) - Te Arawa, Ngati Porou, Ngati Kahungunu and lower Whanganui - to launch their own independent expeditions... (Oct 4, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),29)

native country¶

1 n. (Rural) land that has native grass, shrubs or bush growing on it.

ANDERSON A large area of native country taken over by the Crown was released for ballot. (1962,Life's Roundabout, A,39)

We aim .. stock on the native hill country .. requiring less time to spot and snowrake. (May 19, 1993,NZ Farmer,6 15)

LOUGHNAN native or native country: pasture which has never been under the plough. Even if it has been oversown with exotics amongst the indigenous grasses it is till termed native. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,55)

Hilly native country is an ideal zone for production of fine and super fine merino wools. ..the bulk of the hilly native country is not stocked all summer. (Sep 1985,NZ Journal of Agriculture,32)

Glenaray farms approximately 4,000 ha of oversown and top-dressed hill country and 60,000 ha of semi-developed native high country. (Jul 14, 2001,Dominion,52)

native crow¶

n.

Native crows - the Maori's kokako - which were very plentiful a few years ago, are being driven further back. (Aug 3, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,17)

Native crows - the Maori's kokako - which were very plentiful a few years ago, are being driven further back. (Aug 3, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,17)

native crow,¶

2 n. (Environment) (See kokako)

TAYLOR The natives have a saying that the huia stole the plumage of the kokako, the native crow, and gave its own tail instead. (Mar 6, 1849,Journal,6/37)

McLINTOCK Native Crow - kokako, Callaeas cinerea (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

.. sometimes incorrectly called the native crow (1879,Heinemann Dictionary of NZ Quotations,113)

native daphne¶

n. (See taranga)

Native Department¶

n. (historical)

The mode in which the Native Departmenthas been administered in the past hasnot been such as to inculcate habits ofindustry, and care, and exactitude in itsofficers. (1909,NZ Parliamentary Debates,CXLVIII/1334)

Hence the need of a permanent NativeDepartment, with the Governor at itshead, not responsible to the Assembly,but bound to supply it with everyinformation sought for. (Jul 5, 1858,NZ Parliamentary Debates,1856-1858 / 581)

Changes in the personnel of the NativeDepartment have been much more rapid thanMinisterial changes have hotherto provedin New Zealand. (1858,AJHR,E-No. 1/11)

He [the Governor] has no knowledge oftheir language, and hence is entirely inthe hands of the officials of the NativeDepartment. (Aug 3, 1860,NZ Parliamentary Debates,1858-1860 / 190)

The activities of the Native Department have reached the stage when the pakeha, who had been strenuous in his advocacy of the proper utilisation of native lands, was due to look for weaknesses ... (Sep 17, 1932,Na To Hoa Aroha,3/20,1988 ed.) [NOTES: 1932 Sep 17 in 1988 Na To Hoa Aroha (Ngata-Buck Correspondence) 3/20 (Ngata)]

RUTHERFORD We talk of taihoa' in connection with our Native Department. The real home of unadulteratedtaihoa' is Italy ... (1912,Impressions of a NZ Pastoralist on Tour,162)

The activities of the Native Department have reached the stage when the pakeha, who had been strenuous in his advocacy of the proper utilisation of native lands, was due to look forweaknesses ... Ibid. 3/204 (Buck) I am pleased to hear that a change for the better has taken in the head office of the Native Department. The bureaucratic rule by civil servants who have no sympathy or knowledge of the native people that the department is supposed to administer ... (Sep 17, 1932,Na To Hoa Aroha,3/20,1988 ed.) [NOTES: Ngata]

This [Ruatoki] valley is Native land and is being farmed by the Maori owners with the assistance and supervision of the Native Department. It is only one of the many Native-land-development schemes scattered throughout New Zealand, ... (1948,Our Own Country,49)

Native difficulty¶

n. = Maori problem

MANING Talk to me of the `native difficulty' - pooh! I think it was in 1822 that an old friend of mine bought, at Kawhia, a woman who was just [212] going to be baked. (1863,Old New Zealand,(xiv) 211)

WILLIAM MORGAN Were this native difficulty settled, the country would go ahead with amazing stride, .... (May 27, 1863,Journal,41,1963 ed.)

VOGEL (ed.) native difficulty, native question (1875,Official Handbook of NZ,65)

My own impression with regard to the Native difficulties in the past is that there has scarcely been a difficulty - there has scarcely been a single war in this colony - in which the Europeans have not been more to blame than the Natives. (Aug 16, 1881,NZ Parliamentary Debates,39/550) [NOTES: John Ballance]

LAMBERT When Dr. F.F. Ormond purchased the Orangitirohia block on the north side of the river, not allthe Natives had been satisfactorily dealt with, and a `Native difficulty' of the first grade soon arose. (1936,Pioneering Reminiscences of Old Wairoa,20)

native dock¶

n. = Maori dock

native dog¶

n.

McNAB Q. Are their any quadrupeds in New Zealand, wild or tame? A. None but the native dog that resembles that of New Holland, tho' in New Zealand it is capable of being domesticated and they are trained to catch pigs. (1908,Historical Records,1/536) [NOTES: 1821 May Evidence of Ensign McCrae before Commissioner Bigge in 1908 McNab Historical Records 1/536]

TAYLOR ... the native dogs are great obstacles to their [sc. poultry] increase for as their owners only feed them on vegetables it is natural that they will ... make a banquet on a fowl. (May 10, 1839,Journal,2/131)

HAAST The old native dog (kuri) seems to be extinct. (1861,Report on Topographical Exploration of Nelson,135)

HAY Pigeons, nestors, parrots, rail, kiwi, swamp-fowl, water-fowl, owls, parson-birds, all these and more were eaten; while the native dogs and rats were held to be great dainties. (1882,Brighter Britain,2/151)

TREGEAR Crozet described native dogs as looking like domesticated foxes, ... (1904,Maori Race, The,167)

BEST The native dog, now extinct, is said to have been introduced by old-time Polynesian voyagers from the isles of Polynesia. It was sometimes slain for food. The native rat was quite an important article of food. (1925,Tuhoe: The Children of the Mist,11)

DIEFFENBACH ... I placed it [sc. soft whalebone] on the roof of a native house; but on the following morning I had the mortification to find that the rats and native dogs ... had eaten all the softer parts ... Ibid. 1/362 [The] native rat still lingers here and there [in the central North Island], although it has disappeared on the coast; the native dog has become a mongrel. (1843,Travels in NZ,1/50)

And yet, strange to say, the numerous half-starved native dogs never think of destroying them. (1841,Establishment of New Plymouth Settlement) [NOTES: 1841 Establishment of New Plymouth Colony in 1940 Establishment of New Plymouth 76]

THOMSON What are called native dogs by the Middle Island shepherds are English animals, free, not wild. That the true native dog was introduced into New Zealand is proved by traditions, by the Maori term for dog being a true Polynesian word. (1859,Story of New Zealand, The,1/22)

S. PERCY SMITH At 2 p.m. we got into a pretty little clearing, where our dogs were driven in by some native dogs. It being such an unusual thing for native dogs to show so much pluck, we imagined there might be some Hauhaus about, so we left the camp. (Feb 11, 1867,Taranaki Journal) [NOTES: >1867 Feb 11 S. Percy Smith Taranaki Journal [=?Maori dog, i.e. a dog belonging to a Maori] in 1922 Cowan NZ Wars 2/533]

BEATTIE It [Central Otago] was a silent land, voiceless save for ... the long-drawn, eerie howl of a wild native dog. (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,118)

native duck¶

n. -

There are eleven species of Native Ducks belonging to nine genera, all found elsewhere, except two--the little Flightless Duck of the Auckland Islands (genus Nesonetta) and the Blue Mountain Duck (Hymenolaemus). Among the most interesting of the non-endemic forms, are the Paradise Duck or Sheldrake (Casarca variegata), the Brown Duck (Anas chlorotis), the Shoveller or Spoonbill duck (Rhynchaspis variegata), and the Scaup or Black Teal (Fuligula Novae-Zealandiae). (1889,Catalogue NZ Exhibition,117) [NOTES: [Morris]]

Native fashion¶

n.

LADY CAMPBELL `That's native fashion; the Maoris know how to live, bless 'em!' (1864,Martin Tobin,1/102)

SUTHERLAND When clad in a shoulder mat, Native fashion, or when stripped to the waist with the haft of a tomahawk in his flax-cord belt, which supported his kilt-like piupiu ... (1941,Numismatic History of NZ,37)

native flax¶

n.

Native flax. (1785,Cook's Third Voyage)

CAPT. RAVEN The flax grows here [in Dusky Sound] in great abundance, from which our people made fishing-lines and kellick-ropes. (Nov 19, 1793,Letter) [NOTES: 1793 Nov. 19 Capt. Raven to Lieut-Govenor King in 1908 McNab Historical Records 1/179]

SAVAGE The dress of the natives consists in a mat - finely woven of the native flax, and its glossy appearance, with a fringe all round, renders it by no means an inelegant sort of mantle. Ibid. 56 Small baskets made of the green native flax. (1807,Some Account of NZ,50)

New Zealand must be always considered as the great emporium of the South Seas, from its local situation, its safe harbours, its navigable rivers, its fine timber for ship building, its rosin, native flax, etc., etc., specimens of which I intend sending to the Society by this conveyance. (Sep 22, 1814,Letters & Journals of Samuel Marsden,133,1932 ed.)

(And) (Jan 1856,Edinburgh New Philosophical Journal) [NOTES: Tancred Notes on the Natural History of ... Canterbury]

MORRIS Flax, Native, n. The European flax is Linum usitatissimum, N.O. Linea. There is a species in Australia, Linum marginale, Cunn., N.O. Linacea, called Native Flax, In New Zealand, the Phormium is called Native Flax. See next word [Flax, New Zealand]. (1898,Austral English,147)

BOYD (And) Phormium tenax (1900,Our Stolen Summer)

(And) Phormium tenax (1921,NZ Journal of Science & Technology)

(And) Phormium tenax (1923,NZ Journal of Science & Technology)

A.BATHGATE ... we passed through an area where grew the most luxuriant native flax I have ever seen. (1925,Random Recollections,19)

native flax n 2 : NEW ZEALAND FLAX (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,1506)

GRUNDY Our back yard rose steeply from the house to the fence line, where native flax had been planted as a wind break. (1968,Who'd Marry a Doctor?,30)

In all, New Zealand has over 15 800 ha of self-sown native flax, ... (1974,NZ Agriculture,153)

ASKEW The kits are made of native flax. They have two handles or loops to lift them by. They are the same in shape as those used by the carpenters, and some are as well made. (1857,Voyage to Australia & NZ,347)

NEAVE The [Otematata homestead] building [in 1858] consisted of the usual cob and clay, ... and thatched with cutty grass tied on with native flax which had been boiled to make it tough. (1980,Land of Munros, The,65) [NOTES: 1917 James Strachan Experiences (Hocken L.) in 1980 Neave The Land of Munros 65]

native flax n. plant yielding fibre used by aborigines for making fishing nets. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),621)

native flax n. plant yielding fibre used by abos. for making fishing nets. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),14)

native forest¶

n. [[NB: never native woods]]

POLACK (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/347)

The southern portion of the county was originally covered with native forest, ... (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,274)

The Island is much as it was but Wharekauri [his station] is returning to its native forest. (Jan 24, 1915,Chudleigh Diary,414,1950 ed.)

COWAN Here and there along the rim of the valley were patches of native forest. (1922,NZ Wars, The,1/270)

SOLJAK These exotic forest resources [insignis pine, Douglas fir, etc.] are being expanded to ... facilitate preservation of the native forests, which the early settlers wastefully reduced ... (1946,New Zealand (various authors/titles),11)

HAWES ...suddenly.. he could see forest. Native, uncut. You can tell real native forest, it sort of sticks out like pop-up books, as though it's in 3D - or 4D - because it has another dimension from the flatness of other bush. (2000,Dream of Nikau Jam, The,168)

native forget-me-not.¶

n. (Environment) Myosotis spathulata

RICHARDS Myosotis ... spathulata ... A perennial forget-me-not, shaggy all over. ... [41] Native Forget-me-not. (1952,Chatham Islands,40)

native frog¶

n. Leiopelma Archeyi

According to information supplied ... the native frog is confined to the upper slopes of Mount Moehau, near the north end of the Hauraki Peninsula, and lives in the moss there so abundant.... A second species of New Zealand native frog was recently discovered on Stephen Island (see ...[TrNZI 1919 51/447-449]). (Jan 1921,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,3/308) [NOTES: (Morgan)]

McLINTOCK Native Frog - peketua, pepeke, Leiopelma (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-12)

MCALLISTER Halfway up, [we] found our first native frog, Leiopelma Archeyi - a timid brown and green creature less than 2 inches long. (1976,Old Taranaki,183) [NOTES: SIR GILBERT ARCHEY [1890-1974] was Director Auckland Institute & Museum to 1964]

native grass¶

n. [often in plural] (See cf. English grass(es))

YATE The native grasses flourish throughout the year ... All English grasses flourish well; but the white clover never seeds; ... (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),75)

POWER The only plan will be to lease sheep and cattle runs, at a cheap rate for a long term of years, on much the same system as in New South Wales with the squatters; with this difference, that the rate ought to be even cheaper in this country, as there are scarcely any native grasses, and the whole face of the country is fern and swamp, which is improved each year by the introduction of stock, - ... (1849,Sketches in NZ,113)

EARP A few words on the native grasses will not be out of place.The grasses of the Wairarapa ... are very numerous, and if cultivated, would be fully equal to English grasses: ... There is abundance of native rye-grass, and the sheep are very fond of a species of catch-grass ... ` (1853,New Zealand (various authors/titles),125) [NOTES: 1853 Allom letter in 1853 Earp NZ]

MACKIE In his paddocks he has several of the english grasses, they are found to be very advantageous here, being hardier than the native grasses, they produce more herbage through the winter. (May 2, 1853,Traveller under Concern,104,1973 ed.)

BUTLER I may as well here correct an error, which I had been under ... - native grass cannot be mown. (1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,iv/47) [NOTES: 1860 Feb 13 in 1863 Butler First Year]

Native grass is a good as oates and the open air in this climate keeps them [sc. horses] as harde as nails. (Nov 1, 1865,Chudleigh Diary,203,1950 ed.)

Mr. Holmes' sheep are running on native grass and the above increase has been obtained at one lambing. (1914,History of North Otago,177,1978 ed.) [NOTES: 1865 Dec 1 in 1914 History of North Otago (1978)]

BARKER Nothing seems [25] so wonderful to me as the utter treelessness of the vast Canterbury plains; occasionally you pass a few Ti-ti palms (ordinarily called cabbage-trees), or a large prickly bush which goes by the name of `wild Irishman,' but for miles and miles you see nothing but ... undulating downs of yellow tussocks, the tall native grass. (1865,Station Life in NZ,24)

To facilitate the collection of such information, they prepared a printed list of such native grasses as appeared to them most valuable (33 in number), ... Ibid. 298 Several of the native-grasses, as Microloena stipoides, Danthonia semi-annularis, Agrostis oemula, etc., maintain their ground against, and unite with, several of the introduced kinds in the formation of natural pasture in many places in this province. (1872,TrNZI,4/292) [NOTES: Report on Grasses]

BLAIR In the olden times it was an accepted theory in Otago, that ... the milk of cows fed on native grass would not make butter; ... (1884,Industries of NZ,59)

In the Middle Island a large area is covered with native grasses. (1892,NZ Official Handbook,1)

The extent of land in sown grasses was, in November, 1899, no less than 2,320,505 acres, while 2,042,789 acres were in tussock or native grass. (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,11)

Then on to see J.J.Fougere where I got a sod of buffalo grass and another sod of native grass ... (Apr 17, 1909,Chudleigh Diary,447,1950 ed.)

MACDONALD In some districts the seeds of native grasses, such as danthonias, would be more suitable for sowing; ... (1920,Australian & NZ Sheep Farming,122)

PERRY Nearly all the ordinary commercial flocks in New Zealand started from the Merino, but change of pasture from Native to English grasses ... has driven the Merino back to the high country. (1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,50)

LEE In those days the rolling hill-tops were still native grass and virgin plume tussock, good natural pasturage long since ploughed under and replaced with imported grasses. (1934,Children of the Poor,28,1949 ed.)

In the light of these conditions, and bearing in mind that native grasses are the dominant crop on uncultivated areas, the dependence of New Zealand on a pasture economy can be readily understood. (1936,Agricultural Organization in NZ,20)

AYSON All the country was very rough, with scrub, fern and tutu mixed with native grass, especially long green almond grass, which made splendid cattle feed. (1937,Thomas,101)

HYDE But the native grass stands back,/ Uncouth and alone. (1939,Selected Poems,85,1984 ed.) [NOTES: c1938-1939]

BEATTIE From this onward [in Central Otago c1860] two native grasses, known to the early stockmen as barley grass and oat grass respectively from a chance resemblance to those two cereals, were predominant ... (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,119)

The half-bred, three-quarter bred, and Romney sheep are more likely to overgraze areas of native grasses ... (1941,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,22/22A)

LEVY The early settlers of a century ago introduced to New Zealand various `English' grasses and clovers to supplement and later to replace the native grasses on the average-to-superior soil types. (1951,Grasslands of NZ,166,1970 ed.)

41 The floor and gently sloping sides were verdant with English and native grasses from the broad strath at our feet right up to where the cleared country narrowed and ran out in the higher ground of the bush range at the head. (1953,Golden Bush, The,SUTHERLAND,1963 ed.)

WHEELER Unless you walk over this country [Central Otago] you'll miss the native grasses, like danthonia and the blue tussock. To a Merino, one mouthful of this hard feed [13] is worth 10 of soft greenfeed. (1982,Historic Sheep Stations NI,12)

BOYD The Maori ran pigs in the swamp and grazed horses, sheep and cattle on the few rough patches of native grass on the side of the old track from Te Awa O Te Atua to Paki Paki and on the margins of the two creeks. (1984,City of the Plains,4)

MORRIS [A.=Aust.; T.=Tasmania] -->[Only species marked N.Z. selected from the Morris entry and given below: A. = Aust.; T. = Tasmania.] -->Mr John Buchanan ... has prepared ... a `Manual of the Indigenous Grasses of New Zealand', which enumerates eighty species, many of them unnamed in English, and many of them common also to Australia and Tasmania. ...3 (1898,Austral English,167) [NOTES: Morris's list is incorporated into grass]

1 n. (Rural) indigenous grass species, principally danthonia and tussocks.

BARKER Tussocks, the tall native grass, has the colour and appearance of hay. (1869,Station Life in NZ,25) [NOTES: Station Life in NZ (1874)]

The pakihi seems to need further capital fertiliser after the fourth year, otherwise it starts reverting to yorkshire fog, lotus, native grass and fine-stemmed pakihi rushes. (Mar 1987,NZ Dairy Exporter,26)

WILLIAMS And the carrying capacity of all the native grass ... (1889,Colonial Couplets,2)

In general hill country carrying native grasses is safe, but soem hill paddocks do produce the disease and these should be avoided. (Mar 15, 1943,NZ Journal of Agriculture,146)

The programme of development is for around 100 to 150 acres of native grass and more predominantly manuka scrub ... (Nov 1963,NZ Farmer,16)

native guano¶

n.

NORRIS Unfortunately, I cannot say whether the author of the following advertisement [in the 1880s] was successful in his enterprise: `New Patent Manure Native Guano Made from nightsoil, is a most valuable manure and is guaranteed to contain more than 42 per cent of phosphates of lime ... [Pounds]5.10.0. per ton net. ' (1964,Settlers in Depression,185)

native harebell¶

n.

STEVENSON Everywhere a graceful native harebell[fn. Wahlenbergia gracilis] shows itsblue or white flowers, and occasionally apretty white orchid [fn. Thelymitralongifolia] is to be met with, or a tuftof the grassy-leaved small-flowerednative iris [fn. Libertia ixioides]. (1900,Canterbury Old & New,183)

Native Interpreter¶

n. [see interpreter; licensed interpreter]

[Advt]. Parata & Co... Land & Estate Agents, Native Interpreters, Native Agents, Insurance & Financial Agents. (Jan 6, 1912,NZ Free Lance,10)

native iris¶

n.

DENDY Liberta ixioides (1900,Canterbury Old & New)

WILSON Libertia ixioides MIKOIKOI ... Native iris ... Tuukaauki (1982,Stewart Island Plants,296)

STEVENSON Everywhere a graceful native harebell[fn. Wahlenbergia gracilis] shows itsblue or white flowers, and occasionally apretty white orchid [fn. Thelymitralongifolia] is to be met with, or a tuftof the grassy-leaved small-flowerednative iris [fn. Libertia ixioides]. (1900,Canterbury Old & New,183)

native ivy¶

n. Senecio mikanoides. =African, =German ivy.

5/58 Just below the Nile Street Bridge [Nelson] (over the Marton River) there a steep bank covered with the so-called `native ivy' (Senecio mikanoides).... (1922,NZ Journal of Science & Technology) [NOTES: Grimmett]

STRONACH There was a lot of native ivy growing in them and it looked well, above the lake - but I found it not very dependable as an aid to rock climbing. (1953,Musterer on Molesworth,28)

Beneath willows.. near Nile Street, Nelson, there is a mass of the plant popularly known as native ivy. (Jun 8, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,15)

Native King¶

n. (historical) = Maori King

Everything points to a satisfactory settlement of the native question when the meeting of Sir George Grey and the native King takes place. (Apr 26, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,5)

Native land¶

n. [often in plural]

Of the Native lands in this district, a very considerable portion has been leased to Europeans, but there still remains in the hands of the Maoris a valuable estate, ... (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,11)

This [Ruatoki] valley is Native land and is being farmed by the Maori owners with the assistance and supervision of the Native Department. It is only one of the many Native-land-development schemes scattered throughout New Zealand, ... (1948,Our Own Country,49) [NOTES: from Korero, AEWS magazine]

The Government has it in its power to perpetrate the grossest favouritism by allowing one man to acquire native lands, while it prevents another. (Apr 19, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,12)

FINLAYSON When he left school he got a job in the Native Lands Department - a swanky white- collar job like the Pakehas admire. (1938,Brown Man's Burden,18)

Take the case of the New Zealand Native Land Settlement Company. (Aug 27, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,8)

For the purpose of rendering any Nativeland or any land owned by Natives fit forsettlement, the Native Land SettlementBoard (formerly the Native Minister) maydecide to apply the provisions of section522 to that land. (1934,AJHR,G-11/32)

n. (Rural) land owned by Maori.

WILSON There were two classes of offenders - those who leased land from the natives and paid them rent, and those who allowed their sheep and cattle to graze on native land and refused to pay rent for such grazing. (1976,History of Hawke's Bay,212)

[union platform] That native lands which benefit from the expenditure of special and general rates shall be placed upon the same footing as European lands so situated. (Mar 9, 1907,Farmers' Union Advocate,4)

With the idea of giving information to those requiring land, there will be published in this column full particulars of all Crown, public, and native lands thrown open for settlement. (Aug 13, 1908,Weekly News,47)

He exhibited a map showing the large tracts of native lands that were locked up in the Kawhia County. (Jun 3, 1909,Weekly News,21)

.. signs of a modest prosperity are forthcoming in the much-improved rate collection on European and native lands alike. (May 3, 1945,NZ Farmer,6)

Native Land Court¶

n.

... an able an popular man, well known in the Native Land Courts ... (1895,TrNZI,27/598)

The Native Land Courts, in the eyes of the present generation of colonists, are chiefly interesting as the means of investigating Maori titles to land, and as the agency for peacefully transferring, by consent of the Maori proprietors, these lands to European owners. (1876,TrNZI,8/422) [NOTES: J.C. Firth]

SUTHERLAND A debt of this nature contracted some twelve generations ago was recently recognized by the Native land court. (1941,Numismatic History of NZ,14)

The Native Land Court of New Zealand (hereinafter called the court) shall be a Court of Record for the investigation of the titles of persons to Native lands and to hereditaments of which the Native owner shall have died intestate and for the other purposes hereinafter set forth. (1865,NZ Statutes,29 Vict. 71/264)

The Native Land Court of New Zealand (hereinafter called "the Court) shall be a Court of Record for the investigation of the titles of persons to Native land according to Native customs and usage, and for the other purposes hereinafter set forth. (1873,NZ Statutes,37 Vict. 56/239)

A judge of the Native Land Court may suspend an interpreter. (1909,NZ Statutes,9 Edw. VII 15/256)

There shall continue to be a Court of record called as heretofore the Maori Land Court. (1931,NZ Statutes,22 Geo.V. 31/166)

The cumbersome machinery of the Native Land Court had to be brought to bear on the several blocks... the Natives being fleeced by the lawyers, interpreters, Pakeha-Maoris, et hoc genus omne. on the one hand, and by the publicans on the other. (Jan 23, 1890,Otago Witness,7)

Any European is considered more likely to do justice in the Native Land Court than a native expert, however learned in the lore of his race. (Jun 25, 1904,NZ Observer,23)

We cannot believe that either the Native Land Court or the Native Minister, any Native Minister, would not be particularly careful before approving an application. (Jan 11, 1913,NZ Observer,3)

Maori freehold land is essentially land which the Native (or since 1945 Maori) Land Court has converted from customary Maori tenure to English freehold tenure and has not been alienated by its Maori possessors. There are a good many specialised terms in this field such as ahiwhenua trust and putea trust. (Jan 1999,NZWords,2)

The practice of the Native Lands Court lately is to endorse on the back of the memorial of ownership the names of all the persons having an interest in the block. (Apr 5, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,12)

English Law Courts are.. pantomimes in briskness compared with a Native Lands Court. (Sep 3, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,21)

A peculiar position was mentioned at a sitting of the Native Land Court at Greymouth. (Feb 5, 1924,Otago Witness,1)

Saw Rolleston who is holding a Native Land Court [at Christchurch]. (Apr 22, 1868,Chudleigh Diary,220,1950 ed.)

Native land question¶

n.

RUTHERFORD The manner in which he has handled the Native Land Question on behalf of the Maoris has beenadmirable. (1912,Impressions of a NZ Pastoralist on Tour,162)

native land snail¶

n. (Environment) a land snail, Powelliphanta traversi otaki

Habitat of the native land snail (Powelliphanta traversi otaki) has been protected in the new Catalonia subdivision in Kapiti. (Nov 2006,Footnotes,26 / 11)

Native Lands Act¶

n.

In 1862 a Native Lands Act was passed. (May 21, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,28)

Native Lands Department¶

n. (historical)

Stealing all round. That seems to havebeen the motto of the Native LandsDepartment. (Oct 16, 1875,Otago Witness,14)

FINLAYSON (1938,Brown Man's Burden,78)

Native Lands Purchase Commissioner¶

n.

Mr. Williams, Native Lands Purchase Commissioner, arrived at Parihaka. (Mar 29, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,18)

native lark¶

n. (See pihoihoi)

STUDHOLME Native Lark, dipping and rising. (1940,Te Waimate,235,1954 ed.)

BEATTIE `Swampies' (swamp hens) and paradise and grey ducks were abundant in the waterlogged valley, while the native lark seemed ubiquitous. (1947,Pioneer Recollections,5,1956 ed.)

HAY The Pihoi (Anthus N.Z ) is the so-called native `lark.' It is a ground pipit, and may often be seen fluttering and chirping about a bush road. (1882,Brighter Britain,2/224)

MANNERING Stilts were common on the river - blackbill gulls, black-backed gulls, shags, dotterel, native larks (pipits). (1943,Eighty Years,22) [NOTES: [In Canterbury in the 1870's]]

McLINTOCK The New Zealand pipit, sometimes inaccurately called ground lark or native lark, is a local race (Anthus novaeseelandiae ) of a widely distributed species ... (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,2/776)

Pipit Anthus novaeseelandiae (GMELIN, 1789) ... New Zealand Pipit A.n. novaeseelandiae (GMELIN, 1789). Auckland Islands Pipit A.n. aucklandicus GRAY, 1862. Antipodes Pipit A.n. steindachneri REISCHEK, 1889. ... OTHER NAMES: Pihoihoi, groundlark, native lark. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,270)

The eggs of the native lark.. are so marked as to be well concealed in the tussock and fern where they are laid. (Dec 11, 1890,Otago Witness,41)

The native lark is a pipit. (Mar 18, 1924,Otago Witness,70)

native laurel¶

n. (mainly NI) Laurelia novae-zelandiae, =pukatea.

n. Griselinia littoralis (unless the ref. here is to karaka???), =broadleaf. [(?early Otago occas.)]

PYKE The native laurel (the broadleaf of the colonists) ... (1874,George Washington Pratt,42)

native lease¶

1 n. (Rural) land owned by Maori and leased for farming.

WESTMACOTT He has some 6,900 acres of native lease, and only needed the capital to bring it all into profit. (1977,After-Breakfast Cigar, The,134)

native lilac¶

n. Quintinia serrata, =tawhewheo, =kumarahou.

FEATON QUINTINIA SERRATA ( A.Cunn .) ... The `NATIVE LILAC'.- The typical form of this tree is confined to the kauri district, about Auckland, where it varies from a shrub with lilac-coloured flowers, to a tree forty feet high ... (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,131)

n. =karaka [unlikely].

[Native name] Karaka .. [Settlers' name] Native lilac .. [Family] Saxifrageae (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,122) [NOTES: 1886 T.Kirk in 1902 Settler's Handbook of NZ]

native logging¶

n. logging of native timber

We have stopped native logging six years earlier than was ever intended. (Sep 18, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),22)

Native magistrate¶

n.

There was unveiled.. a monument in memory of Reihana Kiriwi, who was for many years native magistrate in this district. (Apr 16, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,8)

He was a native magistrate. (Nov 5, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,22)

native mahogany¶

n. kohekohe

Native mahogany (kohekohe) trees stand proudly on the hillsides, lucky survivors of a mishap when an early traction engine fell into the sea when being moved to another site. This brought an end to the New Zealand Mahogany Company, which was based in the harbour. (Sep 20, 2005,Dominion Post,A9)

Native mat¶

n. (See also Maori mat,mat)

W.H.WILLIAMS On their landing, many of them were stripped and furnished with native mats. Ibid.1832 Jan 13 H. Williams Early Journals 217 Some few of the leading men had a mantle of scarlet cloth trimmed with dogs' hair, other had splendid native mats: ... (Jan 7, 1827,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,36,1961 ed.)

Native Minister¶

n. [A real doozy this one, as the Yanks say. Lots of confusion, popular use masquerading as official and confused official use; am working my way through but have to go back to Turnbull where a helpful young lady produced as I was leaving the NZ Almanacks which seem to be the ONLY source of official titles. Will chase them up further. People in Hansard use very loose terminology and there is no official listing of Ministers in Hansard. The following is my best effort from the Wellington Almanack (and others): 1822-1850 No record. 1851 Commissioner for acquiring the Cession of Lands from the Natives: - Donald McLean. 1851 Native Secretary H. Tacy Kemp GBP200 per annum [in addition to above]. 1852 Native Secretary [from Estimates]. 1853 Native Secretary Native Secretary's Department [from Estimates]. 1855 Native Secretary's Department [from Estimates]. 1857 Native Secretary - D. McLean. 1858 AJHR E-No.1/17 Donald McLean, Native Secretary, writes from Native Secretary's Office, 28 June 1858. 1860 Native Secretary's Department. 1861 Minister for Native Affairs - Honourable C.W. Richmond Native Secretary's Office. 1862 Minister for Native Affairs - F.D. Bell (Acting) Native Secretary's Department OR Native Department. 1863 Native Minister - F.D. Bell Native Land Purchase Department - Crown Commissioner .. D.McLean Native Secretary's Department - Native Secretary D. McLean NOTE; This is the first time the big three Ministers are joined by a new portfolio. 1864 Minister for Native Affairs - Honourable William Fox Native Secretary's Department. 1866 Native Minister - Honorable A.H. Russell Native Department - Minister for Native Affairs - Honorable A.H. Russell. 1867 Native Minister - Honorable J.C. Richmond Native Department - Minister for Native Affairs. 1868 Native Department - Under Secretary W. Rolleston. 1870 Ministry has now become Cabinet Donald McLean, Minister for Colonial Defence and Native Affairs. 1873 Honorable Donald McLean, Native Minister. 1878 Native Minister & Minister of Justice. 1879 Native and Defence Office Native Minister. 1880 Honorable John Boyce, Minister for Native Affairs Native Office. 1885 Native and Defence Minister Native Office. 1888 Minister of Public Works and Native Affairs. I gave up about here. Basically, you can take your pick.]

There was nothing in the Bill itself orin the speech of the Native Minister inintroducing it, to show what area wouldbe affected by this legislation. (1873,NZ Parliamentary Debates,XIV/351)

The Prime Minister is the NativeMinister, and he is looked upon by theNative people as the Great White Chief,which undoubtedly he is. (1926,NZ Parliamentary Debates,CCXI/289)

Why should there not be a permanentNative Minister as His Excellency'sAdviser on Native affairs? (Jul 5, 1858,NZ Parliamentary Debates,1856-1858 / 581)

Ministers understand that the system lastdescribed, is that actually in operationunder His Majesty's Memorandum of 28August, 1856.. although in consequence,mainly, of the want hitherto of a NativeMinister, it has scarcely yet been brougheffectively into play. (1858,AJHR,E-No. 1/10)

Old colonists, who recollected how Mr.Clarke and other Native Ministers hadbeen got rid of, know well how much suchsort of stability was worth. (Jul 5, 1858,NZ Parliamentary Debates,1856-58 ? 582)

He had listened attentively to thestatement of the Native Minister; itopened no new ground. (Aug 3, 1860,NZ Parliamentary Debates,1858-1860 / 187)

Dismissing, then, these proposals, I turnto the policy of the present Governmentas indicated by my honourable friend theNative Minister. (Aug 10, 1860,NZ Parliamentary Debates,1858-1860 / 276)

I can.. even sympathize with resistancewhich has been made by the NativeMinister. (Sep 25, 1860,NZ Parliamentary Debates,1858-1860 / 578)

A reference to [the documents] will showthat the conduct of Native affairs wasundoubtedly reserved by the Governor. Ibid He was of the opinion that Ministersshould have no control over Nativeaffairs. (Jun 21, 1858,NZ Parliamentary Debates,1856-1858 / 545)

I cannot address myself to theconsideration of measures.. withoutlooking to.. the department of theExecutive Government which has themanagement of Native affairs. (Aug 10, 1860,NZ Parliamentary Debates,1858-1860 / 275)

I desire to thank the Minister for NativeAffairs for his very able statement. (Aug 3, 1860,NZ Parliamentary Debates,1858-1860 / 187)

Before the Native Minister removed the A.C.'s there was every chance of starting a butter and cheese factory at Pungarehu. (Mar 28, 1885,Wairarapa Daily,2)

MANING ... I must confess I don't know any more about the right way to tell a story, than a native minister knows how to `come' a war-dance. (1863,Old New Zealand,(i)8)

Papers written in 1874 by Sir William Fox, M.H.R., and Sir Donald McLean, then Native Minister, state that at what time the discovery was made by the Maoris ... are matters which are lost in obscurity ... Ibid. 275 The latest feature in Native affairs is the change which has come over Tawhiao, the so-called Maori King. ... He has ... quite recently ... accepted a pension from the present Native Minister. ... it is hoped that it will lead to the end of the `King movement'. (1892,NZ Official Handbook,3)

... the hectic career of the Native Minister should be stayed ... (Sep 17, 1932,Na To Hoa Aroha,3/20) [NOTES: Ngata. 1932 Sep 17 in 1988 Na To Hoa Aroha (Ngata-Buck Correspondence)]

The police will not serve it [sc. an information] till they receive direct instructions from the Native Minister. (Mar 15, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,8)

For the purpose of rendering any Nativeland or any land owned by Natives fit forsettlement, the Native Land SettlementBoard (formerly the Native Minister) maydecide to apply the provisions of section522 to that land. (1934,AJHR,G-11/32)

IRVINE & ALPERS When the Grey Government went out ofoffice, Mr. John Bryce succeeded Mr.Sheehan as Native Minister. (1902,Progress of NZ in the 20th Century,303)

native mint¶

n.

WILLIAMS Hioi ... 1. mentha cunninghamii, a plant, native mint. (1957,Dictionary of the Maori Language,52)

WILSON Mentha Cunninghamii NATIVE MINT ... Hiioi (1982,Stewart Island Plants,266)

Mentha Cunninghamii (1896,Dunedin Field Club Plant Catalogues) [NOTES: also 1916]

native mistletoe¶

n.

Five native mistletoe species are among more than 400 plants species identified as being at risk of extinction. (May 2004,Footnotes,No. 21/8)

The [Greytown] motor camp is one of the few places you can still find native mistletoe. (Dec 17, 2003,Capital Times,6)

The magnificent beech forests of the South Island, now aflame with the scarlet flower of the native mistletoe. (Jan 26, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,19)

BULLER It is placed on the lateral fork of totara, supported underneath by an epiphytic growth of native mistletoe (Loranthus micranthus). (1888,Birds of New Zealand,1/233)

LINDSAY V[iscum] Lindsayi [Oliver] is one of the `Native Mistletoes' of the settler: an extremely insignificant one ... when compared with the handsome Otago species of Loranthus, whose showy scarlet flowers alone are sometimes ... two inches long ... (1868,Contributions to NZ Botany,52)

One [new plant] is a native mistletoe with large red flowers.. (Feb 5, 1924,Otago Witness,6)

On the whole the beech forest is dark and gloomy, but here and there it may be lighted up by a tuft of scarlet or yellow native mistletoe [fn Species of Loranthus.], or in spring by the gay garlands of white clematis; while in the more open places grows the beautiful ribbon-wood [fn Gaya ribifolia, slightly different from the more western Gaya lyallii.], with a profusion of white flowers resembling pear-blossom. (1900,Canterbury Old & New,186)

MASTERS `From this point back to Moawhango the track, for some miles, leads through a lovely piece of bush where again native mistletoe rautawhiri [=P. tenuifolium] and other lovely shrubs were in bloom.' (1959,Tales of the Mails,49) [NOTES: c1880s an anonymous tourist in 1959 L. Masters Tales of the Mails 49]

New Zealand has eight native species, seven of them endemic and one found also on Norfolk Island. A ninth species, also endemic, was last seen in the 1950s and is presumed extinct. (Sep 2002,NZ Geographic,No. 5/80)

native myrtle¶

n.

Myrtus bullata native myrtle (1917,Duncan & Davies' Catalogue) [NOTES: (And)]

THOMSON Myrtus obcordata native myrtle (1909,NZ Naturalist's Calendar) [NOTES: (And)]

BROOKER et al. Lophomyrtus bullata (A. Cunn.) Burr. Common name: Native myrtle Maori name: Ramarama ... It was known as Myrtus bullata Sol. ex A. Cunn. (1981,NZ Medicinal Plants,72)

Native Office¶

n.

I might go on multiplying proofs from theextraordinary correspondence the NativeOffice carries on with the aborigines. (May 18, 1858,NZ Parliamentary Debates,1856-1858 / 448)

He would refer him to the records of theNative Office in Mr. Protector Clarke'stime. (Jun 15, 1858,NZ Parliamentary Debates,1856-1858 / 528)

The 73rd clause of the Constitution Act..enables Her Majesty to delegate the powerof negotiating for the extinction of theNative title. (May 2, 1856,NZ Parliamentary Debates,1856-1858 / 49)

The Grants to individual Natives willeffect a gratuitous transmutation of theNative Title of occupancy into an Englishfee-simple. (1858,AJHR,E-No. 1/7)

It is expedient.. to make and put intoforce within districts over which theNative title has not been extinguished,such regulations.. as may appear adaptedto the special wants of the inhabitants (May 18, 1858,NZ Parliamentary Debates,1856-1858 / 447)

Mr. Graham asks the Colonial Secretary,What steps the Government intend to takeso as to keep up a fund for extinguishingthe Native title to land in the NorthernIsland? (Jul 6, 1858,NZ Parliamentary Debates,1856-1858 / 588)

The measures ought to be framed.. foreffecting.. the following objects:- Theindividualization of Native title. (Aug 10, 1860,NZ Parliamentary Debates,1858-1860 / 283)

It had been one of the traditions of the Native Office since its institution, that no European, out of its pale, should ever say anything to a native, and that all who did so were enemies of the Government and of their own race. (Jul 5, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,12)

Native official¶

n.

With Judge Butler.. goes one more of the old school of native officials, the men who received their earlier raining in the "flour and sugar" days of Donald McLean. (Feb 6, 1904,NZ Observer,5)

native olive¶

n. A name for one of the plants of the olearia group. (See olive)

native oven¶

n. (See Maori oven,umu)

LEE & KENDALL A'ngi; Name of a certain tree; a native oven; ... (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,134) [NOTES: [|prec.= acute, '= stress]]

MARKHAM Coppre [kopa] Mourie, or the Native Ovens are described I rather think in Captain Cookes Voyages. They are done this way. (1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles),44,1963 ed.)

POLACK The only method of cooking formerly in use [by the New Zealanders] was by the kapa [a's-acute] or angi maori, the native oven, already described. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/399)

BIDWILL ... and when I visited it, I saw all the native ovens (copper mowries, according to English pronounciation) in which the cooking had been performed, and a portion of the entrails, etc., were strewed about. (1841,Rambles in NZ,30,1952 ed.)

SELWYN A small native village is here [at Ohinemutu], with the usual appurtenances of a native steam kitchen at the hot springs; namely, hot plates, made of large slabs of stone, laid over boiling water ... steam hanghis, or native ovens, always in readiness ... A native swing completes the equipment of this fashionable watering place ... (1845,New Zealand (Selwyn),Part II (Church in the Colonies VII) 32) [NOTES: 1843 Oct 30 Selwyn Journal in 1845 NZ Part II (Church in the Colonies VII)]

ANGAS On one occasion, when on a visit to one of the missionaries at Waimate, a fine gander attracted his [sc. Waka Nene's] attention, and he secretly ordered it to be seized, and prepared for his dinner in a native oven; ... Ibid. 2/125 ... Newman [was] busily engaged in cooking ... the pig, in a native oven in the ground between hot stones. (1847,Savage Life,1/298)

POWER The friendly natives ... were busy ... cleaning their arms, singing `hakas', and making speeches, while waiting till the old women opened the native ovens, which, well filled with pork and kumeras, sent up an appetising steam in all directions. (1849,Sketches in NZ) [NOTES: 1849 Power Sketches in NZ 29 Aug 24th [1846].-]

SHORTLAND KAURU, the root of the Ti or Whanake after it has been baked in the native oven. (1851,Southern Districts of NZ,308) [NOTES: Vocab]

MACKIE Two women were preparing a native oven as we passed and we stopped to watch the process. (Apr 5, 1853,Traveller under Concern,97,1973 ed.)

SWAINSON Two long lines of native ovens mark the spot where the bodies were cooked; and a smaller oven with a wreath around its edge ... (1853,Auckland,145)

MOSER I am regaled with some potatoes and a bit of fish, admirably cooked in a native oven; ... (1863,Mahoe Leaves,6)

WILLIAMS Hapii, n. native oven or cooking pit; haangi. Ibid. 59 kopa ... 2. ... native oven. (1871,Dictionary of the Maori Language,19,3rd ed. ed.)

WILLIAMS Hangi, n. native oven. Ibid. 21 Hapi, n. native oven or cooking pit; haangi. (1892,Dictionary of the Maori Language,20)

It ... is generally known among European settlers as the native oven', though the termsteaming-pit` would be a more exact description. (1903,TrNZI,35/23)

GORST (1908,New Zealand Revisited,108)

WILLIAMS Hangi, n. 1. Native oven, consisting of a circular hole in the ground, in which the food was cooked by heated stones. 2. Contents of the oven. (1957,Dictionary of the Maori Language,34)

native owl¶

n. (Environment)

The sea-gulls would come down by the shore and bush-hens would call as it grew dark and then only our sad native owl would cry upon the night. (2003,Long Journey to the Border,83)

mopoke, morepork The aboriginal name for Australian bird, adopted in New Zealand for the native owl. (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),265)

native parrot¶

2 n. indigenous parrot, the kaka [aka kaka]

The storyteller, when a lad in Kumara, had a semi-tame kaka, or native parrot, and was playing with it one day when Mr. Seddon happened along. (Jun 12, 1906,Evening Post,5)

One of their pastimes was to find a nest of native parrots and to put a large cage over it, with netting so that the mother bird could feed the young through the holes. (Apr 2004,NZ Memories,47/52)

1978 The first year after it had been completed the roof was entirely torn off by an invading army of kakas and native parrots, which came there in thousands just as the paraquets have done in more recent times. (1914,History of North Otago,32) [NOTES: 1894 Oamaru Mail in 1914 History of North Otago (1978) 32]

WILLIAMS Kaka, ... Nestor meridionalis, native parrot. (1917,Dictionary of the Maori Language,96)

HYDE Through the forests the outlaws and the native parrots, the red-plumed kakas, had swept in varying degrees of magnificence. (1936,Passport to Hell,31)

Native party¶

n. A Wellington NZ Company word for Maori supporters.

WAKEFIELD ... the missionaries ... by the appointment of one of their number to be Protector of Aborigines, were identified with the native party. (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,72)

native passionfruit¶

n. (See kohia)

Native path¶

n. (See cf. Maori track)
