So the NBR's Fran O'Sullivan.. went to Australia to write her stories. (Nov 21, 1992,Listener (New Zealand Listener))

NBS¶

abbr. National Broadcasting Service, the fore-runner of the BCNZ (or previously NZBS) [see c1944 Whitcombe and Tombs Mod. Jun Dict 453.]

Time and again I have heard them simpering cautiously on the NBS - gutless, boring and insincere, frotting their bacons in pseudo-controversy. (Apr 1952,Here & Now,16)

NCEA¶

abbr. National Certificate of Educational Acheivement

They're talking of course about NCEA - the system they have to teach and administer every day, the system that's sticking in their craws. (Jul 14, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),21)

There's excessive angst over whether Johnny or Mary is going to pass NCEA... (Jan 31, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),29)

For those who haven't heard the rumbling, NCEA is New Zealand's experimental, 10-years-in-gtestation, standards-based assessment qualification thatlumbered into action in 2002 when it first replaced School Certrificate. (Jun 2004,North & South,40)

ne/nei¶

exclam. interrogative, giving emphasis to a question, request, or proposal (cf. eh) [ORIGIN: Maori, usu. in Maori-English contexts (ne, nei used in Maori like n'est-ce pas). [Ma. n&emacr. /ne:/]

CAMPBELL In vain my protestations. Taihoa, taihoa, all in good time - what's the hurry, O Pakeha!' time was made for slaves - hurry no man's cattle, as we in the classics say.What's the odds, a day or two sooner or later? There's Motu-Korea; it won't run away - taihoa nei?' with a chuck back of the head as they ended with the interrogative. (1881,Poenamo,Bk4/4/269)

VOGEL I will be back ...' [Maori girl answers]And be with me all the summer, ne?' (1898,Maori Maid,32)

VOGEL You big chief, ne?' the [Maori] woman said in a tone that suggested an assertion rather than a question - though thene' is a verbal note of interrogation. (1909,Tragedy of Flirtation,45)

ASHTON-WARNER nei? [complete the cit.] (1963,Spinster,70)

MASON KANI. Dug it,Pera. ... Five feet, almost roast an ox in it [sc. hangi], whole, Time for a beer, ne? [note p. 97] ne: to give emphasis to a question. (1969,Awatea,17,1978 ed.)

MASON HINGAWARU ... When Rangi chooses his wahine, someone else pays, ne? RANGI: When I choose, Dad, I'll choose a girl, not a wahine! Hate that word! Makes me see fat slobbery old tarts waddling along the beach. (1974,Hand on the Rail, The,20) [NOTES: 1981 TS]

HULME Then, he had only chuckled again and said, `Well, we got him on the way, nei?' (1983,Bone People, The,5)

1986 You hate me now, ne?' the matriarch called.Yes!' he shouted. `I hurt you, ne?' she asked. (1986,Matriarch, The,132)

HULME She's proud of that whakapapa. As she's one of the blue-eyed white-blond kind of Maori, she probably feels she needs it, nei? (1986,Te Kaihau,92)

Ihimaera 'I suppose you were still trying to protect your papa, ne?' (2007,Ask the Posts,256)

near¶

adj.

BOWEN NOTE: The sheep's right legs and right side are referred to as the near' and the sheep's left side and legs as theoff.' (1955,Wool Away!,21)

near and off¶

phr. [station]

Near and Off.- Right and left. On stations, sheep, like horses, have n. and o. ears and legs. (C.) (Nov 11, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

near at hand huntaway¶

1 n. (Rural) a specialist huntaway sheepdog that works in close proximity to its master and quarry.

ANDERSON You've one useful yard and near at hand huntaway ... (1962,Life's Roundabout, A,25)

Near North¶

n. A semi-jocular Australasian term for the Far East.

TURNER During the war, the term Near North was popularized [in Australia], and is now used in New Zealand too, for places like Bangkok to the north-west, as far from Wellington as from London! (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,69)

near profit¶

1 phr. (Rural) [of cows or ewes] about to produce offspring. (See close-up; close to profit)

All cows and heifers near profit caused keen competition whilst backward and doubtful calves were hard to quit. (Aug 7, 1900,Hawera Star,3)

Egmont Farmers Union Report - cows near profit were keenly competed for. (Aug 25, 1900,Hawera Star,4)

near-shore, nearshore¶

adj.

Mr Ingram's council has argued that the fishery cannot survive purse seine vessels of large New Zealand companies targeting near-shore kahawai schools. (Aug 15, 2005,NZ Herald,A2)

PhD projects include studies of nearshore sand transport at Timaru and in the Marlborough Sounds. (Jul 1982,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,57/19)

neat, eh¶

phr.

We actually don't have a grand plan., But we get seduced by what I call the 'neat, eh' concept. It is when you look at a contract and think 'that would be neat, eh?' (May 9, 2001,Dominion,24)

He said [his business] was thriving on the "Neat eh! concept. "When we hear about work that we get excited about, something that's challenging, we say,'that'll be neat, eh!'" (Aug 15, 2001,Evening Post,3)

neato¶

adj. neat, great (also as exclamation) [(adolescents') 1984 14 F E139 Wgton Girls C. 18 NEAT-O [exclam delight] -->1984 14 F E139 Wgton Girls C. 35A NEAT-O [exclam approval] -->1984 15 M E62 Pakuranga Coll. 4 NEATO (NEETO) [excellent] -->1984 15 M E62 Pakuranga Coll. 18 NEATO (NEETO) -->1984 15 M E62 Pakuranga Coll. 35A NEATO (NEETO)]

But it was fish-and-chip night after all. Neato!'That's great!' we said. (1984,NZ Short Stories,15) [NOTES: 1984 Marcus Campbell (Lady of Yesterday) in NZ Short Stories 15]

JONES `I didn't mean it like that, but I've just read this neato book by Abbie Hoffman, Steal this Book. (1985,Gilmore's Dairy,142)

McGILL neato pleasing;variant of `neat', as in neat, eh? (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,75)

neats¶

adj. a silly person [check the form.] [1953 16 M A32 Thames DHS 1 NEATS secondary school]

nebby¶

adj. nosy, inquisitive

Conversation with a local might also introduce you.. to the word nebby. As in "you're a nebby soul, aren't you?"... A migrant from the Scottish border regions, neb means a "nose, beak, tip or projecting point", and a nebby person is nosy, inquisitive and/or sharp-tongued. (Jul 6, 2002,Hey Hey Hey,R9) [NOTES: Otago]

NECAHR¶

abbr. National Ethics Committee on Assisted Human Reproduction

The Ministry of Health's National Ethics Committee on Assisted Human Reproduction (Necahr) has given Fisher's Fertility Associates a very limited go-ahead to conduct a feasibility study into FISH.Ibid. 23 Necahr, too, is likely to find its role amended under any new law. (Mar 3, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20)

neck¶

n. ?Usu. pl necks, the wool shorn from a sheep's neck (cf neck wool). [wool-classers]

`Necks,' which are generally removed when skirting, are baled separately in the case of large clips. (1936,Agricultural Organization in NZ,710)

Frames hinged to a wall can be very useful to support a wool pack for bellies, necks, etc... (caption) Frames hinged to a wall [of a shearing-shed] can be very useful to support a wool pack for bellies, necks, etc. (Oct 16, 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,33)

FERNANDEZ Erina had gathered up Mutu's last fleece and thrown it expertly on the table before the classer. A few random wrist movements removed the necks and edging pieces. (1973,Tussock Fever,3)

Sheaves wool (Mar 28, 1979,Otago Daily Times,21) [NOTES: Griffiths]

neck ... NZ & Austral. (also neck wool) matted wool round neck of sheep. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng.Dict.]]

2 n.

going up the neck: This expression refers to the blows on a sheep from the brisket towards the head. Opening up the neck' orgoing up the spout' mean the same thing. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/24) [NOTES: Wallace Shearing Glossary]

neck back¶

v. drink

In 1994, the nation necked back an amazing 355 million litres of beer. (Nov 9, 2003,Sunday Star Times,D3)

neck wool¶

n. a matted collar of wool from around the neck of a sheep; (cf. neck n.). [not NZ: in OED 1726, 1886, 1999]

Neck wool: Matted collar of wool from around the neck of a sheep. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,57)

necklace fern¶

n. Asplenium flabellifolium

DOBBIE (And) (1921,NZ Ferns)

Aspleniaceae Asplenium flabellifolium necklace fern (1975,Tane,21/8) [NOTES: (Wright Vegetation Mt Maungatawhiri)]

necklace seaweed¶

n.

MARTIN Neptune's Necklace or Necklace Seaweed (Hormosira banksii).. . Each stem and each branch resembles a string beads, ... (1929,Flora NZ,18,1961 ed.)

WILSON Hormosira banksii NEPTUNE'S NECKLACE ... Venus' necklace ... Necklace seaweed ... Brown or yellow-brown strings of thick-walled bladders, flopped over rocks ... at low tide. (1982,Stewart Island Plants,318)

necklace shell¶

n. Tanea zelandica

POWELL NECKLACE SHELL (Tanea zelandica). About an inch in diameter, and has a beautiful pattern of reddish-brown markings on a light brown to white polished surface. It lives on the open coast in sandy localities, but is seldom found alive. (1947,Native Animals of NZ,27)

necko¶

n. (See nikau)

ned¶

v.

McGILL ned throw two heads in the game of two-up; from Ned's (Edward VII's) head on the penny. ANZ. (1989,Dinkum Kiwi Dictionary, The,71)

neddy¶

n. a truncheon, a waddy.

He would strongly advise the use of knuckledusters and needys. (1869,Punch or the Auckland Charivari,120)

WILSON If [the constable in c. 1860s] strikes with his `neddy', we'll kill him. (1912,Reminiscences of Early Settlement Dunedin,51)

n. a horse [Jim writes : NSOD and Collins tag neddy as Austral. but it is surely used internationally as an informal synonym of horse - "gee up Neddy". The plural may be distinctive Aus (and NZ) E - I have often heard it in NZ e.g. "he did his money on the neddies." DEH adds: I remember this term in exactly this sense from the 1940s-1950s.]

PHILLIPS After tying up my neddy I strolled round to see the sights. (2000,First Past the Post,190) [NOTES: Leon Smith "A Maori Race Meeting in the King Country" from Lone Hand 6, 1909]

need one's brains brushed¶

phr. to need one's thoughts clarifying

Whoever conceived the idea of taking a vehicle over that country wants his brains brushed. (Apr 25, 1908,NZ Truth,149/1/3)

needle¶

n. a blasting tool. [miners', quarrymen's]

(Annual Contracts, Col.Secretary's Office) [heading] TOOLS FOR ROAD PARTIES ... Blasting Tools/ Crowbars ......per lb./ Jumpers ......per lb./ Rammers .....per lb./ Spoons and Needles ......per lb....Saws/ Hand .....per foot./ Cross Cut .....per foot./ Pit......per foot. (Dec 21, 1852,NZ Government Gazette,V/31/193)

MONEY [There being] no good fuses to be obtained for blasting, he made vesta matches answer equally well, using a needle' andtamping' instead of the regular fuse. (1871,Knocking About in NZ,79)

n.

needle: bottle of beer at midday. / (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/25) [NOTES: Wallace Shearing Glossary]

needlefish¶

n.

GRAHAM LONG-SNOUTED PIPEFISH Syngnathus (Novacampus) norae Waite (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,143,2nd ed.)

DOOGUE & MORELAND NEEDLEFISH ... Other names: Scomberesox forsteri; saury, skipper, double beak, ocean garfish, ocean piper. (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,205)

MORELAND NEEDLEFISH [Scomberesox forsteri] ... Other names are ocean piper, skipper, saury, and doublebeak. (1967,Marine Fishes,16)

NATUSCH Family SCOMBERESOCIDAE (skippers and needle fishes). Scomberesox forsteri ... is likely to have its name altered ... It looks superficially like a garfish, but has a double beak. (1967,Animals of NZ, The,213)

WILSON NEEDLEFISH (Scomberesox forsteri) The sea-going version of the common Piper, or Garfish, this fellow is a common, surface-water fish that is widespread in our territory and is often found well out to sea, ... (1981,Fisherman's Bible,169)

AYLING SAURY (Needlefish) Scomberesox saurus ... It is similar in shape to the piper but on the saury both the upper and lower jaws are projected forward to form a sharp beak. ... [172] Sauries are often called skippers in reference to their habit of leaping clear of the water and skipping along on their tails for short distances. (1982,Collins Guide,171,1984 ed.)

[species name] garfish .. [scientific name] Hyporhamphus ihi .. [other name(s)] piper, halfbeak, needlefish... [species name] needlefish .. [scientific name] -- [other name(s)] may be GARFISH [Hyporhamphus ihi], or SAURY [Scomberesox saurus]; Hastings region, GARFISH. (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] needlefish 975-9, 1134 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

needlegrass¶

1 n. (Rural) an exotic grass Stipa variabilis which is invasive in sheep fleecewool.

LOUGHNAN speargrass: another name for needlegrass. Both terms refer to more than one plant species, but perhaps the most common are Stipa variabilis or S. neesiana. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,76)

LOUGHNAN needlegrass: an exotic grass (Stipa variabilis) accidentally introduced, with a tiny, hard, barbed head which penetrates in hundreds through the pelts of sheep and deep into the flesh of their briskets. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,55)

needlewood¶

n. Dracophyllum longifolium

(1906,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin,No. 6 (ns): 10) [NOTES: Morgan: Mikinui]

neenish tart¶

n. [A small round short-pastry tart with a custard filling but especially characterised by the icing, half of which is black and half white; in Dunedin with a peppermint flavour (check). Other variations in the filling include lemon juice, rum essence or vanilla. Known to me from Dunedin in 1952. An Australian version (see below) is on a biscuit base instead of being in a tart and includes a layer of jam but has the essential bicoloured icing. Possible origins of the name : Nimes (in France); Neen in Shropshire (Neenton, Neen Savage, Neen Sollars); have been told of a Dutch woman making them. There is an outside chance it might be related to the neem tree ("a meliaceous tree of India and Ceylon, sometimes 50 feet high... The natives chew its small twigs and use them as tooth brushes") but I think not. David Burton does not mention them in his books on the raj. Kathryn Walls knows the lemon-flavoured variety from Invercargill (thought they were bakery rather than home-made), Vincent had heard of them, Bill Manhire hadn't. Nelson Wattie does not know them from NZ but when the bicoloured icing was described said he knew them from Germany as "Americans", possibly because of the black and white racial suggestion. Tony Simpson makes, them, his mother made them, his grandmother made them, but he doesn't know anything about the origin. The name appears as a headword in the Macquarie Dictionary but none other that I can find. None of the books on the cookery shelves at National Library has them, not do any of the present stock of second-hand ones in Quilter's but then most modern cookery books are written (or compiled) by restaurant chefs who do not bake and not by bakery cooks.]

Neenish Tarts... 4 tablespoons Butter 4 tablespoons Sweetened Condensed Milk 4 tablespoons Icing Sugar 2 dessertspoons Lemon Juice. Soften butter, add sifted icing sugar, condensed milk and lemon juice. When set, ice half the top with white icing and half with chocolate icing. (1982,Budget Macquarie Dictionary,447)

Neenish Tarts... 4 tablespoons Butter 4 tablespoons Sweetened Condensed Milk 4 tablespoons Icing Sugar 2 dessertspoons Lemon Juice. Soften butter, add sifted icing sugar, condensed milk and lemon juice. When set, ice half the top with white icing and half with chocolate icing. (1966,Edmonds Cookery Book,30)

Neenish Biscuits... Spread half the tops of each biscuit with icing, allow to set. Add sifted cocoa to remaining icing... spread over remaining half of biscuit. (1800,Big Book of Beautiful Biscuits,The,28)

Nimish tarts... Ice half chocolate and half white on each. (1800,GHB Cookery Book,22)

NENISCHE TARTS. 1 lb. ground almonds, a? lb. icing sugar, 3 tablespoons flour, 4 egg whites, custard as below, icing in two colours. Sift ground almonds; icing sugar and flour. Beat egg white stiffly and add to dry ingredients. Make all to stiff paste. Line tins with this mixture, thinly. Prick with fork, bake in moderate oven till just crisp. Fill with custard and ice each cake with soft white icing and soft brown icing. CUSTARD.- 2 oz. butter, 2 oz. flour, a pint milk, 2oz. sugar, 2 egg yolks, essence to taste. Melt butter, add flour, stir in till smooth and cook one minute. Add milk, stir till boiling and cook 2 or 3 minutes. Add sugar and yolks, and cook without boiling. Cool and add essence. (1942,Aunt Daisy's Cookery Book,5th ed.:)

(1968,Edmonds Cookery Book,9th printing) [NOTES: as Neenish Tarts]

Neenish Tarts.[This recipe uses raspberry jam in the filling and raspberry coloured icing in place of chocolate. The only recognisable constituent is having a circular iced top in two colours - in this case, white and pink. (1994,Family Circle Tempting Treats) [NOTES: So far no further NZ recipe books have turned it up and it looks as though the 60s might be about the earliest printed occurrence, but I haven't given up hope yet. I have now been through the Turnbull's five boxes without luck.]

Stories paint pictures around the recipes, and there are many which will bring back memories for New Zealanders. Remember Neenish tarts, chicken Kiev, roly-poly pudding? (Dec 20, 1997,Dominion,21) [NOTES: A friend suggests this might be a Yiddish word.]

I was on my way to a big house, once a children's home. now filled with small ghosts. When I got there I said, "I saw a lake like a Neenish tart." (Jan 8, 1994,Listener (New Zealand Listener),36)

The study of basalt columns on the Chatham Islands.. joins a host of similar images playing with repetition and variation, whether of Neenish tarts or the snows on Ruapehu. (Jun 28, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),57)

negalitarianism¶

adj. negative egalitarianism

Victoria University political scientist Jon Johansson says "negalitarianism", or negative egalitarianism, is pervasive in our culture. (May 1, 2005,Sunday Star Times,C1)

One might conclude, therefore, that Winston [Peters] appeals to that strand of New Zealand political culture that maintains a basic negalitarian outlook towards symbols of wealth and power. (2003,New Zealand Votes: The General Elaction of 2002,67)

negro¶

n. a Maori, an occas. early derogatory term for a Maori see nigger [a euphemism for J.C.R.'s nigger]

Domett has promised to act decisively one way or another about Taranaki ... If we cannot keep the negroes in order it would be most cheerful to clear out and try to get a bit reunited. (Dec 5, 1862,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/807,1960 ed.) [NOTES: J.C. Richmond, Nelson]

negrohead¶

adj. . [negro-head] (See also niggerhead n1)

YATE ... for the mere trifle of a fig of negro-head tobacco (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),127) [NOTES: Griffiths Collection]

ANGAS We left Tuhua, and on taking leave of our hospitable chief, I gave him five figs of negrohead tobacco (worth about three pence) ... (1847,Savage Life,2/103)

n.

n. A tobacco type; NZ use common in early colonial days and as a common payment to a trade with the Maoris; also smoked by early settlers, sailors, stationhands etc. [negro head, negro-head]

HODGSKIN I purchased a pig ... for a few negro-heads of tobacco and two gun flints. (1841,Narrative of Eight Months Sojourn in NZ, A,38)

McLEAN Improving the road, so as to make it worth his [the Maori chief's] while to erect a turnpike tote, and exact a negrohead - or some other equivalent for every passenger (1845,Papers,1/12)

Tobacco is the currency of the Island: you could no more travel without it than in Europe with `the ready'; nothing however but American negro-head will pass; Brazil they [sc. Maoris] will scarcely accept as a gift - ... (1834,NZ Independent,31,1979 ed.)

CHAPMAN The proper way to arrange a blanket for the bush is to sew it up like a sack. As to food you carry what you like; and what the host always furnishes is tea (at every meal), damper, i.e. a sort of dough cake baked in the ashes, very good if well made; and fried pork. He can generally furnishthe traveller with a short black pipe and some `negro-head' or Cavendish. (Nov 24, 1847,Letters to His Father, 1843-1851) [NOTES: 1847 Nov 24 H.S. Chapman Letters to His Father [TS,ATB] in 1958 Miller Early Victorian NZ 140]

WAKEFIELD tobacco, negro-head, [per] lb, 6-1/2d. to 10d.; ... (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,180)

McLEAN ... payment of 400 sticks of negrohead. Thomson, JT Reconnaissance Survey foetid negrohead. Reed NZ 165 (1851,Papers,IX/199) [NOTES: Halse]

HURSTHOUSE TOBACCO. - The `Lion' brand (negrohead) is getting much liked; ... (1857,New Zealand (various authors/titles),2/568)

WILLIAMS & REEVES Only think how much more graceful all the landscape will appear. / No more pigroots, whalebacks, hogbacks - these names that shall not last; / ... Negro-heads shall be re-christened. I for one will take no heed, / While to me there yet remaineth Negrohead, the fragrant weed. (1889,Colonial Couplets,3)

HALL ... foetid negrohead through a `cutty pipe' (1971,Mr Surveyor Thomson,21) [NOTES: Griffiths Collection]

n. a swamp-tussock bush (cf niggerhead, maorihead).

WILLIAMS & REEVES Only think how much more graceful all the landscape will appear. / No more pigroots, whalebacks, hogbacks - these names that shall not last; / ... Negro-heads shall be re-christened. I for one will take no heed, / While to me there yet remaineth Negrohead, the fragrant weed. (1889,Colonial Couplets,3)

NULLER I cast my eyes for a moment below, and there, in a `negro-head' swamp ... I witnessed a very pretty picture of wild bird life. (1888,Birds of New Zealand,2/255)

n. [plant]

neho¶

n. ?? [ORIGIN: Maori, not in Williams or Ryan]

I've been sat by the phone for weeks waiting for that neho to call. (Jul 3, 2005,Sunday Star Times,8,sports supplement ed.)

neighbourhood watch¶

n. [OED gives this as US from 1972]

The neighbourhood may be about to make a comeback in the 21st century as one of the most successful community organisations of the 1980s - Neighbourhood Watch - is being reinvented... Neighbourhood Watch was first set up in 1983 after film and television produced Robin Scholes was viciously beaten in her Auckland home. (Oct 25, 2000,Dominion,11)

neinei¶

n. A small North Island tree with long tapering leaves. Also called pineapple tree, spider wood. [ORIGIN: Maori]

The surface is covered with stunted nei- nei, Bidwill's Pine, mountain flax, dwarfed forms of tawhero and tawari, and danthonia, brightened up by patches of snowberry. (Jun 15, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,15)

From there, the group takes a well-graded track through red and silver beech, mountai neinei (Dracophyllum traversii), tree daisy (Olearia lacunosa) and mountain cedar to Mt Arthur Hut. (Oct 17, 2000,Dominion,15)

POLACK There are many other woods of much service to Europeans, differing in quality, among others: the 30 Warangai - 31 Pata -32 - Niho - 33 Tangio , - 34 Maihoi - 35 Nene [e's-acute] - 36 Taraiti - 37 Kohihihu 38 Waihupuku - 39 Kaikamoko - 40 Pukapuka - 41 Karanghu - 42 Utuhutu - 43 Angiani - 44 Akkas of various kinds. 45 Parekireki , &c. Of all these woods there are abundant quantities. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),2/400)

TAYLOR [We found] what was to us quite a new kind of tree, called nei nei . It is something like a diminutive ti. (1959,Early Travellers,355) [NOTES: 1858 Jan 8 Smith Notes of a Journey in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 355]

HOOKER Neinei, Col[enso]. Dracophyllum latifolium. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),766)

HAAST An undescribed, superb, tree-like Dracophyllum , not unlike the Drac. latifolium of the northern island, began to appear here [D. Traversii ]. The natives call it Nene. Ibid. 119 There were some very large groves of nene (Dracophyllum traversii ), surrounded by a great number of good sized shrubs of Dracophyllum latifolium ... (1879,Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland,78)

HAY The Neinei (Dracophyllum latifolium) is but a small tree. The wood is hard, and is valued for making mallets ... (1882,Brighter Britain,2/197)

HECTOR Dracophyllum longifolium, Br. Neinei.--An ornamental shrub-tree with long grassy leaves. (1883,Handbook of New Zealand,128)

[Native name] Neinei .. [Settlers' name] Neinei .. [Family] Epacrideae [Native name] Neinei .. [Settlers' name] Grass-tree ..[Family] Epacrideae (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,122) [NOTES: 1886 T.Kirk in 1902 Settler's Handbook of NZ 122]

Neinei .. Dracophyllum latifolium .. Wood of a reddish brown colour, prettily figured; ... (1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,12)

Among the strange shrubs [on the West Coast range] the nei-nei is most noticeable, having sometimes growing to thirty feet in height. (1894,NZ Alpine Journal,6/326)

MORRIS Neinei, n. Maori name for New Zealand shrub, Dracophyllum longifolium, R. Br., also D. traversii, N.O. Epacridea. (1898,Austral English,318)

VON HAAST (1865,Geology of Westland,78) [NOTES: 1865. J. Von Haast, A Journey to the West Coast, 1865' (seeGeology of Westland,' p. 78):]

CHEESEMAN D[racophyllum latifolium] ... Neinei. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,419)

LAING & BLACKWELL Dracophyllum latifolium (The Broad-leaved Grass-tree). A shrub or tree, from 10 ft.- 25 ft. high ... Maori name, Nei-nei. (1907,Plants of NZ,330,1940 p. 351 ed.)

COWAN We have climbed above the pines [on the West Coast]; ... and up here on the mountain side the vegetation is the flowering rata, the akeake, the native alpine broom, the white blossomed ribbonwood, ... the flax-like kiekie, and the semi-tropical neinei, half-shrub, half-palm, and whole forests of fern trees. (1926,Travel in NZ,(Vol II South Island) 95)

BUCK Portions of spear, made of nene (Dracophyllum sp.) .. 1 (1937,Moa-Hunters of NZ,85)

nei nei The Maori name for a New Zealand shrub with very long, narrow leaves. (Pronounce nay| nay|). (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),273,8th ed.)

MARTIN Reference has already been made to the PINE-APPLE TREE of the western uplands of Nelson and Westland, otherwise known as the NEI-NEI or less commonly as the SPIDER-WOOD. (1961,Flora NZ,192,1929 ed.)

neinei, nene n. New Zealand ornamental shrub [Maori]. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),621)

neinei, nene ... n. N.Z. ornamental shrub; broad-leaved grass-tree [Maori]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),14)

neinei n. NZ shrub with long narrow leaves. [M] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,503) [NOTES: nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng.Dict.]

The channelled stems of the Neinei (Dracophyllum latifolium), and the ... saplings of Toatoa, or Tanekaha (Phyllocladus trichomanoides), made valued walking-sticks. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/34) [NOTES: Colenso Botany North Isd]

neinei, a shrub (Dracophyllum latifolium), grass-tree. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/154) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

2 n. native broom [is this correct.]

HOOKER Neinei, Lyall. Carmichaelia australis. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),766)

3 n.

nekau¶

n. (See nikau)

neko¶

n. (See nikau)

nellie¶

n. Nellie Bligh, a lie [ORIGIN: rhyming slang]

NEWBOLD [He] must have been walking around telling a few nellies about what had happened. Ibid 251 NELLIE BLIGH (n) and (v) Untruth, lie. (1982,Big Huey, The,72)

Nellie bin¶

n. a fish bin [[note: this term Nellie bin' is an error. The correct term isNally' bin, which is a brand name. Source: Tony Walker, Director, Fishing Industry Services, Christchurch, agent for Nally bins.]]

JOHNSON Vessels were often under catch restrictions: no more than four or five baskets (the term 'baskets' was still freely used despite wicker baskets having been replaced by plastic Nellie bins) of species such as trevally and dogfish. (2004,Hooked,305)

nelly¶

n. Macronectes giganteus, giant petrel,=stinker, =stinkpot (See giant petrel)

Saw a number of Nellys [petrels] and had a fine chase after several. Killed 5. (1999,Enderby Settlement Diaries,50) [NOTES: Entry for 25 October, 1850]

We headed up a great herd of nellies (giant petrel or breakbones). (Jan 30, 1890,Otago Witness,15)

We got an egg which contained a full-grown Nelly chick. (Mar 6, 1890,Otago Witness,11)

RICHARDS Ossifraga ... or Macronectes ... giganteus ... If a birder comes near the nest the old birds move away a little and the young ones squirt a horrible smelling oil out of their mouths for a distance of 8 ft. Nellies are filthy birds that range the whole of the Southern Hemisphere and deserve their name of stinkpot. Nelly, Stinkpot. TOROA-RURU. (1952,Chatham Islands,86)

(1955,Cook's Journals,1-60 [fn])

[27b. Macronectes giganteus (Gmelin, 1789) Southern Giant Petrel (Nelly) (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,21,1980 ed.)

GRADY Many giant petrels, larger scavenger birds, known [to the Cook Strait whalers] as Nellies or stinkers, were also found. (1982,Perano Whalers,114)

FALLA et al. GIANT PETREL Macronectes giganteus Other names : Nelly, Stinker, Black Molly. (1966,Birds of New Zealand,35)

Northern Giant Petrel Macronectes giganteus (GMELIN, 1789) ... OTHER NAMES: Nelly, stinker, giant fulmar. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,68)

n. northern giant petrel

Northern Giant Petrel Macronectes halli MATHEWS, 1912 ... OTHER NAMES: Nelly, stinker, Hall's giant petrel giant fulmar. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,69)

[27. Macronectes halli Mathews 1912] Northern Giant Petrel Nelly ) ...ranging widely throughout the southern hemisphere. (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,20,1980 ed.)

n. giant petrel [[?is this a different bird or merely a synonymous name: CCRansom notes that O. gigantea `giant bonebreaker' is listed nowhere: Giant petrel = giant fulmar]]

HUTTON 123. OSSIFRAGRA GIGANTEA. Gml. Nelly. (1871,Birds of New Zealand,44)

Amongst birds he has obtained [at the Chathams] are ...a Dotterel, differing from the common Dotterel of this country ...; a sea-bird, called by the whalers the `Blue Billy', the beak of which is singularly shaped, and of a blue colour, hence its trivial name; the Nelly Ossifraga gigantea ) ... (1872,TrNZI,4/64) [NOTES: Travers Notes on the Chatham Isds]

BULLER OSSIFRAGA GIGANTEA. (GIANT PETREL.) ... The Giant Petrel, or `Nelly', as it is called by sailors, is by no means uncommon in our seas, ... (1873,Birds of New Zealand,297,1888 2nd edn 2/225 ed.)

HAAST Of birds still belonging to the Avifauna of New Zealand, the following species were represented :- Graculus punctatus , spotted shag; Eudyptula undina , small blue penguin; Anas superciliosa , grey duck; Graculus carbo , black shag; Graculus varius , pied shag; Graculus brevirostris , white throated shag; Ossifraga gigantea, nelly ; Apteryx australis , large kiwi, Nestor meridionalis , kaka; Stringops habroptilus , kakapo, and some other undetermined species. (1879,Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland,417)

Ossifraga gigantea , Nelly,'Stinkpot.' (1883,TrNZI,15/401) [NOTES: Scott Macquarie Island]

DOUGALL [We] had two nellies on board, which are reckoned valuable birds ... (1888,Far South,18)

REISCHEK A few nellies followed in our wake, eagerly devouring the waste food we threw overboard. (1930,Yesterdays in Maoriland,269,1933 ed.)

As we came out [of the Snares Islands], flocks of sea-birds flew and swam around us, andwe headed up a great herd of nellies ( Ossifraga gigantea, giant petrel or breakbones), and chased them awhile. (1891,TrNZI,23/492)

GUTHRIE-SMITH At the very head of the inlet [at the Snares] many young full fledged Nellies ( Ossifraga gigantea ) crowded together; ... . Ibid. 239 Here and there [in the Bounty Islands] a dark Nelly, or Stinkpot, or Giant Petrel, ( Ossifraga gigantea ) breasted in single self importance ... (1936,NZ Naturalist,192)

BUICK Awl made of distal end of tibia of nelly ( Ossifraga gigantea ) (1937,Moa-Hunters of NZ,85)

nelly-birding¶

n.

GRADY Nelly-birding - Quite often the Peranos would pursue a pair of whales. If the cow was harpooned first, the bull whale would hang around. The whalers, therefore, tried to get a bomb into a bull in a near vital spot. But sometimes the chaser got out of position, and one of the other chasers would fire their harpoon into it. This was called `Nelly-birding'. (1982,Perano Whalers,227)

Nelson boarfish¶

n.

WILSON The third, and rarest New Zealand Boarfish is the Nelson Boarfish, first found in 1890. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,35)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] Nelson boarfish 1526 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

Nelson cave spider¶

n. Spelungula cavernicola

The Nelson cave spider, Spelungula cavernicola, with a leg-span of 13 cm, is New Zealand's largest spider. (1990,Tramping in South Island Forest Parks,64)

Nelson green gecko¶

n. brightly coloured lizard common in, and exclusive to, the Nelson Province. [Naultinus stellatus aka starred gecko]

Nelson green gecko (Naultinus stellatus), Station Creek, Nelson Lakes. (2009,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.doc.govt.nz/conservation/native-animals/reptiles-and-frogs/lizards/geckos/facts/ date estimated]

Nelson Green Gecko Heteropholis stellatus: [sic] Also known as the star gecko this gecko is restricted to the Nelson province but can show different patterning depending on the area they are from. (2006,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.reptilepark.co.nz/nzlizard.htm#Nelson%20Green%20Gecko]

The Nelson green gecko is endemic to New Zealand, found only in the Nelson area of the South Island. (2009,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.absoluteastronomy.com/topics/Nelson_green_gecko]

Nelson huntaway¶

n. a boulder rolled downhill to move stock [musterers' local]

ELWELL In mustering times,Ernest used to set some of the huge boulders on the sides of [the cliffs] rolling, and they make quite a roaring noise ... This noise startled the sheep ... which always made upwards.] (1878,Boy Colonists,169)

McCASKILL Danger could also be caused by a musterer rolling a large rock to frighten sheep along and save running a dog. [These rocks, started on purpose, were known as `Nelson huntaways' becauseyoung men from that district used to come mustering with young, untrained dogs. When frustrated they would use any method to move a sheep along the beat. (1969,Molesworth,100) [NOTES: [? 1907-14] A.G. Mowat Diary (? or reminiscence)in 1969 McCaskill Molesworth 100]

BAKER Nelson huntaway, a stone rolled down a hillside to move stock below instead of sending a dog out. `From the fact that in the early days the Nelson musterers were noted for having few and poor dogs.' (1941,NZ Slang,59)

NEWTON Brownie sent a boulder hurtling down the face - a `nelson huntaway' (1949,High Country Days,29)

McLEOD On the hill, when sheep are sticking far below you, it's sometimes possible to roll a large rock down a steep face and scare them into movement with its crashing and bounding. This is called aNelson huntaway,' or just aNelson.' (1951,High Country,42)

TOMLINSON A lot of young fellows from Nelson used to start off mustering there [at Hillensden Station, Marlborough] and they became known as the Nelson College. If anyone said `I'm going back to the college, you knew where he was going. Nelson men in Marlborough and North Canterbury used to be called Sandy Hookers. Stones being rolled down steep faces to frighten sheep were called Nelson Huntaways. (1968,Remembered Trails,128)

Nelson huntaway n. stone rolled down a hillside to move stock, used instead of sending a dog out. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),14)

Nelson plan¶

n.

LAY The school had been designed, like every other of its era, according to the Nelson Plan. There was an administration and assembly block near the gates, and five identical, detached, two-storeyed classroom blocks behind it, separated from each other by an expanse of concrete. (1988,Fools on the Hill, The,159)

Nelson scallop¶

n. (Marine)

And then there's Nelson scallops and then asparagus pops out of the ground. (Sep 3, 2006,Sunday Star Times,3)

Nelson school system¶

n.

It is the introduction of what is called the Nelson school system, having been originated by a Presbyterian minister settled in Nelson. (Aug 4, 1911,Maoriland Worker,3)

Nelson snob¶

n.

THOMSON ...it is worthy of notice, that the colonists, soon after the formation of all the settlements, acquired distinguishing epithets; thus there was an Auckland cove, a Wellington swell, a Nelson snob, a Taranaki exquisite, an Otago cockney, and a Canterbury pilgrim. These epithets, almostalready forgotten, are too characteristic to be buried in oblivion, as each originated in some peculiarity of the leading colonists. The Otago settlers derived theirs from their ignorance of the country in which they lived; the Auckland people from their extensive Sydney connexions; and the origin of the other names are sufficiently obvious without explanation. (1859,Story of New Zealand, The,2/188)

McGILL Nelson snob a person from Nelson. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,75)

Nelson system¶

n. a system of religious instruction for State schools

The agreement was made through the supreme courts of the Churches which give the major attention to the Nelson System. (May 3, 1955,Dominion,14)

SALMOND Lesson Outlines for Christian Education in New Zealand Schools under the Nelson System [title] (1930,Lesson Outlines for Christian Education)

PINFOLD I used to attend, week by week, the State school of the town in which I lived, and gave Bible lessons to the children whose parents indicated their desire for them to remain. This is called the `Nelson System' because it was started in that city. (1930,Fifty Years In Maoriland,133)

McSWEENEY When in 1897 the `Nelson system' of religious instruction was introduced by the Rev. J.H.McKenzie, Presbyterian minister at Nelson, Catholic priests followed this method. (1966,History of Catholic Education in N.Z.,208)

TAYLOR Since schools taught for more than the four hours daily required by law, it had become usual, and was legal under the system started in Nelson, for ministers of religion with the approval ofheadmasters and school committees to take classes for half-an-hour weekly, though the children did not have to attend. (1986,Home Front,1/129)

Nelson weather¶

n.

EARP In other settlements of New Zealand, it is not unusual, in extraordinarily fine weather, tohear the observation - `This is Nelson weather,' ... (1853,New Zealand (various authors/titles),143)

Nelson/Nelson huntaway¶

1 n. (Rural) a rock sent down a hillside to disturb sheep [ to save running out a dog.] (See Taranaki huntaway,Maori huntaway)

MCCASKILL These rocks, started on purpose, were known as 'Nelson huntaways' because young men from that district used to come mustering with young, untrained dogs. (1969,Molesworth,100)

BAKER Also reported is Nelson huntaway, a stone rolled down a hillside to move stock below instead of sending a dog out. (1941,NZ Slang,59)

MCLEOD On the hill, when sheep are sticking far below you, it's sometimes possible to roll a large rock down a steep face and scare them into movement with its crashing and bounding. This is called a "Nelson huntaway" or just a "Nelson." (1951,NZ High Country,42)

You only run a 'Nelson huntaway' when the sheep have defied your dogs and they, in turn, have defied you. "If your best dog's tired and beaten early, all you've got left is heart strain, hoarse voice and a Nelson huntaway." [Nelson] (Nov 15, 1983,NZ Journal of Agriculture,20)

Nelsonian¶

n. a New Zealand Company sponsored emigrant, Nelson-bound

T.J. THOMPSON I think that this question [of a Panama route] will be taken up by the Nelsonians, anxious as most of us are to revisit England (Jan 22, 1842,Diary) [NOTES: on board ship>1842 Jan 22 DIARY [] in 1954 Dec11 Nelson Evening Mail]

n.

A Nelsonian became quite excited theother week and informed us all Nelsonwould be holding holiday that day. Shesaid they called it "Spud Monday" in thegarden province because it was the firstday of spring and the new potatoes wereto be planted that week. (Sep 14, 1927,NZ Tablet,58)

As the 5000-odd Golden Bay residents know, the definition of a Nelsonian is someone who was heading for the bay but never quite made it (and thank goodness for that, they might say). (Jan 29, 2001,Evening Post,17)

These are the kinds of [sunshine hours] statistics Nelsonians don't just read about; they're statistics we live. (Jun 22, 2008,Sunday Star Times: Escape,6)

.. Nelsonian (1850,Stafford Papers,44,1843 ed.)

WAKEFIELD The Transalpine Nelsonian. (1851,Letter,13) [NOTES: 1851 EJ Wakefield Letter to Sir George Grey 13]

MARKS ... the Nelsonians gave us all the encouragement and cheer they could. (1934,Memories (Mainly Merry),35)

CRESSWELL Everyone knows he was a Nelsonian and took his title from that town, ... (1951,Canterbury Tales,95)

MUIR `Good old Nelsonians. Can't miss a chance to plug the sunshine, can you?' (1960,Word for Word,114)

MILLER The religion of many Nelsonians seems to have been of a simple, non-controversial character, `plain but good and improving in its applications'. (1958,Early Victorian NZ,180)

MANTELL Behind him, Steven could hear subdued whisperings from a surprising number of curious Nelsonians. (1980,Murder and Chips,5)

HENDERSON Oh, the ruby ripe gooseberries of Christchurch, the shelling of green peas every true Nelsonian loves, ... (1981,Exiles of Asbestos Cottage, The,82)

adj. [[?nonce]]

CRAWFORD There is a Nelsonic absence of wind [in Havelock]. (1880,Travels in NZ,262)

n.

Oh, you're from Sleepy Hollow...Nelsonites rise to the bait. (Nov 15, 1916,Chronicles NZEF,I/6 : 134)

WAITE Thirty men of the Nelsons were at once doubled over to assist the Indians. (1919,New Zealanders at Gallipoli,54)

neotribe¶

n.

Rata introduced her concept that today's cultural divisiveness results from the rise of the "neotribe", a political organisation fundamentatlly different from the traditional tribe .. evolved from treaty settlements which enable them to privatise and capatalise resourses, and build not just resourses. (Feb 20, 2005,Sunday Star Times,C2)

nephrite¶

n. [for pounamu, greenstone, 'nephrite jade']

SHORTLAND In Phillip's Mineralogy this stone [pounamu] is described under the name of Nephrite, .. (1851,Southern Districts of NZ,38)

HAAST They did not possess implements of greenstone (Nephrite). (1879,Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland,430)

It is called pounamu or poenamu by the Maoris, and jade,'jadeite,' or nephrite,' by various writers, while old books refer to thegreen talc' of the Maoris. (1892,TrNZI,24/481)

TREGEAR The Maori greenstone (pounamu) called jade, jadeite, nephrite, etc., by Europeans, is a mineral very restricted in its deposits. ... one variety (tangiwai) is found at Milford Sound. (1904,Maori Race, The,248)

Pounamu (Nephrite, or Greenstone). - Used for ornamnental purposes. (1918,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,1/36)

ELDER Ninety-nine per cent. of genuine tikis are made of nephrite,the lighter and more translucent varieties of the stone beingpreferred. (1932,Letters & Journals of Samuel Marsden,432,1932 ed.)

BUCK Doubtless many of the nephrite implements found have been concealed in former times ... (1937,Moa-Hunters of NZ,205) [NOTES: fn quoting Best Stone Implements of the Maori 172]

The Natives are very fond of New-Zeeland green stones [ed. fn nephrite], of mother of Pearl-Shells ... (1982,Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The,IV/608) [NOTES: 1982 note in 1774 Aug 17 Forster Resolution Journal (1982) IV/608]

(Oct 4, 1864,Lyttelton Times,2) [NOTES: Nephrite (Greenstone of the Maoris), in rolled pieces, on teh beach of the West coast.]

Besides these there is heitiki, or nephrite neck ornament, and a carved tahaia, or staff of manuka. (Aug 24, 1880,Colonist, The,2)

Neptune's necklace¶

n. = Venus' necklace

CROWE Neptune's necklace Hormosira banksii... A well-known seaweed up to 50 cm high, made up of pimply olive-brown hollow beads, each usually about 1 cm across. (1997,Field Guide to Native Edible Plants of NZ,149)

CROWE Neptune's necklace Hormosira banksii... A well-known seaweed up to 50 cm high, made up of pimply olive-brown hollow beads, each usually about 1 cm across. (1997,Field Guide to Native Edible Plants of NZ,149)

CROWE Neptune's necklace Hormosira banksii... A well-known seaweed up to 50 cm high, made up of pimply olive-brown hollow beads, each usually about 1 cm across. (1997,Field Guide to Native Edible Plants of NZ,149)

CROWE Neptune's necklace Hormosira banksii... A well-known seaweed up to 50 cm high, made up of pimply olive-brown hollow beads, each usually about 1 cm across. (1997,Field Guide to Native Edible Plants of NZ,149)

CROWE Neptune's necklace Hormosira banksii... A well-known seaweed up to 50 cm high, made up of pimply olive-brown hollow beads, each usually about 1 cm across. (1997,Field Guide to Native Edible Plants of NZ,149)

CROWE Neptune's necklace Hormosira banksii... A well-known seaweed up to 50 cm high, made up of pimply olive-brown hollow beads, each usually about 1 cm across. Ibid. 150 When the incidence of goitre was high in New Zealand, a schoolteacher here claimed to have appreciably reduced the goitre incidence in his school by getting the children to eat one 'bead' of Neptune's necklace a day. (1997,Field Guide to Native Edible Plants of NZ,149)

HULME & MORRISON Neptune's necklace (again, just 'rimu') is tangy when you nibble it, and so are the young tips of rimuroa (bladderweed). (1989,Homeplaces,61)

MARTIN Fig.1. Seaweeds of the intertidal belt, Stewart Island, here consisting mainly of Bull-kelp (Durvillea), Strap-weed ( Xiphophora), Moss-weed ( Bostrychia), Neptune's Necklace ( Hormosira), and Sea Bombs [sic] ( Adenocystis). (1961,Flora NZ,4,1929 ed.)

DEMPSEY Every shallow pool is a garden of seaweed, with long ruffles of sea lettuce, carrageen and Neptune's necklace. (1964,Little World of Stewart island,25)

NATUSCH Hansard ... could see [in Otago Harbour] large chitons and delicate seaweed overhung with beads of a coral-like growth - perhaps the seaweed that children call `Neptune's necklace'. (1978,Cruise of the Acheron,109)

BURTON Other edible varieties of seaweed commomly used by the Maori include rimurapu or bull kelp (Durvillea antarctica), which was also dried and then boiled with tutu juice to form a jelly, and the beaded Neptune's (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,9)

WILSON Hormosira banksii NEPTUNE'S NECKLACE ... Venus' necklace ... Necklace seaweed ... Brown or yellow-brown strings of thick-walled bladders, flopped over rocks ... at low tide. necklace ( Hormosira banksii), which is palatable raw. (1982,Stewart Island Plants,318)

He's got a James Bond cheekiness about him and the presence of a couple of nerdettes adds a bit of slap and tickle. (Nov 19, 2003,Capital Times,14)

A caller says that..he heard a commentator describe a batsman's pathetic attempts to keep the ball from hitting his stumps as nerdling. Asked for the origin of the unfamiliar word, the commentator claimed it had something to do with cider-making. (Mar 27, 1999,Dominion,16)

nest of gold¶

n. see cit.

Another piece showed a nest of gold about an inch square. This stone is still more closely impregnated with gold. (Nov 21, 1867,Daily Southern Cross,3)

It is very common in quartz-specimens to get what is called a nest of gold, which generally consists of one large speck surrounded by a number of smaller ones at various distances from it. (1890,TrNZI,22/401)

nester¶

n. a dog trained to find rabbits' nests

n. a baby rabbit, still in the breeding nest [farming]

McCASKILL Rabbiters ... would receive a bonus for 1s. on each large skin and 4d. on each nester (1969,Molesworth,160)

1 n. (Rural) a dog that is skilled at uncovering rabbit breeding nests. [rabbiting]

LOUGHNAN nester: a dog in the rabbiter's pack skilled in finding the rabbits' breeding nests. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,55)

Nester: Dog for finding rabbits' breeding nests. Most rabbiters have one in their pack. (C.) (Nov 11, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

nester: (?obs) a dog for finding rabbits' nests or breeding places. (1980,Goldie Brown Collection)

nesting mussel¶

n.

Most of the others [sc. mussels] - flea mussels, mud mussels, date mussels and nesting mussels - are too small to be worthy of the pot. (Feb 19, 1994,Listener (New Zealand Listener),58)

WILSON NESTING MUSSEL (Ryenella impacta) gets its name from the fact that it `spins' a nest of byssus thread and lives communally in a large matt-like group. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,169)

nestor¶

n.

HAY Pigeons, nestors, parrots, rail, kiwi, swamp-fowl, water-fowl, owls, parson-birds, all these and more were eaten; while the native dogs and rats were held to be great dainties. (1882,Brighter Britain,2/151)

2 n. kaka

DIEFFENBACH Before it was quite dark, flights of the Austral Nestor passed over our encampment, shrieking in a dismal manner, and alighted for a moment on one of the dead trees ... (1843,Travels in NZ,2/151)

net-fungus¶

n. a fungus whose mature form is of a ball-shaped net or lattice, also called basket-fungus, fairy's closet (See fungus)

net-gun¶

n. [deerhunters]

But may I suggest that in a future edition [of the Collins English Dictionary two more New Zealand words which are associated with deer hunting be included, namely net -gun', and the verb `to bulldog'. (Apr 5, 1987,Dunedin Star Weekender,16)

1 n. (Rural) a capture gun, incorporating a net, used for live deer capture.

FORRESTER .. the method was superseded by the net-gun. Net-guns made on old .303 Lee Enfield actions would mostly blow up or disintegrate with constant firing ... (1983,Chopper Boys, The,63)

FORRESTER .. around ten helicopters shot themselves down in a very short space of time with these hand-held net-guns. (1983,Chopper Boys, The,65)

nettle¶

n. native nettles Urtica spp. esp. U. ferox (?= U. incisa) (See ongaonga)

Amongst the known kinds of plants are common and rough Bindweed, [ed. fn 4 Probably Calystegia sepium and the smaller C. turguriorum.] Nightshade [author's fnd Solanum Linnaei. [ed. note [Probably Solanum aviculare, described by Forster from Queen Charlotte Sound: ...]]] and Nettles, [fne Urtica [ed. [Urtica ferox]]] both which grow to the size of small trees; a shruby [sic] Speedwell ... (1777,Cook's Journals,3/804-805) [NOTES: Queen Charlotte Sound1777 Feb Anderson's Journal in Cook Journals (1967)]

The gardens [of Totoe's village at the mouth of the Mataura] were kept very clear from weeds; Nettles grow in abundance, and it is said that this alone is [63] a proof of the goodness of theland. (1986,Boultbee Journal,62,1986 ed.)

HOOKER The New Zealand Nettles are similar in general appearance to the English, but quite different specifically. As a genus Urtica is known by its small unisexual flowers ... (1853,Flora NZ,I Flowering Plants 224)

HOOKER Nettle. Urtica, various sp. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),766)

Nettle.Urtica incisa, Poiret (1869,TrNZI,1/III/48) [NOTES: Buchanan Botany Otago]

Urtica incisa nettle (1870,TrNZI,2)

Urtica ferox nettle (1896,Dunedin Field Club Plant Catalogues)

2 n. tree(-)nettle (see also nettle-tree) [cf and stinging tree 1827] x-ref only now at tree-nettle]

Urtica ferox tree-nettle (1903,TrNZI,35)

CHEESEMAN Urtica ferox tree-nettle (1906,NZ Flora) [NOTES: And.]

(1907,TrNZI) [NOTES: Andersen]

Urtica ferox tree-nettle (1921,NZ Journal of Science & Technology) [NOTES: And.]

One plant of which the extinction would not be a matter for regret is the tree-nettle (Urtica ferox). (1922,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,4/281) [NOTES: Bathgate, Otago)]

nettle, tree [s] Urtica ferox Forst.f. Ibid. 80 tree nettle [s] Urtica ferox Forst.f. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,52)

MOORE & IRWIN URTICA FEROX, ongaonga. The tree nettle can form great thickets taller than a man. Pale stinging hairs on leaves and stems are poisonous, a real danger to horses and dogs. (1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,82)

It is possible to proceed ..., but beware of the native tree nettle, ongaonga! Here [at Nugget Point, South Otago] is the habitat of the world's rarest penguin: the yellow-eyed penguin. (1988,Pacific Way,48)

McLINTOCK Tree nettle .. .. ongaonga .. .. Urtica ferox (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

  1. various introduced nettles, esp. of Urtica spp. see also DEAD NETTLE, RED DEAD NETTLE a. U. urens, (ANNUAL) NETTLE (1907,AJHR) [NOTES: Cockayne Report on a Botanical Survey of Kapiti Island (And)]

nettle [s] Urtica urens L. ... nettle, annual [=] nettle [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,52)

TAYLOR NETTLE (Urtica urens) ... This cosmopolitan plant, introduced to New Zealand, is common in the South Island, Wellington Province and Hawke's Bay, but less common further north.. . (1981,Weeds of Lawns,77)

2 n. Urtica ferox, =NETTLE(-TREE) (?growing like a bush; ?in the or at the edge of the BUSH A1)

The native fuchsia [fn Fuchsia excorticata.] - an exile from South America - and the fierce bush-nettle [fn Urtica ferox.] are conspicuous amongst the undergrowth, together with the bush-lily [fn Astelia nervosa.], but we see but few species of the characteristic New Zealand daisy-trees [fn Species of Olearia.] or of the bushy Veronicas (koromiko), which are so conspicuous in other parts of these islands. (1900,Canterbury Old & New,184)

2 n. Urtica linearifolia

The rare divaricating (branching at very wide angles) species Coprosma pedicellata, Olearia gardneri, Coprosma wallii and Urtica linearifolia (swamp nettle) were planted in previously weed-infested areas in Carter and Lowes Bush scenic reserves. (Oct 2003,Footnotes,No. 20/7)

2 n. ?Urtica incisa [WDJ, 1850.]

2 n.

LAING & BLACKWELL Urtica ferox fierce nettle (1906,Plants of NZ)

SANSOM Herekopare and Woman's Island are the only two beneficiary muttonbird islands. All the rest are Crown lands. ... I know ... that the fierce nettle also grows on Herekopare. Other lovely ... plants are there too - the Stewart Island yellow senecio, teteaweka of course, ... Cook's health-giving scurvy grass, soft native tatahi grass and punui, the giant-leafed umbrella-like araliad. (1982,In the Grip of an Island,69)

McNAB All the trees keep a continual verdure all the year. I saw nettle (?)[McNab's query] trees here of 9 and 10 inches round. (1908,Historical Records,2/206) [NOTES: 1773 April 12 Bayly's Journal in 1908 McNab Historical Records 2/206 [?ghost: McNab is doubtful of the ?form or ?meaning; are there nettle trees so-called in e.g. the West Indies that Bayly might be thinking of?]]

2 n.

HUDSON (1898,NZ Moths & Butterflies) [NOTES: And.]

2 n. staggerweed

HILGENDORF STAGGERWEED (Stachys arvensis), also called by its English name[s] of wound wort and hedge nettle, is found abundantly in cultivated fields in the North Island and is one of the worst garden weeds in Wellington. [and less frequently in various parts of the South Island.] It is an annual with stem branched from the base,. . . The leaves are nearly heart-shaped up to an inch long, and sparingly hairy. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,149)
