nettle-leaved¶

adj. (See fat hen,goosefoot)

nettle-tree¶

n. Urtica ferox ongaonga, tree-nettle

R TAYLOR The nettle-tree, a singular but disagreeable shrub attains a height of about twelve feet, its long, narrow leaf is covered with large white spines very sharp and painful if touched (1846,Journal,IV/117)

TAYLOR We passed by a nettle tree which the old chief [100] immediately cut down as being a very disagreeable thing for naked feet to come near. (May 25, 1849,Journal,6/99)

Urtica ferox. nettle tree HMB, 1898. (1869,TrNZI,1)

Nettle tree. Urtica ferox, Forst. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/48) [NOTES: Buchanan Botany Otago]

nettle-tree n. several trees the leaves of which possess rigid stinging hairs. (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,8)

nettle-tree n. large scrub tree with broad leaves and virulent stinging hairs. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),621)

nettle-tree large scrub tree with broad leaves and virulent stinging hairs. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),14)

BAYLY All the trees keep a continual verdure all the year. I saw nettle (?)[McNab's query] trees here of 9 and 10 inches round. (Apr 12, 1773,Journal) [NOTES: 1773 April 12 Bayly's Journal in 1908 McNabHistorical Records 2/206 [?ghost: McNab is doubtful of the ?form or ?meaning; are there nettle trees so-called in e.g. the West Indies that Bayly might be thinking of?]]

netty¶

n.

LYNN The old Privy ... WC ... Lavatory ... Dunney ... Netty ... Little House ... Little House at the Bottom of the Garden ... or any one of the countless names it was called, ... - (1982,Under the Lynnwood Tree,125)

neuter-athon¶

n.

Activities, such as the neuter-athon, resulted in complaints of professional misconduct to the Veterinary Council (they were not upheld). (Feb 2005,North & South,68)

During the annual week long neuter-athon to reduce the wild cat population Ward-Mcgrath does about 600 free castrations. The tom with the biggest testicles wins two months' supply of cat food. (Feb 2005,North & South,68)

never-never¶

n. [never-nevers, never never, never nevers]

A shearer comes along with a cheque for 80 or 100 [pounds], gives it to the publican, gets rapidly drunk, and then drunker, and then D.T.'s and then wakes up and goes back into the never-never to rake up another cheque. (Oct 3, 1908,NZ Truth,172/4/5)

THOMSON To have lived such an open life and then to be suddenly caged up in an enclosure such as this Army camp often tempted me to make a break for the never-never, ... (1952,Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker,108)

never-never n. the thinly populated country far from settlement, esp. in Western Queensland and the Northern Territory. [prob. fr. Abor. (Comderio) nie-vah vahs, unoccupied land] (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),621)

Never Never n. the sparsely populated far outback, the back-blocks. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),14)

never-never ... NZ & Austral. any remote area, esp. land beyond backblocks in central Australia. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,505) [NOTES: cf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 758; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 327]

THOMSON The other four shooters were out on the job for a few more days fly-camping, so the two of us had the first night in the never-nevers to ourselves, ... (1952,Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker,32)

n.

new¶

adj. >in various uses in NZ relating to Pakeha immigration and settlement [cf AND New 1. with nouns denoting land, country, settlement not previously occupied by white people 1835 2. with nouns denoting recently arrived new settler

New Zealand violet¶

n.

new bell¶

n. new boy [ca1943 Wellington Boys' College (H.S. Gajadhar)]

new bug¶

n. new boy [1951 14 M 14 St Bede's, Chch 25 NEW BUGS -->1951 16-18 M 26 Marlborough C. 25 NEW BUGS (5) -->1960 16C F B1 Nelson Girls C. 25 NEW-BUGS -->1951 14-16 M 59 Wellington H.S. 25 NEW BUGS]

HENDERSON But curiously enough, someone considered [at Nelson Boys' College] a dag',a bit of a one', `a rough diamond', could get away with a lot, even a lowly new bug; ... [c1930s] (1983,Down from Marble Mountain,148)

new chum¶

n. a newly arrived settler or immigrant; a novice [See 1871 citation]

"Aw, may I awsk what a colonial is?" said a supercillious new chum the other day to a full-blooded Aucklander in Queen-st. "Certainly, a colonial is an Englishman," was the answer, "with all the modern improvements." (Apr 2, 1887,Te Aroha News,2)

New chums come and go in great numbers. (Nov 14, 1855,Nelson Examiner,2)

They naturally think they are equally as worthy attention as new chums. (Apr 12, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,6)

Mr. Singleton is a recent arrival in the colony - a new chum, so to speak. (Oct 4, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,19)

Our driver.. was a bit of a "new chum" at the wheel. (Apr 1, 1924,Otago Witness,72)

SIR,- Some numbers of your paper, containing an effusion of two from a new chum, y'clept "A Pilgrim of the Plains," have just reached this out-of-the-way place. (Feb 4, 1854,Lyttelton Times,7)

One of the party (our new chum, who would wear a coat) not being used to river wading got giddy when he had reached the middle, and decalred he should fall, and could not go a step further; when losing both his nerve and balance at the same time, he was carried off his feet and floated down the river. (Jan 20, 1863,Colonist (Nelson),3)

"Well I don't wonder at a new chum like you, fresh from the drawing rooms of Belgravia, being surprised at anything you see out here," replied Harold Courtney, in a tone of veiled sarcasm; "but if you knew the circumstances you would understand that his marrying a Maori wife and settling down at Stratford was the easiest and most natural thing in the world." (Dec 15, 1896,Observer (Auckland),17)

As he is, comparatively, a new chum, he clearly was not aware of the conditions when the bridge was built. (Jul 23, 1904,Wanganui Chronicle,2)

I am - a New Chum. My business is to critcise, moralise upon, compare, sketch, and, where necessary, correct or praise the peculiarities of my adopted countrymen. First, then, arises this question: what is a 'New Chum'? and it may be answered in two ways, according to the manner in which it is asked. For there is a real New Chum; and there is a New Chum that is ideal only. The New Chum proper, is, I understand, a person who has but freshly come to the Colony from some part or other of the old world. The New chum that most colonists, here, appear to have in their mind's eye, is quite a different being in most cases. He is a pattern of neatness and elegance in his dress; of cheek and superciliousness in his deportment; of ignorance, meanness, cowardice, spiritlessness, vagueness, helplessness in time of emergency, vanity, presumption, and emptiness, in his temperament; and of all these vices, combined with effeminate and pedantic precision, in his talk. His delight is to abuse colonial customs; to run down the local 'bigwigs'; to show contempt for the industries and pursuits of the colonists generally; and affect a languid indifference to the matters which most engage their interest. His purse is even emptier than his head. He is without resources and without pluck. His ambition is at once low and unreasonable. he puts his trust in letters of introduction, and looks for a Government billet. (Aug 30, 1871,Timaru Herald,6)

CARR ... the sooner a `New Chum' loses his identity as such, the better for himself. (1913,Country Work,5)

1 n. (Rural) an initiate, or one inexperienced in farming.

To their credit .. farmers out here are ever willing to teach a 'new chum ... ' (Aug 27, 1864,Weekly News,7)

BARKER A stranger, or colonially speaking, a 'new chum' would have thought we must needs cross that barrier-range before we could penetrate any distance into the back-country ... (1873,Station Amusements in NZ,63)

BATHGATE If an unfortunate new chum ventures mildly to protest against some trifling hardships, he is at once silenced by being told that it is evident that he is not 'colonised' yet and that he must get used to such things. (1874,Colonial Experiences,8)

There are of course, new-chums and new-chums; we speak of those who come out to the colony burning with British eagerness to own land and cultivate it. (Aug 1882,Northern New Zealand Settler,3)

STUDHOLME A new chum who was working at the station had a theory that a beast would not charge if one turned his back on it.. (1940,Te Waimate,137)

MULGAN In New Zealand the joke is rather on the 'new chum' who shows his ignorance of country life like the Bulletin's English visitor to the sheep station who shoots his host's prize ram in the belief that it is a wild animal. (1946,Pastoral NZ,94)

WILSON Altogether the neighbours, so critical of 'new chums' formed a high opinion of him. (1955,Land of My Children,170)

If he succeeds in satisfying his companion that he is fit to be trusted alone, our new chum will presently be sent off on a sweep of this own ... At this preliminary stage of a muster men often work in pairs, and the new chum will be sent with an old hand. (Apr 13, 1955,Weekly News,34)

KERR They [Merinos] roamed far in the days before fences, and mustering was difficult. The new chum found to his cost that 'they'd rush for miles at the sound of a bark, and you would have a pile up and a smother on your hands.' (1976,From the Beginning: chronicles of a county,131)

STACEY His [harvesting] fork was his own and tapu'd an inch thick. Lord help any new chum who had the impudence to touch it. [newch'm] (1996,Tales of a Tussock Jumper,41)

new chum dam¶

n. (See swinging rafter dam)

new chum gold¶

n. [also new chums' gold]

COOPER Many new comers are misled by the abundance of mica and mundie [sic], which is consequently called `new chums' gold', and it is difficult to convince them that they have not got theprecious metal. (Nov 12, 1867,Digger's Diary,12,1978 ed.)

PAULIN The sand [in Dusky Sound] ... glittered with scales of yellow mica. It is sometimes called New Chum Gold, as, seeing it for the first time, one can hardly believe it is not the precious metal itself. (1889,Wild West Coast,14)

When the battered dish flowed empty, bar a tail of new-chum gold,/ Or it gave a ring of colour' that betokened wealth untold. <i>(1985,Penguin Book of NZ Verse,93</i>) [NOTES: c1890-1900 EDWIN EDWARDSWaitekauri Every Time' in 1985 Penguin Book of NZ Verse 93]

THOMSON We found traces of gold at different places, golden mica, known as new chum gold, and two types of pyrites. (1952,Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker,73)

new chummy¶

adj.

I think the price asked depends in a great measure upon the appearance of the purchaser - those with a `new chummy' look paying through the nose ... (Jan 18, 1862,Otago Witness) [NOTES: 1861 Dec 16 C.M.O. to Lyttelton Times in 1862 Jan 18 Otago Witness (Griffiths Collection)]

new chumship¶

n.

BUTLER ... I was anxious to become an old chum, as colonial dialect calls a settler - thereby proving my new chumship most satisfactorily. (1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,iv : 55)

New Edinburgh¶

n. (Dunedin) [cf. Edinburgh of the South]

IRVINE & ALPERS Colonel Wakefield.. had in 1844commissioned Frederick Tuckett, asurveyor and engineer.. to examine theeastern coast of the Middle Island with aview to selecting a site for the "NewEdinburgh" settlement. (1902,Progress of NZ in the 20th Century,167)

new egg¶

n. a new boy [1951 14 M 14 St Bede's, Chch 25 NEW EGGS]

New Enzedder¶

n. a non-British immigrant

[Hdg] Truculent "New Enzedders." (Jan 2, 1951,NZ Truth,6)

The [Prime Minister's] visit [to a Danish immigrant girl in Adelaide] originated a new phrase, New Enzedder', which Mr Holland said would become the equivalent ofNew Australian'. Thegirl said to Mr Holland: You can't call us new New Zealanders; it's too clumsy. Why not NewEnzedders?'That is excellent.' said Mr Holland. `we will use it'. (Jun 18, 1952,Evening Post)

new fart¶

n. a new boy [1951 15 M 9 St Bede's, Chch 25 NEW FART]

new fish¶

n. a new boy [1953 16-17M A39 Thames DHS 25 NEW FISH -->1951 14-16 M 59 Wellington H.S. 25 NEW FISH]

new fry¶

n. a new boy [1951 16-18 M 26 Marlborough C. 25 NEW FRY]

new hand¶

n. new chum; not an old hand

WAKEFIELD A new hand, pulling one of the oars, begins to look frightened .... a volley of oaths from the headsman accompanies a threat to `break every bone in his skin if he funks now'. (1845,Adventure in NZ,1/327)

Of course, Mr. T. is a new hand here and knows nothing of the particular case. I am sure no old hand could have so written. (1871,McLean Papers,37/161)

New Holland¶

n. an early name for Australia

WILLIAMS Mr. Marsden entered with much apparent interest, upon the idea of a New Zealand settlement in Port Jackson; that is to say, within the Colony. ... [We think] that it should not be within one hundred miles of Sydney; that the natives should not be subject to visits from the curious intruders, ... [May 5 54] The natives have had much conversation, relative to the projected settlement in New Holland; ... They wish to be distinct from the whites or blacks, to retain their own teachers... (Apr 9, 1827,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,51,1961 ed.)

New Holland n. (now only historical) name given to Australia by first Dutch explorers. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),621)

new iniquity¶

n. the newcomers (espec. miners) to Dunedin in the 1860s. (contrast OLD IDENTITY) [(obs. Otago) often pl. constr. in sg. usually with the.]

In our celebrations of the arrival of theOld Identities, we overlook the all-important fact that had it not been forthe advent of the digger, that "newiniquity".. our Dominion would not sospeedily have attained the forwardposition she new occupies. (Dec 30, 1909,Otago Daily Times,8)

BATHGATE [Old Identity] was the name applied by the people of Victoria, who flocked hither in thousands on the discovery of gold [in 1862], to those who had been in the province before that time. Those honest folks, the tenour of whose ways had previously been very even, were greatly startled by this immense and sudden influx of population. 16,000 persons landed in three months, andeverything went up to worse than famine prices. It is alleged that one minister actually prayed that the stream of rogues and vagabonds which was flowing into the country might be stayed, but this I believe to have been a base invention of the `new iniquity', as the new-comers were nicknamed. (1874,Colonial Experiences,25)

REEVES The canny Scotch old identity' was swallowed up in thenew iniquity', as they mutually styled each other. (1892,Homeward Bound,3)

`the new iniquity' was the Otago settlers' name for the unwelcome Australian immigrants who arrived in the 60's; ... (Apr 2, 1938,Press, The,18) [NOTES: McNab NZ Slang]

AYSON Thomas had had a taste of `the new iniquity' before leaving for the goldfields. An old couple named Reid lived in a sod hut on the outskirts of Milton. (1937,Thomas,33)

PARTRIDGE New Iniquity. Australian immigrants: New Zealand (mostly Otago): coll.: ca. 1862-80. Opp. old identity, q.v. at identity. Morris. (1937,Dictionary of Slang,557)

SINCLAIR Dunedin became the largest town in the country, while, to the horror of the Old Identity', saloons, billiard rooms, gambling dens and dance halls sprang up to attract the gold of theNew Iniquity'. (1959,History of New Zealand,104)

MCGILL new iniquity immigrants, specifically from Australia to the Otago goldrush areas, 1860s to 1880s; the opposite of `old identity'. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,75)

2 n. (non-Otago) a newcomer to a neighbourhood (as part of an influx)

[Wanganui] We got new doctors ... lawyers ... Jew pedlars ... et hoc genus omne, and this infusion of `new iniquities' has fairly bedeviled the place. (Jul 3, 1871,Evening Post,2)

New Leinster¶

n. Stewart('s) Island (see also MIDDLE ISLAND) see also cit. NEW ZEALAND 1859 [hist.]

And we do hereby declare, that from henceforth the said islands shall be known and designated as the colony of New Zealand, and the principal islands, heretofore known as or commonly called the Northern Island', theMiddle Island', and Stewart's Island', shall henceforth be designated and known respectively asNew Ulster', New Munster', andNew Leinster'. 1840 Letters Patent isusued on 16 November: quoted from The Ordinances of New Zealand, Domett 1850 pp.4-8 in 1971 Speeches and Documents 54 And we do hereby declare, that from henceforth the said Islands shall be known and designated as the Colony of New Zealand, and the principal Islands,here to fore known as, or commonly called, the Northern Island,' theMiddle Island,' and Stewart's Island,' shall henceforward be designated and known respectively asNew Ulster,' New Munster,' andNew Leinster.' ... (Nov 16, 1840,Charter for Erecting the Colony of NZ) [NOTES: in 1949 Rutherford ed. Select Documents 8]

New Munster¶

n. the South Island (see also MIDDLE ISLAND) see also cit. NEW ZEALAND 1859 [sic - ? 1840 Letters Patent issued on 16 November: quoted from The Ordinances of New Zealand, Domett 1850

RUTHERFORD And we do hereby declare, that from henceforth the said Islands shall be known and designated as the Colony of New Zealand, and the principal Islands, here to fore known as, or commonly called, the Northern Island,' theMiddle Island,' and Stewart's Island,' shall henceforward be designated and known respectively asNew Ulster,' New Munster,' andNew Leinster.' ... (1971,Speeches & Documents,54)

And we do hereby declare, that from henceforth the said islands shall be known and designated as the colony of New Zealand, and the principal islands, heretofore known as or commonly called the Northern Island', theMiddle Island', and Stewart's Island', shall henceforth be designated and known respectively asNew Ulster', New Munster', andNew Leinster'. (Nov 16, 1840,Charter for Erecting the Colony of NZ,8)

WAKEFIELD On 28th January, 1848, [Grey] appointed and swore in some of the officers of the Southern Province, which is called New Munster'; and on the 10th of March proclaimed as the boundary between that andNew Ulster', or the Northern Province, the parallel of latitude running ... about 39[degrees] 46' S. (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,86)

New Zealand is divided into two provinces, New Ulster, and New Munster, each of which is under a Lieutenant-Governor, who enacts ordinances for the province over which he presides, with the advice of a Legislative Council, composed of the officers of Government, together with a few persons nominated by the crown from amongst the inhabitants. A Governor-in-Chief rules the whole of New Zealand and is assisted in his legislation by a Council constituted similarly to the provincial Councils. At present, the Governor-in-Chief holds the subordinate office of Lieutenant-Governor of New Ulster , in addition to his higher Commission: and Mr Eyre is the Lieutenant of New Munster, the southern province. (Feb 1, 1851,Lyttelton Times,2)

New Plymouth nuts¶

n. (recipe)

NEW PLYMOUTH NUTS ... butter ... golden syrup. Melt ... add ... soda ... boiling water ... sugar ... flour ... cocoanut ... wheatweal. Place small daubs ... bake ... These have a flavour all their own. (1938,Souvenir Book of Cookery Recipes,44)

new settler¶

n.

A large contingent of new settlersreached Wellington on Sunday evening bythe steamer Corinthic from England. (Jan 11, 1927,Otago Daily Times,8)

A further 327 new settlers, due here inthe Rangitata next week, include 237 menand women who have been granted eitherfree or assisted passages. (Jul 23, 1948,Southern Cross (Wgton),00)

BARRY In a comparatively short time the whole of the area was sold to the `new settlers' as they were called by those already farming north of the Mataura-Glendhu road. (1966,In the Lee of the Hokonuis,161)

New Ulster¶

n. the North Island (cf also MIDDLE ISLAND) see also cit. NEW ZEALAND 1859 1840 Letters Patent issued on 16 November:

We were here first - we called the place New Munster, New Leinster, New Ulster, but being paddies we forgot to write it down. (1992,Listener (New Zealand Listener),30) [NOTES: Check month and day]

RUTHERFORD And we do hereby declare, that from henceforth the said Islands shall be known and designated as the Colony of New Zealand, and the principal Islands, here to fore known as, or commonly called, the Northern Island,' theMiddle Island,' and Stewart's Island,' shall henceforward be designated and known respectively asNew Ulster,' New Munster,' andNew Leinster.' ... (1971,Speeches & Documents,54) [NOTES: quoted from The Ordinances of New Zealand, Domett 1850 pp.4-8 in 1971 Speeches and Documents 54]

And we do hereby declare, that from henceforth the said islands shall be known and designated as the colony of New Zealand, and the principal islands, heretofore known as or commonly called the Northern Island', theMiddle Island', and Stewart's Island', shall henceforth be designated and known respectively asNew Ulster', New Munster', andNew Leinster'. (Nov 16, 1840,Charter for Erecting the Colony of NZ) [NOTES: 1840 Nov 16 Charter for Erecting the Colony of NZ in 1949 Rutherford ed. Select Documents 8]

JAMESON Governor Hobson has recently given to the three Islands of New Zealand the names. New Ulster, New Munster and New Leinster; but as no reference is made in recemt communications to these appellations, which are not very euphonious, and are certainly rather perplexing, from the similarily of their terminations, it would appear they are not calculated to please the public taste (1841,New Zealand, S. Aust. and NSW,319)

TERRY [Quoting the Charter, 31st December, 1841] The principal islands' heretofore known as, orcommonly called theNorthern Island', the Middle Island', andStewart's Island' shall henceforward be designated, and known respectively, as New Ulster',New Munster', and `New Leinster'. (1842,New Zealand (various authors/titles),31)

WAKEFIELD On 28th January, 1848, [Grey] appointed and swore in some of the officers of the Southern Province, which is called New Munster'; and on the 10th of March proclaimed as the boundary between that andNew Ulster', or the Northern Province, the parallel of latitude running ... about 39[degrees] 46' S. ] (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,86)

New Zealand is divided into two provinces, New Ulster, and New Munster, each of which is under a Lieutenant-Governor, who enacts ordinances for the province over which he presides, with the advice of a Legislative Council, composed of the officers of Government, together with a few persons nominated by the crown from amongst the inhabitants. A Governor-in-Chief rules the whole of New Zealand and is assisted in his legislation by a Council constituted similarly to the provincial Councils. At present, the Governor-in-Chief holds the subordinate office of Lieutenant-Governor of New Ulster, in addition to his higher Commission: and Mr Eyre is the Lieutenant of New Munster, the southern province. (Feb 1, 1851,Lyttelton Times,2)

New Z.¶

n. New Zealand [ORIGIN: abbreviation]

... the cart being the most extraordinary in New Z. (Jan 26, 1862,Chudleigh Diary,27,1950 ed.)

n. New Zealand [ORIGIN: abbreviation]

REVANS New Z. Library (1839,Letter,12) [NOTES: 1839 Revans to Chapman 12]

... the most extraordinary in New Z. (Jan 26, 1862,Chudleigh Diary,27,ed. Richards 1950 ed.)

I had our map of New Z. pinned to one of the struts. (Nov 8, 1850,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/71,1960 ed.) [NOTES: ? J.C. Richmond]

New Zealand¶

n. (historical) the New Zealand language (Maori)

BUTLER We had prayers both in New Zealand and English. The Natives were very attentive and repeated the sentences in New Zealand correctly. (1823,Journals and Correspondence,252,ed. Barton ed.)

Since I left England I have only studied New Zealand and Hebrew, and have found no kind ofdifficulty with these. (Sep 1, 1843,Letter) [NOTES: 1843 Sep 1 letter in 1969 Macmorran Octavius Hadfield 181]

adj. As an attributive from the Country's name, it had in very early times, a connotation NATIVE, MAORI (cf NEW ZEALANDER) often with suggestions of roughness, wildness, or barbarism. It was quickly adapted (see 1840 entry) to include the white settlers and the civilised homeland they were preparing, a sense and use which obliterated the earlier. Many uses (eg New Zealand Company (1839), New Zealand Gazette) were merely defining, and had, of themselves, no racial reference.

We had not yet sufficient experience of New Zealand troops to trust them too far.' (Oct 6, 1769,Cook's Journals,1/570,1955 ed.) [NOTES: 1769 Oct 6 W.B. Monkhouse Journal in Cook's Journals (1955)]

`New Zealand War Canoes bidd defiance to the Ship' (1955,Cook's Journals,facing 1/208) [NOTES: 1769 Sydney Parkinson Caption to a drawing in B.M. Add. MS. 23920 50 in 1955 Cook's Journals facing 1/208]

FORSTER The New-Zeeland ladies never failed to put on the same kind of rouge mixed with grease, before they come on board to offer their uncouth favours to our sailors. (1778,Observations Made During a Voyage,591)

ELDER `11th. - In the evening Terra told us that he made a fire to cook potatoes and to eat a New Zealand man. (Aug 11, 1815,Marsden's Lieutenants,107,1934 ed.) [NOTES: 1815 Aug 11 John King in Elder Marsden's Lieutenants (1934) 107]

McCRAE While the ship was under weigh Morachie and Echoie two remarkably fine looking New Zealand boys ... came on board to take leave of their friends. (1820,Journal,12,1928 ed.)

CRUISE During our visit to Benny, he entered into a long argument, to prove the superiority of the New Zealand arms over the British firelock; ... (1823,Journal,60,1957 ed.) [NOTES: 1820 Mar 20 in 1823 Cruise Journal (1957) 60]

CRUISE During our visit to Benny, he entered into a long argument, to prove the superiority of the New Zealand arms over the British firelock; ... (1823,Journal,60,1957 ed.) [NOTES: 1820 Mar 20 in 1823 Cruise Journal (1957) 60]

NICHOLAS The New Zealand ladies, though the name of fashion has never reached their ears, are quite as fond of showing off their charms ... as our own fair countrywomen; ... (1817,New Zealand (various authors/titles),1/178)

SHEPHERD He saw a village built in the New Zealand Style and about 20 or thirty Natives, said they behave sivil to him. (Mar 22, 1826,Journal) [NOTES: 1826 Mar 22 Shepherd Journal in 1940 Howard Rakiura 363]

BEGG An old man named Oree Pahbah ... saluted us, by touching noses (the New Zealand custom). (1979,World of John Boultbee, The,185) [NOTES: 1827 Boultbee Journal in 1979 Begg 185]

McNAB ... - The New Zealand Temple is a box made of wood, the size of which is as follows: (1908,Historical Records,1/708) [NOTES: 1830 Aug 4 Rev. S. Leigh in 1908 McNab Historical Records 1/708]

FORSTER [He] has likewise obligingly communicated to me another of the New Zeeland music, which will be sufficient to give an idea of the taste of the people. He ... assured me that there appeared to be some display of genius in the New Zeeland tunes ... (1777,Voyage Round the World,2/477)

WILLIAMS ?Maori christians,? a missionary settlement Mr. Marsden entered with much apparent interest,upon the idea of a New Zealand settlement in Port Jackson; that is to say, within the Colony. ... [We think] that it should not be within one hundred miles of Sydney; that the natives should not be subject to visits from the curious intruders, ... [May 5 54] The natives have had much conversation, relative to the projected settlement in New Holland; ... They wish to be distinct from the whites or blacks, to retain their own teachers. Ibid.314 [1833 May 17]At 3 the natives were served with their repast of beef potatoes and stirabout. As our boys have had some experience in this important duty ... our visitors were ... surprised at the order and expedition with which this assemblage of New Zealand rank was supplied, as the feast consisted of bout 800 dishes constructed of a plant similar to the flag. Ibid. 314. [1833 May 17] At 3 the natives were served with their repast of beef potatoes and stirabout. As our boys have had some experience in this important duty ... our visitors were ... surprised at the order and expedition with which this assemblage of New Zealand rank was supplied, as the feast consisted of bout 800 dishes constructed of a plant similar to the flag. (Apr 9, 1827,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,51,1961 ed.)

CRUISE He [a native] entered into a long argument, to prove the superiority of New Zealand arms over the British firelock; and by way of exemplification, he took up a spear. Ibid. 69 While employed in examining this monument of New Zealand perfidy [the looted wreck of the Boyd] a canoe came up to us. (Mar 20, 1823,Journal,60) [NOTES: 1823 (1820 Mar 20) Cruise Journal (1957) 60]

MARKHAM [his usual word native] New Zealanders are a fine Race of People in this quarter of the Northern Island (Ea hei nomawe) in the Hokianga River, but filthy dirty, stink as bad as Caffres. Ibid. 40 I was certainly ashamed that Europeans could degrade themselves so before their New Zealand Boys, but so they did. ... Ibid. 41 [The Chief] asked me if I had a Waheinee [wahine] ? No. Would I like one? Certainly. Then take my daughter. Which I did in New Zealand fashion. (1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles),39,1963 ed.)

An old man named OOree Pahbah came to us as we were walking up to the village, who saluted us by touching noses (the New Zealand custom). (1835,Boultbee Journal,68,1986 ed.)

YATE As soon as a child is born, it is wrapped up, and laid to sleep in the verandah, which most of the New-Zealand houses possess; ... Ibid.163 [spg =Maori] I far prefer the New-Zealand, to the Friendly-Island canoes: ... a fleet of a hundred New-Zealand vessels. (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),81)

...his wife, a New Zealand woman, 3 children and two New Zealand boys. (1836,Rhodes Whaling Journal,34,1954 ed. Straubel ed.)

This Day one of the Newzeland Whoman got Young Boay (Apr 6, 1837,Piraki Log,51)

The native war-dance, accompanied by those terrific yells which are so well qualified to exhibit the natural ferocity of the New Zealand character, was exhibited for my amusement;.. (1841,GBPP,(No.311) 11) [NOTES: 1840 Feb 17 Hobson Report in GBPP House of Commons 1841 (No.311) 11]

F.MATHEW The arts of civilization have been introduced, and in a New Zealand Pah you will see land cultivated in a manner which would not disgrace a farmer in many parts of England. (Feb 16, 1840,Journal) [NOTES: 1840 Feb 16 F.Mathew Journal in 1940 Founding of NZ 54]

TAYLOR Thus whilst Xt. is the strength and support of the learned and enlightened believer of England he does not disdain the heart of a poor New Zealand child [Poari], (Mar 19, 1847,Journal,V/5)

EARP ... according to New Zealand notions of rank he being the highest in the scale, and his tormentor being regarded as a cookee, or slave, the lowest. (1853,New Zealand (various authors/titles),50)

There was not the slightest degree of shilly shallying - the tomahawk and the mere* going to it with true New Zealand zest; ... (1864,Von Tempsky Memoranda,167)

BUDDLE Manorial rights are imaginary rights when claimed for New Zealand Chiefs. (1860,Maori King Movement,19)

LADY MARTIN Nor was he like some New Zealand and English boys, smart without being clean. His shirt and boots were spotless. (1884,Our Maoris,134)

From a close examination ... of their poetry, it is apparent, that the New Zealand poet had taken some pains towards rhythm ... (1869,TrNZI,1/III/47) [NOTES: Colenso Maori races]

CRAIK And there was the New Zealand woman, a trained nurse who stood at the ready for those who had need of her ... (1830,New Zealanders, The,99)

CRAIK The circumstances ... are all illustrative of the New Zealand character. Ibid.. 115 In some cases, the wounds which the New Zealand women inflict on themselves are intended to express their grief for friends who have perished in the war; ... (1830,New Zealanders, The,99)

adj.

English New Zeland South-sea Islands A Chief Eareete Earee A Man Taata Taata A Woman Ivahino Ivahine (Mar 31, 1770,Cook's Journals,1/286,1955 ed.)

ELDER I also wish to procure a native of New Zealand who is acquainted with the English language as a kind of companion, that I may be enabled to proceed with the New Zealand vocabulary which I have now in hand. Ibid. 215 `How can any man wish to assimilate the sounds of the New Zealand vowels to those of the English when so many other living languages such as French, Spanish, Portuguese, German, and the Hebrew itself will suit the purpose better? (1934,Marsden's Lieutenants,49) [NOTES: 1814 Mar 25 Kendall in Elder Marsden's Lieutenants (1934) 49]

adj. of the country as a geographical entity

FORSTER The Natives are very fond of New-Zeeland green stones [ed. fn nephrite], of mother of Pearl-Shells ... (Aug 17, 1774,Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The,IV/608,1982 ed.)

RUTHERFORD The efficacy of the various general laws ... for the whole of the New Zealand Islands will be tested by some years actual practice ... (1949,Selected Documents,33) [NOTES: 1848 Nov 29 Governor Grey to Earl Grey in 1949 Rutherford ed. Select Documents33]

EARP From Wakatani to Kupanga ... I had the pleasure of dragging my weary limbs through a swamp twenty-five miles in length. Swamps are disagreeable things ...; but they are no impediment to the New Zealand traveller. (1853,New Zealand (various authors/titles),106)

MOSER It is a picturesque spot by the edge of a river flanked by a noble pine bush, the most noble of all the New Zealand forests. (1863,Mahoe Leaves,4)

BARKER [Jack] has ... been in nearly every difficulty incident to New Zealand travelling. (1868,Station Life in NZ,214,1870 ed.)

adj. with connotation European, English-speaking

WILLIAMS The natives had prayers this evening by themselves, and while singing the hymn, theEuropeans, who were near us in a raupo house, and who rank amongst the New Zealand merchants, struck up their vocal powers, and gave us the well known ballad, Old King Cole ... (Nov 14, 1833,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,347,1961 ed.)

JUNE BUTLER We kept one [horse] on the tether - tethered to a tussock of grass by a peculiar kind of New Zealand knot - and let the others loose; ... (1860,Forest Creek MS,48,1960 ed.)

FOREST BIVOUAC. ... Strengthened by the usual New Zealand food of roasted potatoes and damper', we set off ... but soon found ourselves bewildered ... in the surveyor's lines which crossed one another in all directions in the wood. We then resorted to the usual expedient of torches made ofkarehao' (supple Jack) or `katoa'; ... it was [agreed] ... that we should light a fire and bivouac for the night. (1851,New Zealand (various authors/titles),Part V (Church in the Colonies XX) 76) [NOTES: 1848 Aug 30 Selwyn in 1851 NZ Part V (Church in the Colonies XX) 76]

adj.

new zealand adj, usu cap N & Z [fr. New Zealand, Brit. dominion in the south Pacific ocean] 1 : of or from New Zealand : of the kind or style prevalent in New Zealand 2 : of, relating to, or being the biogeographic region or subregion of the Australian region that includes New Zealand and a few adjacent islands (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,1524)

WILSON The energising force in New Zealand life up to now has been this myth of the pioneer, the frontier ... (1976,Pacific Star,19)

n. the country (See cf MAORILAND,ENZED)

The name New Zealand is sometimes wrongly attributed to Tasman himself. (Aug 2000,NZWords,4 : 1)

A gentleman expressed a wish to go and live three years at Otaheite or New Zealand (Apr 29, 1776,Boswell's Life of Johnson,751,1953 ed.)

The inhabitants of Otaheite and New-Zealand are not in a state pf pure nature; for it is plain they broke off from some other people. (1776,Boswell's Life of Johnson,751)

The inhabitants of Otaheite and New-Zealand are not in a state pf pure nature; for it is plain they broke off from some other people. (1776,Boswell's Life of Johnson,751)

[Secret Instructions from the Admiralty] ... or fall in with the Eastern side of the Land discover'd by Tasman and now called New Zeland. (Jul 30, 1768,Cook's Journals,1/cc/xxxii,1955 ed.)

On the sixth of october [sic] 1769 the Endeavour Bark first made the land of New Zeeland:... (Oct 8, 1769,Cook's Journals,I-564,1955 ed.) [NOTES: 1769 Oct 8 W.B. Monkhouse in 1955 Cook Journal]

Part of the East Coast [slip for West] of this Country was first discover'd [check] by Abel Tasman in 1642 and by him call'd New Zeland. (Mar 31, 1770,Cook's Journals,1/274,1955 ed.)

FORSTER Our Ewes intended as presents to the Inhabitants of New Zeeland or New Holland, began to be ill ... (Dec 9, 1772,Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The,2/191)

Intending to put into Dusky Bay or any other Port I could find on the Southern part of Newzealand', ... [fn1] AH. Tavai- poenammoo. Ibid. 2/131 As there is no Port in New Zealand I have been in ... (Mar 26, 1773,Cook's Journals,2/109,1961 ed.)

BOSWELL We talked of having some men of inquiry left for three years at each of the islands of Otaheite, New Zealand, and Nova Caledonia, so as to learn the language ... . He [Capt. Jas. Cook] gave me a distinct account of a New Zealander eating human flesh in his presence and in that of many more aboard, so that the fact of cannibals is now certainly known. (Apr 18, 1776,Ominous Years, The,341,1963 ed.)

FORSTER [New Zeeland] As we stood northward, we also observed more seals ... which came from the coast of New Zeeland. Ibid., 1/129-130 [New-Zeeland] ... the resemblance it bore to the fir tribe ... soon convinced us that it was fitter to serve the purposes of [130] the American spruce-tree, and that a palatable and wholesome liquor might be brewed from it, as a kind of substitute for spruce-beer. ... The spruce of New-Zeeland is a very beautiful tree, and conspicuous on account of its pendant branches ... (1777,Voyage Round the World,1/119)

RUTHERFORD And we do hereby declare, that from henceforth the said Islands shall be known and designated as the Colony of New Zealand, and the principal Islands, here to fore known as, or commonly called, the Northern Island,' theMiddle Island,' and Stewart's Island,' shall henceforward be designated and known respectively asNew Ulster,' New Munster,' andNew Leinster.' ... (1971,Speeches & Documents,54) [NOTES: 1777 G.Forster Voyage Round the World 1840 Letters Patent issued on 16 November: quoted from The Ordinances of New Zealand, Domett 1850 pp.4-8 in 1971 Speeches and Documents 54]

YATE Puriri (Vitex littoralis) - This tree, from its hardness and durability, has been denominated the New-Zealand Oak; ... (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),44)

The consequence [of ignoring the South Island] is, that in works which profess to describe New Zealand, the largest island of the three is not described at all. ... But it seems never to have occurred to the gentlemen who have published their `New Zealands', that it was necessary to see more than a very small portion of it, in order to describe the whole. (Jul 20, 1844,Nelson Examiner,20 et seq.) [NOTES: 1844 Monro Notes of a Journey (Nelson Examiner July 20 et seq.) in 1898 Hocken Contributions 231]

New Zealand is divided into two provinces, New Ulster, and New Munster, each of which is under a Lieutenant-Governor, who enacts ordinances for the province over which he presides, with the advice of a Legislative Council, composed of the officers of Government, together with a few persons nominated by the crown from amongst the inhabitants. A Governor-in-Chief rules the whole of New Zealand and is assisted in his legislation by a Council constituted similarly to the provincial Councils. At present, the Governor-in-Chief holds the subordinate office of Lieutenant-Governor of New Ulster , in addition to his higher Commission: and Mr Eyre is the Lieutenant of New Munster, the southern province. (Feb 1, 1851,Lyttelton Times,2)

THOMSON Of the three islands forming the Zealand group, Rakiura, or the small South Island, is the only one which possesses a native name. Since the days of Cook, the North Island has been named on old maps Eaheinomawe, and the Middle Island Tavai-poenammo. These names originated thus. When the great navigator asked the natives the name of the North Island, he was told that it was a thing fished from the sea by Maui,' - He mea hi no Maui; and that the Middle Island was Te wahi pounamu, orthe place of the greenstone.' When New Zealand became a British colony, the first governor, who was an Irishman, proclaimed that the North, Middle, and South Island were thenceforth to be denominated respectively New Ulster, New Munster, and New Leinster; and these names he selected for the colony because New Zealand, like Irelands, had no toads. This modern method of naming places by applying the epithet `New' to countries which are as old as the originals is not only incorrect, but possesses many disadvantages. The Constitution Act of 1852 discarded this unsuitable nomenclature, and the North, Middle, and Stewart's Islands are the names now invariably given to them by the settlers, and those by which they are familiar toseamen. The South Island was named in honour of the sealer who, in 1808, discovered its insularity. Sentimental settlers designate New Zealand the Britain of the southern hemisphere, on the same principle that the Dutchman Tasman, who discovered the country, called it New Zealand. (1859,Story of New Zealand, The,1/4)

BULLER ... I have accordingly commenced my history of our avifauna with an account of the New-Zealand Crow. (humorously) New Zillund, etc [discuss this pronunciation] (1888,Birds of New Zealand,1/xvi) [NOTES: usu. spg: also North-Island]

MORRIS New Zealand, ... This name was given to the colony by Abel Jansz Tasman, the Dutch navigator, who visited it in 1642. He first called it Staaten-land. It is now frequently called Maoriland(q.v.). - (1898,Austral English,320)

fn Since the pig was introduced by Captain Cook ... [fn] Hence modern Newzealand slang a Captain Cook or Captain Cooker, for a wild pig. (Current since the late 19th century.) Also, slang, Pig-islands, Newzealand, Pig-islander, a Newzealander. Ibid. 1946 55/141 ... Words that appeared to me to have become current in English, at any rate as written and spoken in Newzealand. Neither ... do we Newzealanders in our ordinary writing; (Jun 1945,Journal of the Polynesian Society,54/225)

It is no surprise that a conservative organisation such as the RSA has taken exception to the use of the phonetically pleasant Aotearoa' instead of the clumsyNew Zealand' or colloquial `Newzyullind'. (Jul 1, 1988,Dominion,10) [NOTES: (Davis Jones)]

The name Aotearoa was made popular around 1898 with the publication of William Pember Reeves' book The Long White Cloud - Aotearoa,' historian ... Sir Keith Sinclair says. After 1870, most Maori referred to the country as Niu Tirani - a result of Pakeha settlers calling the three islands New Zealand. Sir Keith said that in all the written Maori he had read from last century the word Aotearoa had been used in only one newspaper. Te Wanaanga, published in Napier, used Aotearoa in the 1870s. Sir Keith said Maori often referred to New Zealand by usingte motu nei' (in this island). Sir Keith said the literal translation of Aotearoa was `land of the long twilight'. The name may have come about because the early Polynesians were not used to the long evenings in New Zealand. (Jul 17, 1988,Sunday Star Times,A6)

MARSH `That's what they reckon. Nothing like it anywhere else in N'yerzillun.' (1980,Photo-Finish,31)

ANGAS She is left with several ... children, who are dressed in the Maori costume, and know no language but that of New Zealand. (1847,Savage Life,1/293)

2 adj. As a separable qualifying prefix to, or in loose combination with, the common names of fauna and flora to denote the indigenous variety distinct from English or European varieties to which it may bear some real or imaginary resemblance; or to denote their origin or habit at in the New Zealand bio-geographic region. In colloquial N.Z. speech often omitted, and is interchangeable with NATIVE and to some extent with MAORI. In this glossary it is considered aseparable prefix when used with most names of specific plants etc. This use is obsolescent in mostcases. Current uses are underlined: -->PLANTS: Acacia, Anise, Aniseed, Arbor Vitae, Ash, -->BEECH, BIDDY-BID, BIRCH, blue-bell, Bramble, BROOM, BURR, CANE, CARROT,CEDAR Celery, Clematis, Coffee, COTTON, COTTONWOOD, CURRANT, Cypress, Daisy, EASTER ORCHID, Edelweiss, EYEBRIGHT, FLAX, FUCHSIA, GRAPEFRUIT, GRASS (seeGRASS ENTRY), HAREBELL, HEMP, Hawthorn, Holly, Honeysuckle ICE PLANT, JASMINE, LABURNUM, LAUREL, LILAC, LINSEED, MINT, MISTLETOE, MULBERRY, MYRTLE, OAK, ORANGE BLOSSOM, Palm, PASSION FLOWER, PINCUSHION, PINE,PINEAPPLE, PLUME GRASS, PRIMROSE, SCREW PINE, SPINACH, STRAWBERRY,TEAK, THORN, VINE, WIND GRASS, YELLOW PINE, NEW ZEALAND -->in general combinations see also BUSHMEN, -->as a distinguishing epithet in the names of plants see also ACACIA, [?talicise current usage: ? or obs usage] ACACIA, ACAENA, ANISE, ANISEED, ARBOR-VITAE, ASH, ATROPIS, BEDSTRAW, BEECH, BEGONIA; BIDDY-BID, BIRCH, BLUEBELL, BOX, BRAMBLE, BROOM, BURR, BURR-REED, CALCEOLARIA, CALTHA, CANE, CARROT, CEDAR, CELERY, CHICKWEED, CHRISTMAS TREE, CLEMATIS, COFFEE, CONVOLVULUS, COTON, COTTONWOOD, CRESS, CURRANT, CYPRESS, DAISY, DAMSON,DANDELION, DAPHNE, DOCK, DONATIA, EDELWEISS, EYEBRIGHT, FERN (various, see entry), FIG, FIR, FLAX, FLAX-PLANT, FUCHSIA, GRAPEFRUIT, GRASS (many, see GRASS entry), GUM-TREE, HAREBELL HAWTHORN, HEMP, HERPOLIRION, HIBISCUS, HICKORY, HOLLY, HONEY-SUCKLE, HYDROCOTYLE, ICEPLANT, JASMINE; BUTTERCUP, KAIKOURA; LABURNUM, LAUREL, LIGNUM VITAE, LILAC, LILY, LINSEED, MARSH MARIGOLD, MINT, MISTLETOE, MULBERRY, MUSK, MYRTLE, OAK, OAK ELM, OLIVE, ORACHE, ORANGE BLOSSOM, ORCHID (various), PACHYCLADON, PALM, PASSION-FLOWER; PENNYWORT, MARSH; PINCUSHION; PINE (various, see entry), PINEAPPLE, PLANTAIN, PRIMROSE, PRIVET, REED, SANDALWOOD, SCREW-PINE; SPINACH, SPURGE, STRAWBERRY,TEAK, THORN, VINE, VIOLET, WATER-PIMPERNEL, WILLOW; WINEBERRY, YEW -->BIRDS: CROW, DOTTEREL, PIPIT, ROBIN, THRUSH, TURKEY, -->animals: BAT, DOG, FROG, FUR SEAL, RAT -->fish: COD, COWRY (shell), GURNARD, HAKE, LATCHET, MINNOW, SHARK (various), SMELT, SOLE, WHITEBAIT

New Zealand lily¶

n. rengarenga

TREGEAR ... the roots of the New Zealand lily ( rengarenga : Arthropodium cirrhatum) had to be cooked in the oven before becoming fit for food. (1848,Maori Race, The,99)

The thick fleshy roots of the New Zealand lily, rengarenga (Arthropodium cirrhatum), were also formerly eaten ... (1881,TrNZI,13/30)

New Zealand Alliance¶

n.

The New Zealand Alliance Convention opened to-day, Mr Wesley Spragg (Auckland), president, in the chair. The report presented stated that the outbreak of war injuriously affected campaign work and the vote for prohibition and no-license. Approval was expressed of the refusal of the Government to allow wet canteens at Expeditionary Force camps. (Apr 14, 1915,Ashburton Guardian,2)

The liquor traffic, in the "Evening Post" of October 11, and in other papers, challenges the New Zealand Alliance to produce "any evidence that the American people have ever voted or had an opportunity of voting upon the question of National Prohibition." (Oct 21, 1922,NZ Truth,10)

Government acted thus, because after making a count they found that the publicans had more noses in the House than the teetotallers; and the object of the New Zealand Alliance for the Reform of the liquor laws was to let Mr Sheehan and those of his sort see that the teetotallers had as many noses in the House as the publicans. (Mar 25, 1879,Bruce Herald,5)

At the annual public meeting, held under the auspices of the New Zealand Alliance for the supression of the sale of liquor, resolutions were adopted pledging an offer of support in the endeavour to have the principle of prohibition represented in the next Parliament, protesting against compensation to publicans whose houses were closed by popular veto, and resolving to take steps for educating the people upon the temperance question ... (Dec 3, 1890,Evening Post,2)

Like Father Hays and the British Alliance, our grand ideal is: local option for all, total abstinence for the individual, and no-license , or prohibition for the State. This has been the paramount aim of the New Zealand Alliance since its inception. (May 11, 1905,West Coast Times,3)

".. In the long run, though not now, the New Zealand Alliance may prove too strong for the publican party." (Jul 19, 1871,Daily Southern Cross,2)

He moved, "That this representative meeting of the New Zealand Alliance draws the attention of the Government to the request made by the Maoris at the congress held at Wellington in 1908, when the principle of local option should be extended to the Native race, and earnestly hopes that the numerous petitions presented by the Maoris to the Prime Minister will be favorably considered." (Jun 28, 1910,Poverty Bay Herald,6)

Bitter complaint was made.. as to the conduct of the New Zealand Alliance in regard to the Tauranga election. (Oct 8, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,19)

Some startling allegations as to the drinking habits of Maoris in Taranaki are contained in a petition presented to the House by Mr Atkinson from the Executive of the New Zealand Alliance. The petitioners forwarded with the petition a sworn declaration by the Rev. R. Haddon, of Hawera, Wesleyan Maori missionary, who is a half-caste, in reference to the disastrous effects of drink upon the Maoris of Taranaki. (Oct 4, 1901,Poverty Bay Herald,4)

Among the Members of Parliament pledged to the New Zealand Alliance are a number who represent "Continuance" constituencies. This, in itself, is sufficient indication of the undemocratic policy of the Alliance, in attempting to force its opinions over the heads of the people. (Oct 11, 1928,NZ Truth,10)

New Zealand aniseed¶

n. [one entry, Angelica montana] (See aniseed,mountain aniseed)

COCKAYNE Angelica montana New Zealand aniseed (1915,AJHR,c-6) [NOTES: Notes on the Plant Covering of Kennedy's Bush... Canterbury]

New Zealand army worm¶

n.

New Zealand Army Worm. Grass Caterpillar (Mamestra composita). Some of its habits greatly resemble those of the American army worm, noticeably the manner of advance from old feeding-grounds to new, marching like an army, sometimes many thousands strong. (1895,Ann. Rep. Dept of Agriculture,III/155)

(1896,Leaflets for Farmers,No. 33/1)

New Zealand Army Worm, Grass Caterpillar (Mamestra composita) . . . During the last few years great complaints have been made regarding the ravages committed in pastures and in crops by armies of caterpillars, which march across the country, eating all before them. (1896,Leaflets for Farmers,No. 33/1)

New Zealand ash¶

n. occas. Metrosideros excelsa (See pohutukawa)

HOCHSTETTER Metrosideros tomentosa [NZ Ash] (1867,New Zealand (Hochstetter)) [NOTES: list of trees from Taylor 1848]

1 n. [1871 TrNZI 3/?, (And). Also[?d] Ed. Fairburn Maharatanga 30 Titoki (this tree sometimes called New Zealand `Ash")]

It is sometimes termed the New Zealand Ash", doubtless on account of its resembling that tree in the shape of its foliage and in the toughness of its wood, but it is most generally known as thetitoki". (1889,Forest Flora,183) [NOTES: (Morris)]

Ash (&abreve.sh), n. [Add.] The term is applied in Australia to many trees of various genera ... The New Zealand ash is the sapindaceous tree Alectryon excelsum; - called also titoki. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2017)

MORRIS Ash ...New Zealand A. (see Titoki). [Alectryon excelsum] (1898,Austral English,7)

COCKAYNE (1907,AJHR) [NOTES: Report on a Botanical Survey of Kapiti Island (And)]

COCKAYNE (1908,AJHR,C-14) [NOTES: Report on a Botanical Survey of Waipoua Kauri Forest (And)]

COCKAYNE (1915,AJHR,C-6) [NOTES: Cockayne Notes on the Plant Covering of Kennedy's Bush ... Canterbury (And)]

LAING & BLACKWELL Alectryon excelsum [(The Titoki)] ... This tree is sometimes called The New Zealand Ash, and its timber is largely used. Maori name, Titoki. (1907,Plants of NZ,225) [NOTES: 1940 ed. p. 239]

TITOKI, TITONGI (New Zealand Ash) Alectryon excelsus (1979,Maori Herbal Remedies,100)

TITOKI (New Zealand Ash) Alectryon excelsus (1982,Field Guide to Common NZ Trees & Shrubs,24)

New Zealand broom¶

n.

Carmichaellia grandiflora. This may be called the New Zealand Broom, being generally found with leaves. (1869,TrNZI,1/iii/35) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

Larvae, loopers, beaten from the N. Z. Broom (Carmichaelia ), about four-fifths of an inch long. (Jan 1884,NZ Journal of Science,117)

Carmichaelia australis (1916,Official Trade Register of Nurserymen) [NOTES: (And)]

MATTHEWS Carmichaelia (New Zealand Broom) ; - A genus almost peculiar to New Zealand ... C. nana, a dwarf ... C. australis ... the variety generally seen ... (1943,NZ Gardening Dictionary, The,32) [NOTES: also 1951 ed.]
