New Zealand Coastal Policy¶

n.

Statutory protection - the Resource Management Act, the New Zealand Coastal Policy statement, both aimed at protecting and preserving the coastline alongside development - is failing. (Dec 7, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),21)

New Zealand coffee¶

n. Coprosma lucida [noun.] (See coffeebush)

Broadleaf, five-fingered Jack, (Panax arboreum) lacebark, matipo, red matipo, New Zealand coffee [fn Species of Coprosma.], titoki or native ash jostle one another in the dense dry bush. (1900,Canterbury Old & New,184)

New Zealand coffee shrub¶

n.

HOCHSTETTER The slope.. was overgrown with bushes of the New Zealand coffee-shrub - karamu of the natives (Coprosma lucida.. ) - full of red berries. (1867,New Zealand (Hochstetter),337)

New Zealand Company¶

1 n.

The first organized attempt to colonize New Zealand occurred in 1826 when the first New Zealand Company was formed and sent an unsuccessful expedition to Hokianga. (1936,Agricultural Organization in NZ,3)

2 n.

McLINTOCK The genesis of the New Zealand Company is to be found in the New Zealand Association, which took shape in the spring of 1837 as a practical expression of Wakefield's challenging theories concerning emigration and colonisation. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,II/658)

New Zealand House,/ Broad-street Buildings, 22 October 1840. ... The gentlemen who have beenassociated under the name of the New Zealand Company, for the purpose of promoting the settlement of New Zealand, ... It is, therefore, with great satisfaction that the Company perceives in the recent proclamations ... an opening for a satisfactory adjustment ... (Oct 22, 1840,GBPP,1841 (No.311) 21) [NOTES: 1840 Oct 22 Joseph Somes to Lord John Russell in GBPP House of Commons 1841 (No.311) 21]

Amongst the most imporant of the measures to be brought under your notice is that which relates to the settlement of titles to land within the territory which was formerly vested in the New Zealand Company. (Jun 7, 1851,Lyttelton Times,6)

We have received private letters from England stating that a negociation is in progress between the New Zealand Company and the Government, for transferring the Company's debt of 268,000 l. from the land fund to the General Colonial Revenue. [detailed history of the New Zealand Company follows]. (Sep 27, 1851,Lyttelton Times,5)

In 1838 a colonisation company, known as the New Zealand Company was formed to establish settlement on systematic principles. (1892,NZ Official Handbook,4)

New Zealand cotton¶

n. ? ribbonwood fibre.

new zealand cotton n, usu cap N & Z : a fiber from the bast of the ribbon tree (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,1524)

New Zealand cowrie¶

n. a local variety of cowrie shell

POWELL NEW ZEALAND COWRY (Ellatrivia memorata). This is about 1/2 inch long with a group of pink blotches on the top of the shell, and is our sole representative of a family very well represented in all tropical countries. The New Zealand species is very scarce. (1947,Native Animals of NZ,27)

New Zealand cream¶

n. cold water added to hot tea in place of milk [station hands]

CHAMIER There is a very good substitute for milk. If you pour a little cold water on the hot tea it has very much the same effect-takes off the sharpness .... we call it `New Zealand Cream'. (1891,Philosopher Dick,26)

New Zealand creeper¶

n. a bird; CERTHIPARUS NOVAE ZEALANDIAE

BULLER CERTHIPARUS NOVAE ZEALANDIAE. (NEW-ZEALAND CREEPER.) ... Native names.- Pipipi and Toitoi. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,105)

BULLER CERTHIPARUS NOVAE ZEALANDIAE. (NEW-ZEALAND CREEPER.) ... native names.- Pipipi and Toitoi. (1888,Birds of New Zealand,1/51)

New Zealand Cross¶

n.

There were Crimean decorations there and New Zealand Crosses, as well as the more plentiful Maori War medal. (Aug 10, 1912,NZ Free Lance,4)

Now, therefore. His Excellency the Governor.. doth by this present Order institute a Decorative Distinction to be conferred on... Members of the Militia, Volunteers and Armed Constabulary, who may particularly distinguish themselves by their bravery in action, or devotion to their duty while on service... The decoration shall consist of a Silver Cross, with the name of the Colony and the name of the recipient engraved thereon. (1869,NZ Gazette,II.Mar.)

Major Ropata.. wore at his side the handsome sword presented to him by the Queen, and on his breast the New Zealand Cross. (May 28, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,22)

The public intimation of the Government intention to decorate Mr. ** with the New Zealand Cross has caused a very great amount of astonishment, indignation, and disgust, not only among the present holders of the New Zealand Cross, but also among Volunteers who rightly consider it their bounden duty to protect the dignity of this much-prized decoration. (1898,AJHR,H-31Q/1)

COWAN Mair was the only pakeha ... in the action that won him a captaincy and the New Zealand Cross. (1940,Sir Donald Maclean,102)

SUTHERLAND NEW ZEALAND CROSS, 1869. [heading] A silver maltese cross with a six pointed star in gold upon each limb. ... Institution, Order of the Governor in Council, dated 10 March, 1869. New Zealand Gazette 1869, p. 127. [229] This cross was instituted by the Colonial Government and awarded to members of the local Militia, Volunteers, and Constabulary for acts of bravery and distinction. (1941,Numismatic History of NZ,228)

A rare New Zealand Cross, awarded for bravery during the New Zealand land wars, is the centre-piece of a major auction of coins and medals in Melbourne later this month. The cross, described as a non-military version of the Victoria Cross, is one of only 23 awarded to the militia, volunteers and armed constabulary during the wars, ... (Jul 3, 1984,Dominion,6)

His Excellency the Governor.. doth bythis present Order institute a DecorativeDistinction, to be conferred on membersof the Militia, Volunteers or ArmedConstabulary. who may particularlydistinguish themselves by their braveryin action, or devotion to their dutywhile on service... The decoration shallconsist of a Silver Cross, with the nameof the Colony and the name of therecipient engraved thereon. (1869,NZ Gazette,127)

The Speaker announced that he hadreceived from His Excellency the Governora message, transmitting the New ZealandCross of Honor (sic) Bill. (1989,NZ Parliamentary Debates,VI/662)

New Zealand crow¶

n. (Environment) kokako (See kokako)

YATE Kokako; called, by some, the New-Zealand crow. ... It has a strong black beak ... and a small brilliant light-blue flap hanging down on each side, from the ear. (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),64)

DIEFFENBACH 29. Callaeas cinerea. Lath. ... Kokako of the natives. - New Zealand crow. Yate. Dieffenbach. Kakako of the natives. Polack. (1843,Travels in NZ,2/19) [NOTES: 1842 Gray's Fauna in 1843 Dieffenbach Travels in NZ II/191]

DRURY BIRDS MET WITH IN PELORUS ...New Zealand Crow - Kokako of the natives. (1855,Sailing Directions,65)

HAAST The first is the kakako (Callaeas cinerea), the New Zealand crow; generally a pair together; ... (1861,Report on Topographical Exploration of Nelson,139)

HARPER It [the Otira Pass area] is also the haunt of the New Zealand crow, a shapely bird, purple, shot with black, and reddish yellow rings under the eyes, very tame, ... (Jul 20, 1868,Letters from Canterbury, NZ,130,1914 ed.)

Callaeas cinerea. Kokako. New Zealand Crow. (1869,TrNZI,1/160) [NOTES: (Hutton Birds Great Barrier)]

WILLIAMS Kookako, n. collaeas[sic] cinerea, or New Zealand crow. (1871,Dictionary of the NZ Language,57)

In this forest ... are found ...the rarer Glaucopis cinerea or Kokako, commonly called the New Zealand Crow. (1872,TrNZI,4/206) [NOTES: (Travers NZ Birds)]

BULLER ... I have accordingly commenced my history of our avifauna with an account of the New-Zealand Crow. (1888,Birds of New Zealand,I/xvi)

GUTHRIE-SMITH Although the New Zealand Crow, the New Zealand Thrush were still to find [in Nelson province], Bush Canary at any rate were plentiful. (1936,NZ Naturalist,57)

WILLIAMS Kokako, n. Callaeas cinerea cinerea and C. Cinerea wilsoni, New Zealand crow. (1957,Dictionary of the Maori Language,129)

SARGESON ... higher up still there was the ding dong of the New Zealand crow, a bird which I have never been lucky enough to see, and have heard a few times only on Te Aroha; ... (1973,Once Is Enough,14)

Sir James Hector, in drawing attention.. to a very fine specimen of the New Zealand crow or jay. as it should more properly be called, made interesting references to the complete isolation of the orange wattle crow, in the South Island, and the blue wattle crow in the North Island. (Dec 21, 1897,Otago Daily Times,10)

McNAUGHTON Higher up still there was the ding dong of the New Zealand crow, a bird which I have never been lucky enough to see, and have heard a few times only on Te Aroha. (1986,Countless Signs,165) [NOTES: From Frank Sargeson (1973) : Once is Enough]

New Zealand cuckoo¶

n.

TAYLOR In early spring the koekoea's note is weak and feeble. ... This is the New Zealand cuckoo a bird of passage. (Dec 25, 1852,Journal,8/62)

New Zealand damson¶

n. tawa

HURSTHOUSE (And) Beilschmiedia tawa New Zealand Damson (1857,New Zealand, or Zealandia)

New Zealand Day¶

n. (historical) a short-lived replacement name for Waitangi Day

HAYWARD Mr K. announced at the Waitangi Day celebrations that henceforth it would be called New Zealand Day and become a public holiday, `though I think that this will still often be called Waitangi Day rather than New Zealand Day. ...' [fn] On 6 February 1976 the day again became officially known as Waitangi Day. (Feb 13, 1973,Diary of the Kirk Years,112,1981 ed.)

New Zealand death¶

1 n. (Rural) death by drowning, especially when crossing rivers on horseback [1800s]. [aka national death]

PASCOE Had he drowned, it would have been said that he had died 'the New Zealand death.' (1959,Great Days in NZ Exploration,67)

PICKERING Freshes were lethal for many early colonists and drowning became so commonplace that it was called the New Zealand death or New Zealand disease. (1988,Hills, The,23)

IRELAND The colonel's name does not appear on the list of drownings - the "New Zealand death' as it was called. (1998,Under the Bridge & Over the Moon,24)

Drowning was once termed "the New Zealand death" because in the young colony it became the biggest killer of settlers chancing swollen rivers like the Rakaia. (Jul 2000,NZ Geographic,No. 47/86)

BEATTIE In the early days .. so many persons were drowned that drowning was often described as 'The New Zealand Death.' (1947,Early Runholding in Otago,24)

HENDERSON 'The New Zealand death' he knew was the old name for drowning in a river. (1984,Tales of the Coast,16)

MCGILL New Zealand death, the: drowning. (1989,Dinkum Kiwi Dictionary, The,71)

Relph Isolation was a real problem in the absence of roads, and increased by the danger of crossing the larger rivers. Indeed, drowning was known as 'the New Zealand death'. (2007,From Tussocks to Tourists,77)

Drowning has ben termed "the New Zealand death," and of the numbers who annually in New Zealand are the victims of drowning accidents, the Wanganui River and Casltecliff beach claim a fair share. (Jan 30, 1912,Wanganui Chronicle,4)

A river-ford death already figures in the holiday casualties. The fords of rivers generally claim a strong, efficient type of victim, because other types usually do not take a risk at an obviously tricky ford; but it was different in the roadless, bridgeless days, when all backblockers had to choose between the ford or remaining in the wilderness, and it was then that drowning in a river became known as "the New Zealand death." (Dec 27, 1935,Evening Post,6)

Fatalities to persons crossing rivers in this colony have been so frequent that they have not inaptly been classed under the heading of "The New Zealand Death." (Aug 15, 1903,Hawera & Normanby Star,2)

New Zealand disease¶

n. the anti-nuclear policy (from an American viewpoint)

The United States still fears the spread of the "New Zealand disease" and will not reactivate military links till New Zealand changes its anti-nuclear legislation. (Jan 1, 1997,Dominion,1)

New Zealand dog¶

n. = Maori dog

FORSTER The New Zeeland dog, mentioned above, ... now fell upon the dead puppy, and ate of it with a ravenous appetite. (1777,Voyage Round the World,1/243)

COLENSO ...whilst here and there a hani (or taiaha, a chief's staff of rank, &c.) was seen erected, adorned with the long flowing white hair of the tails of the New Zealand dog and crimson cloth and red feathers. (1890,Treaty of Waitangi,10) [NOTES: 1890 Colenso Treaty of Waitangi (Brombie) 10-11]

New Zealand dulse¶

n. a seaweed, carragreen

MARTIN The immense masses of NEW ZEALAND DULSE or CARRAGREEN (Gigartina) exposed in some areas are now being harvested for the peparation of sea-meal. (1929,Flora NZ,26,1961 ed.)

New Zealand eagle¶

n. an extinct giant native eagle

Harpagornis Moorei the giant New Zealand eagle was trapped here, also Cnemiornis Calcitrans, the South Island's extinct goose. (Jul 21, 1984,Listener (New Zealand Listener),37)

Among them was the New Zealand eagle, the female at up to 13kg and with a wingspan of 3m, the world's largest bird of prey. It is thought to have disappeared about 500 years ago. (Dec 15, 1999,Evening Post,24)

New Zealand emu¶

n. the kiwi (See emu)

The energy and good feeling of a Colonist from Wanganui placed at my disposal on Wednesday last, a specimen of the kiwi, or New Zealand emu ... (Nov 20, 1841,NZ Gazette,2)

Five somewhat rare birds, described as the roaroa or tokoweka, or New Zealand emu, caught at Kopaka, Stewart's Island, have been on exhibition at Invercargill during the past week. (Jul 18, 1889,Otago Witness,17)

ASHWELL The moor [sic] the New Zealand Emu was found. (1849,Letters & Journals,1/147)

The first stream west of the point is the Grace river, the next Kiwi (Apteryx bird) Burn. The sealers called the kiwi bird the New Zealand emu. (Oct 13, 1909,Otago Witness,63)

New Zealand English¶

n. the distinctive accent, vocabulary, etc. of New Zealanders

NEW ZEALAND ENGLISH. Mr.E.W. Andrews, of the Napier Boys' High School, is an admitted authority on English. His presidential address, recently delivered at the conference in Wellington of the Secondary Schools' Assistant Teachers, is ... the more interesting. The subject was `New Zealand English'. (Aug 10, 1910,Triad, The,37)

TURNER Language in Australia and NZ 152 Mullock is less frequent and retains a specialist sense of rubbish from a mine'. It is not common in general New Zealand English, but mullock rocks,waste material from quartz mines', occurs in a West Coast context. (1966,English as it is spoken in NZ)

There are entries [in The Macquarie Dictionary] ... for Australian English, Australianism and Strine, but none for New Zealand English, New Zealandism or New Zild. 2.That variety of English spoken and written by native-born New Zealanders; the totality of English spoken and written; the English language as it is found in the speech and writing of native-born New Zealanders. by native-born New Zealanders. (Jan 21, 1984,Listener (New Zealand Listener),30) [NOTES: Deverson]

New Zealand ermine¶

n. fur from a stoat [A weasel has a black-tipped tail and brown fur which turns white in winter. In England it is called a stoat while it has its brown coat.]

WODZICKI [The increase in number of stoat skins supplied to the market] is due to ... secondly, the establishment of a modern fur dressing and dyeing plant in Dunedin. In consequence a new article of the fur trade called the New Zealand Ermine has been produced, and such coats are valued at 180 pounds each. (1950,Introduced Mammals of NZ,74)

New Zealand Expeditionary Force¶

n. [WW1]

WESTON In October the main body of the New Zealand Expeditionary Force, with its first reinforcement, also sailed for Egypt. (1918,Three Years with the NZers,7)

SCANLAN New Zealand was equipping an Expeditionary Force which was to sail in a few weeks. (1933,Tides of Youth,243)

WAITE ... the body of the first soldier of the New Zealand Expeditionary Force to die overseas was reverently committed to the deep. Ibid. 40 It was decided to use the New Zealand Expeditionary Force as the nucleus of a Division. (1919,New Zealanders at Gallipoli,17)

TREADWELL Had I not done so I might have started my adventure with the New Zealand Expeditionary Forceas a captain ... (1936,Recollections of an Amateur Soldier,5)

There are fifteen members of the NewZealand Expeditionary Force [sc. as POWs]at Bilmedik, six at Afion Kara Hissar,and as to one man it is uncertain towhich place he has been sent. (Sep 15, 1916,Chronicles NZEF,I/1 : 37)

New Zealand Expeditionary Force Association¶

n.

SINCLAIR The New Zealand Expeditionary Force Association, led by Kenneth H. Melvin, wanted a credit authority set up to stabilize prices and control credit. [c.1946] (1976,Nash,267)

New Zealand falcon¶

n. an indigenous bird of prey, of which there are three forms: the bush falcon, the eastern falcon, and the southern falcon.

The New Zealand Falcon/Karearea is classed as a single variable species divided into three forms, as described by Fox (1977). (2007,Internet - see Notes,1) [NOTES: www.canterburynature.org/species/lincoln_essays/nzfalcon.php]

Falco novaeseelandiae, New Zealand Falcon [check] (1948,NZ Forest Inhabiting Birds,16)

FALLA et al. NEW ZEALAND FALCON Falco novaeseelandiae Other names: Bush Hawk, Sparrow Hawk, Quail Hawk, Karearea. (1966,Birds of New Zealand,99)

  1. Falco novaeseelandiae Gmelin, 1788 New Zealand Falcon (Karearea) (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,39,1980 ed.)

HENDERSON The spot on Sugarloaf where weird old Jimmy Gilfillan had his hut and spent all his time shooting every sparrowhawk (New Zealand falcon) he could find, declaring: `They fly down and pick your eyes out.' (1981,Exiles of Asbestos Cottage, The,122)

New Zealand Falcon Falco novaeseelandiae GMELIN, 1788 ...[155] OTHER NAMES: Karearea, sparrowhawk, bush hawk, quail hawk, eastern falcon, southern falcon, bush falcon. ... Bush falcon: In the North Island confined to the main ranges, ... Eastern falcon: The main ranges of the South Island ... Southern Falcon: Fiordland, the Auckland Islands, and Stewart Island. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,154)

The Raptor Association, through contact with pigeon clubs, has been told by several racing pigeon enthusiasts that they have shot native New Zealand falcons attacking their pigeons. (Aug 21, 1999,Evening Post,4)

A project to reintroduce the New Zealand falcon to Marlborough's Wairau Plains has Conservation Department approval and funding. (Jul 12, 2005,Dominion Post,A8)

New Zealand fashion¶

n. (See cf. Maori fashion,native fashion)

ELDER `In the course of this month several female scholars absent in order to get their lips and chin marked in the New Zealand fashion by an artist from Whangaroa. Each of them had to pay for the tattooing. (1934,Marsden's Lieutenants,136) [NOTES: 1817 Mar 25 Kendall in Elder Marsden's Lieutenants (1934) 136]

MARSDEN I laughed at him presenting his bloody nose for me to rub with mine, and pointed to the wound he had received; he smiled and said it was New Zealand fashion. (1819,Letters & Journals of Samuel Marsden,187,1932 ed.)

MARKHAM House cold, wet and Muddy, determined to built a Chimney New Zealand fashion. (1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles),57,1963 ed.)

New Zealand flax¶

n. [1907 CKM (And) Phormium Colensoi *from the flax-like properties the fibre obtained from the leaf (not the stem as in linen flax) ]

LANG The New Zealand flax is manufactured in Sydney into whaling gear, for which. I believe, it is peculiarly well adapted. (1839,New Zealand (various authors/titles),61)

The New Zealand flax plant is now growing well in Japan. (Jan 26, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,44)

Phormium tenax, or New Zealand flax, is indigenous to this country and Norfolk Island (Jun 6, 1928,NZ Free Lance,7)

COCKAYNE (And) Phormium tenax (1919,NZ Plants & Their Story,2nd ed. ed.)

(And) Phormium tenax (1840,NZ Journal)

PETRE (And) (1841,Account of the Settlements NZ Company)

HURSTHOUSE (And) (1857,New Zealand, or Zealandia)

HOOKER (And) (1864,Handbook NZ Flora)

The Harakeke, or New Zealand Flax (Phormium tenax, and Ph. Colensoi), ... was sometimes planted (1869,TrNZI,1/III/33) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

CHEESEMAN (And) (1906,NZ Flora)

LAING & BLACKWELL (And) (1906,Plants of NZ)

THOMSON (And) (1909,NZ Naturalist's Calendar)

(And) (1916,Dunedin Field Club Plant Catalogues)

COCKAYNE (And) (1919,NZ Plants & Their Story,2nd ed.)

COCKAYNE (And) Phormium tenax (1924,Cultivation of NZ Plants, The)

FORSTER (1777,Voyage Round the World,2/445)

MENZIES NZ flax. (1791,Journal) [NOTES: 1791 Menzies's Journal (Vancouver's Expedition) in 1907 Murihiku 314]

McNAB Q. Did you observe much flax? Where abouts does it grow? ... ... but I don't believe the New Zealand flax requires a very rich soil. (1908,Historical Records,1/536) [NOTES: 1821 May Evidence of Ensign McCrae before Commissioner Bigge in 1908 McNab Historical Records 1/536]

MARKHAM The whole face of the Country where it is not Forest is Covered with this Kicaitore and Fern or the New Zealand Flax. (1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles),36,1963 ed.)

McDONNELL Cordage and fishing-lines, made from good New Zealand flax, has been proved to be far more durable than any made from European hemp. (1834,Extracts From a Journal,19,1979 ed.)

WALTON The most remarkable indigenous production of New Zealand, is the Phormium Tenax, or New Zealand flax. (1839,Twelve Months' Residence in NZ,12)

MURRAY (And) Phormium tenax New Zealand flax *[New Zealand consistently hyphenated in this book.] (1838,Account of Phormium Tenax, An)

F & S MATHEW Their seine' was ... made of thePhormium Tenax' - called by the base vulgar `N.Z. Flax.' (1840,Journal,32)

The only exports from New Zealand are wood, phormium tenax, or New Zealand flax, pork, potatoes, maize, sulphur and oil; ... (1842,GBPP,(No.569) 179) [NOTES: 1841 Dec 4 Hobson Despatch in GBPP 1842 (No.569) 179]

WAKEFIELD Phormium tenax, or New Zealand flax. (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,145)

These plains are all covered with New Zealand flax, fern, or long grass, with here and there a large cabbage tree, and are all surrounded with hills, from whence issue a great many little streams, some of whose courses being stopped spread over the adjoining ground and form what are called swamps. (Apr 16, 1849,Letters from Otago,30,1978 ed.)

MACKIE The N. Zealand flax - Phormium tenax -was growing abundantly by the road side - excellent rope is made from it ... (Feb 2, 1853,Traveller under Concern,74,1973 ed.)

ROCHFORT He earned a scanty living by manufacturing the New Zealand flax, and laying it up in ropes, cords, &c. (1853,Adventures of a Surveyor,35)

ANGAS The phormium tenax, or New Zealand flax, is the most useful plant that country affords. ... Of the leaves of the phormium ... the natives make all their common garments ... (1866,Polynesia,46)

HOOKER Flax, New Zealand.Phormium tenax (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),764)

LINDSAY [P. tenax] is the long-familiar New Zealand Flax' plant orFlax Lily' [fn `Treasury of Botany,' 1866]; terms which must now be held to include P. Colensoi ... (1868,Contributions to NZ Botany,79)

MEREDITH The whole [of the temporary Maori shelter] was then covered by layers of toi-toi, a tall fibrous rush-plant resembling pampas grass, tied in position with the ubiquitous harakiki (New Zealand flax) (1875,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,89,1935 ed.)

The refuse accumulates as a waste product in the process of producing the fibre variously known as New Zealand flax, New Zealand phormium, or New Zealand hemp. (Jan 15, 1913,NZ Journal of Agriculture,16)

native flax n 2 : NEW ZEALAND FLAX Ibid. 1524 new zealand flax or new zealand hemp n, usu cap N & Z 1 : a tall New Zealand herb (Phormium tenax) having erect, sword-shaped leaves and scarlet or yellow flowers 2 : the strong fiber from the leaves of New Zealand flax used chiefly for cordage, twine, and mattings (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,1506)

flax, New Zealand n. plant in New Zealand yielding a strong fibre, growing to height of nine feet. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. (Aust.-NZ Suppl.),616)

flax, New Zealand ... n. plant in N.Z. yielding strong fibre, growing up to nine feet. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),8)

New Zealand flax [s] Phormium tenax Forst. ... 52 New Zealand flax [=] rauhuia [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,52)

MOORE & IRWIN PHORMIUM TENAX, New Zealand flax, harakeke. (1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,180)

N.Z. Flax. Phormium tenax, Forst. (1868,TrNZI,1/III/50) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

Phormium tenax N.Z. flax (1870,TrNZI,2/126)

WEBSTER NEW ZEALAND FLAX, n. A plant, the phormium tenax, having broad, stiff leaves, ofextraordinary strength, whose fibres make excellent cordage. - Loudon. (1854,Dictionary of the English Language,672,(5th ed) ed.)

COLENSO In that country where the New Zealand flax grows everywhere wild. (1888,Fifty Years In Maoriland,5)

McGILL Rauhuia, New Zealand flax, or Linum monogynum was the country's first indigenous export, if you don't count dried heads. (1980,Ghost Towns of NZ,221)

1 n. (Rural) Phormium tenax, the native flax [farmed extensively in 1800s and 1900s.]

The Phormium tenax or New Zealand flax is known by the Maori to be of several species. (Dec 15, 1928,Hawera Star,11)

CAIRD The New Zealand flax (Phormium tenax) is a good deal exported, and in the opinion of many people it bids fair to become an important item in the trade of the country. (1874,Notes on Sheepfarming in NZ,43)

WALLACE New Zealand Flax or Phormium fibre, designated in the home market as New Zealand hemp. (1891,Rural Economy of Aust. & NZ,249)

The refuse accumulates as a waste product in the process of producing the flax fibre variously known as New Zealand flax, New Zealand phormium or New Zealand hemp. (Jan 1913,NZ Journal of Agriculture,16)

New Zealand flounder¶

n. i.e. sand flounder

Sand Flounder New Zealand Flounder, Patiki, Three corner, Tinplate Rhombosolea plebeia (1911,Records of the Canterbury Museum,1/197) [NOTES: Waite]

New Zealand frog¶

n.

On the NEW ZEALAND FROG (Leiopelma Hochstetteri), with an account of its remarkable feature in the history of some species of Australian frogs. By A. WANDER AITKEN. (1870,TrNZI,2/87)

Andreas REISCHEK In this district I found the rare New Zealand frog (pokopoko) both in the creeks and deep down in the mines. (1930,Yesterdays in Maoriland,80,1933 ed.)

new zealand frog n, usu cap N & Z : a rare frog (Liopelma hochstetteri) peculiar to New Zealand and the only amphibian known from that region (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,1524)

New Zealand fur seal¶

n. Arctocephalus forsteri (See Kekeno)

Another interesting specimen is that of the New Zealand fur seal, placed in the case containing the bears, the skin being so perfect that it was thought desirable to keep it under cover; it was killed not long ago on the Ocean Beach by Mr R. Paulin. (Sep 14, 1888,Otago Witness,16)

I can only speak of the latter, or New Zealand fur-seal. Formerly they were very abundant along the west coast of the South Island and on the Tasmanian coast. (1893,TrNZI,25/257) [NOTES: (Hector)]

Seals [ed. fn.3] The New Zealand Fur Seal or Kekeno, Arctocephalus forsteri (Lesson). (Mar 27, 1773,Cook's Journals,2/111,1961 ed.)

McLINTOCK [Arctocephalus forsteri] The New Zealand fur seal is peculiar to this country, although very similar to a closely related form inhabiting southern Australia and Tasmania. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/203)

Arctocephalus forsteri called the `New Zealand fur seal' (Apr 1987,National Geographic Magazine)

WILLIAMS (1917,Dictionary of the Maori Language,277)

Despite being hunted to the edge of extinction in the 19th century, New Zealand fur seals seem to be making a modest recovery. (Nov 2001,NZ Geographic,No. 54/34)

New Zealand fur seals were almost invisible against the rocks as they lay, warming up on the ledges after a morning's fishing. (Aug 14, 2004,Dominion Post,E16)

New Zealand Grammar¶

n. (book title)

MARSDEN I remained in the house nearly all the day examining the New Zealand Grammar, which appearsto be very imperfect. (Sep 1823,Letters & Journals of Samuel Marsden,373,1932 ed.)

New Zealand grapefruit¶

n. (See goldfruit)

When we were living [in South Africa] in the 1960s, we heard of a citrus orchard in Rustenberg that grew hybrod oranges named Rex Union oranges, famous for making excellent marmalade. We went to this pretty little country town and found an orchard named 'Dunedin' and bought a bag of the oranges... What surprised us was that the Rex Union oranges seemed to be identical to our New Zealand grapefruit. Many years later.. I was reading about Morrison's Orchard in Warkworth and was struck by the statement that the original grapefruit tree had come from Kawau Island and that Sir George Grey couldn't remember where he had got the plant. Grey had been Governor of Cape Province, South Africa, from 1854-1861 and was known to have brought many South African plants to New Zealand. Are 'New Zealand grapefruit', 'Rex Union oranges'? (Oct 26, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),40) [NOTES: Letter from Jill Williamson]

One Aucklander.. was unable to obtain a New Zealand grapefruit at any of the hotels at which he stayed. (Feb 9, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,78)

The New Zealand grapefruit is probably the most successfully grown orange in New Zealand. (Apr 27, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,79)

New Zealand grass¶

n. = native grass (See native grass,English grass)

DRURY New Zealand grass (native grass) (1854,Revised Sailing Directions,66)

New Zealand green¶

n. NZ-grown marijuana

YSKA Another muggles-happy jazz drummer earned the nickname N.Z. Green. (1990,NZ Green,53)

New Zealand Green Party¶

n.

Dr Tim Bale.. who is researching the New Zealand Green Party, doesn't believe joining a government spells doom for the Green parties but he notes they don't need to be in cabinet to be effective, Certainly that is what the Greens claim as they wheel out their achievements to celebrate their first parliamentary anniversary. (Nov 26, 2000,Sunday Star Times,C2)

New Zealand harrier¶

n. (See kahu)

HAAST Its large size, more pointed wings, and dark colour distinguished it at once from the New Zealand Harrier (Circus Gouldii), so common on our plains. (1879,Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland,135)

New Zealand hawthorn¶

n.

There is a name of this kind lately given - "New Zealand hawthorn" - to Carpodetus serratus... This tree is not in the least like that of the hawthorn... Seeing that the point of resemblance is in the flower, and that the flower of the hawthorn is known as "may", why not "Maori may"? (1925,TrNZI,56/62)

New Zealand heath¶

n.

On that high ridge.. may be found the New Zealand heath, epacris pauciflora. (Nov 12, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,8)

New Zealand House¶

n. (i) (hist.) the London headquarters of the NZ Company. (ii) the building housing the NZ High Commission in London

New Zealand House received a steady flow of telephone calls from confused prospective migrants..."I think he was worried about getting a punch a day", a spokesman at New Zealand House said today. (Mar 9, 1974,Dominion,3)

MITCHELL At first they [sc. NZ girls] cluster round New Zealand House, where the New Zealand skirt length going up meets the British coming down. (1972,Half-Gallon Quarter-Acre Pavlova Paradise, The,169)

The ILN invited readers and a panel of distinguished people known to be interested in the environment to select buildings that London would be better off without... Other buildings high on the list were the South Bank buildings.. New Zealand House, the Hilton Hotel.. and the Queen Elizabeth II Conference Centre. (1992,Illustrated London News,Spring / 14)

[Caption] Carlton Hotel, London, on thecorner of Pall Mall and Haymarket, whichis expected to be demolished early in1957 to make room for New Zealand House. (Jul 19, 1955,Evening Post,17)

New Zealand House,/ Broad-street Buildings, 22 October 1840. ... The gentlemen who have been associated under the name of the New Zealand Company, for the purpose of promoting the settlement of New Zealand, ... It is, therefore, with great satisfaction that the Company perceives in the recent proclamations ... an opening for a satisfactory adjustment ... (Oct 22, 1840,GBPP,(No.311) 21,1841 ed.) [NOTES: 1840 Oct 22 Joseph Somes to Lord John in GBPP House of Commons 1841]

CHAPMAN I address the following observations to you [Somes, Governor of the NZ Company], because I am well aware of the anxious desire ... to give your support within the New Zealand House, and your influence without, to whatever measures are calculated to promote the prosperity of the colony; ... (1843,NZ Portfolio,97)

?The immigration department at New ZealandHouse has just erected a large notice-board in its reception area to carry jobvacancies. (Apr 10, 1969,Evening Post,12)

﻿If he is successful he will then returnto New Zealand House for travelformalities to be completed. (Apr 10, 1969,Evening Post,12)

[Heading] Demonstrators to Haunt NZHouse. (Jun 4, 1970,Evening Post,7)

New Zealand howl¶

n.

WILLIAMS Having addressed himself to Tu and extolled the acts and brave deeds of these warriors, and viewed the payment (the fourteen heads of Nateawa) he expressed his approbation and turned to Titore, fell on his neck, and immediately both began a New Zealand howl. This lasted a few minutes, ... (Nov 28, 1832,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,265,1961 ed.)

New Zealand Institute¶

n.

Whereas by an Act of the General Assembly of New Zealand, intituled "The New Zealand Institute Act, 1867," it is enacted that.. The Governor,.. and six other persons to be appointed.. shall be a Board of Governors of an Institution which shall be called "The New Zealand Institute." (Mar 9, 1868,NZ Gazette,111)

No Society shall be incorporated with the Institute under the provisions of "The New Zealand Institute Act, 1867," unless such society shall count not less than twenty-five members, subscribing in the aggregate a sum of not less than fifty pounds sterling annually, for the promotion of art, science, or such other branch of knowledge for which it is associated. (1868,TrNZI,I/00) [NOTES: Check page]

An Act to establish an Institute for the Advancement of Science and Art in New Zealand... The short Title of this Act shall be "The New Zealand Institute Act, 1867"... The Governor,.. and six other persons to be appointed.. shall be a Board of Governors of an Institution which shall be called "The New Zealand Institute." (1867,NZ Statutes,31 Vict. 36/443)

von HAAST The New Zealand Institute and the Wellington Philosophical Institute started in 1868 with a great splash. Ibid. 670 I think that if we could get the N.Z. Institute to be peripatetic and meet annually at the different towns, we should have a much greater hold upon it... Remember, too, that all these causes of rupture are temporary: the Institute stands, the members go! Ibid 671 I have not seen Hector's remarks on the report of the Institute. (1948,Life & Times of Sir Julius von Haast,510) [NOTES: Quotes from HUTTON 1876]

FLEMING During the 35 years that followed its inauguration, Hector remained in office as Manager and Editor of the New Zealand Institute. (1987,Science, Settlers & Scholars,19)

New Zealand iris¶

n.

RICHARDS LIBERTIA ...ixioides ... New Zealand Iris. MIKOIKOI. (1952,Chatham Islands,21)

Pick up the colour and interest of a collection of rounded beach or river stones with raoulia, and the spiky blue grass, Festiuca coxii, or contrast with the New Zealand iris, Libertia peregrinans of which some fine selected forms are available. (Sep 15, 2001,Dominion Weekend Magazine,10)

New Zealand jade¶

n.

CAMERON But Te Waipounamu (greenstone, or New Zealand jade) is a more common name for the South Island and describes it well. (1965,New Zealand (various authors/titles),33)

BELICH mere short club, sometimes of greenstone (New Zealand jade) (1986,NZ Wars, The,337) [NOTES: Maori Glossary]

New Zealand king shag¶

n. (Environment)

FORSTER We met with several Shags, espeially with a new Species, less than the common New Zeeland Shag: ... NEW ZEALAND KING SHAG Phalacrocorax carunculatus carunculatus (May 25, 1773,Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The,2/285)

New Zealand language¶

n. Maori

ANGAS ...there being more consonants used in the New Zealand language, Hawaii would become Hawaiki in the dialect of these latter people. (1847,Savage Life,1/306)

WILLIAMS A/ DICTIONARY/ OF THE/ NEW ZEALAND LANGUAGE/ TO WHICH IS ADDED/ A SELECTION OF COLLOQUIAL SENTENCES./ WILLIAM WILLIAMS, D.C.L./ ... [preface iii] The principal feature of this edition of the Maori Dictionary ... is the arrangement of the words. (1871,Dictionary of the NZ Language,[title page], iii [title page],3rd ed. ed.)

New Zealand lark¶

n.

In fact the only wild birds ...[38] were one or two quails, about the same number of New Zealand larks - who, alas! only break through their customary muteness to give utterance to a harsh unpleasant squeak - ... (Oct 4, 1861,NZ Goldfields,37,1976 ed.) [NOTES: Dunedin]

New Zealand laurel¶

n. Griselinia littoralis (broadleaf)

Griselinia littoralis NZ Laurel its flowers. (1877,TrNZI,9:) [NOTES: And.]

n. karaka

MATTHEWS (And) Corynocarpus laevigata NZ laurel (1890,Descriptive & Priced List)

KIRK Corynocarpus laevigata NZ laurel (1899,Students' Flora)

WHITE Corynocarpus levigata, or Karaka, sometimes called the `New Zealand Laurel,' makes a fine large evergreen tree 40 feet high. (1905,My NZ Garden,90)

LAING & BLACKWELL (And) Corynocarpus laevigata NZ laurel (1906,Plants of NZ)

COCKAYNE (And) Corynocarpus laevigata NZ laurel (1907,AJHR) [NOTES: Report on a Botanical Survey of Kapiti Island]

(And) Corynocarpus laevigata NZ laurel (1908,AJHR,C-14) [NOTES: Report on a Botanical Survey of Waipoua Kauri Forest]

NAIRN & SON (And) Corynocarpus laevigata NZ laurel (1912,Catalogue (Nairn & Son))

LAING & BLACKWELL This tree [karaka] is often called by settlers the New Zealand Laurel. The Karaka forms the chief forest in the Chatham Islands, and was much used by the natives in the making of canoes. (1907,Plants of NZ,233,1940 ed. p. 247 ed.)

LAING & BLACKWELL A handsome tree with laurel-like foliage. ... This tree is often called by the settlers the New Zealand Laurel (1940,Plants of NZ,245)

RIVES We saw a number of N.Z. pigeons feeding on the kamacas(?) [sic in TS: surely karacas] or south sea laurel(?) [sic]. We reached the dismal town of Kai-koura about 3 pm. It is the most God forsaken place I ever saw and the inn is indeed fearful. The view from the window included the filthiest of pigs and a black calf in the distance. I have been reading Gladstone's pamphlet on the Vatican decrees. (Feb 12, 1875,Jottings on the Spot,2)

New Zealand Legion¶

n.

SINCLAIR In 1933 the New Zealand Legion,a semi-fascist organization ... sprang up, ... to abolish party government and bring dynamic leadership to the nation. Fortunately it was a weed which, flourishing in sour ground, was soon crowded out by healthier growths when rising prices fertilized the land. (1959,History of New Zealand,238)

BOYD Sir Andrew Russell and other dissatisfied sheepfarmers in the Reform Party lent some support to the New Zealand Legion which advocated a return to free enterprise. (1984,City of the Plains,276)

New Zealand lemon sole¶

n.

GRAHAM NEW ZEALAND LEMON SOLE Peltotretis flavilatus Waite. The Lemon Sole, like the Common Sole, Flounder, Brill and Turbot is a bottom-dwelling fish with both eyes on the upper surface of the body, known as the right side. This fish and the others mentioned are known to fishermen, auctioneers, retailers and the public generally as Flatfish. Skate and Electric-ray are also Flatfish, the upper and lower surfaces being the back and belly. (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,210)

DOOGUE & MORELAND LEMON SOLE ... Other names: Pelotretis flavilatus ; New Zeland lemon sole. (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,219)

New Zealand lilac¶

n. Quintinia serrata, aka tawheowheo [North Island only: Auckland, Hawke's Bay, and Taranaki.]

On rock faces, Pachystegia grow alongside the New Zealand lilac, Heliohebe hulkeana, the crinkly-leaved Senecio monroii and the robust Hebe salicifolia. (Nov 30, 2004,Dominion Post,E 13)

Kumarahou (N.Z. lilac) .. Quintinia serrata .. Timber a light red colour, and principally used for firewood Ibid. 24 423 Kumarahou (New Zealand lilac) slab. (1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,11)

LAING & BLACKWELL Quintinia serrata (The Serrated Quintinia) ... Called by settlers [Sometimes called] New Zealand lilac . Maori name [ Tawheowheo ]. North Island only: Auckland, Hawke's Bay, and Taranaki. (1907,Plants of NZ,186,1940 p. 193 ed.)

2 n. Hebe hulkeana, aka Marlborough lilac

KIRK (And) Veronica Hulkeana NZ lilac (1899,Students' Flora)

COCKAYNE ... the delightful Veronica Hulkeana, with varnished green leaves, whose masses of delicate lilac flowers have earned for it the name of New Zealand lilac; ... (1910,NZ Plants,80)

(Apr 2, 1941,NZ Gardener,641)

MATTHEWS (1943,NZ Gardening Dictionary, The,83,3rd ed. ed.) [NOTES: Also in 5th edition, 1951]

MARTIN These Marlborough shrubs include the ROCK DAISY ( Pachystegia insignis ) finest of its tribe, the NEW ZEALAND LILAC ( Hebe hulkeana ), ... . (1961,Flora NZ,199) [NOTES: 1st ed. 1929]

New Zealand mafia¶

n. an informal NZ professional network in London or Britain; also in Australia [interview on TVI 24/8/84 with Andy Anderson a NZ born actor on Aust. TV - used the expression.] (See cits in DNZE (one for Kiwi mafia also))

New Zealand Medal¶

n. [The New Zealand Medal (its correct name, not Maori War Medal) was awarded to those who had actually been under fire in any engagement from 1845 through 1847 or from 1860 through 1872. It was approved for award to British troops in 1869 and six months later extended to colonial forces.]

TINNE most of them distinguished themselves ... during the war, which are but ill rewarded by the universal New Zealand medal, and a most scanty pay. (1873,Wonderland of the Antipodes,32)

SUTHERLAND THE NEW ZEALAND (MAORI WAR) MEDAL. [heading] ... The Gazette issued at Auckland on 23 October, 1869, p. 590, notifies the extension to the Colonial Forces of the grant for the decoration conferred `for the War in New Zealand to all persons whether belonging to the local forces or loyal native tribes, who were actually under fire in any engagement with the enemy, or were otherwise conspicuous for distinguished service in the field.' (1941,Numismatic History of NZ,228)

New Zealand Militia¶

n.

In 1863, when skirmishes broke out on the Wanganui Coast, Durie was appointed to a command in the NZ Militia however his duties kept him busy in town and he was unable to take up his command. (Aug 2001,NZ Memories,No. 31/46)

New Zealand mint¶

n.

RICHARDS Mentha ... Cunninghamii. A minute, fragrant perennial ... The whole plant has a delicious smell. ... New Zealand Mint. HIOI. (1952,Chatham Islands,43)

mint, New Zealand [s] Mentha cunninghamii Benth. Ibid. 53 New Zealand mint [s] Mentha cunninghamii Benth. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,49)

New Zealand musk¶

n. Mimulus repens

COCKAYNE Mimulus repens New Zealand musk (1919,NZ Plants & Their Story) [NOTES: (And)]

MARTIN ... commonly on the margin of the stream itself grows the NEW ZEALAND MUSK (Mimulus repens), a leafy herb with lilac-tinted flowers internally yellow. (1961,Flora NZ,243,1929 ed.)

New Zealand mutton¶

n. (humorous) pork

My first meal was New Zealand mutton. It was very white.. and I found out afterwards that was the name given to pork. (Sep 17, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,8)

PHILIPS I recollect in very early times,[? d] being served with what looked like very white meat; and, asking what it was, was told `New Zealand Mutton',and it was some time before I was undeceived. (1897,Memories of the Past,38)

The same correspondent also wants to knowwho paid the expenses of the 1888-89 NewZealand Native Rugby Union's team to theBritish Isles and Australia... The NewZealand Natives team's tour was organisedby J.A. Warbrick. (May 20, 1950,Southern Cross (Wgton),10)

Among the little bodies with a big name in this Dominion is the New Zealand Natives' Association, Wellington. ... The N.Z.N.A. had the benefit of a very enthusiastic secretary ... (Mar 1, 1918,Quick March,29)

New Zealand On Air¶

n.

Fortunately, a celebration of the local industry that kicks off with Eric the NZ On Air goldfish practising his acceptance speech was always going to have its lighter moments. (Apr 10, 1993,Listener (New Zealand Listener),71)

NZ On Air funding must also remain fully contestable. (May 26, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),7)

Should TVNZ get most of New Zealand On Air's funds? (May 29, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),26)

New Zealand owl¶

n. morepork

BULLER SPILOGLAUX NOVAE ZEALANDIAE. (NEW-ZEALAND OWL, OR MOREPORK.) ... Native names. Ruru, Koukou, and Peho; `Morepork' of the colonists. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,17,1888 2nd edn 1/192 ed.)

DOMETT Night-hawk or New Zealand Owl ..... Strigidae; Spiloglaux Novae Zealandiae: (Buller) The `morepork' of the colonists. (1883,Ranolf and Amohia,1/305)

BULLER As the night closed in upon us we heard all round the solemn notes of the New Zealand Owl: first, a distinct kou-kou, kou-kou; ... and then, in alternation, the alarm note and ever familiar cry of `more-pork'. (1888,Birds of New Zealand,1/13)

Spiloglaux novae-zealandiae, Gmelin. (The New Zealand Owl.) (1893,TrNZI,25/71) [NOTES: Buller]

Morepork Ninox novaeseelandiae novaeseelandiae (GMELIN, 1788) ... OTHER NAMES: Ruru, New Zealand owl, boobook owl. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,257)

From Mr. Wayte's objurgation against the New Zealand owl in his letter to the Southern Cross of 21st May, it might be inferred that he had derived his knowledge of the habits of this bird from Mr. Ovid's fables rather than from his own personal observation. (Jun 12, 1868,Daily Southern Cross,5)

New Zealand pampas grass¶

n. toetoe [also New Zealand pampas grass] (See pampas grass)

... all the open ground surrounding the settlement [at Piraki] ... being covered with tussac-grass, raupo, or tohitohi (N.Z. pampas-grass). IBid. (Ed. Notes and corrections) [insert] BUSH. - Toe toe. New Zealand pampas-grass. (1911,Piraki Log,155)

BEATTIE They dwelt in whares [11] (huts) built in the traditional shape of an inverted V, roofed with grass, and lined inside with the reeds of the toetoe or New Zealand pampas grass. The orthodox Maori name for these reeds is pukakaho, but the white men called them `bukaka'. (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,10)

New Zealand Party¶

n.

JAMES The vast majority gave as their reason for joining the New Zealand Party National's departure from its principles. (1986,Quiet Revolution, The,129)

JONES I have today seen the letter published in your 25 November issue from the chairman of the New Zealand Party's steering committee. (1990,80s Letters,63)

That saw the emergence the following year of the New Zealand Party, spearheaded by property developed Sir Robert Jones. (Aug 6, 1992,Dominion,11)

New Zealand flax see FLAX; New Zealand hawthorn = MATAGOURI; New Zealand honeysuckle = REWA-REWA; New Zealand Party a right-wing NZ political party founded in 1983 by Mr Robert Jones; New Zealand pigeon see PIGEON; New Zealand spinach annual NZ plant with leaves eaten like spinach. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,506) [NOTES: nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng.Dict.]

New Zealand Pierrots¶

n.

Suitably clothed, and altogether in theright frame of mind, the New ZealandPierrots now proceeded along the road tosuccess and their fame spread. (Mar 27, 1918,Chronicles NZEF,IV/40 : 81)

Another clever coterie of merrimentmerchants are the "N.Z. Pierrots," orBase Concert Party. (Jul 5, 1918,Chronicles NZEF,IV/47 : 248)

New Zealand pigeon¶

n. (Environment) the NZ wood-pigeon, also called a dove, kereru any of a family of fast-flying birds with a compact body, small head and short legs. [wood pigeon, kereru see also native, New Zealand, wild pigeon Hemiphaga novaeseelandiae, bush pigeonwood-pigeon; kuku, kukupa; kereru; (white-)breaster] (See wood pigeon,kereru)

FORSTER In the morning ... I went ... to the Indian Cove, & shot there two new Kingfishers [[ed. fn] Now the new Zealand Kingfisher ...], some new yellow headed Flycatchers [[ed. fn] Now the Yellowhead Mohoua ochrocephala (Gmelin, 1789).], a fine large green and brown Pigeon [[ed. fn] Now the New Zealand pigeon ...] ..., a small Perrokeet, green with a red forehead ... [ed. fn] Now the Red-crowned Parakeet ... (Apr 2, 1773,Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The,2/245,1982 ed.) [NOTES: 1773 May 11 see also HAWK]

FORSTER A very fine species of crayfish (cancer homarus Lin.) longer than the lobster, some shell-fish, and ... a cormorant, duck, pigeon, or parrot gave us an agreeable variety at our table ... (1777,Voyage Round the World,1/144)

SAV AGE ...the only [bird] species I saw that struck me as new, was a pigeon, of beautiful plumage, large size, and delicious eating. (1807,New Zealand (various authors/titles),10)

CRUISE We saw a few small birds of very rich plumage, and shot some wild pigeons. (Mar 14, 1820,Journal,56,1957 ed.) [NOTES: 1823 (1820 March 14) Cruise Journal (1957) 56]

BISCOE [At Chathams] to my great surprise saw a large Black Cat, I likewise shot some very large white & blue pigeon. (Dec 2, 1831,Journal) [NOTES: 1831 Dec 2 J.Biscoe Journal in 1913 McNab Old Whaling Days 420]

WILLIAMS All were very kind; they had prepared a feast of Pigeons, Pipis and Kumara. (May 21, 1833,Early History of the Dovedale Valley,315,1961 ed.)

MAY The Pigeon or Wood Quest (Kukupa) is a very beautiful bird. (1840,Journal of Ensign Best,222,1966 ed.)

BUTLER The pigeon is larger than the English, and far handsomer. (1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,9/138)

DIEFFENBACH In the lower regions the forest was much enlivened by birds. I shot some parrots [fn Nestor meridionalis. Kaka of the natives.], pigeons [fn Columba spadicea, Lath. Kukupa.], and wattle-birds [fn Glaucopis cinerea, Gmel. Kokako.]. Among the branches of the trees hopped the neat fantail flycatcher [fn Muscicapa flabellifera, Gml. Piwakawaka.], and a social bird of a yellow colour, which has been depicted by Forster [fn Orthornyx heteroclytus, Lef. Popokatea.], and which had much the habits of the finch. (1843,Travels in NZ,1/29)

THOMSON Several kinds of birds are indigenous to the woods and waters; among them the oyster-catcher, bittern, kingfisher, cormorant, quail, wild-duck, mocking or [16] parson bird, parrots, parroquets, woodhen, pigeon, etc. (the [sic] gigantic Moa bird is believed to be now quite extinct). (1867,Twelve Years in Canterbury,15)

I noticed the following:- Pigeon, tui, korimako, kaka, ruru, piwakawaka, toutouwai, kingfisher, duck and teal in the lakes, and pukeko in the swamp, and various sea birds. (1884,TrNZI,17/419) [NOTES: Gold-Smith) [pl]]

  1. Carpophaga novae-zealandiae. Pigeon, Kuku. (Jul 1885,NZ Journal of Science,483) [NOTES: (T.H. Potts)]

WILLIAMS Kuku, n. pigeon; (1892,Dictionary of the NZ Language,78)

pigeon ... (also New Zealand pigeon) green and bronze NZ bird. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,568) [NOTES: [cf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 857]]

The stillness is unbroken save by the soft note of the pigeon. (Oct 11, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,7)

A wild pigeon had just been feeding on berries that seemed to have been steeped in turpentine. (Dec 17, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,8)

MARKHAM Pigeons live on berries of different Trees, ...Ibid. 56 When in the Woods she looked out for the (Coo Coupers) [kukupa] or Pigeons, and had a sharp eye. (1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles),34,1963 ed.)

McDONNELL The Pigeon and Zooe are perhaps the handsomest - the former is really a magnificent bird - almost as large as a barn-door fowl, and equally invites the attention of the Ornothologist and the epicurean - the latter has two feathery [35] wattles pendent from its ear, and some few of its notes are not unlike those of the wattle bird of Van Diemen's Land. (1834,Extracts From a Journal,34)

n. (Environment) kereru [ORIGIN: Maori] (See kereru)

DIEFFENBACH ... the berries of which form the favourite food of the beautiful New Zealand pigeon, the plumage of which displays all the colours of the rainbow. (1843,Travels in NZ,1/27)

ANGAS ... one of the beautiful New Zealand pigeons (carpophaga Novae Selandicae), ... would flutter away into the darker recesses of the forest. (1847,Savage Life,2/30)

ELDER The New Zealand pigeons are as small as half-grown fowls. We had them dressed and had a plentiful dinner and something to spare. (Aug 3, 1819,Marsden's Lieutenants) [NOTES: 1819 Aug 3 William Hall in Elder Marsden's Lieutenants (1934) 223]

McDONNELL The New Zealand pigeon is as splendidly beautiful in plumage as it is exquisitely delicious to the taste. (1834,Extracts From a Journal,16,1979 ed.)

BULLER CARPOPHAGA NOVAE ZEALANDIAE. (NEW-ZEALAND PIGEON.) ... Native names. Kuku, Kukupa, and Kereru. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,157,1888 2nd edn 1/229 ed.)

DURRELL [NZ Pigeon]. (1966,Two in the Bush,45)

FALLA et al. NEW ZEALAND PIGEON Hemiphaga novaeseelandiae Maori names: Kereru, kuku,kukupa (1966,Birds of New Zealand,168)

211.a. Hemiphaga novaeseelandiae novaeseelandiae (Gmelin, 1789) New Zealand Pigeon (Kereru) (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,57,1980 ed.)

New Zealand Pigeon Hemiphaga novaeseelandiae GMELIN, 1789) ... [239] Chatham Island Pigeon H.n. chathamensis (ROTHSCHILD, 1891) OTHER NAMES: Kereru, kuku, kukupa. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,236)

An interesting feature is the number of New Zealand birds - the kukupa, or New Zealand pigeon, the tui, kaka, and others. (Jan 11, 1897,Evening Post,5)

2 n. the native huia

Huia, a New Zealand pigeon, whose feathers are worn by chiefs only. (Oct 26, 1893,Otago Witness,39)

New Zealand pine¶

n. an old word for kauri(-pine).

From the great increase of population at Melbourne, and the consequent demand for house room, very large supplies of timber are required; and the great superiority of New Zealand pine over the hard woods of Australia, from the facility with which it is worked, is so great a consideration where carpenter's wages are 20s a day, as to cause it to be in universal request. (May 4, 1853,New Zealand Spectator & Cook's Strait Guardian,2)

.. New Zealand pine, assorted, 9s 3d to 9s 9d. (May 3, 1870,Wellington Independent,3)

MARKHAM ... the Sawn Plank is very cheap in the Colonies and lately there is some prejudice against the New Zealand Pine. (1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles),48) [NOTES: see also p. 33]

McDONNELL Her spars, one and all, were of New [19] Zealand pine (cawdie); they were faultless. (1834,Extracts From a Journal,18,1979 ed.)

MATHEW ... here I first saw the famed Koudi tree which is now so extensively used for masts and spars under the name of New Zealand pine. It is a magnificent tree certainly, but not at all like our ideas of Pine, as it has a fine branching head quite different to any of the fir species. The Coudie or Courie [kauri], as it is called, the New Zealand Pine, growing 80 or 90 feet without a branch .... (Apr 25, 1840,Journal) [NOTES: 1840 Apr 25 Sarah Mathew Journal in 1940 Founding of NZ 126]

In the new duties on timber New Zealand pine is exempt, and 1s 6d per hundred lineal feet is imposed on boardings. (Aug 1, 1892,Hawke's Bay Herald,3)

It is estimated that the tariff will affect butter manufacturers using New Zealand pine to the extent of aGBP10,000 per annum. (Aug 15, 1907,Evening Post,7)

Her spars, one and all, were of New Zealand Pine (cowdie) [sic]; they were faultless. (Jul 18, 1840,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,3)

We are glad to hear that 25,000 feet of New Zealand Pine will be shipped from here in the Mary Anne to Sydney. (Jul 5, 1845,New Zealand Spectator & Cook's Strait Guardian,2)

New Zealand pipit¶

n.

BULLER ANTHUS NOVAE ZEALANDIAE. (NEW -ZEALAND PIPIT.) ... Native names. Pihoihoi and Whioi; `Ground-Lark' of the colonists. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,132,1888 2nd edn 1/63 ed.)

GUTHRIE-SMITH The Ground Lark There are several species ... that may be called homestead birds, such as the New Zealand Pipit, or Ground Lark, the Waxeye, the Warbler and the Fantail. (1927,Birds of New Zealand,133)

POWELL NEW ZEALAND PIPIT (Anthus novaeseelandiae), also called the ground lark, is a common bird throughout the country. (1947,Native Animals of NZ,86)

FALLA et al. NEW ZEALAND PIPIT Anthus novaeseelandiae Other names: Pihoihoi, Sandlark (Chathams). ... The Skylark, with which it is commonly confused, lives in pasture land where the Pipit is generally absent, but the ranges of the two species overlap in rough open country, etc. (1966,Birds of New Zealand,216)

246.a. Anthus novaeseelandiae novaeseelandiae (Gmelin, 1789) New Zealand Pipit (Pihoihoi) (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,65,1980 ed.)

Pipit Anthus novaeseelandiae (GMELIN, 1789) ... New Zealand Pipit A.n. novaeseelandiae (GMELIN, 1789). Auckland Islands Pipit A.n. aucklandicus GRAY, 1862. Antipodes Pipit A.n. steindachneri REISCHEK, 1889. ... OTHER NAMES: Pihoihoi, groundlark, native lark. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,270)

Moon The New Zealand pipit is widely distributed throughout the country. It inhabits rough pastures, riverbeds, sandy beaches and forest margins. (2002,Birds of New Zealand,111)

New Zealand porpoise¶

n. Hector's dolphin

DOOGUE & MORELAND HECTOR'S DOLPHIN ... Confined to New Zealand . . . Other names: Cephalorhynchus hectori; native dolphin, New Zealand porpoise. (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,305)

New Zealand Post¶

n. the Post Office (1988-)

New Zealand primrose¶

n. Ourisia macrophylla, New Zealand primrose

LAING & BLACKWELL The beautiful white flowers, and large cordate leaves, bear some slight resemblance to those of the Chinese Primrose, and it is possibly on this account that O[uris]ia macrophylla is called by colonists , [misnamed locally,] the New Zealand Primrose. (1907,Plants of NZ,385,1940 p. 411 ed.)

New Zealand quail¶

n. koreke (extinct)

The rapid disappearance of the New Zealand quail from this island is a subject of great regret to our sportsmen. (Jul 7, 1866,Daily Southern Cross,5)

DIEFFENBACH ... they [dogs] are perhaps the cause that the New Zealand quail (Coturnix Novae Zelandiae, Quoy et Gaim.) is so scarce in the northern island, - and also the guana. (1843,Travel in NZ,i/417)

BULLER COTURNIX NOVAE ZEALANDIAE. (NEW-ZEALAND QUAIL.) ... Native names.- Koreke {and Kokoreke}. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,1/161, 1/225)

WILLIAMS Koitareke n. New Zealand Quail; coturnix Novae Zelandiae. (1871,Dictionary of the NZ Language,57) [NOTES: 3rd ed.]

WHITE The New Zealand Quail, which was very plentiful, is nearly extinct now: Bush-fires have burnt it, and dogs, cats, and rats have eaten it, but the Australian and Californian varieties have filled its place. (1905,My NZ Garden,69)

Related very closely to the still surviving Australian stubble quail, the New Zealand quail was once common in parts of the North and South Islands. Being a species living mainly in grasslands, it was more abundant in the South Island on its eastern side than in the North where its distribution was far more localised. By the mid-nineteenth century the koreke, as it was known to the Maori, was already uncommon in the North Island, though at about the same time it was still abundant in parts of Nelson and Otago. By 1870 it was regarded as having been completely exterminated in the North, and five years later the South Island populations had vanished too. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/7)

124 Coturnix novaezelandiae novaezelandiae Quoy and Gaimard, 1830 New Zealand Quail ... extinct since about 1870.(Koreke) (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,40) [NOTES: 1980 ed.]

The New Zealand quail (Coturnix novae-zealandiae) is often cited as showing how rapidly a species will become extinct. (1889,TrNZI,21/207)

New Zealand Railways Corporation¶

n.

Staff numbers at New Zealand Railways Corporation - till now known as TrackCo - might swell to more than 500 if it takes back the job of maintaining the railway network. (Jul 5, 2004,Dominion Post,C1)

New Zealand rat¶

n. kiore

Sent him a specimen of N.Z. rat by Pirikawau. (Dec 15, 1850,Torlesse Papers,181,1958 ed.)

THOMSON ... the almost extinct New Zealand rat is like the rats found in the Navigators' Islands and Rarotonga. (1859,Story of New Zealand, The,1/59)

The difference was that the lemmings drowned themselves to end their journey, while the New Zealand rat apparently moved from one district to die in the next. (Apr 10, 1934,Feilding Star,7)

New Zealand Rhine¶

n. the Whanganui River

And quite recently the Under-Secretary for Lands ... in reply to criticism of the policy of... witholding ... certain lands on the Wanganui watershed, very wisely pointed out that, unless the forest in that locality were ... protected, the famous `New Zealand Rhine', not only as a beauty spot, but as a navigable river, would soon be a thing of the past. (1911,TrNZI,43/446)

HOWE The Wanganui River is known as `the Rhine of New Zealand' (1913,Travel Letters,84)

New Zealand robin¶

n. (Environment)

The New Zealand robin (curiously the South Island and not the North Island variety) hopped round the traveller freely. (Oct 20, 1906,Star, The,4)

Across the path ... comes the bush, full of birds singing all day, tuis and bell-birds and New Zealand robins ... (Sep 8, 1851,Letters from Canterbury, NZ) [NOTES: 1851 Sep 8 C. Godley ?Letters from Canterbury in 1947 Reed Story of Canterbury 100]

DRURY BIRDS MET WITH IN PELORUS ... New Zealand Robin - common in the bush (1855,Sailing Directions,66)

HAAST Amongst the small inhabitants ... is the Totoara, the New Zealand robin, which is the first to welcome the explorer in the wilderness, and which remains steadily near the camp. (1861,Report on Topographical Exploration of Nelson,140)

BARKER Many of [the native birds] have English names, which I found very tantalising, especially when the New Zealand Robin was announced, and I could only see a fat little ball of a bird, with a [94] yellowish-white breast. (1866,Station Life in NZ,93)

HAY The Toutou (Miro longipes) is a small grey and white bird, which some people have said is called the New Zealand robin. It is to be seen in the bush now and then, and seems tame, but we prefer to call another species our robin. (1882,Brighter Britain,2/224)

PETROICA. - New Zealand Robin. ... The song is very melodious, especially that of Petroica longipes (North Island Wood Robin). (1886,TrNZI,18/102) [NOTES: (Reischek)]

NATUSCH NEW ZEALAND ROBINS (Petroica australis, ... ) are divided into various subspecies: the North Island longipes is a bit smaller and duller, and rather more mottled, than the South Island australis, the Stewart Island one is rakiura. The Chatham Island robin is P.traversi. (1967,Animals of NZ, The,279)

New Zealand Romney¶

1 n. (Rural) a New Zealand-bred sheep, developed from the Romney Marsh breed.

MEADOWS In 1956, in recognition of the changes it had undergone from its original ancestors, the name of the breed was changed to New Zealand Romney. (1997,Sheep Breeds of New Zealand,66)

The breed [Romney] changed to suit its new surroundings to become, over the years, a distinct breed - the New Zealand Romney. (2001,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: www.sheepworld.co.nz/SheepFarming.htm]

New Zealand sandalwood¶

n. maire (See sandalwood)

Sań.dal-wood́. (s&abreve.ń.dal-w&obreve.&obreve.d́.), n. [Add.] New Zealand sandalwood (Bot.), Fusanus Cunninghamii. See under MAIRE. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2030)

CHEESEMAN F[usanus] Cunninghamii, Benth and Hook.f. ... A small slender tree 10-25 ft. high; ... Maire; New Zealand Sandalwood. ... The wood is hard and dense ... (1906,Manual NZ Flora,624)

KIRK (1889,Forest Flora) [NOTES: (And)]

Fusanus Cunninghamii NZ sandalwood (1908,AJHR,C-14) [NOTES: 1908 Cockayne Report on a Botanical Survey of Waipoua Kauri Forest in AJHR C-14 (And)]

HOCHSTETTER Olea Cunninghamii New Zealand sandalwood (1867,New Zealand (various authors/titles)) [NOTES: (And) 1867 von Hochstetter NZ (list of trees from Taylor 1848)]

New Zealand sea spurge¶

n. Euphorbia glauca [aka shore spurge]

The New Zealand sea spurge, E. glauca, is rare and under cultivation at Otari Bush, Percy's Reserve and on Mana Island, where it was moved from a colony on Kapiti Island. (Sep 1, 2001,Dominion,10)

New Zealand shoveler¶

n. shoveler [or New Zealand shoveller]

FALLA et al. NEW ZEALAND SHOVELER Anas rhynchotis Other names : Kuruwhengi, Spoonbill, Spoonie. (1966,Birds of New Zealand,92)

BULLER SPATULA {RHYNCAPSIS} VARIEGATA. (NEW-ZEALAND SHOVELLER.) ... Native name . Tete, {Pateke,} Putaitai, Kuriwhengi, {Kuruwhengu, Papaungungu,} Kahoho, and Wetawetangu; `Spoon-bill Duck' of the colonists. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,252,1888 2nd edn 2/269 ed.)

Rhynchaspis variegata , Gould. (New Zealand Shoveller.) (1897,TrNZI,29/202) [NOTES: (Buller)]

113. Anas rhynchotis variegata (Gould, 1856) New Zealand Shoveler (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,38,1980 ed.)

New Zealand Shoveler Anas rhynchotis variegata (GOULD, 1856) ... OTHER NAMES: Kuru whengi, spoonbill, spoonie . (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,148)

New Zealand snail¶

n. (Environment) ['predication; in cit.? (predation?)]

Life is tough for the New Zealand snail. Powelliphanta marchanti is one of many large endemic carnivorous snails whose numbers are in decline due to habitat loss and predication from introduced pests. (Jul 2005,Conservation Action,23)

New Zealand spinach¶

n. a spinach-like edible native plant, Tetragonia tetragonoides (formerly expansa) or T. trigyna

For example, so-called New Zealand spinach (Tetragonia tetragonoides), whose seeds are still sold by that name as a native vegetable, is a strand plant found naturally from Japan south across the Pacific to Australia and New Zealand. (Mar 2001,NZ Geographic,No. 50/24)

New Zealand spinach has more bulk than other varieties. (Sep 27, 1999,Dominion,9)

GARDEN SEEDS. PEAS, broad beans, dwarf French beans ... and New Zealand spinach. (Jul 27, 1859,Lyttelton Times,8)

New Zealand spinach, which is supposed to be hardier than ordinary spinach and is used as a substitute for it, is in every way inferior. (Oct 13, 1928,Evening Post,20)

The subject of soil management for intensive cropping with vegetables, fruit, herbaceous borders, and lawns, was then dealt with more fully, and vegetables specially suitable for a sandy coastal soil were mentioned, with a special reference to the New Zealand spinach. (Jul 17, 1935,Evening Post,20)

New Zealand spinach does well now if the seeds are soaked first in hot water. (Dec 29, 1941,Evening Post,8)

..the sea celery.. for example, tastes similar to our own, while Australia's warrigal greens are one and the same as our New Zealand spinach. (Oct 25, 2003,Dominion Post,E6)

What we call kokihi or rengamutu you probably know better as New Zealand spinach or Warrigal cabbage (Tetragonia tetragonoides). (Oct 2000,Growing Today,37)

New Zealand spinach may be sown now, or in some localities plants may be obtained from the sea beach. (Sep 1, 1870,Daily Southern Cross,3)

For the first time in the Colony we have seen New Zealand spinach, a very fine parcel of which was exhibited by Mr. Hendry. (Jan 30, 1863,Daily Southern Cross,3)

New Zealand spinach, Tetragonia trigyna, a succulent plant native to the Chatham Islands. was boiled and eaten by whalers for a month to rid them of scurvy. (Aug 1991,NZ Gardener,29)

Among the species being grown in the new reserves are Muehlenbackia astonii (shrubby tororaro), Euphorbia glauca (shore spurge, thought to have been extinct in the Wellington region for 20 years, then rediscovered in 1996/96 on a rocky stack off Kapiti Island), Discaria tomentosa (a species of anchor plant, one of Wellington's - and the North Island's - rarest plants), Hebe speciosa (showy hebe) and Tetragonia tetragonioides (New Zealand spinach). (Jan 2004,NZ Geographic,No. 67/11)

CROWE (New Zealand spinach is found on coastal sands, dunes and stony beaches; it does not have a red, fleshy fruit, but a dry seed capsule)... While beach spinach is native only to this country, New Zealand spinach is , in spite of its name, native also to Tasmania, Australia, the Pacific Islands, Japan and southern South America, having been used as a vegetable in south Brazil, Mauritius, Tongatapu and Kanaky (New Caledonia). It is eaten also as a vegetable side dish in Indonesia (especially on Java), where it is sometimes grown for sale. (1995,Which Coastal Plant?,30)

New Zealand spinach is a native plant that Captain Cook used to treat his crew for scurvy. It is a coastal plant that scrambles on sand dunes, and will thrive in a dry sunny corner of your garden. (May 1, 2008,NZ Herald,D2)

New Zealand sprat¶

n.

HECTOR CLUPEA SPRATTUS, var. antipodum New Zealand Sprat. (1872,Edible Fishes,133)

Notes on the New Zealand Sprat. (1883,TrNZI,15/203)

PARROTT The New Zealand Sprat is referred to in older publications, under several names, e.g. Clupea sprattus, Clupea antipodum, Amblygaster antipodus and Harengula antipodum . (1957,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,28)

New Zealand steel¶

n. steel manufactured (in England) from Taranaki ironsand [aka Taranaki steel q.v.] (See other Papers Past hits)

(Within the last few weeks the entire cutlery world has been startled from the quiet tenor of its way by the announcement of a new member of the iron family from the antipodes, who is so finely bred, and so capable of high polish and perfect finish, that it bids fair to become the aristocracy of the whole order.) ... The Messrs. Moseley mentioned in the statement are neighbours of ours and old friends of the Rev. G. B. Macdonald. We have seen some of the articles manufactured by them of this New Zealand steel, and certainly they seem superior to any thing we have ever seen. White & Co., 36, King-street, Convent Garden, London. (Mar 23, 1861,Otago Witness,9) [NOTES: the cited article (reproduced from the Morning Chronicle in England) is headed 'Taranaki Steel']

New Zealand storm petrel¶

n.

The eminent ornithologist W.R.B. Oliver was one of the few dissenters, opting for full specific status for the New Zealand storm petrel in The Birds of New Zealand, where he wrote that as Wilson's storm petrel is "only a straggler to New Zealand and is not known, where it is found in abundance, to produce colour varieties, for the present I treat maorianus, of which three very similar specimens have been taken, as a separate species". (Jul 2004,NZ Geographic,No. 68/11)

n.

[He] suggested that it looked like a New Zealand storm petrel which was thought to have become extinct 150 years ago. (Jan 28, 2004,Capital Times,7)

Scientific confirmation of the return of the New Zealand storm petrel, or Oceanites maorianus, is still awaited. (Dec 27, 2003,Dominion Post,A3)

The eminent ornithologist W.R.B. Oliver was one of the few dissenters, opting for full specific status for the New Zealand storm petrel in The Birds of New Zealand, where he wrote that as Wilson's storm petrel is "only a straggler to New Zealand and is not known, where it is found in abundance, to produce colour varieties, for the present I treat maorianus, of which three very similar specimens have been taken, as a separate species". (Jul 2004,NZ Geographic,No. 68/11)

New Zealand strawberry¶

n. (See snowberry)

TAYLOR A ground berry, called the New Zealand strawberry by the colonists, formed an agreeable but rather insipid repast to our parched list. It tastes much like the rose apple of India. [Fn. More usually called Snow-berry, Gaultheria depressa.] (1959,Early Travellers,335) [NOTES: From the 1857 Journal of John Turnbull Thomson.]

New Zealand Super¶

n. (informal) short for New Zealand Superannuation

More Maori, proportionately, depend on just about every kind of benefit - family support, DPB, the dole, the accommodation supplement - except New Zealand Super. (Mar 22, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),22)

New Zealand Superannuation¶

n. (See National Superannuation)

The super debate of recent years has centred almost entirely on propping up state-funded New Zealand Superannuation. (Aug 2, 2003,Dominion Post,C1)

New Zealand tea¶

n. manuka

Amongst our native plants we notice this month several in flower - the New Zealand tea (Leptospernum Seoparium [sic]). (Aug 16, 1851,Otago Witness,2)

MORRIS Tea ... Billy-tea, or Bush-tea. Tea made in a billy (q.v.) There is a belief that in order to bring out the full flavour it should be stirred with a gum-stick. New Zealand tea. Tea made of the leaves of the manuka (q.v.). See Tea-tree. (1898,Austral English,462)

New Zealand thrush¶

n. piopio

HEAPHY Our breakfast ... had consisted of three small potatoes each, and a thrush amongst the party. (1846,Notes of an Expedition to Kawatiri and Araura) [NOTES: 1846 Heaphy Exped. to Kawateri in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 243]

HAAST Every morning ... we were awakened by the songs of numerous birds ... amongst which the New Zealand Thrush (Keropia crassirostris), the Bell Bird (Anthornis melanura) ... could well be distinguished. (1879,Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland,38)

BULLER This bird was the Piopio, or New-Zealand Thrush, ... unquestionably the best of the native songsters. (1888,Birds of New Zealand,1/27)

PASCOE The New Zealand Thrush. (1957,Mr Explorer Douglas,264) [NOTES: c1899 Birds South Westland in 1957 Pascoe Mr Explorer Douglas 264]

GUTHRIE-SMITH Although the New Zealand Crow, the New Zealand Thrush were still to find [in Nelson province], Bush Canary at any rate were plentiful. (1936,NZ Naturalist,57)

JACKSON In one [of Buller's aviary cages], there were parrakeets, yellow heads, New Zealand canary, fantails, robins and tom tits, and a pio pio (New Zealand thrush) one of our best songsters - .. (1935,Annals of a NZ Family,129)

WILLIAMS Koropio ... Turnagra capensis and Turnagra tanagra, N.Z. thrushes. (1957,Dictionary of the Maori Language,145)

FALLA et al. NEW ZEALAND THRUSH Turnagra capensis Maori name: Piopio (1966,Birds of New Zealand,238)

Extinct birds ... New Zealand Thrush Turnagra capensis (SPARRMAN, 1787) OTHER NAMES: Piopio, korohea. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,308)

Several specimens of the New Zealand thrush have lately made their appearance in Napier and the suburbs. (Apr 25, 1871,Daily Southern Cross,2)

n. = piopio

New Zealand titmouse¶

n.

The other birds ... were ... the Fan-tail (Rhipidura flabellifera), the Ground-lark (Anthus Novae Zelandiae), the New Zealand Titmouse (Certhiparus Novae Zelandiae) ... (1869,TrNZI,1/164)

The high slopes would be a ... resort for ... crow (Glaucopis), saddle-back (Creadion), New Zealand titmouse (Orthonyx ochrocephala), creeper ... (1887,TrNZI,19/183) [NOTES: (Reischek)]

The creeper, by the way, was discovered at Dusky Sound in 1773 during Captain Cook's second voyage, when it was called the New Zealand titmouse. (Jan 28, 1939,Evening Post,17)

TREGEAR He visited the wood-fairies ... in the form of a tiny bird, the miromiro, ... [fn] The New Zealand Tom-tit (Myiomoira toitoi). (1904,Maori Race, The,436)

New Zealand trout¶

n. [New Zealand trout]

The kokopu of the Maoris is the well known fish found in streams and from its appearance often called the New Zealand trout. (Feb 27, 1890,Otago Witness,18)

New Zealand turkey¶

n. (obsolete) pukeko [S.I.]

PASCOE Besides being a jack of all trades, this bird [pukeko] has a variety of names, no two people being agreed as to which is correct. The Maories call it the bu-ka-ka - is this spelling correct? ... I have heard it also called [?in Westland] bald pate and New Zealand Turkey. (1957,Mr Explorer Douglas,234) [NOTES: c1899 Douglas Birds of South Westland in 1957 Pascoe Mr Explorer Douglas 234]

'Mr. James King, who has a farm on the banks of the Kaitangata Creek, had for some time been much troubled with a bird called the New Zealand turkey coming over his fields, and, as he thought, picking the seed out of the ground ...' (Nov 24, 1865,Otago Witness,11)

New Zealand vine¶

n. ? tutu

MARKHAM New Zealand Vine is species of Vine and grows on a tree not unlike an Elder tree; they can make a thick Wine from the fruit, but to swallow a Seed is deadly Poison. The Fruit is between a Currat and an Elder but it is useless in general. (1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles),33,1963 ed.)

New Zealand War Medal¶

n.

None of the N.Z. War Medals presented to the Imperial Forces bear the date of their service on the medal. (Jan 25, 1890,NZ Observer,16)

That this Committee concurs in the reportof the Joint Committee on the granting ofthe New Zealand War Medal to such of theColonial forces and friendly Natives inall cases where the claimants have beenactually under fire, or otherwiseconspicuous for distinguished service inthe field; and recommends that the medalbe also given to the nearest relatives ofany who have died of wounds or have beenkilled in action. (1899,NZ Parliamentary Debates,VI/889)

New Zealand War(s)¶

1 n. the series of armed clashes between Maori and Pakeha in the 19th century. [New Zealand War (singular) in 19th-c. citations below] (See Land Wars,Maori War(s))

...there have been, he suggests, a number of worthwhile books about the New Zealand Wars. (Jul 29, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),9)

BARBER But it was not until the Second New Zealand War, the so-called land war, that the Queen's Maori soldiers came into their own. (1984,Red Coat to Jungle Green,38)

Their simple act of wading ashore onto the western banks of the independent Te Rohe Potae effectively ended the complex New Zealand Wars. (Oct 4, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),32)

MASTERS I know there are people in England who say that the New Zealand War was purely agrarian, arising out of disputed lordship and ownership of the soil. (1871,Autobiography,59)

MASTERS I know there are people in England who say that the New Zealand War was purely agrarian, arising out of disputed lordship and ownership of the soil. (1871,Autobiography,59)

DOMETT Having a little discussion about the New Zealand war, and to whose fault, that of the colonists or to the Maories, it was attributable; ...Ibid. 107 Thanking me in his letter [the Governor, Sir George Bowen] went on to urge me to `write a novel on the Maories and the New Zealand war' saying that he had pressed the same thing on Anthony Trollope. (Aug 28, 1873,Diary,102,1953 ed.)

GRACE Preface: This sketch of the Maori War ... A Sketch of the New Zealand War -Ibid. 169The New Zealand War lasted about ten years. (1899,Sketch of the NZ War,title page)

COWAN There is at least one sense, however, in which Cowan can be said to be ahead of his time. He steadfastly clung to the term New Zealand Wars'. He rejected the more popular but misleadingexpressionMaori Wars', which implied that Maoris alone were responsible for the outbreaks of conflict. From the 1960s historians have explored more neutral and more accurate terms to characterise the period. Some opted for Land Wars', but this is not entirely satisfactory because issues were involved in addition to that of land. Others suggestedAnglo-Maori Wars' but this too is less than adequate; the English were not the only Europeans involved and. as already noted, Maoris fought on both sides.
