niniwa¶

n. Niwa. ... niniwa ... Gaultheria oppositifolia a shrub (See also tarawera,Taupo snowberry)

MARTIN Gaultheria oppositifolia Niniwa or Tarawera Snowberry. (1961,Flora NZ,235,1929 ed.)

ninzby¶

n. a NZ nimby (from not in New Zealand's back yard) [ORIGIN: acronym]

NIMBY? Yes, proudly so, but we also subscribe to NINZBY, not in NZ's backyard either. (Jul 6, 2010,Gisborne Herald,?)

nip¶

n. a standard measure of spirits; a small glass of spirits (occas the approx? 3 fluid ounce glass a `nip' is served in) (cf NOBBLER)

Ordinary nips were being charged up to eighteenpence in the lounge and bar. (Nov 29, 1943,NZEF Times,III/127 : 8)

There would be from 21 to 22 quarter-gill "nips" in the bottle. (May 18, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,16)

Poor Haupokia.. will never again receive a "nip" out of the royal bottle. (May 3, 1873,Auckland Weekly News,5)

I had started ... with ... a bottle of grog fo [sic] the men on the other side of the river. ... I gave them a nip and then started back. (Jan 29, 1863,Chudleigh Diary,75,1950 ed.)

Going into pubs is worse. ... If I did get a skinful many a `nip' I drank and stood. (1869,Punch or the Auckland Charivari,83)

MONEY A man who was taking a `nip' five minutes before in a shanty that I had entered for the rum, ... (1871,Knocking About in NZ,122)

LADY BARKER The Landlord ... was amazed at the orders for tea and coffee instead of the usual `nips' of spirits. (1873,Station Amusements in NZ,103)

CAIRD He probably gets a `nip' as a glass of grog is called. (1874,NZ Sheepfarming,25)

ELWELL About every two hours he went round with a bottle of rum, giving each hand a small `nip', as it was called. (1878,Boy Colonists,31)

BRADSHAW [At the hotel] a halt was made, during which the ladies filled their pockets with collies', and the gentlemen made an opportunity for a quietnip' (1883,New Zealand As It Is,85)

D'AVIGDOR Either he takes to nips' and degenerates into a mere loafer, scrambling ... for odd shillings which he spends inshouting' (standing drinks to his friends) - a life which ... never lasts long. (1888,Antipodean Notes,222)

DAVIDSON His friend Kelly could always do a stiff nip when off duty ... (1889,Stories of NZ Life,3)

[Hdg] Price Fixed for Standard Nips (Jul 16, 1945,NZEF Times,IV/212 : 2)

n. pinch esp. Hard nip, hard pinch a steep part of a (coach or waggon) road

BAUCKE Look at mother and dad; pulled the old waggon uphill together, now they can spell-ho. Stands to reason; they took a good grip; hard nips here and there; wheels wanting grease and such-like! (1905,Where the White Man Treads,305)

v. to take a (companionable) nip

PHILLIPS Giddy and mate called and nipped (Sep 22, 1867,Journal Kept at Rockwood and the Point,116)

v. to snatch, steal [in ODE, US informal]

Oh an old fellow came in while you were out and nipped yourpaper'.' I said: oh, did he?'Yes,' said the other fellow, `he came in, looked over all the seats, and then put his peeper on your sheet and poled it.' (Jan 21, 1911,NZ Truth,291/6/5)

nipe¶

n.

McNAB ... in former days when in battle ... [they had] only their own implements of destruction - spears, nipes, and an instrument made out of beautiful blue or green marble stone, which they call a Mary, none but a chief is allowed to take them to battle, they are very scarce and very dear. (1913,Old Whaling Days,48) [NOTES: 1833 Sheridan Letter from Sydney Monitor in 1913 McNab Old Whaling Days 48]

nipping¶

n. the taking of nips

MOORE Unnecessary and immoderate drinking of liquor, chiefly in the form of `nipping', has grown into a serious social evil. (1890,New Zealand For the Emigrant,216)

adj. a fast? or slippery turn to extract money from; PUT THE NIPS IN ?

THATCHER And the money used to flow;/ And Shadrach [a publican] did a nipping stroke/ About three years ago./ (1865,Otago Songster,15)

nipplewort¶

n. i>Lapsana communis

HILGENDORF NIPPLEWORT (Lapsana communis) is abundant in gardens and cultivated fields. It is a tender annual, growing 1 or 2 ft. high, with slender erect branched stems. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,201)

nipplewort [s] Lapsana communis L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,53)

TAYLOR NIPPLEWORT (Lapsana communis) ... occurs throughout New Zealand and is common in parts of the South Island in waste land and gardens. (1981,Weeds of Roadsides,105)

Nippon clipon¶

n. either of the Auckland Harbour Bridge extensions [often plural]

Auckland's Harbour Bridge had two lanes added to each side in the early seventies - "the Nippon Clip-ons" - and the contractors towed huge barges in from.. Japan to use as construction platforms. (Mar 1998,Cuisine,88)

armstrong Trouble is.. New Zealand First voters are corried about the big Nippon Clip-on you've attached to the bridge to let large numbers of Asian migrants in. (1997,True Colours,53)

The Auckland Harbour Bridge, built too small from the beginning, and forced to live its life forever with the indignity of the "Nippon clip-ons" hanging off its flanks is another [reminder of letting opportunity slip]. (Jan 31, 2001,Capital Times,19)

In Japan he will be involved in negotiations with ...... I.H.I., known in this country for its "Nippon clip-on" extension to the Auckland harbour bridge. (Aug 5, 1970,Otago Daily Times,2)

When we reach the western "Nippon Clip-on", one of the two massive pre-fab structures literally clipped on to the original structure in 1969 to add four lanes, you can see what he means. The clip-ons move visibly up up and down, up to half a metre at a time. (Oct 29, 2002,Dominion Post,D2)

As far as the public was concerned, what became known as the Nippon Clip-ons couldn't be attached soon enough. (Oct 5, 2000,Evening Post,5)

Built in 1959 as a four-lane span, its [sc. Auckland Harbour Bridge's capacity was doubled 10 years later when Japanese engineers built two more lanes ('The Nippon Clip-ons') on each side. (1987,Insight Guides (NZ),112)

TEMPLE & APSE The centre four lanes [of the Auckland Harbour Bridge] were opened in 1959 but traffic flows trebled in less than a decade forcing the addition of four more outer lanes. These are affectionately known as 'Nippon clip-ons' (1986,New Zealand From the Air,45)

LELAND Nippon-clipon: The AUCKLAND HARBOR BRIDGE was once a two-lane bridge ... Thanks to... Japanese engineering, it is now four lanes. The extra two were built in japan, towed to Auckland and attached to the sides of the existing bridge. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,70)

McGILL Nippon clipon the extra lanes on the outside of the Auckland harbour bridge, Japanese-made and attached without piles to existing structure. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,76)

The motion left more than a 10cm gap between the "Nippon clip-on" and the main bridge yesterday. (Apr 28, 2004,Dominion Post,p1)

POPE & POPE Inevitably its [sc. Auckland Harbour Bridge's] design earns the nickname, 'the coat hanger', while the Japanese-built extensions adding additional lanes on either side are known as the 'Nippon clip-ons'. (1982,Mobil Illust. Guide NZ,45)

nitch¶

n.

ANTHONY I examined my features thoroughly ... The worst blemish I had, to my mind, was the nitch the razor stuck in every time I shaved. [227 note:] `nitch'. A Scots word for nick or notch.'] (1927,Gus Tomlins,185,1977 ed. Sturm ed.)

nitella¶

n.

nitella [s] Nitella (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,53)

niu¶

n. (historical) a pole erected for the religious ceremonial purposes of the 19th century Pai Marire cult. [Maori niu, divination] -->esp. in collocation with POLE, MAST [ORIGIN: Maori]

IHIMAERA & LONG (ed.) The shadow of the niu which fell upon the land has been taken from the land. (1982,Into the World of Light,32)

It was Hauhau who had raised the niu pole Rongo Nui at Maraekowhai. (Oct 1998,Mana,No. 24: 56)

Perhaps we could do well to remember another monument, away up the other end of the river, the niu pole, Riri kore ("No more war"), erected by the King movement at the cessation of hostilities. (Dec 3, 1994,Listener (New Zealand Listener),7)

A pole of a certain height, to be called a Niu, should be erected, around which all true believers were to worship, standing in a circle; those found worthy would receive the gift of tongues. (May 16, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,14)

In the flat open space behind the pa there was a pole (or niu) standing used in their new Pai Marire religion. It was about 10 feet high, square for 2 or 3 feet at top & bottom & rounded in the middle. Ibid. 2/155 (A.S.Atkinson) I was curious to know where the first niu, or worshipping post, was set up & when he said at Kaitake during the present war I said I did not see it there. To you,' he said,it was a color (flagstaff) to us it was a niu. . Ibid.2/228 (A.S. Atkinson) There is a flagstaff here [Waimate Plains], fenced in and surmounted by the figure of a bird, probably a kawekawea as it was a great niu or Pai Marire pole at one time. (Oct 11, 1864,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,2/125,1960 ed.) [NOTES: A.S. Atkinson]

TAYLOR Their [Hauhaus'] worship consisted in uttering some singular compositions containing a strange mixture of heathenism with popery and gibberish, which they chanted whilst dancing round a pole, called their Niu; (1868,Past and Present of NZ,147)

TREGEAR [The priest] cast the niu rods, or interpreted the `jerkings' (takiri) of the limbs or body of asleeping man ... (1904,Maori Race, The,336)

COWAN This niu was the central symbol of worship under Te Ua's dispensation. The term was the olden Maori word for the short sticks used by the tohunga in his mystic arts of divination, particularly before a battle. Te Ua's niu was a tall pole or flag-mast, round which the faithful were to march in procession chanting their hymns. Ibid.. 157 A tall niu, the pole of worship, stood in the principal part of the settlement; ... There were similar niu masts at other villages ... (1922,NZ Wars, The,2/6)

COWAN At the principal villages in that rugged region ... the Hauhau poles, the sacred niu, were set up and round them marched the half-crazed people ... chanting their newly learned hymns ... the prayers of the `Kororia,' Maorified English phrases and scraps of English and Roman Catholic church services. (1940,Sir Donald Maclean,85)

BABBAGE The central object of worship [of the new religion of Tella Haumene] was the Niu.' The origin of this innovation was described in the following terms:- .in 2;The Angel Gabriel said: Go back to your house and erect a niu.' Horopapera enquired what a niu was. The Angel replied:A post.' Horopapera enquired for what pur- pose? The Angel replied: To work for you for the acquirement of the languages of all the races upon the earth.'' The termniu' was the old Maori term for the short sticks used by the tohunga priest in his mystic arts of divination, particularly before a battle. (1937,Hauhauism,29)

niu, divination by means of small rods. Niu is a Polynesian name of the coconut, and in the Pacific the nut was spun in a divination rite: the Maori lost the name for the tree when he came to Newzealand, but retained it for the divinatory rite. The Hauhau fanatics gave the name niu to the pole they set up for their ceremonial dancing procession i[n] what was a horrid kind of maypole dance. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/154) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

SINCLAIR The services of the new Maori evangelism were held at a niu, a long pole, perhaps fifty feet high, with yard-arms from which hung ropes. The congregation revolved roundthis mast as round a maypole while the priests conducted a service of prayer. . Ibid. 302 [Maori glossary] niu Small sticks used in divining;a pole (1959,History of New Zealand,137)

BRATHWAITE NIU Mast erected for purposes of religous rites and observances in Pai-marire faith. (1967,Evil Day,380) [NOTES: Gloss.]

But that is Pakeha history. More significant are the Nui poles, erected in the early 1860s and well-known to canoeists who traverse the river today. The remaining two poles, at Marae-kowhai, are distinguished by their cross-arms reaching to the compass points, oneof which (Rongo Niu) has carved hands on it. From this flew the war pennants of the Pai Marire or Hauhau, around which the warriors danced prior to battle. (Mar 31, 1983,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20)

BUTLER A few [colonial] expressions were not familiar to me. When we should say in England, Certainly not', it is hereNo fear', or Don't you believe it'. When they want to answer in the affirmative, they say,It is so', `It does so'. (1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,ch.iii 31) [NOTES: 1860 Jan 27 in 1863 Butler First Year]

BUTLER A few [colonial] expressions were not familiar to me. When we should say in England, Certainly not', it is hereNo fear', or Don't you believe it'. When they want to answer in the affirmative, they say,It is so', `It does so'. (1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,ch.iii 31) [NOTES: 1860 Jan 27 in 1863 Butler First Year]

Niu Sila¶

n. New Zealand [ORIGIN: Samoan, also Niu Sela]

Okay, taro leaves baked in coconut cream may not be an instant hit, but somewhere among all those urban dwellers, lies the economy of Niu Sila's tomorrow. (Oct 16, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),54)

n. New Zealand (?play title) [ORIGIN: Samoan]

As well as writing Niu Sila, you have been involved in transforming your Naked Samoans comedy group into cartoon characters for a show called bro'Town. (Apr 17, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),11)

Just who is a New Zealander? That's not the premise of Niu Sila, I hasten to add, and not all the answers are here. (Apr 7, 2004,Capital Times,12)

Niu Tireni¶

n. New Zealand [ORIGIN: Maori, also below Tirini, Tirani; transliteration]

A further (obsolescent) Maori name is Niu Tireni, the Maori transliteration of New Zealand (with many variants: Niu Tirani, Niu Tirini, Nuitereni, Nui Tireni, Nu Tirani, etc...Both Aotearoa and Niu Tireni.. are listed among the Maori place names approved for addressing purposes by New Zealand Post. (Oct 2000,NZWords,4 : 2)

TUWHARE Niu Tireni (Long White Shroud) / (a bare-arsed land, manipulated by the wrong white crowd of minority speculators - with big foreign investors - busily weaving a long white shroud to fit us all). (1997,Shape-Shifter,88)

HOCHSTETTER Of New Zealand, for example, they make Niutireni. (1867,New Zealand (Hochstetter),216)

Niu Tirini is in a mist for the loss of his medicine. (Dec 19, 1860,Taranaki Punch,8) [NOTES: Check spelling of Tirini]

I am proud of that ship [sc. Maheno]. Wegirls felt we could jump over the moon.Well done Nui [sic] Tireni! (Dec 2, 1915,Hawke's Bay Herald,6)

TAYLOR ... Potatau the First ... in June 1858 ... entered [Rangiawhia] preceded by his flag, bearing the device of a cross and three stars, with the name of the country, `Niu Tirini,' in the centre, ... (1868,Past and Present of NZ,123)

New-Zealanders have long spoken of Peowhairangi,' Bay of Islands;Akarana,' Auckland; Niu Tirani,' New Zealnd, &c. <i> Ibid.</i> 25/411 In some cases our English names of places have been adopted by the Maori, with such alteration as is necessary to make them easily pronounced by Maori organs of speech. New Zealanders have long spoken ofPeowhairangi,' Bay of Islands; Akarara,' Auckland;Niu Tirani', New Zealand ... (1893,TrNZI,25/402) [NOTES: (Smith)]

I observed that the term New Zealander' is already employed in this district; only, in lieu ofNoui-Tireni", as the natives of the Bay of Islands pronounce it, they say Noui-Tirangui' [Nui Tirangi] [sic], which gives the word more of an indigenous sound. The word pakeha serves them to signify all whites, whom they also callIouropi' (Europeans). I did not observe that they had a special name for the English. (1909,TrNZI,41/139) [NOTES: Smith transl. D'Urville's Visit to Tolaga Bay in 1827]

CURRIE Whether in Niu Tireni or Te Reinga/ Now you live, or in countries over the ocean - (1949,Centennial Treasury of Otago Verse,110) [NOTES: (`Epilogue')]

I very much object to Sir James Henare's suggestion that this country be known as Nu Tirini. That is merely the corruption of the English name to which so many Maoris object. (Aug 13, 1988,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15) [NOTES: M.A.C. Blanshard]

Niuean¶

n. one born or resident in the Pacific island of Niue.Niuean, adjective.

Niuean 1. n. native or inhabitant of Niue, a self-governing state in the South Pacific in free association with New Zealand; the Polynesian language spoken in Niue. 2 a. of orrelating to the Niuean people or their language. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,508) [NOTES: nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 328]

The Government has been urged to redefine the term Pacific Islander so more people can qualify for scholarships. Melanesian and Micronesian students are excluded from some grants. ... [The Pacific Island Education Foundation] says grants can only go to pupils of Samoan, Cook Island, Niuean, Tongan or Tokelauan descent. (Sep 16, 1988,Dominion,8)

NIWA¶

abbr. National Institute of Water and Atmospheric Research Ltd - the Crown Research Institute formed from the old DSIR NZ Oceanographic Institute,the MAF Fisheries Research Laboratory and the research division of the Meteorological Office [ORIGIN: acronym]

Niwa said early winter [sic] was likely to get lower-than-normal pressures over, and to the north of the North Island ... (May 4, 2006,Timaru Herald,2)

Niwa, the National Institute of Water and Atmospheric Research, advises that the hole has extended north to New Zealand earlier than usual. (Oct 7, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),45)

no¶

n. a fern

WILLIAMS Another kind [of fern] grows abundantly in the woods. I think the appellation for it is No, andflowers round the leaf. [Glossary 119 ... Hen and Chickens fern (Asplenium bulbiferum)]. (1844,NZ Journal,110,1956 ed.)

No 2¶

n.

BATHGATE [quoting Thatcher] Take this glass of nice P.B.,/ Which I now hold in my hand,/ 'Tis of the brand of Hennissy [sic],/ Taste this most superior brand,/ ... Pale brandy or P.B. was the favourite spirit [in Dunedin, 1860s], and a sparkling moselle, which was dubbed champagne, was popularunder the name of No. 2. There was even a bar on board the harbour steamer ... and I have heard No. 2 called for there on the way to Port Chalmers. ... I was told that owing to the large sales of No. 2 the producers sent a consignment of No. 1, which was the better liquor, but no one would buy it. (1925,Random Recollections,17)

No 8 Ventures¶

1 n. (Rural) a capital venture fund in which investor money assists the development of new industries or businesses.

The new fund has a working title of No 8 Ventures 2002. (May 6, 2002,NZ Herald,24)

No 8 Ventures 2002 Fund. No 8 Ventures is an established venture capital fund manager with strong US links, focused on IT, electronics and biotechnology. (May 27, 2002,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: www.nzvif.com/news]

No 8 Ventures turned down vastly more investments proposals than it invested in. No 8 Ventures was looking for companies with talented, entrepreneurial management ... (May 29, 2002,Dominion,23)

No 8 is one of six firms chosen last month to co-invest with the Government in its Venture Investment Fund ... (Jun 8, 2002,NZ Herald,C1)

No 8 wire ingenuity¶

n. expertise at fixing equipment etc. with little or no technical support [attributed to New Zealanders]. (See No 8/Number 8 (wire/fencing wire))

What Ritchie and the almost 100 other Kiwis who were chosen lacked in experience of desert conditions - .. - they made up for with No 8 wire ingenuity and hardiness born of such civilian occupations as farming. (Apr 25, 2009,Listener (New Zealand Listener),28)

.. various real Kiwi jokers have been shoving sport, booze, No 8 wire ingenuity and self-satisfied ignorance down the throats of certain poor fools for the past 160 years. (May 12, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),8)

No 8 wire mentality¶

n. (See No 8/Number 8 (wire/fencing wire))

However, as a result of this the drug-users retaliated with some good old-fashioned "No 8 wire mentality" and invented homebake. (Jul 12, 2005,NZ Herald,B5)

The "No 8 wire" mentality also shone through. When police stopped the importation of heroin in the early 1980s, drug users invented homebake. (Jul 18, 2005,Dominion Post,A2)

No 8 Wired¶

n. (Rural) a rural television programme.

At a No 8 Wired farmer mentor group meeting in Wellington in January, it was agreed that the WoolPro/Meat New Zealand segment of the programme was going well. (2001,Wool Grower,Autumn 6)

Rowan talks about his philosophy and his farm next Sunday on No 8 Wired. (May 22, 2002,RD1.com,On the Farm)

.. Number 8 Wired is nearing the end of its second season, but Tompkins says they have plans for a third. Number 8 Wired was picked by TV Guide in its top 10 new season local programmes in 2001 and was also the Landcorp Agricultural Communicator of the Year. [Number 8 Wired] (Oct 19, 2002,NZ Herald,75)

No 8-rewire¶

v.

The hero didn't even plan on being a plastic surgeon and winds up No 8-rewiring plastic surgery history and inventing not only new surgical procedures but operating implements as well. (Feb 1, 2005,Dominion Post,B7)

No 8/Number 8 (wire/fencing wire)¶

n. (Rural) standard Number eight gauge fencing wire

MARRIOTT The sag on 65 metres of no 8 carrying the weight of a man is considerable, and for three-quarters of the way it was downhill. (1981,Life in the Gorge,30)

Owen Marshall A strand of number eight under tension had whipped back from the strainer and cut the bridge of his nose and the soft skin beneath his left eye. (2007,Drybread,199)

Just arrived, ex 'Coronilla', 20 tons BB annealed fencing wire, No 8. 1884 North NZ Settler Jan 17 I look upon a wire fence as worse than useless, particularly one of No 8 black wire, let there be as many wires as you like. (Sep 4, 1872,Hawke's Bay Herald,1)

Ordinary No. 8 fencing-wire is stretched along the top of each row of poles each way ... (Feb 20, 1937,NZ Journal of Agriculture,108)

A North Taranaki farmer, A A Jonas, Motunui, uses two strands of No 8 wire twisted together. (Oct 11, 1951,NZ Farmer,19)

So now all gates and fastenings are festooned with snaggles of bent No 8. (Aug 10, 1972,NZ Farmer,39)

SALISBURY Along came also the hunter chains concept of fencing and the introduction of high tensile 125 gauge wire which was slowly to replace man's best friend, the number eight wire. (1994,I Was So Lucky,186)

n. [further cits.]

We have, if you like, extended the myth of what the New Zealand character is. The man alone battling against nature, facing banks, and the expertise with a piece of No 8 wire. (Apr 4, 1987,Listener (New Zealand Listener),21)

Four wires at the bottom of No.8, and two wires at the top of No. 6, will require 1 ton 7 cwt. per mile. (1883,Brett's Colonists Guide,77) [NOTES: Pagination from 1980 edition.]

The thing is, New Zealand has plenty of culture. And not just Culture with a capital 'C' like opera and ballet - we've got the good old, down home, No 8 fencing wire culture that big-spending visitors would ford the Fox River in flood on a farm bike to experience. (Aug 31, 2003,Sunday Star Times,A3)

The first military telegraph signalling in New Zealand used No 8 wire, strung into place behind British troops as they advanced into the Waikato during the land wars of the 1860s. (Oct 19, 1996,Listener (New Zealand Listener),10)

Nothing is worse than the military myth, the belief that - give us a piece of number eight wire and, if the need is there, we can go overseas and be good. (Apr 10, 2004,Dominion Post,E4)

If one could make records out of No 8 fencing wire, this is what they would sound like. (May 4, 1997,Listener (New Zealand Listener),42)

It's high time we put No 8 fencing wire behind us. Anyway, it doesn't exist any more; standard wire gauge was metricated years ago. (Aug 24, 2002,Dominion Post,A15)

'You made that movie with $10 million dollars?' And it was all held together with No 8 wire. (Dec 16, 2003,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: Witi Ihimaera discusses "Whalerider" on Nine to Noon]

If they see a threat.. they'll fix it, or better still, make sure it never eventuates. You could call it the No. 8 Wire School of Jurisprudence. (Sep 11, 1998,Dominion,8)

The home-made toasting forks... were made from No. 8 wire. (1989,Recollections (various authors/titles),43)

Learned tomes might be found on the miraculous qualities of No. 8 fencing wire "that have kept New Zealand food supplies at a superior level to those in the Caucasus for one thousandth of the cost". (Sep 25, 1999,Dominion,18)

New Zealanders have a reputation as innovators - part of our number eight-wire heritage. (Oct 1999,NZ Computer,90)

Ask yourself which were the 10 best movies top come out of this No 8 wire industry, and you'll struggle not to complete the list but to contain it. (Nov 30, 1999,Evening Post,15)

Presented by veteran agricultural reporters Don Carson and Rachel Donald, Number 8 Wired is nearing the end of its second season... Now, says Tompkins, 69.4 percent of farmers have watched Number 8 Wired at some stage. (Oct 19, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),75)

Earlier this year, we had sampled the more No 8-wire alpine experience of past memory up Mt Taranaki. (Aug 14, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),36)

[Hdg] What's the Spanish for No 8 wire? (Apr 18, 2004,Sunday Star Times,C8)

Bell's got a distinctive DYI number eight fencing wire approach to theatre publicity. (Apr 23, 1997,Capital Times,7)

If one could make records out of No 8 fencing wire, this is what they would sound like. (May 24, 1997,Listener (New Zealand Listener),42)

Undaunted, New Zealand addicts adopted the No 8 wire approach and invented their own - homebake - converting pharmaceuticals, mainly headache pills like codeine and Panadene, for their opiate fix. (May 5, 2001,Evening Post,2)

I believe we are losing our rural roots and with it our Kiwi No 8 wire mentality, can-do attitude and spirit of free enterprise. ... List MP Kate Wilkinson also lamented the loss of the no 8 wire attitude. (Nov 18, 2005,Dominion Post,A11)

Don't know about you, but those No. 8 wire Kiwi stories just make me shiver with pride. (Nov 14, 2005,NZ Herald,B4)

"We are losing our rural roots and our No. 8 wire Kiwi mentality, can-do attitude and spirit of free enterprise." (Nov 28, 2005,Dominion Post,B7) [NOTES: Nathan Guy, National MP maiden speech]

But we're not talking No 8 fencing wire here. (May 29, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),40)

You couldn't edit videotape back then so if you made a mistake you'd have to start all over again. But we produced miracles with a bit of number eight fencing wire. (May 28, 2000,Sunday Star Times,A4)

Hoar is no doubt that Rutherford.. was a hands-on hero who owed a great deal to his New Zealand background and what we would now call the "No. 8 fencing wire" mentality. With little money and makeshift resources he broke open the secret of the atomic nucleus. (Mar 11, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),38)

Along the way he gets beaten to a pulp by 10 guitars and generally takes the Kiwi, No 8 wire, "Let's effing do it!" spirit to absurd extremes in the home of trash television. (Jan 4, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),78)

Do we sleep better at nights because a piece of New Zealand number eight fencing wire might one day hurtle through space and miss its target by a million miles? (Jan 18, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),23)

As well as being the acme of the No 8 wire tradition, Pearse was also the acme of the self-deprecating achiever - and you can't help thinking that the last thing on his mind was public recognition. (Mar 29, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),23)

I think we are of an international standard, but we do it on No 8. wire. (Jul 18, 2001,Dominion,29)

In its turn, the LTSA last week released a brochure to try to educate young drivers about vehicle modification... "It's a bit of a battle, especially here in New Zealand... It's the No 8 wire mentality." (Apr 28, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),31)

Now he is teaming up with Wellington venture capitalists Jenny Morel and Peter Allport at No 8 Ventures Management... No 8 Ventures turned down vastly more investment proposals than it invested in. (May 29, 2002,Dominion,23)

Peter Jackson's incredible achievement is in a category all of its own in many ways: self-effacing Wellington boy sticks two peeves of number eight fencing wire together and makes movie monument., That the series keeps reaching new heights is nothing short of gobsmacking. (Dec 22, 2002,Sunday Star Times,D2)

[Cartoon caption] We regret Creative New Zealand will no longer be giving out money... We do, however, have a strictly limited allocation of Number Eight wire. (May 23, 1998,Listener (New Zealand Listener),44)

Then the reactor heats up and rather than abandon ship or accept help from the Americans Harrison chooses the proud Soviet option of fixing the problem with number eight wire. (Nov 10, 2002,Sunday Star Times,F4)

So baches are examples of what it is to be Kiwis - bugger the council, we can do anything with No 8 wire. (Jan 19, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20)

Number eight (4mm thick) wire formed kitchen implements, latched a million dunny doors, and dried the nation's laundry. (Aug 28, 1992,Dominion,23)

While they could, no doubt, benefit from having a quick peruse of the Madden working drawings, I feel sure that in the twinkling of a Southland eye, a more robust design would emerge as the number eight wire mountain men of Central Otago jam their thinking caps on. (Dec 3, 2001,Dominion,13)

MCGILL Number Eight. The best, strongest, most likely to succeed; from the thick gauge No 8 fencing wire used on farms ... (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,77)

We can't see that archival footage of a farmer playing his No 8 fencing wire too often. (Dec 25, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),70)

In the tradition of number eight wire down on the farm, New Zealanders are booking marquees, generators and barbies for hire in unprecedented numbers to avoid the possibility of singing "Auld Lang Syne" in the dark. (Dec 25, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),26)

A key phrase that's been going backwards and forwards is: "Don't know. Can do." It captures one of our biggest assets, our "number eight wire" mentality. (Oct 30, 2000,Dominion Infotech Weekly,No. 465 : 4)

We have made our one lapse into folly work, in a number-eight fencing-wire sort of way. (Aug 5, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),17)

The Kiwi No 8 fencing wire attitude is everywhere, even down to raising preschool children. (Mar 28, 2002,Evening Post,6)

Thieves raided his highly publicised bra fence three times in 10 days during February, leaving him virtually bra-less. "I even had a huge one ... I reckon it was a No 8 wire ... but it got stolen," Mr Lee said. (Apr 16, 2002,Evening Post,5)

HENDERSON There was just one telephone line that ran away down to the end of habitation - a good stout 8-gauge fencing wire, often stapled from tree-trunk to tree-trunk beside the pack-track. (1967,Return to Open Country,20)

New Zealanders live off their reputation as super-competent all-rounders who can.. play Mozart on tea-chest with a length of No. 8 fencing wire. (1991,Cuisine,101)

I can relate the occasion when I watched my mother teaching a group of Maori women how to knit, using Number 8 wire fashioned into knitting needles. (Oct 2003,NZ Memories,No. 44/32)

We really do believe that the world is a simple place and that there's no problem than can't be solved with a bit of of Kiwi ingenuity. Or the Weta special effects team - our post-modern equivalent of No 8 wire. (Dec 7, 2003,Sunday Star Times,C8)

n. a Number 8 gauge (4mm) fencing wire, esp. when used inventively and practically for other than fencing purposes; a smooth wire, 8 gauge; a standard wire, of many and almost legendary uses around the farm

No! - let me tell you about No 8 fencing wire... You might notice its ingenious usage, from makeshift umbrella spokes to a water diving rod (one man I knew used it in his car to strap the engine block onto the mount) or again as a staple of the eternal temporary-fix we are so fond of - tying a flying fox round a tree, containing old newspapers on a shelf, even in the backblocks holding tight a wired-up broken jaw. (Jan 14, 1991,Listener (New Zealand Listener),18)

SHERWOOD They were buying a roll of number eight ...'Fencing wire,' Johnson interjected. (1985,Botanist at Bay,131)

number eight NZ wire of 4mm. gauge used esp. for fencing. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,514) [NOTES: nf 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 332]

[Ironmongery advt includes] Fencing Wire, Nos. 6, 7, 8, 9, and 10; Fencing Staples and WireStretchers. (Jul 8, 1876,Saturday Advertiser,10)

... a good paling fence on ordinary bushlands with double No. 8 wires at top and bottom ... can be erected at about 12s. per chain. (1894,NZ Official Yearbook,514)

(2.) Batten and wire fence, at least 3 ft. 9 in. high, of substantial material, firmly erected, with one or more wires, not lighter than No. 8 in steel, or black or galvanised iron; battens either driven securely into the ground and securely stapled, or intertwined in wires in an upright position, and not more than 3 in. apart. Ibid. 19 ... and a good paling fence on ordinary bush land with double No. 8 wires top and bottom, with 1/2 in. palings, and 7 in. posts sunk 2 ft. in the ground, can be erected at about 12s. per chain. (1895,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,161) [NOTES: 1895 Fencing Act in 1902 Settler's Handbook of NZ 161]

The palings are interwoven by a double No. 8 wire at the top and a double No. 8 wire at the bottom. (Jul 15, 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,10)

EVANS The variety so well known as No. 8 has become the unwritten standard for New Zealand fences. (1962,Waikaka Saga,131)

Turner (p. 135), gives a quotation from Crump on wire. I think `A piece of No 8' is well-enough established in farming jargon to deserve a place as No 8, signifying 8-gauge fencing wire. (Jul 29, 1966,Letter) [NOTES: Letter I. Davey (Whangarei)]

WILSON Then eventually we made barbs for our harpoons, by cutting a length of Number Eight wire from some farm fence at the strainer post, ... (1973,NZ Jack,27)

WHEELER A very long toasting fork made of twisted No. 8 fencing wire, last night's unwashed coffee cups, . (1973,Historic Sheep Stations NI,102)

SUTHERLAND Each bale had half a kerosine tin with handle made of number eight wire. (1978,Elver, The,37)

LELAND number 8 fencing wire: The traditional 5 wire fence on New Zealand farms is made with this stuff. In consequence it is one of the things that is always available round a farm when you need to build or repair something. It is said that some cockies can put together a landrover, a tractorand half a milk shed with nothing but a roll of number 8. Wire comes in sizes ranging from 1 to approx. 64, with 1 being the thickest. Number 8 is 5/32 of an inch or about half the diameter of a pencil. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A)

GLEN This time I took a piece of No.8 wire and carried the trap to the creek. (1980,Bush in Our Yard,68)

Wire ... No. 8 wire: Smooth wire, 8 gauge (4mm). (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,30)

CHRISTIE Christoffer looked at what he supposed was a gate. It was made of barbed wire and battens strung between two strainer posts to which it was tied with No 8 fencing wire. Being the first Taranaki gate he had encountered, he studied the primitive contraption with a puzzled frown, then realised it was simplicity itself. Just lift off this wire loop.' The gate sprang from his fingers, coiled into the air and collapsed in a tangled heap. Christoffer cursed the man who had invented it. However he had to admit that it was an efficient, cheap and easily-made thing - a sort ofinstant gate'. Ibid. 150 The swing bridge, made of No 8 fencing wire, made a good support for the pipelines. (1987,Candles and Canvas,86)

MILLER97 No. 8 wire was to him as string is to the average man. He could tie it ..., and with a strainer he could tighten a wire until it literally sang when it was flicked. (1946,There Was Gold)

RICHARDS The only tools we used to build the camp were an axe, spade, slasher, a short length of No. 8 wire, ... (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,56)

No 8 wire has always been the great standby of rural handypersons. (Jul 23, 1988,Dominion,8)

New Zealanders are proud of their `do it yourself' flair, whipping up anything to order with a few lengths of four-by-two and some No. 8 fencing wire. (Feb 14, 1989,Press, The,6)

One by one [the vehicles] ground to a halt, despite some amazing feats of No-8-wire-mechanical engineering and cannibalism. (Sep 12, 2001,Capital Times,2)

...nimble-fingered Hawke's Bay ladies.. started tossing scone dough round tins with 5 cent piece holes, and dousing the dough with local boy-made-good James Wattie's canned spaghetti in tomato sauce that it hit me... Now we're an enlightened species, we all know it was a No 8 fencing wire attempt that spawned parlours and pizzerias more resembling the real thing. (Feb 22, 2003,Dominion Post,F8)

He is an eloquent chap, wild-haired and more than a little wild-haired and more than a little wild-eyed as he reels off the traumatic list of disasters and desperate remedies that made up the "No-8-wire treasure hunt". (Jan 31, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),23)

Innovation exponents have criticised New Zealand's "No 8 wire" philosophy as outdated and question its relevance to the country's constantly evolving national identity... Historian Jock Phillips said No 8 wire was an ingrained part of the national identity, but did not exclusively belong to New Zealand. "I think there's been a very powerful mythology about it, which you will find also in other countries ... Australia, the United Kingdom, and the United States," he said. (Jun 28, 2004,Dominion Post,C3)

No 8/number 8 (wire/fencing wire)¶

n. (Rural) [fig.] a symbol for Kiwi ingenuity.

No 8 wire can't fix it: New Zealand needs to tap into the international corporate culture. The No 8 mentality is about making do, about having no ambition to be or have the best. (Mar 3, 2002,Sunday Star Times,E2)

Number Eight the best, strongest, most likely to succeed; from the thick gauge No. 8 fencing wire used on farms; eg Joy Shepard remembers a doctor saying to a patient on whom he had done surgery that had come a bit unstuck: `I'll use No.8 this time and make a real job of it.' (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,77)

With a No 8 fencing wire approach, he has turned the logistical labyrinth into a workable reality. (Jan 30, 2006,Dominion Post,A11)

Whack 'em on the backs of the trucks with No 8 wire and drive as fast as we can? (Mar 3, 2001,Dominion,22)

This, together with the sheer competence of the New Zealand farmer, is what has made the varied uses of number eight wire - the metaphor for many New Zealanders' basic approach to life," said Dame Silvia. (Jun 14, 2001,Waikato Times,4)

'Beyond No 8 wire' is the theme of Massey University Richmond Southern North Island Sheep and Beef cattle farmers conference ... (May 2, 2002,Internet - see Notes,News) [NOTES: www.agriculture.massey.ac.nz]

No 8/Number eight (wire)¶

adj. (Rural) [of people or ventures] ingenious.

DENSEM From these layers outwards "Men," in the number-eight-wire sense, dominated. (1995,Letter,90) [NOTES: in Dominy (2001) Calling the Station Home]

Despite this failure Richard Pearse was a genuine Kiwi original - a No 8-wire man of the first rank. (Nov 1994,Quote Unquote,30)

DOMINY As the back country that "number eight Men" populated gets retired and covenanted for conservation purposes ... (2001,Calling the Station Home,91)

If you have a production story, a community event or comments for the programme, the No 8 team would love to know. (May 22, 2002,RD1.com,On the Farm 39)

Burt Munro was the ultimate eccentric - a real 'number eight' wire inventor. (May 2007,Tearaway,22)

no beg-pardons¶

phr. (See beg-pardon)

no biggie¶

phr. no big deal

"I'm not really too fussed about it," he shrugged. "If it happens it happens. But it's no biggie." (Jul 23, 2000,Sunday Star Times,B1)

I don't think I've got to churn out a play every year too. If it happens for me too it's great but if it doesn't that's no biggie. (Mar 3, 2002,Sunday Star Times,F7)

no fear¶

exclam. I don't believe you; not under any circumstances; no way, an exclamation intensifying a negative (`certainly not') answer to a question or request is very common in NZ, and often thought to be local idiom.

BUTLER A few [colonial] expressions were not familiar to me. When we should say in England, Certainly not', it is hereNo fear', or Don't you believe it'. When they want to answer in the affirmative, they say,It is so', `It does so'. (1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement) [NOTES: 1860 Jan 27 in 1863 Butler First Year]

MUTER A mob of cattle', to use the colonial term, after a few expressions ofMy word' and `No fear' would be sold at some 10 pounds per head. (1864,Travels in NZ,2/273)

BURGESS He replied: `Did you think I was going to let a bloody wretch like that best me? No fear, the - shall sweat there till Monday ...' (1866,Confessions,93,1983 ed.)

COOPER One energetically declared that the new ground to the south was the best, while another ... vociferated, `No fear! no fear!'. (Dec 14, 1867,Digger's Diary,22,1978 ed.)

BAINES Why, Janson, I thought she was going to turn turtle.'No fear', he replied ... (1874,Edward Crewe,75)

As expletives My word' andNo fear' are favourites, both drawn out as long as possible. (1885,TrNZI,18/54) [NOTES: J.C.Crawford]

BATHGATE Are you not going to make a pile at the diggings ... 'No fear,' laughingly replied Leslie; ... (1881,Waitaruna,145)

Can you produce them?'No fear'. (1895,Diary of Jonathan Roberts,5)

It is the result of conviction or the dictates of conscience? No fear. Nothing of the kind. (Jun 24, 1905,NZ Truth,1-2)

SINCLAIR The settlers, he learnt, said no fear' instead ofcertainly not'. [He = Samuel Butler]. (1959,History of New Zealand,101)

MUIR `She didn't commit no bloody suicide, mate. No bloody fear. The flatties thought of that one. Mind you, she was in pod, you know.' (1960,Word for Word,254)

DAVIN ... I'd like to see the bloody Hun who's going to make me start now. No fear, me old cobber General Freyberg, VC,'d never forgive me. (1975,Breathing Spaces,97)

HUNT And there was no hot water laid on, no fear. (1981,Speaking a Silence,20)

LADY CAMPBELL [Tobin warns the speaker that it is T's father he is to tell bad news of] `No fear; I am not likely to forget.' (1864,Martin Tobin,2/68)

no good to gundy¶

phr.

This [interference] was no good to Gundy, so cobber the wood-chopper got busy swinging his axe ... (Sep 2, 1918,Quick March,1)

(phrase) elaboration of the simple phrase `no good to me' [orig. doubtful, possibly American. [cf NZ nickname]. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. (Aust.-NZ Suppl.),616)

gundy, no good to (Phr.) elaboration of phrase not good enough for me [Scot. coll. gundie greedy]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),10)

No Maoris, No Tour¶

phr. slogan of the campaign to prevent the All Blacks touring South Africa without Maori representation

The subsequent success of the No Maoris - No Tour movement affirmed the belief that New Zealand rugby would be played the New Zealand way and not according to the repugnant rules applying in South Africa. (Jun 28, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),5)

The radical Notes from the Second Year.. focused me very firmly in the muddled turmoil of No Maori No Tour, hippiedom and the Vietnam war. (Sep 17, 1990,Listener (New Zealand Listener),108)

no milk in one's coconut¶

phr. no brains in one's head

BEARDSLEY no milk in her coconut no brains in her head (1984,Blackball 08,244)

no sense sticking your nose in butter...¶

phr. in full: no sense sticking your nose in butter if you're going to have to eat dripping the rest of your life

McGILL no sense sticking your nose in butter if you're going to have to eat dripping the rest of your life a discouragement to put on airs if you cannot afford them, usually parental negativity towards offspring leaving the nest in Depression era, as quoted in Stevan Eldred-Grigg's Oracles and Miracles. (Longest c/p known to compiler.) (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,76)

no show/not a show¶

phr. no chance (also as exclamation - see notes) [As exclamation meaning something like Not Likely, or No Chance, or Over my Dead Body, as in: "Are you going to the Smith's Cocktail Party?" "No show!" This is quite different from no-show as used in restaurants - "They're a no-show" meaning they didn't turn up to claim their table reservation.]

BARLOW Engineers, to use a colonialism, have not a `show' at all [of making money] - particularly now that the borrowing policy has been partially given up. (1889,Kaipara and Waitemata Echo,205)

ASHTON-WARNER She's dying ... [sic] or should be; there's not a show.'What does that mean ... [sic] there's not a show'?'Oh ... [sic]', he laughs. It meansShe hasn't got a chance'. New Zealandese.' (1960,Incense to Idols,162)

no worries¶

phr. not a problem (US), she'll be right; cf. no sweat [ca1961 Wellington No worries. I'll get a dozen from home.]

McGill 'Forget the damned dog,' Jack growled. 'Ring that priest, will you? See if he's coming.' 'No worries,' Ron said, wondering what was eating Jack. (1995,Gold in the Creek,29)

McGILL no worries expression of confidence; eg `Even without Martin Crowe we're a match for the Aussies, no worries.' NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,76)

no wukkers¶

phr.

I offer him a few of my own ideas [of Kiwi words], and he reaches for a pen and paper. House of Pain? "It's very regional." No wukkers? "Spell it." Sweet as? "Well ... I don't know...it doesn't strike me as particularly New Zealand." (Jun 29, 2002,Dominion,11)

no-boner¶

n. [? mistake for no-brainer]

"It's a no boner," he said. (Jun 16, 2003,Dominion Post,D1)

no-build¶

adj.

Developers Buckle Barracks plan to protect the airspace above the McDonald's building with a no-build condition. (Jul 21, 2005,Wellingtonian,3)

no-capacity man¶

n.

MAY ... councillors advocated that the names of the `no-capacity' men (that is, those unwilling to assist the war effort in any capacity whatever) be made public. (1975,Miners and Militants,134) [NOTES: Griffiths Collection]

no-exit¶

adj. [Jim Cameron writes: This is used attributively as well as being a road sign]

Conservation Minister Sandra Lee has asked.. park managers to spend $260,000 upgrading a no-exit road. (Aug 22, 2000,Dominion,1)

The californian bungalow is nestled among mature trees at the end of a quiet no-exit street. (Aug 22, 2000,Wairarapa Times-Age,Suppl. : 00)

MANTELL The mansion sprawled across the end of this no-exit street. (1998,Mates,32)

TAYLOR There are a few no-exit offshoots near the town but once the ten miles of tarseal give on to the rough, metalled surface, one is bereft even of the comforting sighting of a friendly crossroads and a few direction signs. (1971,Plekhov Place, The,9)

no-eyes¶

n. a person wearing spectacles (cf FOUR EYES) [early ? nonce]

POWER [Maoris' nicknames for the pakehas in Power's party] A stalwart officer ... is generally known as Puku-nui, or Big-belly; an artillery officer is Biggy-bung; one wearing spectacles is Four-eyes, or No-eyes. (Jan 30, 1848,Sketches in NZ,159,1849 ed.)

no-go area¶

n. area dubbed "low employment location" (See dead zone)

A year ago Sunday Star Times visited the tiny Wairarapa settlement not long after it was designated as one of 160 "low employment locations" (better known as dead zones or no-go areas) by Work and Income, meaning that people could not move there and receive a benefit. (Mar 6, 2005,Sunday Times (NZ),A15)

no-go zone¶

n. areas in which benefits will not be paid to unemployed able-bodied workers

The no-go zones policy perpetrates the idea the unemployed people are dole bludgers, willing to move to Nightcaps or Ruatahuna in order to render themselves unemployable beyond all risk. (Mar 6, 2004,Dominion Post,B4)

Footrot Flats bas been declared a no-go zone. Cooch hasn't had his dole cut off yet, but is being regularly hassled by Work and Income to move to the city. (Apr 2004,Green Times,4)

no-hoper¶

n. totally incompetent or inadequate person socially or at sport [1960 17C F B10 Napier Girls H.S. 10 NO HOPER -->1960 17C M B6 St Bede's, Chch 1 NO-HOPER ->1981 Feb Avondale College (Auckland) Slang Words in Use (Goldie Brown Collection) no-hoper]

TURNER Marginally colloquial are the words from phrases no-hoper useless person' and offsiderhorse harnessed at the right of a main horse in a team', helper',companion' generally. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,46)

SLATTER Her husband, whom she openly scorned as a no-hoper, sold paint in the hardware store ... (1968,Pagan Game, The,166)

no-hoper n. NZ & Austral. sl. incompetent person, failure. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,509) [NOTES: nf 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

McGILL no-hoper totally incompetent or inadequate person socially or at sport; used in horse racing for a useless racehorse; eg `Cripes, that horse is a no-hoper: six starts, and last in every one.' c. 1925. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,76)

n. a. A horse with no prospect of winning, an outsider. b. A useless or incompetent person, one from whom no good can be expected. [In OED as Austral. from 1943]

ELDRED-GRIGG Thew working class in state housing districts were also the worst working class. No-hopers. (1995,Mum,62)

ELDRED-GRIGG The working class in state housing districts were also the worst working class. No-hopers. (1995,Mum,62)

We've seen some amazing talent come out of people who would otherwise have been called no-hopers. (Oct 18, 2001,Evening Post,37)

McGEE I've got a wife and child to pull through this world, and that kid is not going to be sitting in a class of no-hopers getting the sort of shit thrown at him that I got. (1981,Foreskin's Lament,39)

no-license¶

n. a state of affairs whereby the sale of liquor in an area was prohibited; a proposal to this effect; (adj.) describing a district where a vote on that proposal was carried, or that lost its licences by reason of boundary changes [Historical. Cf wet, dry Not in DNZE. See eg Report of Royal Commission on Licensing 1946 AJHR H-38, p. 33, 206 etc.]

In the first [voting-paper], the voter is asked whether he votes for continuance or no-license. (1910,NZ Parliamentary Debates,153/603)

I VOTE for ContinuanceI VOTE for No-License (1910,NZ Statutes,1 Geo. V. No. 46/210)

The triennial poll came round again and again the people voted "no license". (Sep 24, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,14)

It is not a question of license or no-license, trade or no-trade, hotels or no hotels. (Oct 5, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,23)

n. [attrib. use; see no-license noun]

From Oamaru - which is a "no-license" town. (Dec 30, 1924,Otago Witness,1)

no-nukes¶

adj. non-nuclear

But if its rebellion succeeds, Canterbury will not be New Zealand, and the "no-nukes" legislation was enacted in Wellington by a parliament comprised mostly of Aucklanders. (Apr 15, 1991,Listener (New Zealand Listener),38)

no-remittance¶

adj. referring to a system of importing (espec motorcars) where the importer had sterling or other overseas funds and did not need to `remit' funds from New Zealand. (1960's - c. 1973 ??) [obs]

Exceptions are made only for no-remittance cars and leprosy (Jun 25, 1972,Sunday Times (NZ),35/5)

no-till¶

adj.

The farmers were comparing no-till peas with traditional cultivation at Smedley Station and at the Ritchies' Drumpeel property in Otane. (Nov 29, 2002,Dominion Post,C8)

no-tillage¶

adj.

A no-tillage farm will be under the spotlight at a field day in Manawatu on December 5... No-tillage involves sowing seeds without disturbing the soil, except by the seed drill. (Nov 29, 2002,Dominion Post,C8)

No. 8 gauge¶

n.

A really good wire fence generally consists of six plain steel wires of No.8 gauge, and stout ironstandards ... (1902,Brett's Colonists Guide,94)

LEVY ... the fence consisted of four posts [246] to the chain, with seven plain galvanised No. 8 gauge wires supporting three or four battens between each post. (1951,Grasslands of NZ,245,1970 ed.)

No. 8 wire¶

n. the standard, number eight gauge fencing wire

.. six wires of not less diameter and weight per ton than the wire commonly known as No 8 wire. (Mar 28, 1885,Weekly News,4)

The notions that Mitchell whipped up out of surfboards, Tom Wolfe and No8 wire still resonate. (Aug 27, 2005,Listener (New Zealand Listener),33)

noa¶

adj. free from tapu or any other restriction

IHIMAERA & LONG The taniwha in im curled up and went to sleep with a contented smile on its face. Henry at last was noa. (1982,Into the World of Light,218)

Metcalf explains the Maori concept of noa, where food is used 'to make things normal, to make things okay, after a cermony". (Jul 5, 2003,Nelson Mail,13)

After a burial everyone comes back for the hakari or feast that brings back noa. (Jul 5, 2003,Nelson Mail,13)

The solution was to draw an aukati line around the floor, dividing tapu from noa. (Nov 23, 2005,NZ Herald,B5)

In Tauranga there has been a plethora of disturbing unexplained phenomena, which has resulted in calls for tohunga intervention to make the area "noa" - or free from tapu. (Jul 24, 2000,Evening Post,TV Week : 15)

NICHOLAS Common Noa (1817,New Zealand (various authors/titles),2/336) [NOTES: English-NZ Vocabulary]

LEE & KENDALL N|oa, a. Common, free, disengaged, &c. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,185)

WILEY & MAUNSELL He replied that his grandfather Kukutai had sent word that he would not consent to his (Ngataru's) becoming Noa (common) while he retained those garments. (Nov 2, 1839,Robert Maunsell,61,1938 ed.)

BIDWILL The natives always require an additional consideration for taking off the taboo', or makingnoa' any places which may be included in a purchase. (1841,Rambles in NZ,118,1952 ed.)

SHORTLAND [The] ceremony of making noa' thetaua', that is, of restoring the men who composed it to their ordinary condition, by severing the intimate connexion existing between them and the Atua' so long as they remainedtapu'. Ibid/ 103 Every thing not included under the class of tapu is called noa, meaning free or common. (1851,Southern Districts of NZ,69)

... the spirit is held fast whilst some food is being cooked; and ultimately the tapu is pronounced no'[sic] or void'. (Aug 15, 1857,Lyttelton Times,3)

Up to the time when the planting commenced everything was noa, or `common', but once the seed began to be handled ... the whole thing became tapu, or consecrated... (1903,TrNZI,35/17)

TREGEAR The new-born babe and its mother were both very sacred at this time and not to be touched by outsiders till they had been made `common' (noa). (1904,Maori Race, The,43)

noa, common; free from tapu. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/154) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

HENDERSON The dining-house was noa, and slaves or any person could enter it. (1948,Taina,29)

HOWE Noa - the narrowest sense of this word is freeing from restriction' orcleansing', but like itscomplementary quality tapu' (q.v.) it pervades all aspects of Maori life and custom. Generally it is associated with cooked food, water, women, the low-born, and the young, good, and ordinary life events. (seetapu') Only women or special males have the power to remove `tapu'. (1985,Towards Taha Maori,21)

Noah's ark¶

n. a nark, informant [ORIGIN: rhyming slang]

There are also terms specific to the prison situation such as Noah's ark for a nark (informer). (Oct 1999,NZWords,2(2) : 2)

NEWBOLD NOAH'S ARK (n) Informant. Rhyming slang from NARK (q.v.). (1982,Big Huey, The,251)

nob¶

n. a double-headed coin

DEVANNY Sometimes two pennies are filed down to half their thickness and then joined together. A double-tailer is called a 'grey'; a double-header a 'nob. (1928,Dawn Beloved,163)

nob onto¶

v.

THATCHER And the girls too we find carry on some nice games,/ Nobbing on to the fellows who're in therich claims; (1869,Gold in Local Songs,25)

nobber¶

1 n. (Rural) a young wild deer.

ANDERSON A grand little Maori lad by the name of Wongi joined me for two months outback in the wild country thinning out deer, nobbers, hinds and fawns and pigs (1962,Life's Roundabout, A,36)

nobbie¶

n. a nob-shaped hill

HAMILTON Bill would say, `I'll show you where the fence is. You see that nobby away over there? The one with the rocks on it?' I could see at least fifty nobbies with rocks on them and said so. (1969,Wild Irishman,108)

nobbies¶

n. a name for excrement; POOS, (etc) Spg perhaps knobbies (Prob. from knob a lump') [1953 (Johnsonville Children)I wanna do nobbies']

nobble¶

v. of money, to spend, to use up (possibly reformed from nobbler; or from nobble to secure a person (or racehorse) to one's side by bribery OED 1865; NZ 1890 (Parliament))

WICKHAM The bridge, a noble structure - ... half a hundred thousand was `nobbled' to build it - still spans the stream. (1888,Ramblings,60)

nobbler¶

n.

Sure enough there were two full whisky nobblers on my dresser. (1969,Landfall,23(1) No. 89?29)

The hotel-keepers and publicans ofWestport.. reduced the price of theindispensable "nobbler" to the smallcharge of one sixpence!... Moreover, thereduction was made not alone for thatday, but for all time; "stout, spiders,and hot grog excepted." (Mar 27, 1869,Westport Times,2)

BATHGATE ... a box of `nobbler glasses', as small thick tumblers of limited capacity were called. (1913,Sodger Sandy's Bairn,79)

nobbler n. a drink of spirits. - nobb'lerise v.i. to drink heavily. (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,8)

BRERETON Mr Ross [true Milesian type of Irishman'] had lived in America and sailed on Yankee ships and he affected a few Yankee expressions. He often spoke of having anobbler of whiskey'. (1947,No Roll of Drums,77) [NOTES: [Refce.1880's]]

DAVIN Putting the nobbler down empty (1949,Roads from Home,45)

MUNDY ... from a bottle of whiskey poured him out a good nobbler, (1953,Days That Are No More,30)

~ n. a glass of spirits. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),621)

nobbler n. glass of spirits. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),14)

(1969,Landfall,23/29)

WILSON The steward came over with our drinks, and by the time we'd paid for our nobblers Don had ... disappeared again. (1973,NZ Jack,91)

nobbler n. NZ & Austral. sl. small alcoholic drink. [orig. unkn.] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,508) [NOTES: nf 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]

McGILL nobbler mid-C19 dram of any alcoholic spirit, usually gin, brandy, whisky, rum or brandy. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,76)

Meals, beds, and horse-feeds were from half a crown to 5s each, and nobblers 1s. (Mar 11, 1924,Otago Witness,60)

DAVIES On one occasion, an inventive genius tooka "nobbler" of "pain killer", pronouncedit good, and the whole stock was sold ata shilling a nip. (1884,Poems & Other Literary Remains,273)

When the hateful `nobbler' shall be forgot,/ (Nov 1856,Canterbury Rhymes,41)

1/306 (Sep 12, 1857,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/306,1960 ed.) [NOTES: (C.W. Richmond)]

HIGGINS In the Colonies glasses of anything are called noblers so that if youwant anything you ask for a nobler of what you want... (Dec 27, 1858,Letters,(3)) [NOTES: Griffiths Collection]

SHAW You are accustomed to the lazy and lounging and nobblerizing community too often to be found in the towns of New Zealand and in Sydney where people prefer ...nobblers to occupation. [F.N.] A `nobbler' is, I believe, half a glass of grog or spirit. (1858,Gallop to the Antipodes, A,58)

UNCLE JOHN What harm in the young wife serving them over the counter with nobblers. (1859,Hints to Colonists,16)

THATCHER In vain I nobbers drank. (1862,Canterbury Songster,9)

I subjoin the retail prices of a few articles sold at Tuapeka:- Brandy, 15s. per bottle, or 1s.6d. per nobbler; ... common lace-up boots, from [pounds]2 to [pounds]2 10s. per pair; American pegged boots, [pounds]3 10s.; ... (Oct 1, 1861,NZ Goldfields,31,1961 ed.)

.. business, drinking `nobblers' (1864,Chambers Edinburgh Journal,349) [NOTES: A glance at Dunedin]

When [spirits] shall be as common as ginger beer .... men will not think of treating each ither to the deleterious nobbler. (1864,Saturday Review,1/3)

... sending up a nobbler or a fig of tobacco. (Aug 12, 1864,Dunedin Punch,113)

MUELLER From them I heard that a report has been spread in Invercargill of Price selling nobblers on board the steamer Bruce. ... Price refused to serve them, saying he would sell spirits only by the bottle, and I know for certain that never did sell one single nobbler while here. (Oct 12, 1865,My Dear Bannie,59,1958 ed.)

THATCHER And the [bar] counters all are full, and folks for nobblers loudly call,/ (1865,Otago Songster,10)

THOMSON a nobbler from his private cellar stood for good sauce for our meal. (1867,Rambles with a Philosopher,49)

FRERE Even at that early hour in the morning, `nobblers' were considered desirable. (1870,Antipodes,102)

MONEY ... and there behind the bar ... was Reinecker ... serving a `nobbler' to a sashed and booted digger. Ibid. 102 Turning into the nearest store, I called for a nobbler, and asked the storeman, while he bittered the decoction, what he would give a man for bringing the various articles he required. (1871,Knocking About in NZ,13)

TINNE ... a nobbler' or drink ... <i> Ibid.</i> 5 ... when I requested them to give me anobbler' ordrink, his wife informed me that not having a spirit license [sic], she must refuse to serve me; ... (1873,Wonderland of the Antipodes,3)

WISNIOWSKI .. I went to fetch the brandy - a quarter of a litre f it, the quantity served in the colonies, in smalltumblers of very thick glass. This modest drink is known as a `nobbler'. (1877,Tikera,250)

BATHGATE There's nothing like a good stiff nobbler first thing in the morning for picking you up. (1881,Waitaruna,220)

NESFIELD Their object is the `nobbler'. (1881,Chequered Career,29)

HOPEFUL If spirits are called for, instead of the quartern or half-quartern, it is here, and inAustralia, called a `nobler.'[sic] (1887,Taken In,135)

MORRIS Nobbler, n. a glass of spirits; lit. that which nobbles or gets hold of you. Nobble is the frequentative form of nab. No doubt there is an allusion to the bad spirits frequently sold at bush public-houses, but if a teetotaler had invented the word he could not have invented one involving stronger condemnation.[1852] (1898,Austral English,321)

SATCHELL I'll take a nobbler of rum. (1902,Land of the Lost,25)

... dispensing the sixpenny nobbler to the multitude. (Sep 30, 1905,NZ Truth,15/1/6)

nobblerise¶

v.

ROLLESTON `The ladies nobblerise to an extent much to be regretted'. (1980,Master, The,45) [NOTES: 1858 Dec Hannah Richardsons' Journal in 1980 Rolleston The Master 45]

MORRIS Nobblerise, v. to drink frequent nobblers(q.v.). [1864] (1898,Austral English,322)

v.

No more at even shall our fast young swells/ For drinks at yankee grab, or euchre play./ ... Nor Justices' who guard the public weal,/ Standnobblerising' at the public bars. (1876,Southern Advertiser,5)

FERGUSON On Saturday and market nights frequent the company of hard-gristed cockatoos - smoking and nobblerising, if you will - ... (1905,Poems & Sketches,86)

nobblerising¶

adj.

WAITT Our delightful sojourn for a few days at Akaroa with the old nobblerizing Admiral and his quaint stories - ... (1856,Progress of Canterbury, NZ, The,2)

SHAW (1858,Gallop to the Antipodes, A,58) [NOTES: [see NOBBLER n1 1858] Morris: nobblerize 1864]

nobody home¶

phr.

McGILL nobody home not concentrating; a vacant mind; eg `I asked him why he did it, but I might as well have saved my breath, there's nobody home.' (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,76)

nodder¶

1 n. (Rural) a nodding thistle.

CANDY Gather ye nodders while ye may, They'll only be worse another day. Recently a prize was awarded for the biggest nodder, and it went to a grazier with a choice specimen nearly 3m high. (1988,Every Living thing,13)

noddie¶

n. A four-wheeled barrow or small wagon on which passenger luggage was formerly (to the mid-1970s) placed for carriage on the inter-island ferries. The noddie, or a rake of them, are drawn by hand or by tractor onto the ferry, and again onto the terminal at disembarkation.

A slowly moving rake of waggons had caught a luggage noddie' ... and the noddie in turn had caught the deceased ... I instructed him to take off the centre rake of railway wagons first, and then pull off one passenger luggage barrow ornoddie' by hand. A tractor was not needed or necessary. ... I then discovered a smashed luggage noddie on the port side of the linkspan [of the Cook Strait rail-ferry] and could see feet protruding from beneath it. (May 26, 1972,Evening Post,18)

nodding thistle¶

n. (See thistle)

HILGENDORF NODDING THISTLE (Carduus nutans), also called bastard Scotch thistle, is found in Auckland, South [established in] Canterbury and Otago. [and is increasing in other parts of both islands.] ... It is biennial with deeply-cut prickly edged leaves, ... (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,192,1967 ed.)

nodding thistle [s] Carduus nutans L. Ibid. 78 thistle, nodding [s] Carduus nutans L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,53)

noddy¶

n. a nodding head, used in TV interviews

Also, make the reporters part of the story, using noddies, two-shots and live crosses in anoraks as often as possible. (Jan 31, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),78)

n.

POLACK The small noddies (sterna solida) abound in large flocks, as also the oyster-catchers and water-hens, whose excessive tameness has nearly annihilated them. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/307)

POLACK The small noddies (sterna solida) abound in large flocks, as also the oyster-catchers and water-hens, whose excessive tameness has nearly annihilated them. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/307)

FALLA et al. WHITE-FRONTED TERN Sterna striata Other names: Sea-swallow, Kahawai Bird, Tara, Blackcap, Grenadier, Swallowtail, Noddy (Chathams), Tikkitak (Stewart Is.) (1966,Birds of New Zealand,164)

White-fronted Tern Sterna striata (GMELIN, 1789) ... OTHER NAMES: Tara, sea-swallow, kahawai bird, black cap, grenadier, swallowtail, noddy. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,232)

2 n.

Grey Ternlet Procelsterna cerulea (BENNETT, 1840) ... The grey ternlet breeds in loose colonies on the coasts of Pacific islands. ... OTHER NAMES: Grey noddy, blue-grey noddy, little blue petrel, blue billy. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,235)

2 n.

White-capped Noddy ... OTHER NAMES: Black noddy, lesser noddy, titerack. ... In New Zealand breeds at the Kermadec Islands ... (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,234)

  1. Anous minutus minutus Boie, 1844 White-capped Noddy Tropical and subtropical seas, including Kermadec Islands; ... (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,56,1980 ed.)

Noddy house¶

...terraces so far have proved most likely to leak and rot. "We call them Noddy houses," he says. "It's not an apartment problem, it's a Noddy house problem." (Oct 12, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),24)

Noddytown¶

n.

Final plans for the townhouse development at 123 Aro Street, slated as "Noddytown" by affected residents, has been publicly notified without such restrictions. (Jul 20, 2000,City Voice,2)

nog¶

n.

SALMOND Nog (or dwang). a short piece of framing timber fixed tightly between studs, to which lining materials are fixed. (1986,Glossary of Building Terminology,232)

v.

(1957,NZ Timber Journal,59/2)

noggin¶

n. drink

He sinks three pages of variegated noggins. (Jan 31, 1944,NZEF Times,III/136 : 7)

nogging¶

n.

NOG: (Bld) A block of wood the size of a brick, built into a wall to provide a means of nailing, skirting, etc. Hence "nogging", the filling in of the spaces between timber in walls and partitions.NOGGING PIECES : Stiffening pieces between studs. (Dec 1957,NZ Timber Journal,59)

The building is what they call brick nogging. (Feb 3, 1853,Journal of Henry Sewell,1/123,1980 ed.)

PAUL ... church of brick noggin ... [fn] The design ... was for a long, high structure of timber with brick in-filling and tower, but the length was reduced for economy reasons and the unseasoned timber shrank rendering the building unsafe. (1857,Letters from Canterbury, NZ,64)

BACON The house was a mere shell, all its constructional details plainly visible. Rafters, studs and noggings, in all their naked glory, flaunted themselves unashamedly before my eyes. Ibid. 181 (Glossary) noggings-In building, horizontal spacers securely fastened between the uprights (studs) of a house frame. Usually covered by exterior walls and interior lining material. (1963,In the Sticks,7)

nogging pieces¶

n.

horizontal spacers securely fastened between the uprights (studs) of a house frame. Usually covered by exterior walls and interior lining material. (Dec 1957,NZ Timber Journal,59/2)

nohi¶

n. Luzuriaga parviflora

MOORE & IRWIN LUZURIAGA PARVIFLORA. Nohi is a stringy little plant that grows on the CoromandelRanges and extends to Stewart Island, reaching sea-level in the south. (1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,186)

WILSON Luzuriaga parviflora LANTERNBERRY ... Nohi ... Wiry-stemmed litle plant, the leafy shoots arching from a creeping base. ... Fruit white, crisp-fleshed, filled with numerous small, hard, pale seeds. ... (=Enargea parviflora). (1982,Stewart Island Plants,252)

n. (See Jack Nohi)

noho kainga¶

n. a village [ORIGIN: Maori]

.. meaning marae founder Bruce Stewart is a step closer to his dream of building a noho kainga, or village, there. (Dec 11, 2004,Dominion Post,A7)

noho marae¶

n. residential sessions for distance learners [ORIGIN: Maori, [Ma. noho (-ia) live in] cf. P.M. Ryan Dict. Modern Maori (1995) 152.]

I put much of this new-found confidence down to the noho marae at Tauranga, and the chance to speak the language. (Jul 10, 2011,Sunday Star Times,C7)

Next year the four wananga reo, including noho marae (literally stay-overs on marae) may be held only at AUT's nga Wai O Horotiu marae. (Jul 10, 2011,Sunday Star Times,C7)

You are required to attend four five-day intensive noho marae (live-ins) which take place at the beginning of each school holiday. (Dec 2, 2005,Whakatane Beacon,10)

These noho marae are held in the mataatua rohe (Whakatane student) and in Wellington (Wellington students). (Nov 17, 2006,Whakatane Beacon,13)

Most of your study is done at home. There are four noho marae held throughout the year, online tutorials and chat rooms, and you'll receive plenty of support from your lecturers who will visit your home area weekly. (Dec 2, 2005,Whakatane Beacon,10)

In addition to the evening classes and tutorials, you use DVD resources, a structured workbook and have two noho marae (live-ins). (Dec 2, 2005,Whakatane Beacon,10)

nohoanga¶

n. a campsite. [also kainga nohoanga, a temporary campsite.]

It was the announcement of the creation of nohoanga (exclusive riverside campsites facilitating access to customary fishing sites) and topuni reserves (the granting of additional status to areas of special significance) within the Ngai Tahu settlement that resulted in Mr Graham's recent comments that there were some different laws for Maori and pakeha. (Jun 15, 1997,Sunday Star Times,C1)

A total of 72 nohoanga (literally places of temporary occupation) entitlements will provide Ngai Tahu with temporary campsites near rivers and lakes throughout the tribal area. (Sep 28, 1997,Sunday Mirror Magazine (London),A6)

Misunderstandings around possible nohoanga (camping and food-gathering sites) had also arisen, Mr Logan said. (Aug 31, 2000,Evening Post,2)

That 1868 judgement [of the Native Land Court] also did not make redress regarding mahika kai or kainga nohoanga. (May 28, 2012,Otago Daily Times,A11)

More than 300 nohoanga have been found on the Waitaki River valley - a reflection, says Davis, of both its significance as a food source and as a convenient pathway through a landscape largely covered with scrub and bush to moa-hunting grounds in central Otago and pounamu rivers in Westland. (May 2001,NZ Geographic,51/44)

Nohoanga were established in the South Island under the Ngai Tahu Treaty settlement in 1996 but former Treaty settlements minister Doug Graham said no national park land would be used. (Aug 22, 2000,Dominion,1)

nohu¶

n. Williams 223 Nohu (i) A fish with poisonous spines, like a porcupine fish, but reddish in colour.:

BEST (1929,Fishing Methods,43)

noise¶

n.

HARTLEY When the heading dog begins to develop sufficient noise, he is much more valuable if he will hunt. (1949,Shepherd's Dogs, The,38)

1 n. (Rural) [sp.use] the bark of a huntaway sheepdog. [Google search Feb 2006: New Zealandism.]

HARTLEY The dog should direct his noise at the sheep. (1949,Shepherd's Dogs, The,76)

Noise - a huntaway's bark. From whatever angle it's delivering its noise from, it should be 'square on' to the sheep. (Nov 15, 1983,NZ Journal of Agriculture,20)

With uncanny understanding of sheep and dog, Dudley stopped Corby and asked for noise when the dog was perhaps one third of the way to the sheep. (Mar 9, 1967,NZ Farmer,37)

Mark is a good strong, direct Huntaway with excellent noise. (Jul 8, 1971,NZ Farmer,102)

SINCLAIR In breeding if she went to a strong-eyed dog, she threw pups with some eye, but with noise on a mob. (1973,Boot in the Stirrup,9)

GORDON Has it got good noise? of all the questions that can be asked about a working sheep dog, the standard enquiry about the quality and quantity of its noise will be asked only in this country. (1998,Three Sheep and a Dog,69)

KERR Huntaways or barking dogs work with noise: chasing, blocking and pushing to herd sheep into position. (2000,High Times in the High Country,135)

[advertisement] YOUNG seven year old Huntaway dog. Good noise and sides etc. $2000. Phone 874 9013 (Jul 23, 2005,Hawke's Bay Today,Weekend Market)

McCALLUM I find that the mother-in-law has been earwigging to the races on the noise-box (1963,Half-Gallon Jar,25, 84)

n.

"Nolan's Cooee" - a stick of gelignite used to attract the ferryman or anyone else hidden by the all-enveloping forests - is not heard in South Westland these days. (1944,Korero (AEWS Background Bulletin),2(18) ; 7)

nominee¶

n.

HOCKEN So passionate elsewhere was the popular feeling that with difficulty did Sir George Grey equip the new Legislative Council at [117] Wellington with its non-official members - `nominees' they were called, a term which indeed became one of reproach. (1898,Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand,116)

non compos mentis¶

non-association order¶

n. a criminal sanction introduced in 1989 by the Criminal Justice Act, s 2. [Jim Cameron writes: It prohibits an offender from associating with specified persons or classes or persons for a period up to a year.]

Another new sanction is the non-association order (1989). The term is not found in NSOD and there seems to be no sanction in England of that name. (Jan 1999,NZWords,2)

HULME When it's a good season, tons are lovingly packed into freezers against the lean, non-bait portion of the year; ... (1986,Te Kaihau,37)

non-Coaster¶

n. person not from the West Coast

He's cagey, though, and reluctant to share his name with a nosy non-Coaster. (Oct 9, 2005,Sunday Star Times,C3)
