adj.

DOWNES & HARCOURT It happened also with 'Dad and Dave' on 2YD and other non-commercial stations. (1976,Voices in the Air,150)

non-iwi¶

n. a population exclusive of an iwi [ORIGIN: blend]

You'll find that, iwi adopting non-iwi as their own is a lot more common than it appears in general. (Jan 30, 2008,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.maori.org.nz/papa_panui/forum_topic.asp?TOPIC_ID=4415&FORUM_ID...]

The Government's first big Maori policy test, legislation that will, at least on paper, allow the banning of non-iwi from parts of the East Coast shore is looming. (Jan 7, 2009,Listener (New Zealand Listener),5)

adj.

This meant that agencies such has the social welfare agencies could fund non-iwi groups. (Sep 2000,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.knowledge-basket.co.nz/waitangi/temanu/celebrate.htmlTe Manutukutuku Number 52]

"Iwi Maori and not least Ngati Porou respect wahi tapu and all we ask non-iwi people is to accord the same respect to wahi tapu as well." (Feb 4, 2009,Gisborne Herald) [NOTES: http://www.gisborneherald.co.nz/Default.aspx?s=3&s1=2&id=8777]

This seminar is directed toward: .. research teams (which may include non-iwi members) who are conducting research for their iwi and/or under the umbrella of their iwi. (2007,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.mkta.co.nz/Default.aspx?page=1440 Iwi Research]

non-Maori¶

adj. [also as noun]

Michael King ...Anzac Day services, the country's first example of non-Maori indigenous ceremonial... (2003,Penguin History of New Zealand,434)

Outside this sequential linkage of ancestor to successive descendant cultures, there is no evidence for any pre-Maori element in New Zealand. The supposed pre-Maori and non-Maori Moriori of mainland New Zealand as depicted by earlier writers are simply the early Maori. (1984,Te Maori,61)

Secondly, the commission sought a Maori-speaking secretary. ... Maori-only advertisements did not preclude non-Maori from applying for the job because there were many non-Maori people who did have adequate Maori language skills ... (Jan 19, 1989,Evening Post,2)

non-molestation order¶

n.

Jacqui's answer is to keep the child from him with a non-molestation order through the courts. (Jan 16, 1982,Listener (New Zealand Listener),25)

non-New Zealander¶

n.

Suppose a friend says to me, `You know that drongo who was on the chain with me at the works last summer? Just a little joker he was, remember? A real serious ankle-biter. Hailed from somewhere down the Wire Wrapper. A right useless bastard. Couldn't see the road to the dunny if it had red flags on it. Well, it seems that he's shacked up with some pluty Remmers sheila and she's about to drop her bundle.' ... A non-New Zealander will probably require a translation, ... My friend is communicating to me the information that a slow-witted, incompetent person of diminutive stature, who was reared in the Wairarapa district and worked for a time in the killing gang of an abattoir, is now cohabiting with a wealthy woman from the affluent Auckland suburb of Remuera. This woman is soon to give birth. (Jan 1989,Pacific Way,10) [NOTES: Sharp New Zildish]

non-notified¶

adj. secret, in committee

Bureaucrats have added a troublesome euphemism, the word "non-notified", to the language. "Non-notified" is a cover-up for "secret", and enables councils to exercise their powers without the community's knowledge. (Jul 28, 2004,Dominion Post,B5) [NOTES: Frank Haden]

non-shouting¶

adj.

[Leader] ... a meeting has been held in ... Otago for the purpose of forming a `Non-Shouting Society', ... all present pledged themselves to abstain from treating their neighbours, friends and acquaintances, to liquor of every sort. (Jan 16, 1868,Evening Post)

non-strip¶

adj. (Rural) [of farms, herds and cowsheds] where cows are not stripped before and after milking by machine.

Half share-milking on a one-man farm with a non-strip herd and a tractor is not such a hard job for a strong man. (Oct 2, 1950,NZ Dairy Exporter,89)

This is a non-strip herd. (Jun 10, 1958,NZ Dairy Exporter,30)

This is a non-strip shed. (Apr 11, 1960,NZ Dairy Exporter,13)

non-stripping¶

adj. (Rural) [of farms, herds and cowsheds] where cows are not stripped before and after milking by machine.

This is a non-stripping shed. (Mar 1, 1947,NZ Dairy Exporter,7)

The adoption of a non-stripping technique and the elimination of leg-ropes from the shed will have other effects besides those mentioned. (Aug 1, 1949,NZ Dairy Exporter,15)

Expecting satisfactory production under a non-stripping milking technique, without due consideration to all other aspects of farm and shed management ... (Dec 1, 1952,NZ Dairy Exporter,54)

n. (Rural) the milking of cows without stripping before and after the process.

I had to axe one or two hard milkers when I first started but non-stripping has certainly speeded up the whole job. (Mar 1, 1947,NZ Dairy Exporter,7)

Where the milker handled 1.5 sets of cups or less, the percentage of herds practising non-stripping or machine-stripping was 16 per cent. (Aug 1, 1949,NZ Dairy Exporter,15)

The Dairy Board intends to obtain more detailed information on these latter farms and to examine the effects, if any, on production since non-stripping was introduced. (Mar 1, 1955,NZ Dairy Exporter,42)

non-tangata whenua¶

adj.

This was not a mechanism for council to exhaust its responsibilities to non-tangata whenua Maori under the 2002 Act. (Nov 3, 2005,Horowhenua Mail,5) [NOTES: -]

non-wowser¶

n. [cf wowser]

There's a lot more to this nation than a commercially driven tribal game. Non-wowsers should take note. (Jul 26, 2011,Dominion Post,A26)

"Non-Wowser". - You start off too well. Your opening sentence, "Pimply ‒‒‒ wowser, prohibitionist, municipal muck-rake and star-chamber clown offers his miserable 9st 2lbs of water-fed carcase to ratepayers as Mayor," is too hot for this respectable weekly unless well backed up by facts that warrant the language. (Mar 28, 1908,NZ Truth,4)

The wowser and the non-wowser is [sic] bailed up at the point of the collection box, and anything from a "thrummer" to a "nickel" is thankfully received, the beigger the contribution the greater the oily thanks. (Jul 4, 1914,NZ Truth,12)

That the average non-wowser emits a loud "bah!" at the people who are ponderously surprised at Archdeacon Calder's famous wire. (Sep 6, 1913,Observer (Auckland),7)

nondi¶

n.

The students over whom he placed their fellows honoured him for the trust he reposed in them from the 'nondies' down. (1935,St Patrick's College 1883-1935,49)

They made me a Nondi. (1960,St Patrick's College 1883-1960,26)

LAWLOR I had marched gaily to camp hoping to become a soldier 'full of strange oaths and bearded like the pard';. Instead, they made me a 'Nondi' (i.e. nondescript'). (1962,More Wellington Days,149)

Being one of the Nondies, or in otherwords, one of the small fry, I have beenasked to make a few remarks on theirbehalf. (1919,Blue and White,114)

nong¶

n. a fool; a silly or stupid person (cf NING-NONG) [1984 16 F E36 Pakuranga Coll. 1 NONG -->1960 16C F B1 Nelson Girls C. 1 NONG -->1960 16C F B3 Marton D.H.S. 1 NONG -->1960 16C F B4 Wanganui Girls C. 1 NONG -->1960 16C F B5 Wellington Girls C. 1 NONG -->1960 17C M B7 Hamilton H.S. 1 NONG 1961 June Stage I University Student's Essay She's a nong]

Some don't want urban nongs straying over their land, leaving gates open, biffing their rubbish; others just let them take their chances with the bulls. (Nov 16, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),58)

There may be the odd enrolled nong who thinks, "Well, I was going to vote for the one that starts with L, and has lots of red on it, but it looks as if I was mistaken and it actually starts with A and has a lot of green, silly me, oh well, tick tick." (Jul 6, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),5)

WILSON I told you not to come, Dick. Don't be such a flaming galah.' ...I can't see you. Don't be such a nong.' (1976,Pacific Star)

Mortimer looked a real nong. This here is Mortimer,' said Fred.He's a pongo, but he can't help it.' (1977,Listener Short Stories,147) [NOTES: 1973 Grant `NZ Short Story' in 1977 Listener Short Stories 147]

BERRY Like assuming that all [prison] psychologists are nongs ... (1980,First Offender,69)

DUCKWORTH Like assuming that all [prison] psychologists are nongs ... (1984,Disorderly Conduct,12)

WILSON `Don't be a nong. Why should we! You'll still have plenty of fun.' - (1984,South Pacific Street,57)

The poor little nong thinks deer velvet makes you sexy - he'll get himself killed. (Oct 1, 1987,Evening Post,34) [NOTES: (Footrot Flats)]

McGILL nong idiot; short for ningnong'; egI tell you, Pasmore is a complete and utter nong. You only have to look at the stupid way he walks.' NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,77)

JANET HOLMES/L. BAUER In course of a lecture at x[?Lancaster] University on apologetic language referred to one interlocutor using I felt a bit of a nong.' British audience did not know this word in sense offool, wet' etc. (1989,Personal Communication)

nonghead¶

n. [(c1950s)]

THOMPSON In other words I was a lad of some pretension - a dreamer, who soon gathered to himself a series of unlovely nicknames. Ken Robins, a young man with whom I worked, called me Clueless Moody', the local barber coinedNonghead', and of course `Merv the Perv' ran out of every mouth like an epidemic. (1980,All My Lives,36)

noni¶

(a fruit grown in the Cook Islands) n.

The fruit of the noni is believed to alleviate arthritis. "Everyone's into noni," says Dennis. "Noni noni everywhere." (Nov 24, 2002,Sunday Star Times,C14)

On Saturday mornings at the lively Frankton market in Hamilton, a Fijian man sells large bottles containing the distilled juice of the nonu fruit, also known as noni... Nonu/noni, botanical name Morinda citrifolia, has been part of any Pacific healer's treatment kit for many hundreds of years, whereas kava (from the plant Piper methysticum) is the base of a drink consumed on both ritual and social occasions. (Sep 21, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),28)

noni juice¶

n. a juice made from the fruit of the noni tree, a Polynesian remedy for various ills

A friend rang up and by way of extolling the virues of noni juice began: "You know I can be a cruel, ruthless bastard ..." Well, he continued, he'd been taking noni juice for a month now. He pissed like a fire hydrant, he felt boundless energy, his blood pressure count had dropped; he dropped his voice as he came to the relevant part, the bit he thought would interest me "And my hair's grown back." I thought, "You cruel, ruthless bastard." (Jan 6, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),29)

Noni juice is a pungent, dark-brown concotion, but the fruit from which it is made has been identified as a key ingredient in transforming Niue from a struggling nation dependent on New Zealand aid to a blossoming market economy. (Oct 29, 2004,Dominion Post,B5)

Among the various wines, beer and spirits left over was a soft-drink bottle about a quarter filled with noni-juice, the all-purpose and powerful-smelling elixir of the islands... (Nov 2, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),7)

nono¶

n. buttocks [ORIGIN: Maori, cf. P.M. Ryan Dict. Modern Maori (1995)]

.. "whose nono is that?" ... (Nov 21, 2006,Whakatane Beacon,B4)

nonpareils¶

n. [-->Chambers 1983 gives sq. `a kind of comfit'. but no reference to hundreds-and-thousands which it defines as little sweets used as ornamental dressing -->Havelock 1935]

Noo Zilland¶

n. New Zealand (joc. broad Kiwi, or US)

Sir, - Thank you to R Herd for directing me as to where Noo Zilland is - couldn't hulp larfin. (Sep 26, 1987,Dominion,8)

Noogoora burr¶

n.

A quantity of earth-ballast was placed on the reclaimed land; a few months later the heap was.. covered with a luxuriant growth of weeds.. many" of them unfortunately but too well known in the colony. Others, however, including the notorious Noogoora burr, and the spiny dock or cat's-head, were new. (1894,Ann. Rep. Dept of Agriculture,II/50)

nooker¶

n. a nickname for a small boy, a `squirt' [ca1935 Havelock]

nookie¶

n. tiny, little

FUSSELL Nookie, nookie man (1917,Letter from Private Henare Tikitanu,19)

TUCKER Len's nickname ... was `Nookie', which today bears a totally different connotation to that which it did in those early years [c1930s]. How he came by it I will never know ... (1978,Thoroughbreds Are My Life,6)

nor'-wester¶

n.

[They] farm at Rongokokako.. where the nor'-westers touch land after being deflected by the Tararua Range. (Jul 8, 2004,Dominion Post,C8)

nor'west¶

adj.

The sensitive nor'west afternoon/ Collapsed, and the rain came;/ (1971,Nowhere Far from the Sea,124) [NOTES: Curnow `House and Land']

nor'west arch¶

1 n. (Rural) a delineation between cloud and clear sky that appears with a nor'west wind in Canterbury region.

Relph High country people are only too aware that the nor'west arch is the precursor of strong winds roaring down the valleys of the Waimakariri, Rakaia, and Rangitata Rivers, with heavy rain falling in the headwaters. (2007,From Tussocks to Tourists,34)

THOMSON The sun had set through a low nor'west arch .. the dusk was taking on a velvety, indistinct aspect ... (1952,Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker,13)

SLATTER The sky is clouded but with some blue far to the west where the nor'west arch sweeps across. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,19)

VANCE Its distinctive cloud formation, the lenticular alto-cumulus 'hogback', has become the warning signal to mountaineers as well as musterers, and the 'nor'west arch' is one of the features of Canterbury. (1965,High Endeavour,41)

VON HAAST The Canterbury plains are swept by two winds. On a Nor'-West day before the Nor'-Wester comes from the north-west across the mountains drained of its moisture, the clouds in the sky form a `Nor'-Wester' arch, ... (1948,Julius Von Haast,128)

... the sky is clouded but with some blue far to the west where the nor'-west arch sweeps across. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,19)

nor'west days¶

adj. a hot dry weather

SWANTON There are [in Canterbury] what are called `nor-west days', when hardly any wind is perceptible, so named on account of the close, dryheat (1892,Notes on NZ,57)

nor'wester¶

n. the hot, dry summer wind of the Canterbury Plains.

Surf driven before a brutal nor'wester hurls itself towards the big windows. (Jul 12, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20)

He loves being belted by a nor'wester, or taking the hard way up mountains. (Oct 19, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),33)

Later, in the back garden and out of the hot Canterbury nor'wester. Sue produces a bag of wine, fresh bread, cheese, salami. (Feb 1997,North & South,60)

Summer and spring are likely to be plagued by the nor'wester. (1944,Korero (AEWS Background Bulletin),2(10): 6)

Oliver (a certain former All Black captain who has a cottage nearby) reckons if I'm not careful the nor'wester will blow me over. (Sep 26, 2004,Sunday Star Times,B13)

Lift the lid on the box and the nor-wester scatters the contents across the paddocks. (Apr 21, 1984,Listener (New Zealand Listener),35)

Unpleasant though the Canterbury nor'wester undoubtedly is, its freakish tricks sometimes have their humorous side. (Feb 4, 1937,King Country Chronicle,4)

PEACHE Next day was a nor'wester ... (May 26, 1876,Journal) [NOTES: 1876 May 26 Peache Jnl in 1970 Gray Quiet with the Hills 44]

nor'westery¶

adj.

SHARPE On a nor'westery night, when there is no dew, header operators still work long hours. (1962,Country Occasions,89)

Norfolk pine¶

n. The Norfolk Island pine tree (Araucaria heterophylla) [Jim Cameron writes: this common and long-standing variation of the international term Norfolk Island pine is given only Aust and NZ citations in OED - the first is 1940 (Sargeson). it goes back to at least the 1930s - is not recorded in any dictionary I have seen.]

[Hdg] Lights out for norfolk pines at Parliament. Parliament's Speaker Jonathan Hunt.. won't be putting Christmas lights on the norfolk pines at Parliament. (Dec 12, 2000,Evening Post,3)

SHADBOLT Contrast clumsy macrocarpas with delicate Norfolk pines along a pleasant white beach. (1959,New Zealanders, The,203)

SARGESON In those days it was a quiet place up in the North there; a very old settled place with a row of Norfolk pines planted along the beach. (1937,Collected Stories,88)

STOKES Quote needed (1980,History of Tauranga County,288)

The wind rattles noisily in the towering Norfolk pines, icons of Napier. (Jun 1999,North & South,8)

"I look at all the Norfolk pines and pohutukawa around Wellington and I think - they're very pretty, but do they say anything to me about Wellington at all," she says, leaping astride a favourite hobbyhorse. (Sep 2004,Branch Out,No. 14/2)

The Chatham Islands astelia (Astelia chathamica) or kakaha is a plant used frequently by both home gardeners and landscapers. (Nov 13, 2004,Dominion Post,E13)

A large enough seaside garden is immediately given atmosphere by the addition of a Norfolk pine (Araucaria heterophylla), but your neighbours may not be so pleased, nor may your successor, for the eventual size is immense. (Feb 2001,Growing Today,57)

The Norfolk Pine (Araucaria araucana) and the monkey puzzle (A. heterophylla) are related evergreen conifers. The former has branches with a stiff upward tilt, the latter, from Chile, "fingers that hang off the branches", and, according to the Reader's Digest: Your Gardening Questions Answered, its spiral foliage pattern is :"supposed to be difficult for a monkey to descend". (Oct 15, 1990,Listener (New Zealand Listener),113)

ANDERSON There is a Norfolk Pine which her mother called a monkey puzzle when Una was little but never explained why. (1990,Girls High)

The shape of the political process is approximately that of a Norfolk pine. (Jan 14, 2000,Dominion,00) [NOTES: check page]

... the Norfolk pine in the front yard, the grapefruit tree and the woolshed and the sleep-out in the backyard. (Oct 6, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

DUDER We arrived at dusk.. and drove slowlypast a skating rink, sound shell,.. andthat mighty row of Norfolk pines you seein every picture of Napier. (1987,Alex,154)

Floodlighting along the beach foreshore was by courtesy of the Keys wallet and it is said that the fine stand of Norfolk pines fringing the northern border of Churchill Park were personally dug in by Len himself. (Aug 2001,NZ Memories,No. 31/43)

nork¶

n. [Contributed by Bill Pearson 1984 16 F E37 Pakuranga Coll. 22B NORK [a meal-food]]

If he were to have made a reference to breasts, he would have used the word "norks" instead of tits or boobs, he told a court martial. (Apr 2, 1998,NZ Herald,A6)

Normal School¶

n.

[Heading] Normal School in "DeplorablyFilthy State." (Aug 18, 1949,Southern Cross (Wgton),9)

The only institutions at present established for this [training] purpose are the Normal Schools in Christchurch and Dunedin, and a Training-school in Napier. (1901,NZ Journal of Education,3/134)

Norman¶

n. [1984 15 F E1 Pakuranga Coll. 3 NORMAN [something/one silly -->1984 15 M E62 Pakuranga Coll. 1 NORMAN or disliked or useless] -->1984 14 F E137 Wgton Girls C. 10 NORMAN [F2]]

Norsewood lantern¶

n.

ANDRESEN They also brought their 'Norsewood lanterns'. These were obtainable from Ole Olsen's smithy for tuppence each. In fact, they were bottles turned upside down, with the bottoms taken off with hot metal wire... Then a candle was thrust into the necks of the bottles. (2000,Johanna's World,138)

North¶

n. [see also Far, roadless, winterless North]

MANDER But the north was not respectable. It was the land of lost men. It was peopled with nomads and wasters. And it was the roadless north', thebarbaric north', where the Maoris still might war upon you in the night. It had no railway beyond Helensville. The Southerner curled his lip at it. (1925,Allen Adair,6,1971 ed.)

HULL Between Waimea and the North Cape lies a tract of country which ... is vaguely referred to as the North'; at election times the alliterative title ofthe Neglected North' is bestowed upon it. (1907,College Songs,46)

n. usually UP NORTH, occas. GO NORTH (cf DOWN SOUTH) check UP Broadly, anywhere north of the speaker's home district, but in different districts the idiom has a specific meaning. In the South Island, North' is usually the North Island (even in Dunedin) and Wellington the objective. In Marlborough (where one speaks ofgoing over to Wellington', up north' means furtherup the line' q.v. In more Southern parts of North Island `up North' would usually be taken to mean Auckland or thereabouts.

SCOTT Business called me up north for a few weeks [to North Island]. (1900,Colonial Turf,216)

MIDDLETON `The family was brought up on a farm up north', said the Professor. (1959,Stone, The,70) [NOTES: Corporal's Story]

ELDRED-GRIGG He went away up north [from Christchurch]. (1987,Oracles and Miracles,24)

North Auckland¶

n. (See also Far North)

  1. Sterna nereis (Gould, 1843) Fairy Tern New Caledonia, Australia and Tasmania; New Zealand, rare and local; a few pairs breeding North Auckland. (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,55,1980 ed.)

MOORE & IRWIN NOTHOFAGUS TRUNCATA. Hard beech, the only Nothofagus native to north Auckland, is absent from the east and south of the South Island. (1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,80)

North Aucklander¶

n.

This weekend two North Aucklanders didthe same for us. (Oct 30, 1916,Chronicles NZEF,I/5 : 107)

North Cape green gecko¶

n. bright green gecko with white or yellow markings, resident at the upper tip of the North Island. [Naultinus "North Cape green gecko" aka yellow-lipped gecko]

North Cape Green Gecko - Naultinus "North Cape green gecko" Threat Classification - 6 Sparse .. (2008,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.nhc.net.nz/index/lizards-new-zealand/risk-classification-nz-lizards.htm]

Ornate skink (Gradual Decline), North Cape Pacific gecko (Gradual Decline), Matapia gecko (Gradual Decline), North Cape green gecko (Sparse), Cyclodina levidensa (regionally significant), shore skink, and common gecko. (1997,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.conservation.govt.nz/upload/documents/conservation/land-and-freshwater/land/te-paki-ecological-district/te-paki-shrublands-n02-003.pdf]

This is one of the last large remaining contiguous habitats in Northland for a distinct form of the endemic North Cape green gecko ... (1997,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.conservation.govt.nz/upload/documents/conservation/land-and-freshwater/land/te-paki-ecological-district/te-paki-shrublands-n02-003.pdf]

North Cape Pacific gecko¶

n. a mottley brown gecko resident only at the tip of the North Island and nearby islands. [Hoplodactylus "North Cape Pacific Gecko" aka Northcape gecko]

Ornate skink (Gradual Decline), North Cape Pacific gecko (Gradual Decline), Matapia gecko (Gradual Decline), North Cape green gecko (Sparse), Cyclodina levidensa (regionally significant), shore skink, and common gecko. (1997,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.conservation.govt.nz/upload/documents/conservation/land-and-freshwater/land/te-paki-ecological-district/te-paki-shrublands-n02-003.pdf]

North Face Peak to Peak race¶

phr. (Sport)

SPORT The north face Peak to Peak race Man's ongoing fascination with battling the elements and conquering harsh terrain emerges in force this month with the return of The North Face Peak to Peak race. (Jul 2006,Air New Zealand inflight magazine,79)

North Harbour¶

v. the Northern Auckland catchment; a rugby super 12 franchise

North Island¶

n. [It is collocated with the definite article in NZ usage. (as is the South Island',the Middle Island', but not Stewart[s'] Island'). -->The absolute use without the article is not used by New Zealanders except (so R. Mason) Dr L. Cockayne, Dr H.H. Allan (see A Handbook of the Naturalized Flora of N.Z., D.S.I.R. Bulletin 83, e.g. 211... and the northern half of South Island') and G Simpson, all botanists who may have picked up the usage from Cockayne]

As the scenery in North Island is spectacular, so that in South Island is magnificent. (Jul 1949,Potomac Appalachian Trail Club Bulletin) [NOTES: E.H. Walker `A New Zealand Flight' in Potomac Appalachian Trail Club Bulletin (R. Mason)]

In North Island, New Zealand.... (Mar 1953,Potomac Appalachian Trail Club Bulletin,No 4 107)

... on North Island, New Zealand (Apr 1953,Scottish Geographic Magazine,69(1)/32) [NOTES: (J.B.T.).]

McDONNELL Coffee, sugar, indigo, and rice, would succeed well on the North Island, as also all the tropical fruits. New Zealand, more particularly Poenammoo, is yet but little known. (1834,Extracts From a Journal,20,1979 ed.)

adj. of or from the northern of NZ's two main islands [in early journals, often NORTHERN ISLAND, but this usage soon gives way to the standard form; as a distinguishing epithet in the names of plants and animals see EDELWEISS, EYEBRIGHT, LILY, RATA, crow, kiwi, oystercatcher, robin, saddleback]

BRASCH He had collected too a number of North Island trees andshrubs, at that time rareties in Dunedin, ...-a kauri, a whau, a puriri, a toro, a tawa and others. (1980,Indirections,53)

LEVY The South Island in an occasional `North Island' season still suffers from rank, foggy feed, and in such season hogget ill-thrift is rampant. (1951,Grasslands of NZ,336,1970 ed.)

North Island brown kiwi¶

2 n. (Environment) Apteryx australis mantelli North Island [Brown] Kiwi

The Western Bay of Plenty's North island brown kiwi population has grown this year thanks to the hard work of numerous landowners, agencies and volunteers, as part of Bank of New Zealand Save the Kiwi programme. (Jun 2007,Conservation Action,48)

1.a. Apteryx australis mantelli Bartlett, 1850 North Island [Brown] Kiwi (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,15,1980 ed.)

Ornithologists have separated the brown kiwi into three subspecies: the North Island brown kiwi Apteryx australis mantelli; the South Island brown kiwi A. a. australis; and the Stewart Island brown kiwi A. a. lawryi. ... OTHER NAMES: Rowi, Tokoeka. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,38)

North Island bush wren¶

n.

240.a. Xenicus longipes stokesi[i] Gray 1862 North Island Bush Wren ... very rare, possibly extinct. (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,63,1980 ed.)

Bush Wren Xenicus longipes (GMELIN, 1789) ... This tiny, inconspicuous bird may be extinct; ... South Island Bush Wren X.l. longpipes (GMELIN, 1789) North Island Bush Wren X.l. stokesii GRAY, 1862. Stead's Bush Wren X.l. variabilis STEAD, 1936. OTHER NAMES: Matuhituhi, green wren, Tom Thumb bird. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,265)

North Island crow¶

n.

The North Island crow, which is sometimes given the title of bell-bird on account of its notes, is larger than a tui, dark bluish-grey, and has blue wattles. (Dec 16, 1924,Otago Witness,6)

North Island fantail¶

2 n. (Environment)

256.a. Rhipidura fuliginosa placabilis Bangs, 1921 North Island Fantail (Piwakawaka) (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,67,1980 ed.)

Fantail Rhipidura fuliginosa (SPARRMAN, 1787) North Island Fantail R.f. placabilis BANGS, 1921. South Island Fantail R.f. fulginosa (SPARRMAN, 1787). Chatham Island Fantail R.f. penitus BANGS, 1911. OTHER NAMES: Piwakawaka, pied fantail, black fantail. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,280)

North Island fantails are almost always pied in colour, with jaunty bands across the throat, a buff chest and a black and white tail. (Jan 2002,NZ Geographic,No. 55/74)

North Island Hector's dolphin¶

n. an endangered marine dolphin, now known as Maui's dolphin. (See Maui's dolphin)

Since 1985, at least 20 of the North Island Hector's dolphins have died. (Mar 30, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),26)

North Island kaka¶

n. N. meridionalis septentrionalis.

216.a. Nestor meridionalis septentrionalis Lorenz, 1896 North Island Kaka (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,58,1980 ed.)

Already, one of our rarest birds, the North Island kaka, has been turning up in parks and backyards in the middle of Auckland. (Jun 24, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),28)

North Island kiwi¶

n. Apteryx mantelli

Only North Island brown kiwi regularly lay a second egg, two to four weeks after the first. (Jan 2000,NZ Geographic,No. 45/78)

BULLER APTERYX MANTELLI {BULLERI}. (NORTH-ISLAND KIWI.) ... Native names.- Kiwi and Kiwi-parure. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,358,1888 2nd edn 2/308 ed.)

56. Apteryx mantelli, Bart. North Island Kiwi, Brown Kiwi. - Still to be found in many parts of the North Island, it is also met with on some adjacent islands. (Sep 1885,NZ Journal of Science,505) [NOTES: (T.H. Potts)]

POWELL NORTH ISLAND KIWI (Apteryx mantelli). The kiwi has become so widely known as a symbol of New Zealand that description is scarcely necessary. (1947,Native Animals of NZ,76 ed.)

NATUSCH There are three species of kiwi, divided into five races: the North Island kiwi (Apteryx australis mantelli ... ); the South Island tokoeka (A.a. australis); the Stewart Island Kiwi (A.a. lawryi ... );the little spotted kiwi of west and southern South Island (A. owenii);and the great spotted kiwi from more northern parts of the South Island (A. haastii). (1967,Animals of NZ, The,250)

North Island kokako¶

2 n. (Environment)

279.a. Callaeas cinerea wilsoni (Bonaparte, 1851) North Island Kokako (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,72,1980 ed.)

Kokako Callaeas cinerea (GMELIN, 1788) ... North Island Kokako C.c. wilsoni (BONAPARTE, 1851). South Island Kokako C.c. cinerea (GMELIN, 1788). OTHER NAMES: Blue wattled crow, blue gill, orange wattled crow, organ bird. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,303)

North Island lily¶

n. Arthopodium cirratum ; rengarenga.

MATTHEWS (And) Arthopodium cirratum North island lily (1890,Descriptive & Priced List)

NAIRN & SON (And) Arthopodium cirratum North island lily (1912,Catalogue (Nairn & Son))

North Island little shearwater¶

n.

65.c. Puffinus assimilis haurakiensis Fleming and Serventy, 1943 North Island Little (Allied) Shearwater (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,28)

North Island Main Trunk¶

n. railway

The King Movement and its supporters retreated to the hills, where they were able to hold up construction of the North Island Main Trunk railway for years until the government finally made peace, but not amends, with them. (Nov 1999,North & South,60)

The first section of the North Island Main Trunk railway runs through the whole length of the block, and trains run twice a week to a point called Rangatira, three miles beyond Hunterville. (Jan 23, 1890,Otago Witness,7)

LEITCH In contrast to the North Island Main Trunk which opened up large areas for settlement, the South Island's Main North Line would cross barren hill country suitable only for extensive sheep grazing. (1972,Railways of NZ,129)

North Island rata¶

n. M. robusta [aka northern rata]

LAING & BLACKWELL Metrosideros robusta (The North Island Rata). A tee, 50 ft.-100 ft. in height. ... North Island and northern extremity of South Island. ... Maori name Rata. ... [297] This is the North Island rata, but it is also found on the west coast of the South Island ... It is often described as twining round some forest tree, ensheathing it and finally killing it by a close embrace; this account .... misrepresents, ... M. robusta. It does not begin life as a climber, though there are species which do so, e.g., M. scandens; but it very often germinates as an epiphyte high up in the forks of a tree ... As the young plant develops, it sends down roots to the ground. These roots inosculate, and slowly enclose the stem of the supporting tree. (1940,Plants of NZ,296)

North Island robin¶

n. (Environment)

[Caption] The first North Island robin chick to be hatched at the Society's forest reserve at Bushy Park near Wanganui. (May 2002,Forest & Bird,304/42)

It's an unlikely breakfast call, but within minutes a North Island Robin flutters around us, then pounces on the worms Luton has shaken onto the ground. (Sep 2002,AA Directions,16)

Four kilometres off Whangaparaoa peninsula, the predator-free reserve is now home to saddleback, little spotted kiwi, whitehead, parakeet, kokako, North island robin and takahe. (Apr 2000,North & South,85)

They are now applying to bring back another bird, the North Island robin, and hope in future to have whitehead, kakariki parakeets and other rare birds gracing the peninsula again. (Nov 2002,Forest & Bird,305/42)

The North Island robin is a small sooty-black forest bird with grey streaks on head and throat, and a white belly and under-tail .. It has very long thin legs and stands upright. It is smaller than a starling but bigger than a sparrow. (Jun 2001,Absolutely Positively Wellington,4)

The arrival of the first "resident" North Island robin chicks on Matiu / Somes Island coincided with celebrations of a 25-year volunteer effort ... (Nov 2006,Footnotes,26 / 1)

On the lower slopes we found that rare bird, the North Island robin. (Apr 27, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,38)

I saw the North Island robin (Miro australis) several times ... (1908,TrNZI,40/501)

Robin Petroica australis (SPARRMAN, 1788) ... North Island Robin P.a. longpipes (LESSON, 1828). South Island Robin P.a. australis (SPARRMAN, 1788). Stewart Island Robin P.a. rakiura FLEMING, 1950. OTHER NAMES: Bush robin, toutouwai. F . NORTH ISLAND ROBIN (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,282)

MORRIS (1898,Austral English) [NOTES: see Morris above]

BULLER MIRO LONGPIPES {MIRO AUSTRALIS}. (NORTH ISLAND ROBIN.) .. Native names. Pitoitoi, Toutou, Toutouwai, and Totoara. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,121,1888 2nd edn 1/33 ed.) [NOTES: (?P.)]

Miro longipes Lesson. North Island Robin. Buller (1905), in a pathetic lament, speaks of the `last-heard-of pair of this expiring species' seen near Levin. (1923,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,6/89) [NOTES: Myers Endemic Birds]

GUTHRIE-SMITH .. I gathered that the North Island Robin (Petroeca longpipes) had also at one time been common (1926,Tutira,114)

McLINTOCK Robin, North island .. toutouwai .. Miro longipes. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

258.a. Petroica australis longipes (Lesson, 1828) North Island Robin (Toutouwai) (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,68,1980 ed.)

.. a flutter up ahead and a North Island robin hops nervously from branch, to branch hoping for the ground to be disturbed and some insects uncovered. [North Island Robin] (Feb 13, 1981,Dominion,11)

[caption] The North Island robin prefers the shade of the forest to the edge of the bush. (1983,Land of the Mist,69)

Robin Petroica australis (SPARRMAN, 1788) .. North Island Robin P.a. longpipes (LESSON, 1828). South Island Robin P.a. australis (SPARRMAN, 1788). Stewart Island Robin P.a. rakiura FLEMING, 1950. OTHER NAMES: Bush robin, toutouwai. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,282)

North Island thrush¶

n.

North Island Thrush. The native thrush, the piopio, appears to be a fast expiring species. (May 19, 1928,Evening Post,17)

BULLER TURNAGRA HECTORI. (NORTH ISLAND THRUSH.) ...Native names. Piopio, {Koropio,} Korohea, and Tiutiukata. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,135,1888 2nd edn 1/26 ed.)

MYERS Turnagra tanagra Schlegel. North Island Thrush. This is practically the only species of which absolutely no records are forthcoming. (1923,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,6/91)

281.a. Yurnagra capensis tanagra (Schlegel, 1865) North Island Thrush (Piopio) ... now rare and local, perhaps extinct ... (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,73,1980 ed.)

NATUSCH Family TURNAGRIDAE (thrushes). Any thrushes most of us see today are likely (let's face it) to be imported ones; however, Oliver's description of the native South Island thrush (Turnagra capensis) optimistically puts its distribution (south-west of South Island, west Nelson) in the present tense. The last North Island one definitely recorded was encountered in 1887. (1967,Animals of NZ, The,286)

Next we come to the cases of New Zealand birds, and here the species seem also to be well represented, including the extinct quail, the stitch bird, North Island thrush, kiwi, and many others that are nearly gone. (Apr 4, 1894,Wanganui Herald,2)

2 n.

North Island tit¶

n. = North Island tomtit [the white breasted tit or North Island tit - see each]

Another bird with pert and pretty ways is the North Island or white-breasted tit. (Apr 27, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,38)

North Island tomtit¶

n. (Environment) [also (see each) white breasted tit, North Island tit]

[Caption] North Island tomtit. Tomtit have begun to return to Matuku. Tomtit, a close relative of the New Zealand robin, are rare beteen Whangarei and the southern Waikato. (Nov 2002,Forest & Bird,306/37)

BULLER MYIOMOIRA TOITOI. (PIED TIT {NORTH ISLAND TOMTIT}.) ... Native names. Miromiro, Komiromiro, Pimiromiro, Ngirungiru, Pingirungiru, and Pipitori}. ... [40] Its note in the early morning is like the Maori syllables ngi-i-ru, ngiru-ngiru, from which it derives its name, the first syllable being rather prolonged. (1888,Birds of New Zealand,1/39)

Myiomoira toitoi Lesson. North Island Tomtit. As early as 1886 Reischek (p.101) included this species in a list of birds extinct or extremely rare on the mainland. (1923,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,6/88) [NOTES: Myers Endemic Birds]

The North Island tomtit (Myiomoira toitoi) was seen on every trip we made ... (1923,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,6/88) [NOTES: -->1925-26 NZJST 8/17 (Hamilton Poor Knights)]

North Island tomtits, males particularly, were much in evidence. (Jun 8, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,15)

North Island weka¶

n.

Forest and Bird was delighted to be asked to supply North Island weka for release. This bird is a threatened species... (Nov 2002,Forest & Bird,306/42)

134.a. Gallirallus australis greyi (Buller, 1888) th Island Weka (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,42,1960 ed.)

The North Island weka was scarcer and more valuable than a kiwi, and he thought the Society should give a vote of thanks to Mr. Boulter. (Aug 4, 1868,Daily Southern Cross,4)

In matters of nomenclature the changes which will be most apparent are the substitution of the name Apteryx bulleri (North Island kiwi) for A. mantelli, and of Ocydromus greyi (North Island weka) for O. earli. It appears that the old and well-known names were in both cases applied to South Island birds, and that the North Island forms have hitherto been strictly speaking nondescripts. (Jun 29, 1889,Otago Daily Times,1)

Mr McCormick, one North Island weka (albino). (Jul 27, 1908,Wanganui Herald,7)

The hybridisation in the offspring is shown by the birds having the red legs of the Stewart Island breed and the body markings characteristic of the North Island weka. (Mar 18, 1925,Evening Post,7)

Such species is the blue wattled crow, brown kiwi, and North Island weka are found in the district. (Aug 16, 1930,Evening Post,17)

Eventually one female North island weka, a different species of bird, was found, and the two birds were put on Kapiti Island. (Oct 18, 1941,Evening Post,8)

North island weka were once so common in the Gisborne area they were considered a pest. (Jul 2004,Conservation Action,25)

North Island woodhen¶

n. [weka]

Ocydromus greyi, Buller. (North Island Woodhen.) This species of Woodhen is still numerous on the wooded hill-sides and mountain gullies in the Murimotu-Taupo country. (1895,TrNZI,27/118) [NOTES: Buller]

n.

Ocydromus earli. - Weka, Northern Wood-hen (1886,TrNZI,18/113) [NOTES: (Martin).]

BULLER OCYDROMUS EARLI {GREYI}. (NORTH-ISLAND WOODHEN.) ... Native name.- Weka (1873,Birds of New Zealand,165,1888 2nd edn 2/105 ed.)

BULLER North-Island Woodhen... Native name. - weka. (1873,NZ Birds,165)

North-Island Woodhen... Native name. - weka. Ibid. 106 In my former edition, I treated the North-Island Woodhen.. as the Ocydromus earlii of Mr. G.R. Gray's 'List of 1862'. (1888,NZ Birds,II/105)

2 n. [weka {1888 2nd edn 2/105}]

North Island zebra moth¶

n.

A closely related moth, the North Island Zebra Moth, which is confined to the North Island, has the forewings ornamented with broken black lines, giving the wings a more or less speckled or spotted appearance. (Sep 16, 1972,Press, The,11/8)

North Islander¶

n.

The New Plymouth boatmen are some of them great scamps. ... These North Islanders are a bad lot. (Jul 11, 1877,Chudleigh Diary,259,1950 ed.)

n. a resident of, or person from, the North Island of New Zealand. [ca1955 R. Mason notes that North Islander' is a South Island term (cf MAINLAND (ER)). People in the North Island do not usually look upon themselves as North Islanders, but as, say, Aucklanders or Taranaki-ites, or merely as New Zealanders. In the South Island one is often told:' Oh you're a North Islander are you?' Perhaps this is a reflexion of the parochial orcinderella' spirit of the South Island which sees itself as being overcome in importance by the more populous and industrial North Island. ?a S.I. usage mainly]

Well, who runs the South Island... North Islanders! (Jul 12, 1943,NZEF Times,III/107 : 6)

BROOME The creed of the North Islander will depend on his province...... The political belief of every province is moulded and modified, as is only natural, by its own particular circumstances. (1869,Crisis in NZ,417)

BULLER NOTORNIS MANTELLI. (MANTELL'S NOTORNIS.) ... Native names. Moho, Takahe, and Tokohea. [191] Mr. Walter Mantell states that ... It was known to the North-Islanders by the name of Moho', and to the South-Islanders by that ofTakahe'. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,189, 191,1888 2nd edn 2/85 ed.)

HENDERSON Unscathed in four campaigns, two North Islanders had been invalided home. (1945,Gunner Inglorious,122)

DEMPSEY And we are apt to say, when speaking of a person who is away, that he is `off the Island'. If we are told that someone has gone over to the Other Side ... we understand he has gone to Invercargill or to Bluff. Where the North Islander talks of his beach cottage, or bach, we call these little places cribs, a much more euphonious name. (1964,Little World of Stewart island,6)

And he told me he had one broadside he wanted to deliver while he was still a North Islander.] (Oct 31, 1972,Dominion,1/4)

WHEELER Although living in the back-blocks, (North Islanders say `in the sticks', presumably referring to bush or scrub) station people seem to encounter more than their fair share of incident. (1973,Historic Sheep Stations NI,100)

FRY Song of a North Islander [title] (1979,Brushed Words,1)

SANSOM I'm not a North Islander either. (1982,In the Grip of an Island,146)

North Islander native or inhabitant of the North Island. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,511) [NOTES: nf 1982 Collins Concise Eng.Dict]

ELDRED-GRIGG Friendly, chatty ... Australians, Americans, English, North Islanders. (1987,Oracles and Miracles,208)

North Isle¶

n. (obsolete)

FORSTER This had happened at the North Isle. But in Queen Charlotte's Sound, no such thing had ever been remarked or apprehended. (Jun 24, 1773,Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The,2/307)

North of Auckland¶

n. Northland

WAKEFIELD The far north of New Zealand, `North of Auckland', as it is often familiarly called, even in official documents, ... is semi-tropical, and the people are like unto it. (1889,New Zealand After 50 Years)

North Sea rabbit¶

n. (humorous) a herring [WWI] (See SHANGHAI BALLAST,UNDERGROUND MUTTON)

6 ...the ever popular `North Sea Rabbits' (Nov 22, 1918,NZEF Chronicles,20)

PARTRIDGE [The] following [was] employed by those who served in the [Great] War ... .us;North Sea rabbits , English herrings; (1935,Slang Today,286) [NOTES: Mitchell and Strong in Partridge Slang Today]

PARTRIDGE North Sea Rabbits. Herrings as food: New Zealand soldiers': 1916-18. Ex the abundance of herrings in N. Z. camps in England and of rabbits in N.Z. (1937,Dictionary of Slang,569)

Food gave an idiom or two: shell shock breadand sandbag duff' were not much liked; nor wereNorth sea rabbits' (herrings) ... (Apr 2, 1938,Press, The,18) [NOTES: McNab NZ Slang [Slang of the N.Z.E.F.]]

BAKER [NZ soldiers in England, because herrings were as plentiful there as rabbits in NZ.] (1941,NZ Slang,50)

76 North Sea rabbit herrings to WWI soldiers. (1988,Lake Wakatip Mail)

North Shore¶

n. a city of Auckland [Usu. constr. with the]

With the largest Polynesian population in the world, you can question the logic of taking the game to Auckland's North Shore, where you're more likely to find biltong than taro. (Jul 11, 2004,Sunday Star Times,A1)

The Governor and Mrs Browne have been staying for some time on the North Shore. (Jan 15, 1859,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/446,1960 ed.) [NOTES: C.W. Richmond]

north-west¶

n.

BARKER One morning an arch-like appearance in the clouds over the furthest ranges was pointed out to me as the sure forerunner of a violent gale from the north-west, and the prognostic was fulfilled. (1866,Station Life in NZ,55,1870 ed.)

north-west day¶

n.

THOMSON Or, again, he thinks of a hot north-west [22] day with the sun glinting off the shingle and himself loaded down with a pack of skins and an eight-mile tramp back to camp. (1952,Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker,21)

north-wester¶

n.

Next day a rude north-wester blew thetent down. (Oct 12, 1935,Christchurch Star-Sun,2)

ELDRED-GRIGG I failed to think far enough ahead to the drought and norwesters of this solstice. (1995,Mum,269)

BARKER How many of us would be in that valley ona Christmas Day in the far future, when these trees would have struggled up against their enemy the Nor'-wester. (1871,Christmas Cake in Four Quarters,267)

L.C.ACLAND The ordinary man in the paddock in Canterbury recognises only three winds: east (from N.E.), sou'-wester (from S.E., S., etc., S.W., etc.), and nor'-wester. (Dec 2, 1933,Press, The,15/7)

MCLINTOCK In summer the hot, dry 'Canterbury Nor'wester' is generally a most unpleasant wind. (1959,Descriptive Atlas,22)

TURNER The Canterbury nor' wester resembling the European Fohn wind..and the three-day sou'wester in New Zealand. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,163)

Heavy North-wester, smothered with sand - thick country. Ibid. 152 North Wester among the mountains. (Jan 9, 1849,Torlesse Papers,47,1958 ed.)

SEWELL The hot Northwesters melt the Mountain snows, sending down freshes. A fresh was just beginning in the Rangitata as we got to it. (1856,Journal,2/221,1980 ed.)

Usually a north-wester commences about 10 o'clock in the morning, and if it does not rain by 3 p.m., is driven back about 5 p.m. by the south wind. (1875,TrNZI,7/106) [NOTES: McKAY]

[title] THE CANTERBURY `NORTHWESTER'. (1933,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,14/65)

They were friendly hills except perhaps when about sundown the norwester, gathering strength, would reach gale force. (Sep 2000,North & South,138)

Some will say that the magnificent scenery would be spoilt in heavy nor-westers, but that happens now when travelling by bus or car on the roaded sections. (Dec 2, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),8)

Lines of stooks spring up as if by magic, and look the perfection of neatness until the howling nor'-wester comes along and blows them over. (Jan 30, 1890,Otago Witness,9)

... their elliptical shape is ideal for coping with the screaming Canterbury norwesters that can wreak havoc with conventional buildings. (Jul 29, 1989,Listener (New Zealand Listener),32)

As a rule Otagan soil is not sufficiently light and friable to be borne away upon the wings of a nor'-wester. (Nov 27, 1890,Otago Witness,7)

The Home is unfortunately exposed to the full force of those terrible nor'-westers which blow across the plains. (Dec 18, 1890,Otago Daily Times,31)

The farmers were "scared" of north-westgales, familiarly called "nor'-westers". (Feb 13, 1918,Otago Witness,22)

LANCASTER You can't do anything but get out of the way of a nor'-wester when it's on the ramp. (1904,Sons o' Men,155)

BARKER Before a "nor'-wester" the colours over these mountains and in the sky are quite indescribable. (1883,Station Life in NZ,186) [NOTES: Pagination from 1980 edition]

WOODHOUSE Then the scorching hot Nor'-wester / Makes the meat begin to fester. (1967,Farm & Station Verse,24) [NOTES: Original from Williams 1891]

The Christchurch Nor'-wester lashes the newcomer. (Oct 15, 1923,Aussie (NZ Section),IV)

HENDERSON It is the nor'-wester driving in, warm and moist from the sea. (1967,Return to Open Country,17)

NEWTON A raging nor'-wester has blown the roof off a year or two before. (1966,Boss's Story, The,170)

northern¶

adj. as a distinguishing epithet in names of plants and animals see LANCEWOOD, HEATH, RATA

adj. as a distinguishing epithet in names of fish see CONGER; DOGFISH SPINY; KINGFISH; TUNA, BLUEFIN; YELLOWTAIL , NORTHERN BLUEFIN TUNA

adj. as an epithet in the names of fish see: BLUEFIN TUNA, CONGER, DOGFISH, KELPFISH, KNGFISH, MULLET, TUNA, TUNNY [seldom EASTER/WESTERN divisions in NZ] NORTHERN DOGFISH, KELPFISH, KINGFISH -->see DOGFISH, KELPFISH, KINGFISH,NORTHERN

northern blue penguin¶

n. (Environment)

10.a. Eudyptula minor iredalei Mathews, 1911 Northern Blue Penguin [northern North Island] (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,16,1980 ed.)

Blue Penguin Eudyptula minor (FORSTER, 1781) ENDEMIC Northern Blue Penguin E.m. iredalei MATHEWS, 1911. Cook Strait Blue Penguin E.m. variabilis KINSKY & FALLA, 1976. White-flippered Penguin E.m. albosignata FINSCH, 1874. Southern Blue Penguin E.m. minor (FORSTER, 1781). Chatham Island Blue Penguin E.m. chathamensis KINSKY & FALLA, 1976. OTHER NAMES: Little blue penguin, little penguin, fairy penguin, korara. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,46)

northern bluefin tuna¶

n. Thunnus thunnus

Catching southerns and northerns is lucrative but rare and New Zealanbd's 100-plus tuna boats often return to port without landing a big-paying fish... Midway through a six-day trip.. his crew.. are putting in 18-hour days of back breaking work in the southern or, even better, northern blue-fin tuna. (May 15, 2004,Dominion Post,C1)

We get several species of tuna in New Zealand, including yellowfin and northern bluefin, but I used the quite dark-fleshed southern bluefin variety. (Oct 17, 2004,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),43)

northern bluefin tuna .. [scientific name] Thunnus thunnus .. [other name(s)] -- (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] bluefin tuna, northern 2065 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

northern Buller's albatross¶

n. (Environment)

Northern Buller albatross Thalassarche bulleri platei A medium-sized 3 kg species which breeds only in New Zealand at the Chathams. Nests - similar to those of several other species - resemble a shallow cup scooped out in the top of a pedestal. (2007,NZ Geographic Poster,No 84 Mar-Apr)

northern diving petrel¶

n.

FALLA et al. NORTHERN DIVING PETREL Pelecanoides urinatrix Local name: Dipchick. (1966,Birds of New Zealand,57)

n.

DOOGUE & MORELAND NORTHERN DOGFISH ... Other names: Squalus blainvillii; Griffin's dogfish, common spined dogfish, brown dogfish; pioke, okeoke (Maori). (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,186)

AYLING GREY SPINY DOGFISH (Northern dogfish) Squalus blainvillei ... In New Zealand they ... are generally more abundant in the north ... (1982,Collins Guide,65,1984 ed.)

Northern Island¶

n. an occasional early name for the NORTH ISLAND (See cf. Southern Island)

Have they [missionaries] any station in the southern island? - Not in the southern island. When I said to the south, I meant to the south of the northern island. (Jul 20, 1840,Minutes of Evidence,815) [NOTES: 1840 July 20 Minutes of Evidence taken before the Select Committee on NZ (from Report from the Select Committee (of the House of Commons) on New Zealand 11 August 1840) 91 [Rev John Beecham] 815.]

n.

FEATON MYOSURUA ARISTATUS (Benth.) The Bearded Mousetail. ... This minute plant is a native of the Northern Island; ... (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,5)

[fn 3] NORTHERN ISLAND (1955,Cook's Journals,1/248) [NOTES: 1955 Beaglehole Cook's Journals 1/248 fn 3]

ADAMS [The hilly region] stretched far away ... to the distant mountains of the Northern Island. (1853,Spring in the Canterbury Settlement, A,16)

(1770,Banks Journal,51 [passim]) [NOTES: (Grey MS)]

... there were seven large Cannoes of these New-comers, and.. They came from somewhere towards, if not actually from the Northern Isalnd [check Wales's position: Ship Cove?] (1773,Cook's Journals,2/790,1961 ed.) [NOTES: 1773 Wales Journal in Cook's Journals (1961) 2/790]

LEDYARD [Queen Charlotte Sound] The food of the New-Zealanders is chiefly fish, some of which they dry and some they eat raw: They also have some yams upon the northern Island, but not in plenty; ... (Feb 1777,Journal,14,1963 ed.) [NOTES: 1777 Feb in 1783 Ledyard Journal (1963) 14]

FORSTER ...they have nothing in which to keep liquids except a minute kind of calabash or gourd, which grows only in the northern island, and was extremely scarce among the people of Queen Charlotte's Sound. Ibid. 1/230 [Teiratu] seemed to know [potatoes] very well, evidently because a similar root, the Virginian or sweet potatoe (convolvulus batatas,) is planted in some parts of the Northern Island, from whence he came. (1777,Voyage Round the World,1/220)

McNAB A proposal was some time since made to me ... of forming a settlement at their own expence on the northern island of New Zealand, for the purpose of collecting the flax plant of that country, and manufacturing it .. (1908,Historical Records,1/297 5.) [NOTES: 1810 Mar 12 (Sydney) Governor M acquarie to Viscount Castlereagh in 1908 McNab Historical Records 1/297 5.]

McNAB ... there is every prospect of a rapid increase of trade ... under the ... protection of the British Government, which could not be given so effectually from any station as from the Northen Island of New Zealand. (1908,Historical Records,1/664) [NOTES: 1826 Apr 24 Memorial to Earl of Bathurst in 1908 McNab Hist Records 1/664]

MARKHAM New Zealand or the Northern Island, as there are three, is known to the Natives by the name of Eaheinomawe. (1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles),29,1963 ed.)

RUTHERFORD And we do hereby declare, that from henceforth the said Islands shall be known and designated as the Colony of New Zealand, and the principal Islands, here to fore known as, or commonly called, the Northern Island,' theMiddle Island,' and Stewart's Island,' shall henceforward be designated and known respectively asNew Ulster,' New Munster,' andNew Leinster.' ... (1971,Speeches & Documents,54) [NOTES: 1840 Letters Patent issued on 16 November: quoted from The Ordinances of New Zealand, Domett 1850 pp.4-8 in 1971 Speeches and Documents 54]

And we do hereby declare, that from henceforth the said islands shall be known and designated as the colony of New Zealand, and the principal islands, heretofore known as or commonly called the Northern Island', theMiddle Island', and Stewart's Island', shall henceforth bedesignated and known respectively asNew Ulster', New Munster', andNew Leinster'. (Nov 16, 1840,Charter for Erecting the Colony of NZ,8) [NOTES: 1840 Nov 16 Charter for Erecting the Colony of NZ in 1949 Rutherford ed. Select Documents 8]

DIEFFENBACH We now saw more of the middle island, which seemed to consist of a chain of steep snow-capped hills, running through the middle of the island, and rising in a succession of ridges from the sea-shore. On the northern island we saw the mountains of Tararua in the neighbourhood of Port Nicholson; these also were covered with snow. [187] ... I have reason to believe that the Middle Island has a configuration similar to the Northern; ... (1843,Travels in NZ,1/22, 187)

ANGAS Early in the spring of 1844, I set out on a journey ... to explore [2] various portions of the interior of the Northern Island; ... (1847,Savage Life,2/1-2)

EARP The Middle Island is separated from the Northern Island by Cook's Strait, and from Stewart's Island by Foveaux's Strait. Ibid. 95 [l.c. init.] The Wellington settlers ... were ardent followers of the whale fishery, carried on chiefly on the coasts of the northern and middle island by means of boats - a method technically called `bay-whaling', ... (1853,New Zealand (various authors/titles),34)

SEWELL ... they have never succeeded in attaching to their cause, more than limited support, confined mainly to the central parts of the Northern Island. (1864,NZ Native Rebellion,4)

ANGAS The natives in the Middle Island had always been inferior in numbers ... to the Northern Islanders, who from time to time made cruel and butcherly raids upon them. (1866,Polynesia,166)

TAYLOR The New Zealand group chiefly consists of the Northern, Middle, and Stewart's Islands; ... (1868,Past and Present of NZ,192)

A patuaruhe, or fernroot beater, made of maire (Santalum cunninghamii), another strictly Northern Island tree. (1875,TrNZI,7/61) [NOTES: Haast]

northern kelpfish¶

n.

PARROTT Kelpfish Odax vittatus, Butterfish; Greenbone; Northern Kelpfish (1957,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,169)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] kelpfish, northern 1757 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

northern kingfish¶

n. = yellowtail kingfish

MORELAND YELLOWTAIL or NORTHERN KINGFISH [Seriola grandis] ... The Maori name haku is still in use. (1967,Marine Fishes,50)

DOOGUE & MORELAND YELLOWTAIL or NORTHERN KINGFISH ... Other names: Seriola grandis; yellowtail (Australia); haku (Maori). The general adoption of the term yellowtail for this species would be more appropriate than the sometimes confusing term of kingfish. (1966,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,234)

SORENSON KINGFISH, NORTHERN (a) Scientific name: Seriola grandis. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Kingfish; Yellowtail. (c) Other common names: None known. (d) Principal localities where taken: Auckland, Tauranga, Gisborne, Napier. ...Under the general heading of Kingfish ... is generally lumped with the Silver or Southern Kingfish. Rexea solandri to which it is not related. This fish is a well known gamefish of northen waters. (1970,Nomenclature of NZ Fish,31)

[species name] kingfish .. [scientific name] Seriola lalandi .. [other name(s)] yellowtail, yellowtail kingfish, northern kingfish, northern yellowtail, kingi (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] kingfish, northern 1365-76 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

northern kiwi¶

2 n. (Environment) Apteryx mantelli. -Northern Kiwi.

Apteryx mantelli. -Northern Kiwi. (1886,TrNZI,18/113) [NOTES: (Martin)]

northern lancewood¶

COCKAYNE lancewood, northern lancewood, Pseudopanax Lessonii. (1924,Cultivation of NZ Plants, The)

northern maire¶

n.

Of our shrubs and smaller timber trees, several are of strikingly beautiful growth ... (e.g.) the Houhere, Hoheria populnea ...; the Northern Maire, Santalum Cunninghamii; ... and the truly evergreen Ngaio, Myoporum laetum ... (1869,TrNZI,1/III/5) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

northern oystercatcher¶

n. (Environment) (See mud pigeon)

FALLA et al. NORTHERN (VARIABLE) OYSTERCATCHER Haemotopus reischeki Local name: Mud Pigeon. (1966,Birds of New Zealand,119)

northern rata¶

n. Meterosideros robusta [aka North Island rata. 1875 RDT 1919 CNZ (Andersen, 7 entries)]

The northern rata, Metro sideros robusta, is really a parasite in the way I have mentioned, and in any forests at this end specimens can be seen killing the trees upon which they grow. (Feb 15, 1894,Otago Witness,5)

Northern rata can also establish on the ground, especially where forest has been destroyed by fire. (Mar 13, 2004,Dominion Post,E10)

Northern rata (Metrosideros robusta) does grow naturally in Wellington (in the South Island from Hokitika northwards). Both are known as the New Zealand Christmas tree... Pohutukawa doesn't grown naturally here; it is a weed in parts of the region; it occupies sites where the northern rata should be; being closely related to the northern rata, pohutukawa has the potential to hybridise; pohutukawa inhibits the growth of other plants; northern rata's bloom is superior to pohutukawa's. (Feb 19, 2004,Wellington Contact,31)

Rata, northern .. Metrosideros robusta .. Timber dense, heavy, and tough; used principally for wheelwrights' work and firewood (1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,13)

The kahikatea stands next in abundance, and is closely approached by the kamai, while the miro, matai, totara, Hall's totara, are generally distributed; but the northern rata and pukatea scarcely occur south of Greymouth. Ibid. 335 18. The northern rata ( Metrosideros robusta), A. Cunningham 19. The southern rata ( Metrosideros lucida ), Menzies... 22. Manuka rauriki ( Leptospermum ericoide s), A. Richard. (1894,NZ Official Yearbook,330) [NOTES: (T. Kirk)]

Amongst the most conspicuous trees of this area there are two worthy of special mention, the northern rata and the black-maire. (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,118)

COCKAYNE The northern rata ( Metrosideros robusta ) ... frequently behave in this most ungrateful manner. (1910,NZ Plants,37)

KIRK The Northern rata [sic] Metrosideros robusta), when growing in moist places, produces timber of inferior quality ... (1875,Durability NZ Timbers,3)

KIRK (And) Metrosideros robusta northern rata (1889,Forest Flora)

MATTHEWS (And) Metrosideros robusta northern rata (1905,Tree Culture in NZ)

COCKAYNE And) Metrosideros robusta northern rata (1908,AJHR,C-14) [NOTES: Report on a Botanical Survey of Waipoua Kauri Forest]

COCKAYNE (And) Metrosideros robusta northern rata (1910,NZ Plants & Their Story) [NOTES: Also 1919 edition]

NAIRN & SON (And) Metrosideros robusta northern rata (1912,Catalogue (Nairn & Son))

(And) Metrosideros lucida northern rata (1917,Duncan & Davies' Catalogue)

The chief indigenous trees of commercial value are: Kauri ( Agathis Australis ), Kahikatea or white pine ( Podocarpus dacrydioides ), rimu or red pine ( Dacrydium cupressinum ), totara ( Podocarpus totara and Podocarpus Hallii ), Miro ( Podocarpus ferrugineus ), Kaikawaka or mountain cedar (Libocedrus Bidwilli), yellow pine or silver pine ( Dacrydium Colensoi and D. intermedium ), red and hard beech ( Nothofagus fasca and Nothofagus truncata ), silver beech ( Nothofagus Menziesii ), black beech ( Nothofagus Solandri ), black maire ( Olea Cunninghamii ), northern and southern rata ( Metrosideros robusta and Metrosideros lucida ). (1936,Agricultural Organization in NZ,578)

LAING & BLACKWELL Northern Rata (M. robusta ). This is the North Island rata, but it is also found on the west coast of the South Island as far south at least as Karamea. (1940,Plants of NZ,297)

McLINTOCK Rata, northern .. .. rata .. .. Metrosideros robusta (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

Northern Rata, Metrosideros robusta. ... The tree is large and sturdy and grows in lowland and subalpine forests from Three Kings to Nelson. (1971,New Zealand's Heritage,1/267)

Metrosideros robusta,/ the northern rata. Usually / commencing life as an epiphyte/ becomes a tall, massive tree / 60 to 100 feet high. (1972,Islands,1/5) [NOTES: Curnow `Names are News']

DAWSON Northern rata (Metrosideros robusta ) is the most notable and common example [of strangling epiphytes] here. (1988,Forest Vines to Snow Tussocks,83)

Like the northern rata, M. robusta, Bartlett's rata usually starts life as an epiphyte perched in the branches of another tree or ponga. (Jul 2000,NZ Geographic,47/12)

DENNIS Tall northern rata (Metrosideros robusta) ... and kahikatea ... are scattered emergents ... (1981,Paparoas Guide,157)

Easier to spot, especially when they're laden with scarlet flowers, are the tall northern rata. (Jan 5, 2004,Dominion Post,C3)

The biggest northern rata in the region can be found along the Butterfly Creek and Mount Hawtrey trail in Eastbourne, while one that began its life as an epiphyte can be seen entwined with a 400-year-old rimu in the Otari-Wilton's Bush trail. (May 2003,Footnotes,No. 19/6)

northern rock oyster¶

n.

The Northern rock oyster was found only north of the East Cape; the Southern oyster was not found further north than Banks' Peninsula, and the mud oyster was found all over the colony. (Feb 26, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,29)

northern royal albatross¶

n. (Environment)

19.a. Diomedia epomophora sanfordi (Murphy, 1917) Northern Royal Albatross ... 19.b. Diomedia epomophora epomophora (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,60)

Most interesting are the varieties of albatross - Gibson's, Northern royals and Southern royals. (Nov 2003,AA Directions,No. 58/46)

Northern royal albatross Diomedea sanfordi Slightly smaller than the Southern royal, this species breeds on the Chathams and at Taiaroa Head, Otago--the only "mainland" breeding colony of albatrosses in the Southern Hemisphere. (2007,NZ Geographic Poster,No 84 Mar-Apr)

northern spiny dogfish¶

n. (See dogfish)

Conservation Department marine ecologist Clinton Duffy said it was believed that at least five species of dogfish were being described as northern spiny dogfish. (Jul 14, 2005,Dominion Post,A9)

northern tuna¶
