PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] tuna or tunny, northern 2065 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

Northerner¶

2 n. an express on the northern Main Trunk line [nf 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict]

northerner ... (Northerner) NZ an express train running overnight between Wellington and Auckland. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,511)

MILES Even the 1970s Friday Sunday Christchurch-Dunedin Express and the Blenheim Cabbage Train with the faded glories of its 1930's armchairs and cream interior were far nearer the great age of rail than the Northerner or Southerner of today. (1998,Fay Richwhite's Railway,4)

Friday night saw the Northerner train's last journey on the main trunk line.... But for the 125 passengers who travelled on Friday night's final Northerner out of the capital, the last trip was the only topic of conversation. (Nov 15, 2004,Dominion Post,A5)

The whistle has been blown on a Kiwi tradition - the night trains that have carried passengers between Wellington and Auckland for almost a century are going. The Northerner service is being cut for economic reasons, Tranz Scenic says. Its final run will pull out of Wellington and Auckland railway stations on Friday, November 12. (Oct 30, 2004,Dominion Post,A1)

northerner¶

n. someone from the north of New Zealand

FARRELL I've become a real northerner, I feel thecold. (1992,Skinny Louie Book,93)

Northland¶

n. the North Auckland peninsula, often, by non-residents, North Auckland. The usage has become more frequent outside the region since WW2.

RUSSELL This country, now [?date] officially called `Northland'. (1919,New Zealand Today,27)

REED I board the service car at Northland's capital; ... (1946,Farthest North,13)

`The province in the North called Northland; they don't like to be called North Auckland. (Oct 5, 1950,2ZB) [NOTES: Anne Stewart's Session. S. Toogood:]

GOLDBLATT ... we reach the capital of Northland, the busy, growing town of Whangarei. (1957,Democracy at Ease,11)

McLINTOCK The region is usually referred to as North Auckland, but the use of the shortened Northland is gaining wider currency. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,2/693)

THOMAS [Kauri] grows naturally within the restricted area of the northern part of the Auckland Province and almost wholly in Northland. (1970,Way Up North,29)

CLEARY Every plant ... in Northland ... is crying / out for rain. (1975,Pocketful of Years,1-2)

MARSHALL When I was seven, my father was appointed the first District Public Trustee for North Auckland, ... Northland, as the area north of Auckland is now called, was in those days an isolated community. (1983,Memoirs,24)

Banded Rail Rallus philippensis GRAY, 1843 ... OTHER NAME: Moho-pereru. ... Mainly in northen mangrove swamps from Northland to Bay of Plenty. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,165)

2 n. a suburb of Wellington

Sir, -I see that the Viceregal party has had good fishing in northern Southland streams. This brings up the subject of Northland in the north. Often your writers refer to Northland, the suburb, in a headline, and I have to read the text to see if they are referring to Northland up north or Northland down south here in Wellington.Couldn't we plan a key to this by referring to North Northland or Northland North (as in Palmerston North? I feel there must be some easy way out. - I am., etc. (Feb 27, 1953,Evening Post,8)

3 adj.

First it was a caterer ..., then a Northland kiwifruit farmer and last week a Wellington tailoring company. (May 26, 1986,Manawatu Evening Standard,1)

Yet two Northland cockies got the shock of their rural lives when they walked into Auckland International Airport and saw what tourists were being charged for the meat New Zealand farmers produced. (Jan 13, 1989,Dominion,3)

Northland green gecko¶

n. restricted to upper Northland, a large, pugnacious and brightly coloured gecko. [Naultinus grayii aka Gray's gecko]

Ornate skink (Gradual Decline), North Cape Pacific gecko (Gradual Decline), Matapia gecko (Gradual Decline), North Cape green gecko (Sparse), Cyclodina levidensa (regionally significant), shore skink, and common gecko. (1997,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.conservation.govt.nz/upload/documents/conservation/land-and-freshwater/land/te-paki-ecological-district/te-paki-shrublands-n02-003.pdf]

The Northland green gecko (Naultinus grayii) is bright green on top with gold or grey markings and a paler underbelly. It is most commonly seen on Manuka and Kanuka trees. (2006,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.puketi.org.nz/kids/riverwalk.html]

Widlife experts feared the two Northland Green Geckos and one Rough Gecko were destined for the international black market. (Apr 12, 2006,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz-customs-service/news/article.cfm?o_id=360&objectid=10377174]

Ormandy, 20, an installation installer, and Stirton, 30, a dancer, had been jointly charged after the geckos -- two Northland green geckos and a rough gecko -- were found at their home in the Christchurch suburb of Richmond three weeks ago. (May 3, 2006,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.nzherald.co.nz/richmond-limited/news/article.cfm?o_id=176&objectid=10380100]

Northland salute¶

n. putting your open hand with palm to the car windscreen to prevent flying stones shattering the glass

Northland special¶

n. a pit-bull type dog bred for dog-fighting

Indiscriminate breeding of pit bull types is over the top and scary, says Boyd. The dogs are known as "Northland specials". (Feb 2, 2003,Sunday Star Times,c1)

Northlander¶

n. a person born or resident in Northland 1.

REED As an old Northlander, I could trace its evolution. (1961,North Cape to Bluff,81)

Nick Messenger. Northlander by upbringing, B.A. in Philosophy....a West Coaster by adoption. (1983,Landfall,147: 384)

Northlander Rear [born Whangarei] has won the last four New Zealand cross-country titles ... (Apr 4, 1988,Dominion,18)

Norm of the North: Irrepressible Northlander Norm Bryan milks cows and tourists in the town ofHouhora. (Dec 10, 1988,Listener (New Zealand Listener),110)

RENNIE His only experience of wine was the rough, home-made red Northlanders called `Dally plonk'. (1988,Super Man,167)

Northlanders have always known Auckland is full of sharp operators ready to fleece you quicker than two shakes of a lamb's tail. (Jan 13, 1989,Dominion,3)

Norwegian cinquefoil¶

n.

Norwegian cinquefoil [s] Potentilla norvegica L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,54)

nos¶

n. nitrous oxide

The drug in question is N2O, aka nitrous oxide, laughing gas or nos, a commonly used fuel additive that has also been an industry-standardmedical anaesthetic for over a century... [27] The police intervened and discovered a cylinder of nos on the passenger's seat that was discharging its contents into the chased car. (Feb 1, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),26)

A walk through Christchurch on a friday night shows that the trade in nos is still alive and laughing. (Jun 11, 2005,Listener (New Zealand Listener),32)

What does the law say about NOS?Nitrous Oxide is classified as a prescription medicine under the Medicines Act 1981 and therefore this means that the sale of NOS without prescription is illegal.Want more information?For more comprehensive information about NOS contact FADE to order our new NOS: What you need to know pamphlet. (2006,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.fade.org.nz/alcohol-and-drug-info/nos/Accessed 26/03/06.]

n. (informal) short for nitrous oxide

The mockery that this unfortunate incident brought upon poor Tim was cruel and far-reaching, and caused him far more harm [sic] his nos habit ever did. (May 2005,Lucid,14)

Anderton's "no ifs, no buts" comments came after suggestions that retailers could once again evade the Medicines Act by selling their nos as "catering-grade nos" instead of "get-high-on-this-shit-grade nos". (2005,Internet - see Notes,0) [NOTES: http://www.salient.org.nz/index.php?a=1264&c=55*Accessed on 26/03/06.]

nos bar¶

n. (See nos)

Anderton has declared war on the people he calls "parasites" who run the nos bars. (2006,NZ Herald) [NOTES: http://tvnz.co.nz/view/news_health_story_skin/537940?format+html*Accessed 26/03/06]

Nos barA nos bar is a phenomomen seen especially in Christchurch in the beginning of the 21st century up til halfway thru 2005. They are bars that allow you to purchase nitrous oxide in balloons, and sit on a couch, or around a table outside, and inhale the gas to get high. Similar to places like Cosmic Corner in what they sell, the sit down environment provides a safe place to use a safe drug. Better than doing it on the street. (2006,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.girlza.com/wiki/Nos_bar*Accessed 26/03/06.]

nos-head¶

n. (informal) [-] (See nos)

A nos-head like Tim will shell out around fifty bucks for a cracker, insert a canister of nitrous oxide, release that gas into party balloon, and inhale it from there. (May 2005,Lucid,14)

nose¶

v. to hongi [also bump/join/press/rub/touch noses also nose with below] (See also bump/join/press/rub/touch noses)

FORSTER Then Capt Cook ... shook hands with him, & lastly went up to him & nosed him, which is the mark of friendship among these people. (Apr 7, 1773,Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The,2/248)

NICHOLAS Korra-korra recognized among the women a relation, with whom he nosed very affectionately, and they wept over each other in the usual manner. Ibid. 2/77 Tupee, who upon Korra-korra's coming on deck, nosed with him (as our sailors expressed it) in the most affectionate manner, ... (1817,New Zealand (various authors/titles),2/22)

v.

RENNIE Cattle dogs will also `nose' cattle by running beside the animal and biting at its nose while it charges. (1985,Working Dogs,39)

nose bag¶

n. (Rural, informal) a paddock lunch or smoko.

PETER Nose bag: Your lunch or smoko. (2000,Peter Glossary,6)

nose bleeder¶

n. [(basketballers')]

As basketball in this country is growing so is the terminology to describe the sport. ... The guys that really jump, really get high, are called lightbulb changers, nose bleeders and sky walkers, and the best of them can turn the 360 (full circle) or take the alley-oop pass (ball thrown high up by the basket). They can also throw the rock (ball) down or stuff the pill (ball). (Mar 18, 1984,NZ Times,18)

nose plant¶

n. going over handlebars and landing on one's face

They've done all that without suffering much more than a broken bone or two and frequent "nose plants" (that's MTB talk for going over the handlebars). (Feb 1997,North & South,96)

nose trouble¶

n. over-inquisitiveness.

NEWBOLD NOSE TROUBLE (n) Over-inquisitiveness. (1982,Big Huey, The,251)

nose wiper¶

n. a heavy Antarctic mitten

BILLING & MANNERING A cigarette tastes harsh and dry n the cold and can only be half-smoked otherwise the butt would burn the clumsy, heavy mittens that are called "nose wipers" because they have a woolly back to brush away the ice of frozen breath. (1964,South : Man and Nature in Antarctica,70)

nose-greeting¶

n. hongi [-->1905 Baucke White Man Treads 278 Our college graduate arrives; the home-coming tangi and nose-greeting is over; ... `Whenever I'm out here in the wop-wops with youse jokers, the hori comes out in me. Kapai and hongi..' [check that these two parts belong together]]

nose-rubbing¶

n. hongi (cf. rub noses)

DIEFFENBACH Observing his embarrassment, we withdrew to some distance, leaving him to indulge his natural feeling in hongi and tangi, or nose-rubbing and crying. (1843,Travels in NZ,1/61)

CAMPBELL The principal chiefs then retired a little to the back, and squatted down, according to their manner and custom, to receive the visitors, who are expected to walk up to where the chiefs are sitting and commence nose-rubbing. (1881,Poenamo,Bk3/2/140)

WHITE One does not now see much nose-rubbing for `How do you do?' - at least, in the towns - but a very mechanical shake of the hands instead. (1905,My NZ Garden,107)

... the ardent pakeha finds no satisfaction in nose-rubbing. (Mar 17, 1906,NZ Truth,39/4/4)

nose-throw¶

v. to vomit through the nose [Crisp's two sources in 1989 said it was the going expression then. Upchuck, still common in NZ for vomit (vb.) is listed in OED Supp - not NZ origin.]

nose-warmer¶

n. a very short (clay) pipe [?or merely descriptive]

STUDHOLME The ends of the stems were for ever breaking off, and the [clay] pipes soon became `nose warmers' [in the 1890s]. -- (1940,Te Waimate,67)

noser¶

1 n. (Rural) a cattle dog that works cattle from the head or nose [ as opposed to a heeler.]

SINCLAIR Country hotels often keep a night pen for wet day shearers, so do they keep some wild sorts of sheep for wide running dogs, a sticky mob of woollies for the heavy huntaways and bellowing cattle for the nosers and heelers. (1973,Boot in the Stirrup,61)

nosey¶

2 n. a look

[A Central Otago farmer, ? Mr Mee, speaking of one of the advantages of holding discussion groups on other people's farms] They're also an excuse to have a nosey round other people's farms. (Jun 21, 1986,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: Landline Farm Programme]

The day after the first shoot, we did get to have a nosey at part of the finished product. (Aug 13, 1990,Listener (New Zealand Listener),36)

nosy¶

1 n. (informal) a nosy parker; a prying person. [cf. Jack Nohi]

MARSH He may be a bit of a nosy but he doesn't look like a murderer. (1937,Vintage Murder,155)

2 n. (informal) an inquisitive look around. [also as nosey]

Owen Marshall I wouldn't mind getting out of the office and up there myself for a nosey in the fresh air. (2009,Living As A Moon,22)

not call the King one's uncle¶

phr.

McGILL wouldn't call the king me uncle elation, high spirits, triumph; eg `You see Hadlee equalling the world record? Incredible, eh? Gorh, wouldn't call the king me uncle.' [Jim Henderson] (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,125)

not call the Queen one's aunt¶

phr.

BELL If I had a couple of hundred acres of good bush land, and a wife like that girl down there would make, I wouldn't call the Queen my aunt; and, by Jove! I mean to have a buck at some of those sections in the Whakatangi Block that'll be thrown open shortly, ... (1899,In the Shadow of the Bush,84)

not come within a bull's roar¶

phr. come nowhere near, not to come within cooee of.

1967 May 8 J.SL. Cleveland They create an atmosphere that the happiness boys cannot come within a bull's roar of equating. (May 8, 1967,Personal Communication) [NOTES: 1967 May 8 J.S. Lynch in memo to NZBC Wellington Programme Advisory Committee (communicated by L. Cleveland)]

Chatfield was not within a bull's roar of that [ball]. (Mar 3, 1987,TV1) [NOTES: Cricket Test Commentary NZ and West Indies]

McGILL bull's roar, you wouldn't come within you are not even close; eg `I'd flag away the sprints if I was you, Norty. You're not within a bull's roar of qualifying, let alone winning.' NZA. (1989,Dinkum Kiwi Dictionary, The,17)

not give a butcher's¶

phr. not care a toss [(?confusion with tinker's curse: or butcher's damn).]

SANDYS So long as the meals are on time I don't give a butcher's what the place looks like.' (1982,Love and War,19)

not give a cooee¶

phr. not to give a hoot, a damn (See cooee)

Personally, I do not give a cooey if the Wellington Club stays up or is knocked down. What worries me is that the narrow Terrace neck by Woodward Street is once again to become a quagmire for several years. (Mar 14, 1986,Contact (Wgtn),2)

not give a flying fuck¶

phr. to not give a damn etc.

MARRINER ... that she could do 'whatever she fucking well liked' with 'whomever she fucking well liked', and that the number of flying fucks he gave was significantly fewer than one. (2001,Stonedogs,203)

not give a stuff¶

phr. (informal) not care the slightest bit

Faith Oxenbridge She had to go to her Leavers Ball on her own - which she said she didn't give a stuff about - because no boy wanted to take her. (2007,Six Pack 2, The,26-27)

not go much on¶

phr.

McGILL go much on like or care for, usually in negative phr. not go much on'; egI don't go much on the new Deputy Head. Do you?' Probably NZA first. Recorded Jean Devanny in Lenore Divine, 1926. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,51)

PARTRIDGE go much on, not. Not to care much for; to dislike: New Zealand coll.: C. 20. (Jean Devanney Lenore Divine, 1926.) P8: at go much on adds ... perhaps orig. Aus. and NZ coll but soon also British. (?a variant of OED 61e US coll. in negative contexts, to care for (1882)) (1961,Dictionary of Slang,1111)

not have a dog's show¶

phr. have no chance, no show [ca1945 Students, Victoria College (c1951)]

CROSS I had to admire Bloody Jack for sitting on there even though he didn't have a dog's show of getting any fish. (1957,God Boy, The,vi. 46,1958 ed.)

not have a foggy¶

phr. (informal) not have a clue [ORIGIN: abbreviation, a foggy: abbreviated form of 'the foggiest idea']

He eventually cottoned on that he was a target although he didn't have a foggy about where the aerial assault was coming from. (Dec 7, 2006,Time Out,4)

not have a ghost of a show¶

phr. to have no chance

At first it was thought that Mr. Fraser had not a "ghost of a show". (Dec 4, 1890,Otago Witness,18)

Not Just Gumboots and Scones.co.nz¶

1 n. (Rural) a rural website administered by rural women.

Kate Wilson, a Middlemarch farmer and one of the women behind rural website Not Just Gumboots and Scones, says the Internet is a serious tool for women involved in rural businesses. Not Just Gumboots and Scones was one of New Zealand's first rural information portals, built well before the launch of large commercial sites like www.fencepost.com. Ms Wilson, who farms sheep and hazelnuts with her husband, says Not Just Gumboots and Scones is being rethought to make it even more relevant and easy to use. (Dec 2002,E-farming,04)

The 'sterotypical perception of a rural woman' is what prompted a group of country ladies to set up an organisation in the late 1990s called Not Just Gumboots & Scones. Their website (www.notjust.org.nz) allows rural women to learn about and share views on all sorts of issues, but, in fine country style, it was launched in a woolshed with gumboots and scones much in evidence. (May 2007,NZ Geographic,69)

not know from a bar of soap¶

phr. not to know (someone, something) from a bar of soap: not to recognise, to know nothing of.

"I didn't know him from a bar of soap when he turned up... (Oct 13, 2002,Sunday Star Times,B2)

Didn't know the game [of golf] from a bar of soap, and now that I know something about it, would certainly give the cake to the soap. (Oct 24, 1903,NZ Bulletin,15)

This paper does not know Langlands from a bar of soap. (Aug 4, 1906,NZ Truth,59/4/5)

The second day after his arrival on the job, the workers made a presentation to their cook, a man called Frank Faulkner, whom Savage as he later recollected, didn't know `from a bar of soap'. [note 7] (Jun 16, 1938,Standard, The) [NOTES: 1938 June 16 Standard M.J.Savage in 1986 Gustafson Cradle to Grave 71-72]

SLATTER And even if they didn't know me from a bar of soap they do know I was in the Battalion. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,146)

not know if one's arse is on fire¶

phr. to be very ignorant or innocent.

DAVIN Oh, a lot of profanity about ... colonels who were too dumb to know if their arses were on fire. (1947,For the Rest of Our Lives,258)

not know one from a bottle of detergent¶

phr. [nonce?]

SLATTER Didn't know him from a bottle of detergent - Pull the other tit, boy - (1968,Pagan Game, The,163)

not know shit from clay¶

phr.

McGILL wouldn't know shit from clay naive or stupid persons; eg `Monty's so dense he wouldn't know shit from clay.' (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,125)

phr. to be very stupid or ignorant

FULLARTON I can't tell excreta from clay where strategy is concerned. (1944,Troop Target,121(et pass.))

... poor young android Americans from the new-clear warship Truxton who wouldn't know shit from clay if it was hurled in their faces by every little cunty ship-girl between the Bay of Islands and the Bluff ... (1984,Islands,33/3) [NOTES: (Wedde `Fast History)]

not know the Brighton tram was up them...¶

phr. ... till it rang its bell and people started getting off

McGILL wouldn't know the Brighton tram was up them till it rang its bell and people started getting off, preceded by `so tight', meaning very mean with money, but could as well be used to mean slow-witted; former meaning quoted in Stevan Eldred-Grigg's Oracles and Miracles. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,125)

not know whether one is on one's arse or elbow¶

phr. [(i) [Only DARE mainly N. Atlan urban 1965-70.] one's arse from one's elbow, to be ignorant or stupid. + a var. of ... from one's elbow: P: lower classes: late19-20c.] not to know one's arse from a hole in the ground (occas. a hot rock), to be very ignorant or innocent. Cf. Steinbeck Grapes of Wrath 58 (Penguin). (ii) [nf P8, DARE] whether one's on one's arse or one's elbow, to be confused; not to know where one is or what one's about.]

DAVIN They're all to hell out there, sir. Don't know whether they're on their arse or their elbow. Tanks all over the place. (1947,For the Rest of Our Lives,329)

MIDDLETON That fleeco won't know whether he's on his arse or his elbow in the morning. (1959,Stone, The,43) [NOTES: The Stone]

not much chop¶

phr. not up to much, not much cop [earlier not much chops, no chops]

It wasn't much chop being let down bysomeone who had crept into your heart andthoughts (Nov 1, 1945,NZ Dairy Exporter,67)

There are not many American kids with much chop. (May 10, 2003,Dominion Post,f3)

LYNCH ..not much chop at [marching].. (1997,Stuff It!,15) [NOTES: get full quote]

Harry is no `chops' as regards elegance, but he gets runs, and that is the whole kernel of the run-making game. (Nov 20, 1909,NZ Truth,230/3/2)

VOGEL He ain't much chops, that doctor, I reckon. (1909,Tragedy of Flirtation,219)

DAVIN It's not been much chop so far. (1947,Gorse Blooms Pale, The,207)

chop n. NZ & Austral. colloq. not much chop not up to much. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,126) [NOTES: [cf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 195, sense 14]]

McLauchlan ed. 'Takes all sorts,' she says, opening the big fridge, 'but she doesn't look much chop to me.' (2000,Morrieson's Motel,25)

not take one's lolly for laughing¶

phr. expressing satisfaction or confidence.

A Southland horsetrainer when asked whether he expected his horse to win replied: `I can'ttake my lolly for laughing.' (Aug 2, 1980,TV1) [NOTES: 3.30 pm]

not the full quid¶

phr. -->ca1930 -->1951 Wellington. X SHILLINGS IN THE QUID not all there, mentally deficient (see also POUND) [1951 14 M 14 St Bede's, Chch 2 QUID, NOT THE FULL]

NEWTON Henry snorted that I was mad - only about `two bob in the quid'. (1957,Wayleggo,140)

`That cove looks about seven and six in the quid to me,' remarks a lance-jack. (1941,Troopship Tattoo H.M.T. 32,4)

NEWTON ... be two bob in the quid (1947,Wayleggo,140)

LELAND not the full quid: NOT TOO BRIGHT, our Charlie. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,71)

HENDERSON The Mad Hatter's Teaparty; and who could have been The Mad Hatter, 10s 6d, not the full quid? (1983,Down from Marble Mountain,111)

McGILL not the full quid not sound in the head; eg `There's no doubt in my mind, he's not the full quid. I mean, who else laughs every time there's a quiet moment in the service?' NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,77)

VIRTUE `I heard Mum saying that I'm not the full quid ... I didn't want to leave Waiwhetu Road. It isn'tmy fault that ... we're having to go and live in the sticks.' (1987,Redemption of Elsdon Bird, The,50)

not too clever¶

phr. not too well in health

PARTRIDGE Clever. At first a colloquial and local word', S.O.D.; it still is coll. if =cunning' or skilful' and applied to an animal or if =well', `in good health or spirits' (mid-C. 19-20). Esp. not too clever, indisposed in health; the health sense is common in Australia and New Zealand. (1937,Dictionary of Slang,158) [NOTES: [P8 adds Britain.]]

[The traveller to New Zealand] might be ... told . . . that his acquaintance, somewhat indisposed, did not `feel too clever,' ... (Apr 4, 1938,Press, The) [NOTES: McNab NZ Slang]

not too flash¶

phr. unwell

I wasn't feeling too flash when I got back but that was due to jet lag and a big night. (Apr 4, 2003,Sunday Star Times,B9)

SUTHERLAND There were all sorts of diverting new experiences to enjoy and interesting new words and usages to master. I found, for instance, that you didn't have to be even mildly dishonest to be crook' - only unwell. Also that while recuperating you usually passed through an intermediate state of beingnot too flash' before you won back to being `near enough' again. (1956,Green Kiwi,40,1960 ed.)

not touch with a red-hot poker¶

phr.

McGILL wouldn't touch it with a red-hot poker extreme aversion; eg `If I was you I wouldn't touch those shares with a red-hot poker.' NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,125)

not within cooee¶

phr. in the constr. not come/be within cooee (of): to miss by a wide margin, to come nowhere near (success etc.)

ANZAC The niggers ... wouldn't come within coo-ee of our mob when engaged in bomb-throwing. (1916,On the Anzac Trail,39)

COWAN That was twenty-four years ago, but the railway is not yet within cooey of the Tangarakau (1916,Bush Explorers,24)

PFAFF Arrived there too late, and could not get within coo-ey of the golden claims. (1914,Diggers' Story, The)

coo-ee n. call borrowed from aborigines, used in the bush by one wishing to find or be found by another: whence r.tr. to cooee, and figuratively within cooee of, and not within coo-ee of within or not within possibility of success. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. (Aust.-NZ Suppl.),613)

MANTELL `Kept telling him how good you were, how well-liked. Sniping at him because he wasn't within cooey [of you]. It got on his nerves.' (1978,Murder in Fancydress,153)

BEARDSLEY [not within cooee] cooee (not within c-) not close (1984,Blackball 08,243)

Melbourne, in all its dishonesty and mad-brained speculation, was not within 'cooey" of the present idiotic boom in Auckland. (1896,AJHR,I-4A/2)

There is no crisis, there is no emergency, they haven't come within coo-ee of losing a vote, and the're blaming everybody but themselves. (Jun 12, 2002,Dominion,1)

not worth a cracker¶

phr. worth nothing, worthless (See cracker)

CASEY `She's a dead-end show round about four o'clock of a week-day, isn't she? ... Nothing doing worth a cracker, eh.' (1963,As Short a Spring,89)

not worth a pinch¶

phr. worthless (See see shit)

McCARTHY `No, Russell, he was just no good with cattle, not worth a pinch.' (1973,Listen...!,38)

not worth a tin of fish¶

phr. worthless [tin of fish [added to aid search]]

SLATTER ... he tried to skedaddle the very first night in the line. Cryin like a kid he was. He wasn't worth a tinna fish over there. And now he skites about when he was at the war. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,44)

Two fences further on a well-backed runner in Whitestone turned over, and Winchester was then left to win as he liked from Dorando and Maori Rifle, both of whom are not worth a tin of fish. (Dec 31, 1910,NZ Truth,2)

It is always the same - you're not worth a tin of fish when you are fighting, but knock off and you are a world beater. (Nov 29, 1924,NZ Truth,8)

This Budget is not worth a tin of fish from the point of view of putting the country right. (Aug 12, 1931,Evening Post,9)

.. yet already the support of the Italian people, if such exists at all, is not worth a tin of fish to Hitler, and the world knows - if Germany does not - that the popular support of Germany, ascribed to the Hungarians, has about the same value. (Oct 17, 1944,Evening Post,4)

not-wanted¶

n.

When she went in Mrs Bailey had a baby in her arms, and Mrs Williams said, Oh! what a dear little thing.' Mrs. Bailey said,Yes, it's a poor little not-wanted.'' <i>Ibid.</i> 328/5/4 Mrs Williams had two children of her own. She could not account for her sudden fancy to this littlenot-wanted.' She had never done this before. The coroner expressed the hope that she would not go in for trafficking in `not-wanteds' again. (Oct 7, 1911,NZ Truth,328/5/3)

Poor little `not-wanteds'! Within the past week or two in the city of Wellington alone, there have been found two miniature mites of humanity who came from God knows where, and who were thrown out as one might throw out a shovelful of refuse,. . . (Oct 21, 1911,NZ Truth,330/6/3)

notched tower shell¶

n.

POWELL NOTCHED TOWER SHELL (Phenatoma novaezelandiae). This is characteristic of 77 New Zealand species, most of which have a pronounced cleft or sinus in the outer lip. None of the species are really common and most of them are of deep water occurrence. (1947,Native Animals of NZ,29)

note¶

n.

He asked me to lend him a note so as to make it [pounds] 2-10 (1868,Punch or the Auckland Charivari,63)

PYKE ... I'll send her back her fifty pounds ... And as to the fifty notes - well, I told you I hadn't been muchly at school; but if I can't cipher that up, I'm a Dutchman. Ibid. 3/vii/97 The medico looked at the querist. Would you like to know my opinion?' he asked.Yes to be sure.' `Then hand me over a note. I never give an opinion without a fee.' (1873,Wild Will Enderby,2/x/73,1889,1974 ed.)

WOOD When you see me working at the rate/ Of fifty notes a week!/ .../ And even at half fifty notes a-week,/ You ought to have made a pile./ (1875,Waiting for the Mail,39)

BATHGATE ... but I'm none harder than other folk, except may be some falsh cad like you, Jack, who likes to fly round a bit when they've got a few notes. (1881,Waitaruna,136)

HAY ... everyone rushes at the clerk's table, and ... dumps down his note ([pound]1) for the `Miner's Right', which is his license and authority to dig for gold within the limits of the field. (1882,Brighter Britain,2/289)

D'AVIGDOR [Colonialisms] A `note' means one pound, although sovereigns are as plentiful in Australia as bank-notes, and not scarce in New Zealand. Most of the local banks issue notes for one pound. (1888,Antipodean Notes,170)

WAKEWFIELD The ordinary currency consists of one pound notes of all the six banks, which circulate indiscriminately through the colony. Hence the word note is commonly used forpound'. For instance a man may say, `I gave 100 note for the cattle', meaning he gave 100 pounds for them,though he may given a check for the money or ten pound notes. (1889,New Zealand After 50 Years,191)

COTTLE He had me for a few notes I was fool enough to lend him. 94 He has been giving me a note a week. (1891,Frank Melton's Luck,93)

MORRIS He had me for a few notes I was fool enough to lend him. 94 He has been giving me a note a week. Note, n. short for Bank-note, and always used for a one-pound note, the common currency. A note = [pound]1. [1864] (1898,Austral English,322)

GRACE I gave 5 notes for the horse. (1901,Tales of a Dying Race,132)

She wouldn't return his letters as they might be worth a few hundred notes. (Sep 30, 1905,NZ Truth,15/3/4)

THOMPSON I nefer could take der notes from der till lest I'd hurt der barman's pride!/ (1909,Ballads about Business,27)

LAWSON Twenty notes won't break us. (1951,Gold in their Hearts,102)

HAMILTON They refused to be compelled to deliver their honey to the government and when they were fined fifty notes, they refused to pay. (1953,Till Human Voices Wake Us,178)

2 n.

In the hall, two doors with lead-glasspanels bearing the College crest wereerected to make the hall more sacrosanctthan discipline-notes could make it. (1935,St Patrick's College 1883-1935,81)

Who will ever forget the silence, moreeloquent than words, as the Rector sat onthe stage, with the book of Weekly Notesopen on the table before him, and slowlybit his under lip while pointing hispencil at some unhappy offender, prior tomaking his slow and scathing comments. (1960,St Patrick's College 1883-1960,22)

Always "right dress" and "eyes front"..and "sinker", notes for this and notesfor that. (1956,St Patrick's College, Silverstream 1931-1956,16)

Silverstream is a place of many memoriesfor us all;.. our notes for the weekshowing our rise or decline, thefriendships we made. (1981,St Patrick's College, Silverstream 1931-1980,32)

We missed, too, the pomp and circumstanceof Weekly Notes. (1981,St Patrick's College, Silverstream 1931-1980,55)

note-noho¶

n. Spergularia marginata (Allan 205) for which no Maori name seems recorded: NOTE-NOHO nf Williams [check D'Urville]

HOOKER Arenaria media, L., ... Nat. name, `Note-noho'[e-acute], D'Urville. <./I> (1853,Flora NZ,I Flowering Plants 26)

HOOKER Note[acute]-noho, D'Urville. Arenaria media. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),766)

noter¶

n. big noter

While not wanting to sound like a noter, he sees similarities between himself and REM ... (Oct 25, 1995,Auckland City Harbour News,p6)

nothing¶

n. not to be able to compare with; be nowhere as good as'

BRUNO Demosthenes ... had nothing on him. (1944,Desert Daze,5)

nothing flash¶

phr. a deprecatory phrase nothing out of the ordinary; average' [ca1940 Havelock e.g.How are you feeling?' `Nothing flash.' He was looking nothing flash in his old dungarees.]

nothing to skite about¶

phr. used depreciatingly of something inferior (cf. nothing to write home about)

SYDER & HODGETTS Of no great significance; or conduct better left unmentioned. .in 4;`You might've hoodwinked the boss, but it's nothing to skite about - the other chaps have to do extra work when one of you's [word missing???] for the day.' (1974,Australian & NZ English [TS],782)

The south hurdler had a run in the High Weight the second day, and was in fifth place at the finish - nothing to really skite about. (Jul 17, 1930,NZ Truth,13)

nothings¶

n. [a marbles term]

SUTTON-SMITH Here are some [marble] terms from Taranaki around 1880-1890: firsts, lay-up, stakes, tips, sticking-taw, nothings, anythings, fade-it, knuckledown stiff, dubs, finking [sic, ?funking], sips, spanning, placing; and from Dunedin School in 1949: knee high, manyies, tracks, screws, nuts, sleets, kills, forces, dig, dubs, cheats. (1981,History of Children's Play,269)

n.

nothoscordum¶

n.

notice¶

n. sc. of travelling stock or of intention to cross a run with stock (?under scab regs) [farming hist]

It was 5 p.m. before we got [the sheep] to the stopping place. ... Cooper is gone on giving notices. Ibid. 118 I had great difficulty to keep several mobs from joining with us. I then went on with notices to King and Rhodes 40 miles again. These notices are a great bother. (Nov 15, 1863,Chudleigh Diary,109)

BEATTIE In the early days when there were no fences one had to give notice of intention to go through each run. ... Bill Smith and my brother were once taking 50 sheep up the coast ... and went to cross [Hillgrove run] without notice. (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,152)

n.

BEATTIE In the early days when there were no fences one had to give notice of intention to go through each run. ... Bill Smith and my brother were once taking 50 sheep up the coast ... and went to cross [Hillgrove run] without notice. (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,152)

notional railway¶

n.

TURNER The oddest of all railways is Nelson's notional railway in New Zealand which does not exist, except as a subsidy paid to road transport. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,157)

Yes, we will build a new railway, but Iam not dealing with the railway at themoment; I am dealing with the notionalrailway... The Nelson railway closed on 3December 1955. The notional railwaystarted on, I think, 4 November 1957. (1958,NZ Parliamentary Debates,316/225)

Notocene¶

n. [(Seems to be NZ when introduced? Ask Geol Survey: R. Mason) -->1917 TrNZI 407 (Thomson]

notornis¶

n. (See takahe)

THOMSON The apteryx, notornis, kakapo, and weka, are only found in New Zealand's solitudes. (1859,Story of New Zealand, The,1/35,1974 ed.)

ANGAS The Notornis. [picture caption] The notornis, owing to the feeble nature of its wings, is incapable of flight, but runs with great swiftness amongst the fern. (1866,Polynesia,53, 61)

BULLER Although no examples of the Notornis have since ben obtained, it does not necessarily follow that the species is absolutely extinct. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,192)

Mr. Connor, who was intelligent enough to suspect that he had found a Notornis, at once accepted the offer ... (1882,TrNZI,14/240)

I was informed ... that the skeleton of a Takahe had been found ... near lake Te Anau ... As is well known, the only recent remains of Notornis hitherto obtained are the two stuffed specimens in the British Museum ... (1886,TrNZI,18/78)

By a strange ... coincidence, the first two specimens of the Notornis Notornis, or takahe as it was called in the South island, were secured ... (1889,TrNZI,21/226)

MORRIS Notornis, n. a bird of New Zealand allied to the Porphyrio (q.v.), first described from a fossil skull by Professor Owen (1848), and then thought to be extinct, like the Moa. Professor Owen called the bird Notornis mantelli, and, curiously enough, Mr Walter Mantell, in whose honour the bird was named, two years afterwards captured a live specimen; a third specimen was captured in 1879.... The Maori names were Moho and Takahe(q.v.). (1898,Austral English,323)

The Notornis, longest of our living birds, has not been met with in Canterbury, and is indeed on the verge of extinction - (1900,Canterbury Old & New,195)

REISCHEK The fever of discovery fell upon me, for to what infinite pains had I not gone, and through whatuntrodden wildernesses, without having seen or heard sign of Notornis! At last one seemed to be within my reach! (1930,Yesterdays in Maoriland,264,1933 ed.)

STEVENSON Notornis (named Notornis mantelli after Mantell) resembled the pukaki, but was a much heavier bird. (1947,Maori and Pakeha in North Otago,78)

notornis The scientic name of the takahe, a large fightless bird of New Zealand, with a heavy bill and thick legs. (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),276,8th ed.)

SINCLAIR For instance, in the absence of competition from mammals, several species of flightless birds have developed. One is the Notornis which, as the moa once did, grazes on the grasslands; (1959,History of New Zealand,31)

TURNER For instance, in the absence of competition from mammals, several species of flightless birds have developed. One is the Notornis which, as the moa once did, grazes on the grasslands; (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,168)

notornis n. rarest of New Zealand birds, believed extinct till 1859 when a living specimen was discovered [Maori names moho and takahe]. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),621)

notornis ... n. rarest of N.Z. birds, believed extinct until 1950 when a living specimen was discovered; Maori names moho and takahe (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),14)

138. Notornis mantelli Owen, 1848 Notornis (Takahe) (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,43,1980 ed.)

notornis n. a rare flightless rail of New Zealand. [C19: NL, < Gk notos south + ornis bird] (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,769) [NOTES: 1986 NZPOD 513]

[Hdg.] Home-Made Notornis. (Feb 8, 1956,Weekly News,5)

The first living Notornis was caught in 1849. (May 18, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,15)

The notornis is heavier built, and more olive-green along the back than the swamp hen. (Apr 1, 1924,Otago Witness,71)

This proves conclusively that the Notornis still survives in the secret recesses of these dense West Coast forests. (Apr 3, 1890,Otago Witness,18)

[Hdg] Is Your Car a Notornis? Thename of a New Zealand bird which untilrecently was thought to be extinct, isused in an additional sense - to describea car which is so old-fashioned that ithas become almost extinct. (Aug 23, 1949,Southern Cross (Wgton),2)

notothenid¶

n.

AYLINHG BLACK COD (Black notothenid, maori chief) Notothenia magellanica ... The black cod is similar to the maori chief but has a deeper, less rounded body ... and does not reach such a large size. ... Black cod are common in inshore rocky areas south of Cook Strait ... (1982,Collins Guide,276,1984 ed.)

n.

AYLING SMALL-SCALED NOTOTHENID (Black cod) Notothenia microlepidota ... It is distinguished from the black cod and the maori chief by having very small scales, a slightly lunate tail ... [south of NZ] (1982,Collins Guide,276,1984 ed.)

noveli¶

n. Dalmatian word for newcomers (other Dalmatians)

BATISTICH The noveli, as we called all the newcomers, all wore the same thin brown suits,the same brown boots, carried the same cane hampers. (1987,Sing Vila in the Mountain,87 ed.)

nowler¶

n.

Nowler: Very hard sheep to shear, particularly a rough, sandy merino wether, with a fleece so cotted that it is impossible to keep the shears near his skin. (Jan 27, 1934,Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland]

noxious¶

adj. of weeds, statutorily declared harmful

When obnoxious thistles are permitted to grow on unoccupied land the ownership of which cannot be ascertained ... Ibid. 1857 Thistle Amendment Act in 1873 1781 Any person who shall fail to eradicate or cut down any noxious Thistles having seed stems growing upon land in his occupation ... (1873,Acts of Wellington Legislature,175.4) [NOTES: 1856 Thistle Amendment Act in 1873 Acts of Wellington Legislature 175 4.]

... An Ordinance for the better Prevention of the Growth and Spread of Noxious Thistles. (1867,Ordinances of Taranaki,188) [NOTES: 1862 Thistle Ordinance, 1862. in 1867 Ordinances of Taranaki 188]

noxious ... NZ & Austral. (of plants) considered harmful to the environment (noxious weeds). (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,513) [NOTES: cf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 770]

Boxthorn and barberry hedges grow only in rural sectors of Moaville. In the town ... they're classified as noxious plants, along with ... ragwort and woolly nightshade. (1988,More from Moaville,55)

Colenso Various species of the genus Rumex [dock] are now too frequent in several districts, in common with many other noxious European weeds.) (1844,Journal of an Expedition) [NOTES: in 1959 Taylor Early Travs 40]

noxious animal¶

n. [define acc. to the Noxious Animals Acts]

CRUMP Until we get some real co-operation from these near-sighted cockies, the complete eradication of noxious animals in places like this'll be impossible. (1960,Good Keen Man, A,86)

noxious insect¶

n.

Noxious insects are doing more harm thandeer to the native bush in the TararuaRanges. (Jul 29, 1940,Taranaki Herald,4)

noxious weed¶

n. a legal category of harmful weeds which must (under pain of fine) be eradicated from land by the owner (cf Noxious Weeds Act 1900)

RUTHERFORD For preventing the growth and spread of thistles and other noxious weeds. (1949,Selected Documents,112b) [NOTES: 1861 Nov 2 Sir George Grey Memorandum in 1949 Rutherford ed. Select Documents 112b]

On the Presence of some Noxious Weeds in Nelson District. [title (1895,TrNZI,27/407)

Noxious Weeds. ... Californian or Canadian thistle ... Bathurst Burr ... (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,203)

COCKAYNE The gorse, noxious weed though it may be proclaimed, is a glory when its sheets of gold dazzle the eye. (1910,NZ Plants,135)

ANTHONY He cleared his throat nervously a couple of times and ... passed a few remarks on noxious weeds.`Was it true the blackberry was getting a hold of this district?' (1927,Me and Gus,1977 Gus Tomlins ed.Sturm 85 ed.)

PERRY This will include matters such as character of pastures, presence of noxious weeds, bush, etc. (1922,NZ Sheepfarming,12)

COAD Most of his stock had died, his fences were in disrepair, and noxious weeds were spreading their poisonous tentacles all over the place. (1931,Such Is Life,58)

BRUCE ... the yellow broom ... to be classed among the noxious weeds today. (1932,Early Days of Canterbury,51)

CHERRILL Well, look. Gorse is what they call a noxious weed way out home - anyhow it's the farmers' worst enemy. (1950,Straight Furrow,26)

SHADBOLT The rest was a broken clay bank covered with scrub, gorse and ragwort; ... The local council accused him of growing noxious weeds there, and now and then reluctantly took him to court. (1965,Among the Cinders,99)

TURNER Inspectors call to make sure ... noxious weeds, weeds officially proscribed, arecontrolled. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,142)

McLINTOCK As used in relation to weeds in New Zealand, the term noxious' is a confusing one, as it has two distinct meanings. In a general, non-specific sense, it denotes any weed regarded as significant, for one reason or another, by the use of the term. It has, however, a precise legal meaning denoting weeds whose control and eradication are required under the provisions of the Noxious Weeds Act of 1950 and its amendments. These are the so callednoxious weeds'. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/597-598)

MOORE & IRWIN CASSINIA LEPTOPHYLLA. Cassinia is a genus of Australasian and South African shrubs. The five New Zealand species, known as cottonwoods'ortauhinu', ... The grey-leaved C. leptophylla so invaded neglected hill pastures (as about Wellington) that it, along with the golden tauhinu C. fulvida, was designated a`scheduled noxious weed'. (1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,138)

An Act to prevent the spread of Noxious Weeds and to enforce the Trimming of Hedges. (1900,NZ Statutes,64 Vict. 10/20) [NOTES: There were also Noxious Weeds Acts in 1908, 1928, and 1950]

noxious-weed inspector¶

n.

ANTHONY (1927,Me and Gus,85,1977 Gus Tomlins ed. Sturm ed.) [NOTES: a1927 Anthony Me and Gus (1977 Gus Tomlins ed. Sturm) 85]

One noxious-weed inspector, who thoughtit was "up to him" to do something forhis money, recently strolled on to a farmin Taranaki.. and said: "Hi! Look 'ere..if them blackberries ain't grubbed out byto-morrow, up you goes." (Feb 20, 1904,Free Lance,13)

nozzleman¶

n. [miners']

[Get quote] Ibid. 10/341 The jet spouted from a four-inch nozzle, scoring up and down the rock as the nozzle-man's hand swayed it. (1901,NZ Illustrated Magazine,V/374)

NPC¶

abbr. National Provincial Championship (in rugby union) [superseded by the Air NZ Cup in 2006]

During 2000 there were 111 players in the lower two NPC divisions who had played their club rugby elsewhere. (Mar 31, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),37)

I always thought NPC players earned a reasonable living - they don't. (Oct 31, 1998,Listener (New Zealand Listener),69)

NPL¶

abbr. no panty line

I'm a sucker at the best of times, so Jockey Women's bend-over-butt campaign to launch its new No Panty Line (NPL) range pulled me in. (Jul 31, 2003,Dominion Post,D3)

NPPA¶

abbr. Newlands Paparangi Progressive Association

I advised the Newlands Paparangi Progressive Association of how the report treated their area and obtained a copy of the report for the NPPA. (Jun 12, 2001,Independent Herald (Wellington),4)

NQF¶

We are in the final year of implementing the National Qualifications Framework (NQF) in secondary schools. (Dec 9, 2004,Dominion Post,B7)

NSAD¶

abbr. National Society On Alcohol And Drug Dependence

Then nearly five months.. "talking about myself endlessly on the National Society On Alcohol And Drug Dependence programme in Marton... he has trained to post-graduate level in drug and alcohol addiction, worked for two years as an NSAD counsellor,.. run NSAD in Marton. (May 5, 2001,Evening Post,1)

NTD¶

abbr. National Tenancy Database [ORIGIN: acronym]

The database, run by Australian company National Tenancy Database, began in New Zealand last August and lists thousands of bad tenants... According to the NTD website it costs $15 to get the information immediately, or it is free after 10 working days. (Jan 8, 2006,Sunday Star Times,A2)

Nua pride¶

phr. pride in, or in being from, the Horowhenua district [also as 'Nua pride] (See Nua,the)

"When we go out of the district for things like stage challenge, there's real 'Nua pride," Coral said. (Nov 3, 2010,Horowhenua Chronicle,5)

"I'm Horowhenua born and bred, I know about 'Nua pride," the vibrant 23-year-old said. (Jul 28, 2010,Horowhenua Chronicle,2)

Nua, the¶

n. the Horowhenua district [also as 'Nua, the 'Nua] (See Nua pride)

While Wairarapa Bush now have an extra trophy to dust each week the mighty 'Nua's coach Peter Kemp has plans not even to allow dust to settle here. (Nov 12, 2005,Horowhenua-Kapiti Chronicle,62)

As the evening came to a close he quietly told the crowd no matter where he was playing overseas he never forgot his roots in the mighty 'Nua. (Oct 31, 2005,Horowhenua-Kapiti Chronicle,10)

nub¶

n.

... it is no doubt also responsible for the dark coloured varnishes produced from the chip grades. [fn] The terms dust, seeds, chips, nubs, &c., are the names given to certain of the lower kauri gum grades according to the relative sizes of the pieces. From dust' the size of the fragments increases in the order given, as does also the purity of the grade. Chalk, orchalky gum,' is a particular grade recovered from swampy country and is characterized by its white or chalky appearance and large water content. (1936,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,17/371)

In order of decreasing size, the pieces of gum were known as nuggets, nubs, peas, chips, and dust. (1991,NZ Geographic,41)

nucleus cow¶

1 n. (Rural) a cow that forms the base of a breeding herd.

DAVIS Again, political genetics raised its head as bulls for use in the Waihora herd and on the surrounding blocks were being bred from the nucleus cows. (1994,Lab Coats to Gumboots,9)

DAVIS On one memorable day, all the nucleus cows were yarded at Waihora and held in the crush. (1994,Lab Coats to Gumboots,8)

Nude Blacks¶

n. [Dunedin nude rugby team]

Marissa Calligeros Around one in five residents here is a student, resulting in a vibrant atmosphere, particularly today, when the city's priority is retaining the Nude Black's trophy. .. The Nude Blacks are led onto the field by David Bourkey Bourke, a nude rugby veteran. .. The Nude Blacks take the trophy again. .. This year's Nude Rugby Test will be held on July 22 at Logan Park, Dunedin. (Jul 6, 2011,Dominion Post,Travel 15) [NOTES: Keep in spite of original Sydney source]

nude nut¶

n. a skinhead

More descriptive terms such as light bulb heads, cue balls, nude nuts, bumpheads, pin heads and chrome domes derive from satiric attitudes to Skinheads. (Oct 1999,NZWords,2(2) 2)

nudge¶

n. give something a nudge, to push something along, to increase the speed of, to push to the limits etc; of liquor, gambling, to over indulge; also NUDGE (SOMETHING) ALONG [ca1949 I was giving her a bit of a nudge and hit the gravel at 60. (= I was nudging along at 60 and hit the gravel.) ca1971 Wellington (Duke of Edinburgh Hotel) He's been giving the gambling a bit of a nudge lately and is into the bookies for a wad.]

nudge raid¶

n. an amateurish burglary effort

"It was a lot more professional than the 'nudge raid'," he said. (Oct 7, 2005,NZ Herald,A9)

nudibranch¶

2 n.

A patch of colour on the hull is a clown nudibranch, a member of the sea slug family. (Jul 10, 2004,Dominion Post,E17)

2 n.

What looks at first glance like another wandering anemone is New Zealand's largest nudibranch, the 15cm Wellington nudibranch. (Jul 10, 2004,Dominion Post,E17)

2 n.

Hydroids, that look like white bonsai trees, find space to grow and are grazed on by pink and white Jason nudibranchs. Calling these beautiful creatures sea slugs doesn't seem appropriate. (Nov 1, 2003,Dominion Post,E9)

2 n.

Another nudibranch, the blue and yellow Verco's, munches happily on the blue-green bryozoan. (Nov 1, 2003,Dominion Post,E9)

nudist¶

1 n. (Rural) a shorn sheep.

Meek Nudist: a shorn sheep. (1952,Station Days in Maoriland,110)

Meek Through the port-hole went nudists like a shot ... (1952,Station Days in Maoriland,103)

a newly shorn sheep: nudist. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

nudist: A shorn sheep. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/26) [NOTES: Wallace Shearing Glossary]

Nugget¶

n. (as nickname) [ca1914 Havelock, Nugget `Robinson' nickname of a short, thickset person]

... McGregor with a 4 horse dray, Nugget Dix with [459] a 3 horse dray ... (Jul 29, 1912,Chudleigh Diary,458,1950 ed.)

[If you] asked How are you Tom?' he'd invariably answer,I'm thirsty, Nugget; you [sic] ain't got a pint about yer, eh?' (1918,New Zealand At the Front,110)

nugget¶

n. (of gold)

MORRIS ~ a lump of gold. The noun nugget is not Australian, though often so supposed. Skeat (Etymological Dictionary,' s.v.) gives a quotation from North'sPlutarch' with the word in a slightly different shape, viz., niggot. The word nugget was in use in Australia many years before the goldfields were heard of. A thick-set young beast was calleda good nugget.' A bit of a fig of tobacco was called a nugget of tobacco .'' (G. W. Rusden.) [1852] (1898,Austral English,323)

LUSH One of the boys took out ... a small nugget of gold (Nov 23, 1852,Auckland Journals,126,1971 ed.)

EARP One man brought in a small piece [of gold], which might be termed a nugget, as it was the firstassuming that form which had been taken out. [See also 1853 Earp NZ in 1974 Heinz Bright Fine Gold 110] (1853,New Zealand (various authors/titles),259) [NOTES: 1852 Oct 23 Report of the Sub-Committee onRecent Gold Discovery in the Coromandel District in 1853 Earp NZ 259]

The gold is in dust and nuggets. ... The implement most effectual in economising labour is the `Long Tom', or trough strainer, cradles are but of little comparative service. (Dec 10, 1852,NZ Government Gazette,V/30/183) [NOTES: Heaphy's Report]

Stray notes on Australia and the Diggings (Griffiths Collection) Origin of he word Nugget'. - This word, now so common amongst our population, is a strange sounding word, and destitute of any apparent entymological meaning. It originated at the Ophir diggings in New South Wales, and is probably a corruption ofingot', which is itself a corruption of lingot', a little tongue. The wedge of gold which Achan purloined is called, in the original Hebrew, atongue' of gold, as a reference to a Bible with marginal readings will show. In California, the word lump' is generally used, and sometimes the Spanish wordpepite.' (Sep 30, 1852,Leisure Hour, The,640)

A S THOMSON In November [1852] I visited the diggings [at Thames], and procured the frog which is herewith sent. [221] It was got in this way. The gold-diggers were washing the soil of a mountain-stream in the machine called `long-tom'. In excavating the banks they displaced several large boulders of quartzy rock, underneath which was discovered the living frog. The gold-diggers, who voluntarily submit to the evils and miseries of such a gambling trade, and can rarely be excited by anything unless a great nugget, were so much astonished at the sight of a frog that one of them desisted fom the seductive occupation he was at, and took the frog, and put it into a bottle of water. (1853,Edinburgh New Philosophical Journal,3/220-221) [NOTES: 1853 A.S. Thomson Edinburgh New Philosophical Journal 55/66-69 in 1920 Nov NZJST]

SWAINSON Gold in minute quantities was found by every [prospecting] party almost on the surface of the soil; ... Early in November, however, the prospect began to be of a more promising character : one party being reported to have washed out two or three ounces of gold, including several nuggets, and to have averaged fair daily wages; ... (1853,Auckland,94)

I've circulated rumours .../ Of people finding nuggets by the score,/ To cause a rush, ... (1866,Canterbury Rhymes,92) [NOTES: 1862 Oct in 1866 Canterbury Rhymes 92]

HAAST ... I almost thought that he had discovered a golden nugget on the river bank ... (1861,Report on Topographical Exploration of Nelson,13)

... the general character of the gold being scaly and fine, the reverse of shotty, but some of the nuggets are quite waterworn and solid. (1861,NZ Goldfields,29,1976 ed.) [NOTES: 1861 Sep 27 Tuapeka in NZ Goldfields 1861 (1976) 29]

I've circulated rumours, not a few,/ Of people finding nuggets by the score,/ To cause a rush,... (Oct 22, 1862,Lyttelton Times) [NOTES: 1862 Oct 22 Lyttelton Times in 1948 Von Haast Julius Bon Haast 259]

SMALL And a fifty-pound nugget, bedad, wouldn't draw me/ Away from this city and my Judy again./ (1866,NZ & Australian Songster,25,1970 ed.)

2/121 [fn.] ... nugget ... from niggot of gold: West Country nig, nug `block'] (1876,NZ Magazine)

How is gold formed into specks and nuggets? and [I will] also dispute the theory that alluvial gold was not derived from reefs. (1890,TrNZI,22/400)

32/311 The tin here is found ... in small, worn, brown lumps or pebbles, with occasionally a few larger pieces. I have seen such pieces (or nuggets) of almost pure tin weighing from 12 oz. to 20 oz. (1900,TrNZI) [NOTES: Colenso Cornish Tin Mines]

BUTLER WHEN my father reached the colony for which he had left England some twenty-two years previously, he bought a horse, and started up-country on the evening of the day after his arrival, which was, as I have said, on one of the last days of November 1890. He had taken an English saddle with him, and a couple of roomy and strongly made saddle-bags. In these he packed his money, his nuggets, some tea, sugar, tobacco, salt, ... (1901,Erewhon Revisited,chapter II/207,Everyman 1932 (1960) ed.)

BLYTH Nugget: Alluvial gold in a solid lump. (1935,Gold Mining Year Book,11) [NOTES: Glossary]

In order of decreasing size, the pieces of gum were known as nuggets, nubs, peas, chips, and dust. (Apr 1991,NZ Geographic,41)

n. (?1892) a dumpy island or rock outcrop in the sea; (?1967) rocks set in water, having some vegetation (Stewart Island) a projecting rock or rocky islet or outcrop in the sea, or in a bay. [?orig. whalers', now Stewart Island and s. SI)]

HOCKEN & FENWICK A remarkably beautiful reflection of the breakers and island `nuggets' off the coast. (1892,Holiday Trip to the Catlins District, A,2)

BEATTIE There is a little nugget between Te Waitaua and The Neck and this is the nugget that the whaler, `C. A. Larsen,' struck. Its name is Whero (red) ... (1944,Maori Place-Names of Otago,85)

BEATTIE The whalers [early 19th c] called small islets formed of jutting rock `nuggets', and hence we get the names The Nuggets and Nugget Point. (1948,Otago Place Names,11)

DEMPSEY It is an almost enclosed, tranquil harbour, very small, with a little nugget in the bay. Ibid. 30 They were along the beach near the nugget, where the great bull-kelp writhed and twisted ... (1964,Little World of Stewart island,19)

NATUSCH [The tern] is seen in all New Zealand bays and [The tern] nests on islets and nuggets' - which are little more than rocks, with a tuft of bush, set in the water- ... (1967,Animals of NZ, The,267)

n. a thick-set, chunky animal or person (cf NUGGETTY) [ca1935 applied to a thickset child]

MEADE The chief is noted for his preference for a very little steed. ... It was mounted on some such little `nugget' that he distinguished himself. (1864,Ride Through Disturbed Districts,3,1870 ed.)

BELL And this is your little sister, I suppose? Well, she is a nice little nugget, anyhow; and here's sixpence to buy lollies for her and you. (1899,In the Shadow of the Bush,86)

nugget n. small, solidly built house. (1996,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),621)

nugget ... n. small, solidly built house[sic: =? horse]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),14)

n. a chunk of kauri gum [(gumfields)]

SATCHELL He lifted out a nugget about 10 inches long (1902,Land of the Lost,41)

MANDER ... men ...had the chance to pick up in quantities ... the nuggets of amber gum which only the Kauri tree produces. (1920,Story of a NZ River, The,229,1974 ed.)

REED Lumps of gum weighing half a hundredweight or more have on rare occasions been found, but in general, ... the size varied from an occasional nugget weighing a few pounds down to `nuts'the size of an acorn or smaller. Ibid. 50 The hook was used for drawing up nuggets of gum from the depths of swamps, after location by the spear. (1972,Gumdiggers, The,24)

SUTHERLAND Mechanical outfits for collecting the smaller nuggets and chips by means of washing were invented ... (1956,Green Kiwi,70,1960 ed.)

nugget A large lump of valuable metal, such as gold. (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),8th ed.)

n. a lump or piece of anything

HYDE Inside the loaves were clamped nuggets of butter. He wasn't caught out, but the German prisoners got to know which of the men was slipping them extra provisions, ... (1936,Passport to Hell,88)

Chickmate Crumbed Chicken Nuggets 10.19 kg (Nov 17, 1986,Evening Post,14)

v. to polish (shoes)

WOLFE Even in the home of the bird it is still more usual to 'nugget' one's boots. (1991,Kiwi,37)

Curiously, whereas New Zealanders tended to "nugget" their boots, in parts of England it was customary to "kiwi" them every morning. (Jan 2000,NZ Geographic,No. 45/16)

n.

Please post me my nugget outfit and a spare tin or two of nugget. (Aug 18, 1914,Letter) [NOTES: 1914 Aug 18 letter in 1984 Pugsley Gallipoli 52]

McGILL I knew them well, from ... playing hopscotch laid out with coloured chalk, using Nuggget tins filled with earth. (1985,G'day Country,62)

v. to apply boot polish to; to blacken with `Nugget'

The incident of the egg occurred last July, but it was also stated in evidence that the same [Fire Brigade] officer had his helmet nuggeted about four years ago. (Oct 30, 1963,Dominion)

OLIVER As part of the customary initiation [at King's High School, Dunedin c.1940], his genitals were nuggetted; ... (1983,James K. Baxter,31)

JOHNSTON Danny got a bit stroppy for a while when some of the jokers had tried to nugget his knackers, but otherwise it had been a worthwhile `do'. (1981,Fish Factory,167)

SUTTON-SMITH Fingernails were not subject to scrutiny, nor were we brought to brook with the reproach `Did you nugget (shoe-shine) your boots this morning?' (1870; Waianiwa) (1981,History of Children's Play,45)

KNOX It was a carved wooden gun, nuggeted black and filthy to hold. (1987,After Z-Hour,72)

n. a boot polish (from trademark), usually thought of as black; now any bootpolish; [1984 Orsman letter to an enquirer Nugget boot polish' is a New Zealand and Australian word used, I think, from before the First World War. Eric Partridge in his A Dictionary of Slang gives it as Australian colloquial from about 1910 - the date he thought he first remembered it from. I have it in my collections, but have no early date for it as I have not yet checked it up in advertisements of old newspapers, nor written to the company that produces it to ask them when they adopted Nugget as a brand-name, and why. I assume it comes from nuggeta small lump', as in nugget of gold. Perhaps you or the class might like to write to the Nugget company and ask them about this. It's also now used as a verb - to nugget shoes ', for example. It's like many other brand-names that have passed into common speech: e.g. hoover forvacuum cleaner': to hoover a room, etc.]

HISLOP Off came my boots and sox, and on went the nugget polish. ... with feet as black as the Ace of Spades. ... If the nugget could be made to stick on leather as it does on your skin, the company would have a monopoly in the boot polish line ... (1943,Pure Gold,37)

McKAY Early that morning he turned up at Baigent's place and said: `Lawrence, you haven't any nugget, have you? I'm getting baptized today and look at my shoes.' (Nov 4, 1948,James K. Baxter,116) [NOTES: 1948 Nov 4 in 1990 McKay James K. Baxter 116]

HARVEY I plonked my [shoeshine] box on the footpath, and started looking through all the tins of nugget and brushes to make sure everything was there. (1964,Any Old Dollars Mister?,27)

BREAM (1974,I'm Sorry Amanda,31,I added `Nugget and brushes' to my shopping list. ed.)

RICHARDSON I take the shoes outside and smear them all over with nugget. Elly has shiny black shoes .. (1986,Choices,56)

RICHARDS Before the party broke up, the boys got some nugget and a brush and blackened the sleeping cook's face and bald head. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,95)

KEINZLY The cocoa was like melted shoe nugget and the toast had stuck to the cloth, soldered in its own grease. (1960,Tangahano,152)

GIBBONS The boots had to be oiled for a week or two... We could then revert to using Nugget. (1989,Recollections (various authors/titles),14)

nugget out¶

v. [(goldmining)]

PYKE There,' said Iis where the gold was got'; and on breaking up the surface, the first thing I discovered was a bit of about 3dwts; and that afternoon we nuggeted out 9oz. 6dwts. 3grs., whichall hands which were there could see.' (1887,History of the Early Gold Discoveries in Otago,82,1962 ed.) [NOTES: c1862 Sep in 1887 Pyke History of the Early Gold Discoveries in Otago 1887 (1962) 82]

The first thing I discovered was a bit about 3 dwts; and that afternoon we nuggeted out [of the slide] 9ozs 6 dwts 12 grs, which all hands which were there could see. .ho;1862 Nov 9 Michael Grogan in 1863 V. Pyke's Report in 1887 Handbook NZ Mines 10 `Then I walked to the spot, ... and that afternoon we nuggetted out 9oz. 6dwt. 12gr.' (1863,AJHR) [NOTES: 1862 Letter from Michael Grogan, prospector in 1863 Appendix to Journals Pyke Goldfields Reports]

MURRAY By the end of the afternoon he had `nuggeted out nine ounces and twelve grains ...'. (1977,Costly Gold,7)

nugget-black¶

adj.

HYDE Exception was also taken to the words `Rummies Retreat', which appeared in enormous words of nugget-black upon Tent Eight [at Trentham Military Camp]. Ibid. 176 Their nugget-blacked faces made them look like limp and shattered Christy minstrels. (1936,Passport to Hell,84)

HULME A nugget-black bug rollicked under the till. (1986,Te Kaihau,120)

nuggeting¶

n. applying shoe polish to someone's genitals [also nuggetting]

McGILL nuggeting unpleasant male party habit of removing victim's trousers and underpants and applying Nugget shoe polish to testicles; eg `Let's get him pissed then give him a good nuggeting. Show the stuck-up prick we don't need his hoitytoity ways round here. Whadya say?' (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,77)

Nuggeting at my hostel happened only after the Macleans toothpaste or the Deep Heat had been applied to the genitals. (Dec 4, 2005,Sunday Star Times,C11)

Justice Morris says some of the 81 former cadets he interviewed told him of instances of physical and sexual abuse including: nuggetting, spooning, barrelling, beatings and kicking, verbal abuse, extortion, forced showering, cigarette burns, and beatings with brooms and rifles. (Dec 2, 2005,NZ Herald,A5)

Nuggetting: Covering a cadet's genitals with boot polish. (Dec 2, 2005,NZ Herald,A5)

Nuggets, the¶

n. (Otago islets off Nugget Point)

TUCKETT Within the Noggets [sic] I was glad to observe the schooner at anchor, ... (May 6, 1844,Diary) [NOTES: 1844 May 6 Tuckett Diary in 1898 Hocken Contributions 216]

nuggetty¶

1 adj. (of gold)

McLEAN The gold is becoming more nuggetty ranging from a pin's head to a bean. (1857,Miscellaneous Papers,1V/83)

Where the diggers are now working, the gold is almost all nuggety, some running as large as horse beans. (Mar 23, 1861,Otago Witness,10)

The men are satisfied with the amount of gold found [in Otago] though it is not of a very good [40] quality, too fine, not nuggety enough to use a sluice well so they adopt the slower and surer way of cradling. (May 23, 1862,Chudleigh Diary,39,1950 ed.)

In September, 1862, ... Mr. James lamb ... brought to Dunedin about 28oz. of coarse, nuggettygold, obtained at Moa Creek ... (1863,Handbook NZ Mines,8) [NOTES: 1863 V. Pyke's Report in 1887 Handbook NZ Mines 8]

. 28 ozs of coarse, nuggetty gold. [Also 1863 Pyke in 1887 Handbook NZ Mines 8] (1863,AJHR,D/6/5) [NOTES: 1863 Appendix to Journals D/6/5 Pyke Goldfields Reports]

HARPER The place is prosperous, most of the gold found here differing from that near Hokitika; much larger, nuggety and rich. (Oct 1866,Letters from Canterbury, NZ,105,1914 ed.)

HOGG 'Twas when the Rocky River rush began/ ... `and stories told/ Of ounces gotten in a single pan,/ Of nuggety, and round, and shotty gold./ The news like a bush fire through the diggings ran,/ (1875,Lays and Rhymes,176)

PYKE The gold is described by the Superintendent's correspondent as being of a very fine description' -not much waterworn,' and `half-pea nuggety.' (1887,History of the Early Gold Discoveries in Otago,60,1962 ed.)

There is a nuggety or mammillated appearance about drift-gold which reef-gold does not present.' (1890,TrNZI,22/403)

The effect of such matters ... was rather to disperse any gold it reduces than to concentrate such gold in a nuggetty form. (1898,TrNZI,30/500)

HOWARD They ... obtained the heaviest gold yet seen in rough nuggety pieces up to a dwt. in size. (1940,Rakiura,232)

HISLOP Skippers gold is noted for its nuggety form; ... (1943,Pure Gold,21)

BEATTIE The gold on Coal Island was nuggety, ... (1947,Pioneer Recollections,32,1956 ed.)

TOMLINSON The gold from Digger's was more nuggety and from Patriarch it was nearly black. (1968,Remembered Trails,125)

DENNIS ... the gold soongained a reputation for being coarse and nuggety. (1981,Paparoas Guide,68)

MAY Throughout 1863 the nuggety gold of Lyell Creek supported a population of roughly a hundred. (1967,West Coast Gold Rushes,70,1962 ed.)

2 adj. thickset and compactly built

Nuggety is used in the same sence as Bullocky (q.v.), but with a slight difference of meaning, what we should saycompact.' Bullocky had rather a sense of over-strength inducing an awkwardness of movement. Nuggety does not include the last suggestion.' (Mar 2, 1896,Letter)

MORRIS Nuggety, adj. applied to a horse or a man. Short, thick-set and strong. See G. W. Rusden's note under Nugget. (1898,Austral English,323)

LANCASTER ... lean Yankee boat-steerers and harpooners, nuggetty little breeds from Quebec, ... (1938,Promenade,67)

MULGAN (1949,Man Alone,200)

1953 Middleton in 1966 Short Stories 187 (1966,Short Stories (various authors),187)

~ n. thick-set; short; strong. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),621)

nuggety ... adj. small, thickset. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),14)

Well, out of the boo-ai comes three trampers. One was a nuggety bloke in a sou'wester, .... (Apr 19, 1971,Listener (New Zealand Listener),56)

MASON Small, fierce-eyed, round and gnarled as a nut, he strides along with a nuggety grandeur, ... (1981,Solo,8) [NOTES: 1970 Mason `Golden Weather' in 1981 Solo 8]

BENNETT At first the croquet green at the back would be possessed on fair afternoons by nuggety little thugs on loan from various kindergartens. (1980,Canterbury Tale, A,155)

nuggetty a. (also nuggety) NZ & Austral. colloq. (of a person) thickset, short and sturdy. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,514) [NOTES: cf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 771]

2 adj.

Belle [a sheepdog] was like a smaller copy, more nuggetty, but still powerful. (1966,NZ Short Stories,127,1976 ed.) [NOTES: (Middleton `Saving the Breed')]

nugs¶

n.

HUGHES in Burleigh I remember my first introduction to the "Nugs" which are the cracks and groans, and squeaks that occur in the strata under the ground, all around you. (1984,Burleigh Family, The,18)

nui¶

n. (Rural) a New Zealand-bred cultivar of perennial ryegrass (Lolium perenne). [ORIGIN: Maori]

He began his renovation programme by undersowing 25% of pastures with a mix of nui and moata ryegrass, wana cocksfoot and pitau white clover. (Jan 1989,NZ Dairy Exporter,11)

It appears that aggressive cultivars, such as Nui and Tama ryegrasses, were best suited to establishment by these techniques. [direct-drilling] Establishment data from the experiment on direct-drilling Ruanui or Nui into existing swards indicate that Ruanui was not as suited to this method of introduction as the more vigorous Nui. (Mar 1979,NZ Journal of Agriculture,57)

Northland dairy farmer Doug Taylor includes tama with nui ryegrass when oversowing paddocks. (Jul 1983,NZ Dairy Exporter,5)

He has a variety of special purpose pastures. We saw one of his latest which had been direct drilled with Nui 28 kg, Manawa 6 kg .. (Sep 1985,NZ Journal of Agriculture,16)

A legume crop, Huia white clover, which was undersown in the 1985 pea, grain and Nui ryegrass crops, should prove an attractive proposition. (1987,NZ Journal of Agriculture,Jan/Feb 14)

Lighter green colour and a stronger, denser sward than Nui. (1995,Grasslands Range of Forage and Conservation Plants,17)

.. Nui, a longstanding Hawkes Bay perennial, had the highest spring growth rates. (Aug 4, 2005,Dominion Post,C6)

adj. large (e.g. in pukunui)

ANDERSON E'wakka .. A boat or Canoe./ Nooe .. Large./ Kak'ahoo .. Cloth. (Feb 25, 1777,Journal) [NOTES: 1777 Feb 25 Anderson Journal in Cook Journal (1967) 3/817]

FORSTER A Comparative Table of the Various Languages in the Isles of the South-Sea ... [English] Great ... [New-Zeeland] arahai [a1a2-macron a3-macron grave], nooee [e1-grave] [i.e. two words, synonyms] (1778,Observations Made During a Voyage,284)

COLLINS E-nue[acute], Big, large. (1804,English Colony in NSW,560) [NOTES: NZ Vocabulary]

SAVAGE Nue ... Much, enough. Nuenue .. A great quantity, or large. (1807,Some Account of NZ,76)

NICHOLAS Great A-nue Ibid. 2/337 Great Nue nue (1817,New Zealand (various authors/titles),2/328) [NOTES: English-NZ Vocabulary]

LEE & KENDALL [|prec.= acute, '= stress] 186 N|ui, a. Large; (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ)

plenty - nue [nui] (1835,Boultbee Journal,111,1986 ed.) [NOTES: c1826-1827 list of Maori words in c1835 Boultbee Journal (1986) 111]

nuka¶

n. manuka [ORIGIN: abbreviation, ca1935 Havelock (especially as firewood)]

nuke¶

v. to destroy, to annihilate, to heat

Even if it goes ahead, the delay itself has almost certainly nuked the chances of the bank being up and running in time for election symbolism. (Feb 10, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14)

2 n. [beekeepers']

an Agricultural Adviser speaks: There are bee-keepers who sell basic hive-units to amateurs - nukes they are called. (Oct 4, 1986,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: Landline Farming Programme:]

Nukumaruan¶

adj. rock classification

It should perhaps be pointed out here that the fault passing through Onerahi chaos breccia to the south of the Orewa River, which is marked as a firm line, is intended to be a concealed fault, and that in the legend the Castlecliffian and Nukumaruan stages of the Wanganui Series should be embraced by the Pleistocene, not the Pliocene, bracket. (Dec 1967,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,24/19)

In January 1959 the writer found a well preserved barnacle also belonging to the CORONULINAE in the basal Nukumaruan limestone a Castle Point, Wairarapa. (May 1960,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,8/13)

Gunn, I. A Study of the Variance and Relative Abundance of Globigerina pachyderma in some Nukumaruan Strata, South-east of Matinborough [sic], Wairarapa. (Jun 1974,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,37/19)

Hautawan and Nukumaruan palynofloras may be dated given a rich palynoflora. (May 1975,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,39/51)

nullah¶

n.

The land [at Anzac] rises gradually in [126] a series of hills and ridges ... It is broken by deep nullahs and dongas. and is covered by thick scrub, ... (Aug 26, 1915,NZ Herald) [NOTES: 1915 Aug 26 NZ Herald (Auckland) in 1985 Bromby Eye Witness History 125-126]

number¶

(Dec 1, 1922,NZ Education Gazette,137/1)

PEARSON (1963,Coal Flat,iv/63)
