Number 58¶

n. [?traffic officers')]

There was a steady flow of `number 58s' (driving under the influence) and 140km/h motorway chases but little violence. (May 15, 1988,Sunday Star (Auckland),A3)

Number 8 wired¶

adj. (Rural) [of people] showing initiative with limited means.

.. I think it's great recognition of the overall education system of New Zealand and the innovative spirit of New Zealand. In other words, the great number-8-wired spirit. (Jan 5, 2002,Dominion,13)

number five¶

n. a category of railway station building

We come to Wedderburn, home of the only original number-five station left in New Zealand. A number five is the smallest of the stations designed in 1870. This one has a sloping roof, a "ladies waiting-room" in one end and a stationmaster's office in the other, and an open area in between, where the segregated men shivered in the cold. (Jun 11, 1990,Listener (New Zealand Listener),22)

Number five¶

n.

HOCKEN It was not long before the seed of dissension appeared in the young ommunity. The fifth number of the [Otago] News, long known as `Number 5,' indulged in a very free and unfavourable criticism of the Otago block, ... after scolding the editor, Captain Cargill withdrew his subscription ... Thenceforth the paper became an enemy,.. (1898,Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand,111)

Number Five Scheme¶

n. (historical)

GLOVER Waitikiri Golf Links is a monument to what was then [1930s Depression] known as the Number Five Scheme. (1962,Hot Water Sailor,82)

number nines¶

n. any large (awkward) boots; occas, large feet [ca1935 Havelock.]

NUMBER NINES. - A pill panacea for all the ills that soldier flesh is heir to. (1917,New Zealand At the Front,xiv) [NOTES: glossary]

Number one¶

n. restricted prison diet No. 1 (now abolished)

NUMBER ONE (n) Restricted diet No. 1 (abolished). (1982,Big Huey, The,251) [NOTES: (prisoners' obs)]

number one stand¶

1 n. (Rural) a stand on a shearing board usually occupied by the fastest shearer.

RICHARDS Fred, being the ganger, was on No 1 stand. I being a learner, was on the traditional 'drummers' stand, at the far end of the board. (1991,Off the Sheep's Back,73)

MCMILLAN How I raced to hold the ringer's place and shear at 'number one' ... (1970,In the Shade of the High Country,3)

SQUIRE Gun shearer - a top shearer achieving high tallies and a quality job. Has the right to occupy number one stand. [number one] (1991,A to Z Glossary of Wool Terms,21)

Number two¶

n. restricted prison diet No. 2 (now abolished)

NEWBOLD NUMBER TWO (n) Restricted diet No. 2 (abolished). (1982,Big Huey, The,251)

numbfish¶

n. cramp fish, (blind) torpedo ray, electric ray

Narcobatus fairchildi (Hutton). SOUTHERN NUMBFISH, OR WHAI REPO. ... The species is also called torpedo' orelectric ray.' Hutton states that the Natives (presumably of Napier) call it whai-ngenge. Ibid.101. Fig. 3. - Numbfish, Typhlonarke tarakea. (1929,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,11/98) [NOTES: Phillipps]

NATUSCH [The ray] T[orpedo] aysoni, the numbfish or cramp fish, is round, with short tail and pelvic fins, and grows up to 3 ft. [sic] (1967,Animals of NZ, The,202)

MORELAND ELECTRIC RAY [Torpedo fairchildi] ... Other names are torpedo and sometimes numbfish. (1967,Marine Fishes,14)

GRAHAM BLIND TORPEDO RAY OR NUMBFISH Typhlonarke aysoni (Hamilton) [ibid]. 92]. This uncommon fish has several names, all of which relate to its manner of producing electricshocks, some of which are Numb-fish, Crampfish and Electric Skate. These vernacular names are given by fishermen on account of the fish benumbing or paralysing the person who unwittingly grasps one with his hands. The last name is from the somewhat similar shape to that of a skate or ray, ray being another common term for skates and also the scientific family name. (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,90,2nd ed.)

WILSON NUMBFISH See Electric Ray; also another name for the Blind Torpedo Ray. Ibid. 198 BLIND TORPEDO RAY A rare ray, Typhlonarke aysoni, as he is called in Latin, has theability to emit sparks and make a needle magnetic - yet not to see. Variously named Numbfish, Crampfish and Electric Skate. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,169)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] numbfish 311-20, 325-7 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

2 n.

Typhlonarke aysoni (Hamilton). BLIND NUMBFISH. This numbfish was first described by Hamilton. (1930,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,11/100) [NOTES: Phillipps]

Typhonarke aysoni (Hamilton). Blind numbfish. (1938,TrRSNZ,68/401) [NOTES: Graham Fishes of Otago Harbour]

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] numbfish, blind 325-8 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

2 n.

SOUTHERN NUMBFISH, OR WHAI REPO. The Southern numbfish was first described as new by Hutton in 1872,... (1929,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,11/98) [NOTES: Phillipps]

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] numbfish, southern 310 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

numchukka¶

n. a martial arts weapon (esp. pl.) [various spellings below (in ODE at nunchaku)]

...Detective Mickell said, ... on the floor at the head of the bed was a pair of numkukers (wooden batons). (May 16, 1980,Dominion,10/4)

(Before Judge Palmer) OFFENSIVE WEAPON The Judge said he rejected as `unworthy of belief' the explanation given by John Peter Fearon that a numchukka carried by him in a car which was stopped by police ... was made for him as an ornament. ... Prosecution evidence was given that police stopped a car and saw the numchukka between the legs of a passenger. (May 15, 1981,Press, The,7/3-4)

The police armed offenders squad surrounded a Lower Hut house early this morning after a man had barricaded himself in with a machete knife, numchakas and a rifle. (Oct 10, 1987,Dominion,3)

The numchukkas were featured and pronounced `num-chucks'. [OEDS2] nunchaku (nuntsa.ku). [Jap., f. Okinawa dialect.] Esp. in pl., two hardwood sticks joined together by a strap, etc., as a defensive weapon. (1988,TV2) [NOTES: That's Incredible]

The radical taste tends .. to nunchakus, which go back more than 500 years. They were .. invented by Japanese peasants for self-defence when metal weapons were forbidden to all but the Samurai. (May 2, 1970,Guardian Weekly, The,11)

The experts will give exhibitions in kobudo (weaponery) displaying their martial skill with the sai, nunchaku stick, bow, sword and daggers. (1973,Express (Trinidad & Tobago),31/3)

The proper name is nunchaku sticks. They are made of two sticks of hardwood joined together at one end by a chain, leather or rope. (Apr 17, 1975,Globe & Mail (Toronto),4/1)

nump¶

n.

nump: birdshit (Feb 1981,Avondale College Slang Words in Use)

NUPE¶

abbr. National Union of Public Employees

The strike move is a new low in negotiations between officers, who are members of the National Union of Puiblic Employees, and the ministry... Nupe organiser Martin Cooney said yesterday that with additions made to the scope of officers' jobs during the past few years they now had more responsibility and risk and should be paid more. (Oct 23, 2004,Dominion Post,A7)

National Union of Public Employees (Nupe) organiser Martin Cooney said the union believed their members should not have to do duties outside their normal job expectations, as IRD already had enough work to do... IRD said Nupe had rejected an agreement similar to that accepted by the PSA, which represented most of its staff. (May 25, 2004,Dominion Post,A4)

nurse¶

n. a pick-me-up alcoholic drunk (cf DOCTOR n)

PHILLIPS G.S.P. over for mail and a `nurse'. (Oct 13, 1868,Journal Kept at Rockwood and the Point,165)

2 n. [check SHARK, NURSE]

(Queen Charlotte Sound) Sometimes we got a sort of small Salmon, [ed. fn ?Arripis trutta.] Gurnards, [ed. fn Chelidonichthys kumu.] Skate [ed. fn Raja nasuta.] and Nurses .us;[ed. fn Three genera are found here, and it would be unwise to plump for one.] ... (Feb 1777,Journal) [NOTES: 1777 Feb Anderson's Journal in Cook Journals (1967) 3/808]

nurse cow¶

1 n. (Rural) a cow that rears the calf of another cow.

STEVENS Beef, consisting of forty to forty-five fat two-year-old steers and heifers bred by the dairy herd and nurse cows, and sold on the local fat-stock market. (1958,Sheep. Part 1, Sheep husbandry,195)

Nurse cows are a profitable enterprise on Kontiki farm. (Oct 22, 1998,NZ Farmer,21)

The use of a herd of nurse cows is each to rear two or more crossbred calves for good quality veal .. Most of the nurse cows are dairy culls, some of them good producers but hard milkers. (Dec 16, 1954,NZ Farmer,3)

I do not believe that a farmer should expect improved production from nurse cows through the act of having reared calves. As the weather and morale improve, the nurse cows return to the herd. (Jul 1971,NZ Dairy Exporter,14)

BARTON .. the beef-bred steers were single-suckled on their dams while the dairy-bred steers were raised artificially on a variety of diets or were multiple-suckled on a nurse cow. (1972,Sheepfarming Annual 1972,63)

Some [calves] are raised on nurse cows, but all are off the home farm from weaning. A 4ha paddock of oats provided feed for nurse cows in the difficult 1986 spring. (Mar 1987,NZ Dairy Exporter,15)

For sale: three nurse cows, due 1st Aug, plus 1 calved prematurely. (Jun 21, 2001,Taranaki Daily News,19)

Nurse cows calving early made $680 to $840 ... (Apr 12, 2001,NZ Farmer,44)

nurse crop¶

1 n. (Rural) a crop used to support or protect a more refined one.

The advisability of sowing a nurse crop with lucerne has often been discussed, but this practice seems to have arisen in the instances where there has been some doubt of obtaining a good stand. Many still continue to grow nurse crops, but the majority of farmers have dicontinued to do so. A vigorous nurse crop is bound to leave spindly lucerne plants. (Nov 19, 1927,Hawera Star,14)

nurse herd¶

1 n. (Rural) a breeding flock or herd.

One farmed emu can produce 15-25 chicks or more per year..Cattle produce only one offspring per year, sheep perhaps one and a half. This is a significant difference, generating higher farming efficiency because no large "nurse herd" is required. (1996,NZ Emu Farming Association Journal,Promo 10)

nurse practitioner¶

n. a nurse with certification to dispense certain drugs previously restricted to doctors

Many concerns have been voiced in the general media and in New Zealand nursing literature regarding the role of the nurse practitioner in New Zealand. (Dec 2002,NZ Nursing Review,8)

nurse-rearing¶

1 n. (Rural) the rearing of an animal on a surrogate mother.

If we assume that the cow used for nurse-rearing is average cow and that without nurse-rearing the calf would have been 'bobbied' then we can easily estimate the gross economies ... (Jul 1971,NZ Dairy Exporter,13)

nurseryweb spider¶

2 n. (Environment)

A nurseryweb spider stands little chance once a peripatus has it in its sights. At close range the hunter's aim is true, and its sticky ejecta proves a highly effective means of entrapment. (Apr 2000,NZ Geographic,No. 46/63)

nursing-up¶

1 n. (Rural) the matching of nurse cow and calf.

Only a short period (during the 'nursing-up' process) each year when the stock make many demands on a man's time. (Dec 16, 1954,NZ Farmer,3)

nut¶

n.

McGILL nut, the rugby ball. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,78)

I never really enjoyed All Black rugby because it was boring in terms that you weren't allowed to throw the nut around. (May 28, 1999,Evening Post,20)

n. ball

"The batting at the end was a touch disappointing but the young lad bowled a couple of good nuts." (Dec 2, 2003,Dominion Post,C16)

n. a small piece of kauri-gum (? an official grade-size possibly but perhaps not directly related to the coal-mining term [gumfields] (See also GUM-NUT)

... one ingenious individual, knowing that white range nuts' were twice as valuable asblacknuts', obtained a quantity of the latter and carefully shook them up with some white pipeclay from the hillside. (1923,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,6/96) [NOTES: Firth]

REED a few `nuts' of gum. (1948,Gumdigger, The,13)

BOSWELL Gum-digging and fungus-gathering went on at a furious rate; then there was the washing of the `nuts' (gum [138] too small to be scraped) and the sifting of the gum-dust (the scrapings), then the drying of the fungus - .. (1960,Ernie and the Rest of Us,137)

McLINTOCK An increasing demand for poorer grades of gum [after 1900], used in making linoleum, made it profitable to search for smaller gum: nuts',chips', seeds', anddust'. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,2/207)

THOMAS [Large pieces of gum] were exceptional and much smaller pieces ranging right down to nuts and chips were far more common. (1970,Way Up North,31)

REED Lumps of gum weighing half a hundredweight or more have on rare occasions been found, but in general, on the ranges and flats the size varied from an occasional nugget weighing a few pounds down to nuts' the size of an acorn or smaller. <i>Ibid.</i> 60 To cleannuts' - anythingup to the size perhaps of a pullet's egg - a different method was used. (1972,Gumdiggers, The,24)

... one ingenious individual, knowing that white range nuts' were twice as valuable as blacknuts', obtained a quantity of the latter and carefully shook them up with some white pipeclay from the hillside. (1923,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,6/96) [NOTES: Firth]

3 n. usually pl. small lumps of coal; ?a specific grade of coal-size [so CC Ransom: Household coal cleaned and graded into a large range of sizes in his youth and called after natural products e.g. chestnut] [coalmining]

REID The empty [coal-wagons] from either side can be switched onto the coal shoot line, or the small coal or nut' siding. <i>Ibid.</i> 162 The largest [pieces of black coal] is technically callednuts'. (1884,Golden Coast,148)

MUIR The small coal [is] washed and graded into `nuts' for house & steam purposes. (1906,Handbook NZ Mines,390)

Later I noticed that the State was offering a still cheaper coal, called nuts. (Feb 16, 1907,NZ Truth,87/3/5)

nut 'em¶

v. [two up players']

PARTRIDGE Nut'em. Mostly as nutted'em!, an exclamatory c.p. when the pennies turn up two heads in `two-up': Australian and New Zealand: C. 20. Ex nut, the head. (1937,Dictionary of Slang,575)

nut ball¶

n. [(cricketers')]

KINROSS Bodyline was not born with Jardine as is often imagined; ... the nut ball, bean ball, or head basher, as it was variously called, was resorted to as early as 1908, to my knowledge, in breaking a stubborn partnership. (1963,Please to Remember,32)

nut off¶

v. lose control of oneself, do one's nut

Defence counsel Rennie Gould said Martin had "nutted off", being strung out on amphetamines, drunk and paranoid on October 28 last year. (Feb 17, 2000,Evening Post,9)

With Sydney's angry young men nutting-off across the Tasman, a suburban Pakuranga homeowner shares a unstereotypical experience with a group of local youths ... (Dec 15, 2005,Dominion Post,A20)

nutbar¶

n. (informal) (orig. U.S.). A crazy, mad, or eccentric person; = NUTCASE n.

"It's just a shame that [the group] have attracted so many nutbars," he said. When asked to explain the term 'nutbars', Hopkinson explained that "the mix of personalities in the group was not my cup of tea". (Aug 24, 1998,Salient,20)

The gay men got more a more thrilling share of the action in the form of Hugo, the "nutbar everyone loves to hate". (Jan 12, 2006,NZ Herald,E.G. p7)

nutmeg tree¶

n. Drimys axillaris = horopito, Maori pain killer, pepper tree [>[1919 July 29] Ver.(WB). = Vernacular names used by settlers, supplied by W. Best, Otaki (And) Drimys axillaris]

LAING & BLACKWELL The bark is very aromatic, and is a tonic and astringent.) (1940,Plants of NZ,180)

nutmeg tree Drimys axillaris Ver. (WB) (1927,TrNZI,57/944)

nutriceuticals¶

n. products containing special extracts with a health function added to the nutritional base.

Nutriceuticals are purified proteins which have some sort of useful biological activity in addition to their food value. Best known is lactoferrin, an iron-binding protein with antibacterial properties which has been approved for use on meat as a means of reducing bacterial spoilage. (Mar 2003,NZ Geographic,62/54)

Beyond that - 20, maybe 30 years away - he dreams of a brave nutriceutical world; fractionated oat products with built-in medicinal properties. (Jul 12, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),32)

Nutriceuticals will contain special extracts with a health function added to the nutritional base. These include products aimed at reducing blood pressure, or stimulating the immune system. (Jan 13, 2003,Dominion Post,C5)

nutritional¶

n. products formulated for specific customer requirements

Nutritionals are protein powders derived from milk: caseinates (soluble salts of casein), whey-protein concentrates (WPCs) and hydrolysates of the two. (Mar 2003,NZ Geographic,62/54)

Nutritionals are [health] products formulated for specific customer requirements - for the elderly, for example, and children, and for Asian markets. (Jan 13, 2003,Dominion Post,C5)

nuts¶

n. marbles [marble term]

SUTTON-SMITH Here are some [marble] terms from Taranaki around 1880-1890: firsts, lay-up, stakes, tips, sticking-taw, nothings, anythings, fade-it, knuckledown stiff, dubs, finking [sic, ?funking], sips, spanning, placing; and from Dunedin School in 1949: knee high, manyies, tracks, screws, nuts, sleets, kills, forces, dig, dubs, cheats. (1981,History of Children's Play,269)

n.

NUTTIES ... butter ... sugar ... teaspoon baking powder ... 1 egg ... salt ... walnuts ... Oatina ... flour ... cocoanut ... Drop on greased tray, and bake ... (1938,Souvenir Book of Cookery Recipes,41)

nutty¶

adj. very good [in Aviemore Visitors Book (see fantabulous); ?cf. be nutty about]

nymph¶

nymphomaniac¶

n. a female animal in continuous oestrus (in cattle called a BULLER)

Nymphomaniac: Female animal continuous oestrus. Incattle called a buller. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,13)

NZ¶

abbr. New Zealand

N.Z. is recorded before 1800, and other early forms cited in DNZE are N. Zealand, N. Zeeland, New Z., and N.Z'd. N.Z. is said to have become the standard abbreviation from about the mid 19th century; its modern style is most often NZ. (Sep 2000,NZWords,4 : 1)

Fairburn You know, NZ painting is really more dead than alive (May 14, 1947,Letters,159,1981 ed.)

N.Z. or N. Zeal. abbrev. for New Zealand. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,774) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 515; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 333]]

CARRICK on the coast of N.Z. [check] (Aug 1809,Historical Records,117 et pass) [NOTES: ? 1809 August Shipping Record in R. Carrick Historical Records of NZ South]

WILLIAMS Upon the question of the children's education I was somewhat surprised to observe the general opinion in favour of a colonial education; my brother and myself were opposed to all the rest; ... [Apr 7 50] The question again was entered upon, relative to the education of the children, when I stood alone for the education of the children in N.Z. (Apr 6, 1827,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,50,1961 ed.)

McNAB [The Minerva brought up] 4 bales wool, shorn from the back of sheep at Mayna [Mana] N.Z. and the first imported into this Colony [N.S.W.]. (1913,Old Whaling Days,224) [NOTES: 1838 Aug 16 Cargo Statements in 1913 McNab Old Whaling Days 224]

We were riding quietly along talking about the state of the church at home and in N.Z., ... (Jan 20, 1843,Letter) [NOTES: 1843 Jan 20 letter in 1969 Macmorran Octavius Hadfield 179]

GRACE I also pointed out that we knew more about them than they did about themselves; that we knew where they came from, and the way they travelled to N.Z. (Aug 1877,Journal) [NOTES: 1877 Aug T.S.Grace Journal in Grace Pioneer Missionary (1928) 264]

abbr. New Zealand

Watkin I am sorry to find that the little I have been able to pick of the N.Z. language that it differs materially from [486] the language spoken in the North Island ... (May 30, 1840,Journal) [NOTES: Notes 1840 May 30 James Watkin Journal in 1913 McNab Old Whaling Days 485]

The Aussies have never played the game with us in regard to fruit, excluding N.Z. spuds . (Jan 23, 1933,Na To Hoa Aroha,3/58)

FORSTER [maori] ... they are short but almost shaped like the N.Z. battle Axes. (Mar 15, 1774,Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The,3/470,1982 ed.)

HUNT the N.Z. hemp [frequent] (1822,Letter) [NOTES: 1822 F. Hunt in McNab Hist. Records 1/515]

WILLIAMS [=maori] While in conversation with some of the Natives relative to the formation of a N.Z. settlement in the colony, Toi Tapu asked me why we were going away (Apr 11, 1827,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,52,1961 ed.)

... the N.Z. vocabulary (1828,Journal) [NOTES: 1828 C. Davis Journal 32 in Colenso Papers III [Maori]]

REVANS N.Z. Land Co (1839,Letter) [NOTES: 1839 Revans to Chapman 15]

... the usual characteristics of a N.Z. Valley viz. Narrow bounded by steep scrubby hills. (Dec 9, 1840,Journal of Ensign Best,263,1966 ed.)

HANNAH BUTLER [Maori] N.Z. language (1840,Journal)

HASWELL N.Z. (together with N.Zealand, NZd.) (1841,Letters & Journals,I-64)

CARRINGTON the N.Z. Office (1841,Papers,39)

E.G.WAKEFIELD N.Z.[twice] and N.Zealand [once] (1842,Letter) [NOTES: 1842 E.G. Wakefield in Revans to Chapman]

N.Z. Gazette (1843,NZ Journal,78/11)

[After about 1850 uses other than N.Z. are idiosyncratic, or old-fashioned.] (Apr 9, 1852,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/135) [NOTES: 1852 C.W. Richmond in Richm-Atk Papers Apr 9 1/110 1853 J.Maria Richmond in op cit. Nov 13 1/135]

MACKIE V.D.L. timber is in high repute here for fencing, shingles etc., it is so much more durable thanthe N.Z. wood. (May 16, 1853,Traveller under Concern,109,1973 ed.)

abbr. New Zealand

Mr Butler the person Pattisson lives with, came here to-day. He is one of the cleaverest [sic] men in N.Z.. (Dec 3, 1862,Chudleigh Diary,68,1950 ed.)

We presume N.Z. is unsober. (Jun 24, 1905,NZ Truth,1/5)

BARR [a poem What Kiwi' Means. Said Leo:What's this ... thats broke my blessed head?/ It's called out here `The Kiwi' - alluding to N.Z.,/ It serves this small Dominion as an emblem for a crest, ...' - (1908,British Rugby Team in Maoriland,54)

RODGER (The Boys of N.Z.) N.Z. are initials, I'd have you to know,/ They stand for New Zealand, We, Us, and Co.,/ Who began to make history when Bobs fell in bad/ In the Transvaal, and cooeed, `Come over, N.Z.' (1914,Blue Mountain Rhymes,17)

By all means leave the Coast & if possible N.Z. too. (Nov 25, 1852,Letter) [NOTES: 1852 Nov 25 C. Baker to Colenso in 1986 Baker Never the Faint Hearted 131]

abbr. (as noun) a New Zealand soldier

I never saw the N.Z.s so cheerful before. (Jun 7, 1918,Chronicles NZEF,iv/45 : 199)

[Caption] "Say, N.Z. I suppose you feel abit lonely here all on your own!" (Jan 30, 1918,Chronicles NZEF,III/36 : 283)

The Ossie sat up and said quietly: "Allright, N.Z." (Jun 27, 1917,Chronicles NZEF,II/21 : 224)

NZAEC¶

abbr. New Zealand Atomic Energy Committee

NZAEC abbr. New Zealand Atomic Energy Committee. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,515) [NOTES: nf 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict]

NZAID¶

abbr. name of a semi-autonomous aid agency

The new government agency handling New Zealand's overseas aid was dedicated solely to elimination of extreme poverty in the world, Associate Foreign Affairs Minister Matt Robson said yesterday. From now on the $230 million-a-year overseas aid programme will be run by NZAID, a semi-autonomous ministry agency that replaces the Official Development Assistance agency. (Jul 2, 2002,Dominion,2)

NZAX¶

abbr. New Zealand Alternative Exchange, a stock exchange market for smaller companies

BusinessDay will from today provide daily coverage of the new alternative exchange, the NZAX, in its sharemarket tables. (Nov 15, 2003,Dominion Post,C1)

A rugby theme highlighted the launch of the NZAX yesterday, but the exchange threw a hospital pass by outfitting the only woman executive in a hooker's jersey....He added that AX had been a "long time in the making" but was necessary for the exchange to fulfil its objective of developing capital markets. (Nov 13, 2003,Dominion Post,C1)

NZBC¶

abbr. New Zealand Broadcasting Commission

On March 28, 1962, the New Zealand Broadcasting Corporation (NZBC) came into being, replacing the old New Zealand Broadcasting Service (NZBS). An autonomous corporation replaced the government department, tied firmly to ministerial direction and interference that had governed radio for three decades. (Mar 28, 1987,Listener (New Zealand Listener),46)

And when the N.Z.B.C. banned the song ... I felt like writing some letters to the editor myself. (1965,Some Other Country,135) [NOTES: Stead `A Fitting Tribute']

N.Z.B.C. (formerly) abbrev. for New Zealand Broadcasting Commission. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,774) [NOTES: [nf 1986 NZPOD]]

NZBS¶

abbr. (historical) NZ Broadcasting Service

(1944,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),453)

WALL The N.Z.B.S. and the B.B.C. come in for criticism. (1958,Queen's English, The,11)

THOMPSON Crumpled. Reduced. Trying not to cry [at failing an announcer's test]. The NZBS had scored another famous victory. (1980,All My Lives,61)

'It's really going to be an unprecedented series of domestic cricket in January,' NZC chief executive Justin Vaughan said. (Sep 15, 2009,NZ Herald) [NOTES: Online edition]

BEST ... Acts of Govt and the manner in which the interests of the settlers under the N.Z.C. wereaffected thereby. (1840,Journal,235,1960 ed.)

The opinions.. amount to an aspersion on my integrity and that of the New Zealand Council for Educational Research.... [His] allegations that "The NZCER has never shown any interest in how its tests are used" and that members of its staff engage "in unscholarly conduct" are untrue. NZEF¶

abbr.

WESTON One's subsequent experience has not shaken a belief that the training at Trentham was good, where at that time all the reinforcements for all arms of the N.Z.E.F. were concentrated. (1918,Three Years with the NZers,11)

Slang of the N.Z.E.F. (Apr 2, 1938,Press, The,18) [NOTES: McNab NZ Slang]

HYDE ... Wallie Black ... was said to spin a penny or a double-headed Jack better than any other man in the N.Z.E.F. ... (1938,Nor the Years Condemn,59)

HYDE ... Wallie Black ... was said to spin a penny or a double-headed Jack better than any other man in the N.Z.E.F. ... (1938,Nor the Years Condemn,59)

MacLEAN C.M. Bevan - Brown came ... in 1914. He left to join the NZEF .... (1982,Lifetime at School,18)

THORNTON ... I consulted Chaplain-Major Luxford, the chief chaplain of the N.Z.E.Force. (1917,With the Anzacs in Cairo,53)

[Title] Chronicles of the N.Z.E.F.Records of Matters concerning the Troopsand Gazette of Patriotic Effort. (Aug 30, 1916,Chronicles NZEF,I/1 : 1)

Jock White of Merton, Otago, came overfrom N.Z. with the N.Z.E.F., and wasseverely wounded in the arm and jaw a fewweeks after the landing at Anzac. (Aug 30, 1916,Chronicles NZEF,I/1 : 8)

For the benefit of troops who may also beunder a false impression as to themeaning of the letters "N.Z.E.F.",commanding officers are asked toespecially impress their men that itmeans "New Zealand Expeditionary Force",and not "N.Z. Employer's Federation". (May 10, 1918,Chronicles NZEF,IV/43 : 153)

2 abbr.

NZEF (in New Zealand) abbrev. for New Zealand Expeditionary Force, the New Zealand army that served in 1914-18. 2NZEF is used to refer to the Second New Zealand Expeditionary Force, in World War II. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,774) [NOTES: 1986 NZPOD 515; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 333]

The NZEI is anxious to let the country know that Picot or not, no one is going to kick teachers around. (Mar 4, 1989,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14)

NZFP¶

NZHIA¶

abbr. New Zealand Hemp Insdustries Association

Mac McIntosh, chairman of the New Zealand Hemp Industries Association (NZHIA) has been fighting the same battle for the past 11 years, simply because he could not believe that hemp was a prohibited crop... Musgrave, who is deputy chair of the NZHIA, remembers a visit to the then Police Minister, Clem Simich. (Jun 9, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),30)

NZIA¶

abbr. New Zealand Institute of Architects

The New Zealand Institute of Architects (NZIA) and the Architects Education and Registration Board (AERB) are separately constituted but overlapping bodies established under the 1963 Architects Act... Perhaps because expulsion from the NZIA is the architectural equivalent of a slap on the wrist with a wet bus ticket, the institute prefers to pass all serious complaints.. on to the AERB. (Feb 1997,North & South,91)

NZIER¶

abbr. New Zealand Institute of Economic Research

[Hdg] NZIER forecasts lower growth. A continuing slowdown in world growth has significantly pegged back New Zealand's growth prospects, according to the New Zealand Institute of Economic Research. (Jun 14, 2001,Evening Post,18)

NZIS¶

"We don't feel that's widely known at all," says Robyn Scott, executive officer of the New Zealand Infertility Society... Ibid. 22 The NZIS is also wary of a proposal that would have details of every assisted reproductive birth recorded in a central registry. (Mar 3, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),21)

The New Zealand Nursing Organisation estimates our health sector is short about 2000 nurses... The NZNO recently embarked on a major campaign to lift nurse's pay rates.... (Aug 2, 2003,Independent Herald (Wellington),F3)

This year's programmes include two local documentaries...(funded by TVNZ and New Zealand On Air, though still to air)... There are encouraging signs that the NZOA is prepared to flex its funding muscle to increase the quality, and not just the quantity, of local content. Thus, the fallback position : don't take all NZOA's money, just most of it... [27] Tapping into NZOA funds, he indicates, is not an option. (May 29, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),26)

NZPI¶

abbr. New Zealand Property Institute

The effects on rural land use and valuations of the establishment of a giant dairy company will be looked at by the Property Institute's national conference, which begins today... Late last year the Institute introduced a new logo for its rebranded image from the then letters NZPI on a green background to a stronger visual emblem consisting of a crescent-shaped curve, representing the round back of the letter P, and a round moon-like object representing the dot over the letter i. (May 17, 2001,Dominion,17)

NZPO¶

NZQA¶

abbr. New Zealand Qualifications Authority

Devised by the ministry and the New Zealand Qualifications Authority (NZQA), the clumsily named National Certificate of Educational Achievement weas given the go-ahead by the last National government and launched this year by Labour, after Mallard had delayed it a year. (Jul 6, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),18)

The New Zealand Qualifications Authority.. had to scale the marks more than ever before... The NZQA assures that it will go to "greater trouble" this year to ensure that those who set and moderate the paper consider for longer whether the questions are suitable. (Feb 17, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),26)

"The Cruel C".. highlighted a real difficulty in dealing with the New Zealand Qualifications Authority. When the NZQA is pressed for detailed explanations, it fobs off the questioner with responses such as "the paper was reviewed by professionals". (Mar 3, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),8)

NZSE 40¶

abbr. [NZ equivalent of the Footsie etc.; superseded by the NZSX 50 q.v.]

Last autumn, with the screen listing of shares and listing of Telecom imminent, discussions arose about the future of the Barclays Index. The upshot was its phasing out and the introduction of two new Stock Exchange indices, the NZSE 40 and the NZSE Selection Index or NZSE 30. (Sep 30, 1991,Listener (New Zealand Listener),48)

[Hdg] NZSE revises rules. The New Zealand Stock Exchange (NZSE) released a revised set of regulations yesterday in an effort to improve investor confidence in the local bourse. (Jul 26, 2001,Evening Post,13)

NZSO¶

abbr. New Zealand Symphony Orchestra

On the wall facing Ian Fraser's desk is a collection of photographs of some of the great artists who have appeared with the New Zealand Symphony Orchestra... Fraser may have gained considerable experience in public relations before becoming the NZSO's chief executive two years ago, but you get the impression he means it. (Nov 11, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),50)

We perform the plays of foreigners such as Shakespeare and Chekhov,.. and they are popular, though not as popular as performances of such foreigners as Beethoven, Bach and Brahms by our NZSO. (Jan 10, 1987,Listener (New Zealand Listener),6)

"Maybe that's a good thing because I've been fully absorbed by the NZSO," he says. (Jan 2000,North & South,35)

"Maybe that's a good thing because I've been fully absorbed by the NZSO," he says. (Jan 2000,North & South,35)

Treasury did the same thing to the NZSO that it did to the Department of Conservation - it cut funding to the point where efficiencies disappeared and the infrastructure began to destruct... The NZSO is a fine orchestra,, and a fine orchestra is a part of the cultural infrastructure expected of a civilised nation. (Jun 1, 1996,Listener (New Zealand Listener),7)

The NZSO, to do it credit, has done rather better than usual in prescribing such medicine this year... (Jun 22, 1985,Listener (New Zealand Listener),45)

While the living is easy the New Zealand Symphony Orchestra brings us a programme tailor-mnade for balmy evenings. Summertime, and it's time for a pleasant evening's entertainment at an NZSO Summer Pops concert with William Southgate, Diedre Irons - and George Gershwin. (Jan 26, 1985,Listener (New Zealand Listener),19)

NZSX 50¶

abbr.

The continued strength of the Kiwi market has been remarkable. The NZSX 50, with a 6.3 per cent rise last month, was the world's second-best performer. (Dec 13, 2004,Dominion Post,C3)

NZTE¶

NZVCC¶

abbr. New Zealand Vice-Chancellors' Committee

The NZVCC -- the representative body for the country's eight universities -- wants a Budget that results in increased government investment in university education and research. (May 18, 2005,Dominion Post,B7)

Earlier this year these discussions were reactivated in New Zealand, according to the spokesperson who confirmed that IDP has held preliminary talks with the NZVCC and other relevant New Zealand organisations... (May 29, 2002,NZ Education Review,7(20):1)

NZX¶

abbr. New Zealand Stock Exchange

The New Zealand Stock Exchange considered moving to Auckland but chose to stay in Wellington for a number of reasons. These included the cost of shifting north, that Government is based in Wellington, and that the NZX is a national operator with customers all around New Zealand... (Jan 22, 2004,Wellington Contact,5)

.. but the New Zealand Exchange decided to try agian this year ... NZX's lack of assertiveness might appear awkward. (Oct 28, 2004,Dominion Post,C2)
